Currency dealers said the dollar's surge followed a strong showing in New York, where multiple factors, including escalating tensions in the Soviet republic of Lithuania, were said to have contributed to the U.S. currency's strength. Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11, but the Soviets have termed the move illegal. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev Wednesday ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons. Investors often regard the dollar as a safe haven in times of international tension. A dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said many currency market players had anticipated Tuesday's action by Japan's central bank to raise its official discount rate by a full percentage point to 5.25 percent.

DOC.HEAD: `Roaming Plane' Pilot Indicted on Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Root, the attorney who ditched his plane in the Atlantic Ocean last summer, stands indicted on 33 counts of fraud and other crimes involving radio stations he was representing before the Federal Communications Commission. The federal indictment returned Wednesday accuses Root of defrauding the federal government and five clients in FCC proceedings on permits to construct FM radio stations throughout the United States. If convicted of all charges against him, Root, 37, would face a maximum 200 years in prison and an $8 million fine. Root burst onto the public scene last July when his single-engine plane ran out of gas and plunged into the Atlantic off the Bahamas following a six-hour, 800-mile flight that began near Washington, D.C. He told authorities that he had been unconscious for most of the odyssey, but Navy fighter pilots flying alongside the plane reported seeing him moving in the cockpit. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said a mysterious gunshot wound Root suffered during the flight is part of an ongoing investigation. As Root was recovering from his ordeal, a series of financial and legal questions began emerging. Less than a week after the crash, Sonrise Management Services, a Columbus, Ga., company, sued Root for $584,000. It claimed he failed to perform work and double-billed a client. Root filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors in October, claiming he had $1.64 million in liabilities. Reports surfaced that Root's law practice was the subject a fraud investigation before a federal grand jury. Stephens said Wednesday that Root had been aware of the probe, which began in April 1989, before the flight that put him in the public spotlight. The indictment charges Root with 20 counts of wire and mail fraud, seven counts of filing false legal documents with the FCC, four counts of using counterfeit and altered federal documents, and one count each of forgery and obstruction of the grand jury's investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Study Bolsters Argument That Greenhouse Warming Has Begun
DOC.TEXT: Scientists said today that a key natural process could not have produced the global warming of the past 100 years by itself, supporting the idea that the greenhouse effect is already raising global temperatures. Only about three-fifths of that warming could have come from a natural long-term influence of the oceans, the researchers' computer simulation suggests. The result is presented in today's issue of the British journal Nature by T.M.L. Wigley and S.C.B. Raper of the University of East Anglia in Norwich, England. They said the result does not prove that greenhouse warming has begun. Other scientists agreed, but split on how strongly the result bolsters the idea. The greenhouse effect refers to a warming caused by a buildup in the atmosphere of certain gases, such as carbon dioxide, chiefly from human activity. Scientists are concerned that it could eventually alter climates and rainfall patterns and lead to coastal flooding from raised ocean levels. But they disagree on whether the greenhouse effect has yet produced any detectable impact. The Earth has warmed by about nine-tenths of a degree Fahrenheit over the past 100 years. A major problem in demonstrating a role for the greenhouse effect is that scientists do not know how much of the warming comes from long-term natural variability, said Gerald Meehl of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. The oceans, which slowly absorb and release huge amounts of heat, are probably the most likely source of this long-term influence, he said. The simulation reported in the Nature paper found that over intervals of up to 100 years, the oceans might produce a trend of up to about half a degree Fahrenheit. That means the ocean influence could not have produced the observed global warming by itself, the researchers wrote. Yet, ``we still cannot claim to have unequivocally detected the greenhouse effect,'' they said. Researcher Robert Cess said the study cannot rule out the idea that the oceans did produce the global warming. The simulation was too simplified to produce a firm conclusion, said Cess, an atmospheric sciences professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. But researcher Stephen Schneider of the atmospheric research center, who called himself 80 percent certain that greenhouse warming has begun, said the result adds to his belief. ``It's not proof yet,'' he said, but ``it's another step along the way.'' Scientists will need another 10 years to 20 years of observations to be sure if they are seeing a greenhouse warming, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Public Citizen Sues Pfizer Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group is suing the maker of an allegedly defective heart valve that has been implanted in the chests of more than 80,000 people. Public Citizen said Wednesday its suit seeks to require Shiley Inc. and its parent company, Pfizer Inc., to notify all those who have had the valve implanted about alleged defects and possible life-threatening consequences if it fails. The suit also asks that the companies pay for psychological counseling and medical consultation to advise these people of the risks and benefits of having the valve removed, the symptoms of valve failure and emergency steps to be taken if those symptoms occur. The group, founded by consumer activist Ralph Nader, filed the lawsuit in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Shiley's principal offices are in California. Pfizer, based in New York, said the suit is ``completely without merit'' and will ``frighten cardiac patients unnecessarily and ultimately do much more harm than good.'' Pfizer said the valves ``have saved the lives of tens of thousands of patients. All but a small fraction of 1 percent of these valves continue to function properly.'' The Food and Drug Administration approved the valve in April 1979, but after reports of malfunctions, Shiley removed it from the market in November 1986. The company has reported to the FDA nearly 400 failures of the valve, 248 of which resulted in death.
DOC.HEAD: Meatpacker to Pay OSHA Fine, Hire On-Job Injuries Consultant
DOC.TEXT: John Morrell & Co., one of the nation's largest meatpackers, has agreed to pay a fine of almost $1 million and to try harder to protect its South Dakota workers from injuries. Labor Department officials said they hope the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's settlement Wednesday with the Cincinnati-based company will be a model for the rest of the meat industry, where there are high incidences of repetitive strain injuries. OSHA originally proposed $4.3 million in fines against Morrell for exposing workers at its Sioux Falls, S.D., plant to hazards that produced cumulative trauma disorders, or repetitive motion injuries. Under Wednesday's settlement, which was also worked out with the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, Morrell will pay a $990,000 fine and provide a grant of $260,000 to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health for the continuing study of repetitive motion injuries. In addition, Morrell will retain a consultant for at least four years to carry out its program to eliminate hazards.
DOC.HEAD: INS Reports Surge in Apprehensions Over Past 10 Months
DOC.TEXT: The flow of illegal immigration across the Southwest border appears to be increasing dramatically, reversing a three-year downturn that began when the federal government made it illegal to hire undocumented workers. Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said a surge in apprehensions of illegal aliens _ considered to be the best available indicator of illegal immigration _ began in May 1989 and has continued steadily. According to the INS figures, apprehensions of illegal aliens were up 29.9 percent over the past 10 months, compared with the same period a year ago. Apprehensions totaled 801,937 between May 1989 and February 1990 compared with 617,317 apprehensions between May 1988 and February 1989. Some months recorded surges of nearly 60 percent, while in other months the increases dropped below 20 percent. But the past three months have been among the highest, with apprehensions rising 57.3 percent between February 1989 and February 1990, by 39.6 percent between January 1989 and January 1990, and by 58.3 between December 1988 and December 1989. Apprehensions began dropping sharply in fiscal 1987, the first year after Congress passed the Immigration Control and Reform Act of 1986, which made employers subject to civil and criminal sanctions for hiring undocumented workers. Although the trend in apprehensions continued downward through the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, the first six months of this fiscal year have seen an increase in apprehensions of 37 percent over the same period a year ago. Jervis said the rise in illegal immigration may be due to the availability of fraudulent documents that undocumented workers use to obtain work or simply the ``desperation'' of some in Mexico to seek work here.

DOC.HEAD: Saint Laurent Shines with Colorful and Tailored Looks
DOC.TEXT: Yves Saint Laurent had a winning through abbreviated winter ready-to-wear show, winding up a big week of fashion in elegant Paris style. While the 53-year-old ``king of fashion'' was recovering in a hospital from exhaustion, the collection displayed Wednesday still sparkled with his verve and talent. Assistants from the house would say only that he ``worked on the collection until last Saturday, and now his doctor has prescribed a long rest.'' The clothes had the inimitable Saint Laurent touch. Many of the current trends shown around town were Saint Laurent's own inventions, and his latest versions were replayed in a modern key. The exuberantly flowered folklore reminded the audience that Saint Laurent started the rich peasant styles now seen on runways back in 1976. His black-piped quilted cotton jackets or flounced flare-away coats were updated with a casual appeal for the 1990s. Saint Laurent also brought out some gorgeous multicolored harlequin blouses, and sexily fitted velvet jackets with elaborate embroidered appliques over full print short skirts with ruffled underskirts. Then the pace changed with quietly sleek man-tailored taupe or grey gabardine trouser or skirt suits as only Saint Laurent can do them, giving feminine touches like dripping rhinestone brooches and gold lame gloves. A new YSL couture accessory shop opens today at 32 Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore to offer such goodies, as well as bags and scarves _ for couture prices, with bracelets starting around $250. Saint Laurent also took his fashions on a worldwide trip that included a visit to the Scottish moors, with the most wonderful new draped tartan kilts and tam o'shanters with dashing pheasant feathers. There were Tyrolian maids in spiffy tweed suits with sparkling buttons and velvet lapels, superb boleros decorated with big bands of colorful rick-rack, and excellent hooded duffel coats. The most original duffel was in robin's egg blue, over a pullover in pastel and white Norwegian motifs with stars, topping straight gray flannel pants gathered at the waist. Like just about every other designer, Saint Laurent was inspired by safari country. If you have a yen for a wild-animal print look to YSL. His are absolutely extraordinary _ big patchwork patterns in leopard spots and black-cream ``tachiste'' daubs on the lightest chiffons, caressing the body in sexy puffs, sashes, ruffles and wraps. The glory of the show was that it offered something for everybody, from the sporting set to the showy cocktail crowd, with all lengths of skirt and several cuts of pants. For those who like minis with a wink at the 1960s, Saint Laurent brought out some great modern suede knee or thigh-high boots, some with passementerie-banded tops. Saint Laurent's lingerie-inspired clothes included black lace mini-camisoles topped by belted puffs of organza in hot colors.

DOC.HEAD: Transamerica Gives Up Fight For Widow's Home
DOC.TEXT: A poverty-stricken widow can keep the small home her husband helped build for her 42 years ago, a lending company has decided. Transamerica Financial Services Inc., which hired one of the state's biggest law firms to try to seize Lennie Williams' home earlier this year, gave up its fight Wednesday, lawyers for both sides said. Company officials did not return calls seeking comment, and their Phoenix law firm declined to discuss details of the case without the company's permission. The woman's lawyers attributed the settlement proposal to publicity stemming from an Associated Press report about her case. Mrs. Williams's mental state prevented her from understanding much of the legal battle that surrounded her home, but she knew enough at times to worry that someone was after it, according to her attorneys. ``She was just completely relieved when we finally were able to get it through to her that she was never going to have to worry about someone taking her house again,'' attorney Douglas Erickson said Wednesday. ``The property is free and clear.'' Mrs. Williams, who supports herself on $438 a month, doesn't remember that her husband died 12 years ago, or that she put up the house, in a working-class Phoenix neighborhood, as security for a loan taken out by her former son-in-law in 1987. The Transamerica loan officer who handled the transaction says he doubts Mrs. Williams knew what she was doing. The son-in-law has disappeared. Others who knew Mrs. Williams at the time, including a state lawmaker and a doctor who was treating her, also have said they doubted her competence, and Maricopa County Superior Court Judge Alfred Rogers ruled earlier this year that it appeared the company ``knew or should have known'' that Mrs. Williams was incompetent and was being defrauded. Transamerica was not persuaded. It pressed for trial and demanded that Mrs. Williams make $499-a-month payments even though Rogers was blocking the company from going ahead with foreclosure on the home. Mrs. Williams and her legal guardian filed the suit to block the company, a subsidiary of San Francisco-based Transamerica Corp., from foreclosing. The suit also sought to void her part of the contract and win damages. The case had drawn extensive publicity in the Southwest after an Associated Press story was published in area newspapers. A national television program, ``Inside Edition,'' sent a crew to interview Mrs. Williams on Wednesday. One of Transamerica's attorneys, Robert Miles, said earlier this month that the company believed it was entitled to the property. A second lawyer, Tom Canham, said Wednesday that the company had now determined it would be better to settle the case, and that agreement not to seek foreclosure was part of an overall package. The case was the latest in a series involving consumer-loan companies, and it came at a time when the collapse of many thrifts has forced more middle-class borrowers to turn to them. In Arizona alone, ITT Financial Services paid $1.7 million to settle one class-action lawsuit, and Household Finance Corp. paid about $4 million to settle another. Transamerica Financial Services has already offered to pay about $4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accuses it of gouging poor and middle-income borrowers. Loan-industry lobbyists have said Mrs. Williams' case must be an aberration. But Bill Morris, director of litigation at Southern Arizona Legal Aid in Tucson and chief architect of the class-action suits, said the situation is believed to occur frequently. The $32,000 loan that Mrs. Williams signed for carried an interest rate of nearly 18 percent plus 8 points in prepaid charges and called for total payments of $89,820, or $499 a month over 15 years. Her home, which is less than 1,000 square feet and which her husband helped build for her 42 years ago in a working-class neighborhood, was appraised at $40,000. Sworn testimony shows it was Mrs. Williams' son-in-law, William Smith, who wanted the money in the first place. Smith had married Mrs. Williams' daughter, Alma, but hadn't lived with her for years, said Rachel Freeman, Mrs. Williams' great-niece and legal guardian. Alma died early in 1987. Months later, Smith came around and promised he would help fix Mrs. Williams' home, according to Ms. Freeman. Instead, he allegedly took her to Transamerica, had her co-sign a $32,000 loan and disappeared. Mrs. Williams' attorneys have obtained a judgment against him, but it's of little value since they don't know where he is.

DOC.HEAD: Nineteen Killed in Wave of Indiscriminate Attacks
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ In attacks political and civic leaders blame on thugs angered by the shift from army to civilian rule, marauding gunmen have killed at least 19 people this week, officials and radio reports say. The victims included 11 members of a self-defense group hacked to death in the town of Petit Goave, the birthplace of nationwide demonstrations that forced Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril from power. In the capital of Port-au-Prince Wednesday, assailants killed at least four people and wounded eight, according to the reports. The wounded included five members of a self-defense unit shot by gunmen in speeding cars. The Unity Assembly, the political and civic coalition that chose provisional President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot after Avril went into exile last week, has urged the formation of self-defense units. There has been a dearth of police protection since Avril fled. The Unity Assembly said thugs and members of the ill-disciplined, 6,000-man army _ the traditional power broker in this impoverished Caribbean nation _ are angry at the military's surrender of power to civilians. ``These acts of urban terrorism have been committed by irreconcilable supporters of dictatorship,'' politician Rockefeller Guerre said Wednesday. Others said the attacks were aimed at destabilizing the civilian government. An official at the state hospital in Port-au-Prince said the morgue received the bodies of two people shot before dawn Wednesday. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the hospital treated eight people _ including the five members of a self-defense unit _ for bullet wounds. Privately owned Radio Haiti Inter said gunmen trying to hold up a rice storehouse downtown killed security guard William Desir late Wednesday and shot up the building before driving off and shooting at passers-by. And it said fishermen in the seafront neighborhood of Carrefour on Wednesday found the body of an unidentified, naked man with his hands tied behind his back. The Roman Catholic station Radio Soleil, Radio Haiti Inter and an independent source said 13 people, including 11 members of a neighborhood self-defense group, were killed Tuesday in Petit Goave, 50 miles southwest of the capital. Radio Haiti Inter said the 11 were hacked to death by a gang of assailants while searching for the killers of an elderly couple who were shot and disemboweled earlier in the day. On Tuesday night, 1,000 police at checkpoints in Port-au-Prince searched private vehicles for weapons, state television said. A soldier was shot to death in the capital by unknown assailants Monday, and eight nuns at a Roman Catholic girls' school were beaten and injured by machete-wielding assailants who broke into their compound on Sunday. Haiti has had five governments since a February 1986 popular uprising forced dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier into exile in France. All but the current government were dominated by the military. Avril was elevated to power 18 months ago in a coup by rank-and-file soldiers who said they were outraged with state-sanctioned murder and corruption. His resignation followed a week of nationwide demonstrations sparked by the killing by the army of an 11-year-old girl on her porch in Petit Goave. If the current government holds general elections as promised, the next government will be the first chosen by the people since Haiti declared independence from France in 1804.

DOC.HEAD: Former Air Force Chief In Critical Condition After Assassination Bid
DOC.TEXT: Marxist guerrillas claimed responsibility for the attempted assassination of a retired air force chief who helped lead the 1973 overthrow of leftist President Salvador Allende. The shooting of Gustavo Leigh and a business partner Wednesday was the first political attack since an elected, civilian government replaced Gen. Augusto Pinochet after 16{ years of right-wing military rule. Cabinet ministers, military officials and the Roman Catholic Church condemned the shooting and swore not to let it or threats of future attacks weaken the democracy that was reborn 11 days ago. Witnesses said two young men with handguns burst into the fourth-floor offices of a real estate company run by Leigh and another retired air force general, Enrique Ruiz, in Santiago's wealthy Providencia neighborhood. The two fired point-blank at Leigh and Ruiz then fled, police said. Leigh, 69, was hit in the face, chest, stomach and both arms, a hospital report said. Late Wednesday, the hospital said he lost an eye and was conscious, in critical but stable condition after five hours of surgery. Ruiz was reported in serious condition. In telephone calls to local radio stations, a spokeswoman for a maverick faction of the pro-Communist Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, Chile's main guerrilla organization, claimed responsibility. The spokeswoman, who uses the name Mariela Vargas, called Leigh ``one of the cruelest ideologues behind the thousands of killings committed during the dictatorship.'' She termed Ruiz ``an accomplice.'' She warned of future attacks _ ``We will continue to exercise our right to popular justice.'' Leigh commanded the air force during the bloody September 1973 coup, directing warplanes to bomb the presidential palace where Allende was holed up. The elected civilian president, a Marxist, died in the coup. Leigh, part of the subsequent four-man military junta led by Pinochet, declared the military's mission was ``to cut out the Marxist cancer'' from Chilean society. The armed forces began a harsh campaign of anti-leftist repression. Pinochet fired Leigh in June 1978 after a series of policy disagreements, and Leigh became a public critic of Pinochet and his attempts to remain in power. Pinochet handed over power March 11 to an elected civilian successor, President Patricio Aylwin, a Christian Democrat backed by a coalition of centrist and leftist parties. Aylwin canceled scheduled activities Wednesday to keep informed about developments following the shooting. His interior minister, Enrique Krauss, called the shootings ``a cowardly attack'' and promised an intensive investigation. Education Minister Ricardo Lagos said it was ``an attempt to destabilize the institutional order.'' Defense Minister Patricio Rojas pledged ``no provocation will alter the democratic vocation of the Chilean people ... or the stability that the government gives to democracy.'' Air force commander Gen. Fernando Matthei called it ``an attack against each and every member of the air force. ... It doesn't contribute to the positive climate of the democratic process.'' The attack came on the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Chilean air force, and the institution had suspended all training activities to celebrate the date.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Lithuanian President's Statement
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis' response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order that Lithuanians turn in their firearms. It was issued in Lithuanian and translated for The Associated Press by Lithuanian officials.

This order, like any other adopted by a foreign state that pretends to claim sovereignty over Lithuania, has no legal power. It could be enforced only by brutal military force, and if the Soviet Union is willing to prolong the aggression of 1940 against Lithuania. It's a pity that it continues the mistake of the Third Congress of People's Deputies. It amounts to the claiming of non-existent and unjustified sovereignty of a powerful country over a small and unarmed neighbor. The Soviet Union has recognized as null and void the secret protocol to the agreement between Stalin and Hitler, condemned the policy of ultimatums and violation of international law including the annexation of Lithuania, but now once again is not able to give up the prize and restore justice. The ghost of Stalinism is walking in the Kremlin and the shadow of it lies far to the west (over Lithuania). Tomorrow will show if the world, which greets Lithuania and her desire for freedom, will approve. We'll meet tomorrow, serene and united as we were before facing previous threats.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Text on Lithuania Decree
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree banning firearms sales in Lithuania and ordering residents to turn in their guns. The text, transmitted in Russian Wednesday by the official news agency Tass, was translated by The Associated Press.

The U.S.S.R. president's decree on Extra Measures to Protect the Rights of Soviet Citizens and the Sovereignty of the U.S.S.R. on the territory of the Lithuanian S.S.R. Contrary to the resolution adopted by Congress of People's Deputies of March 15, the Lithuanian Parliament and government continue passing bills violating the rights of the Soviet citizens and the sovereignity of the Soviet Union. In connection with this I decree: 1) The U.S.S.R. Council of Ministers, the executive bodies and local councils of Lithuanian S.S.R., the law-enforcement organs are to ensure the observance of the federal constitution and laws, and protect the rights and legitimate interests of the Soviet citizens living or staying in Lithuanian S.S.R. 2) KGB border forces are to take essential measures to tighten up security on the Soviet border in Lithuanian S.S.R., to halt all unlawful actions violating Soviet border legislation. 3) The federal government's resolution No. 646 of July 23, 1975, on the acquisition, accounting and keeping of hunting rifles is to be temporarily suspended, and the sale of hunting weapons is to be banned for the same period in the republic. Citizens living in Lithuanian S.S.R. are within the next seven days to hand in all their weapons to the law-enforcement bodies for temporary keeping. The U.S.S.R. Interior Ministry is to seize such weapons in cases of refusal to turn them in. The Defense Ministry is to receive from law-enforcement organs the weapons seized from citizens and ensure their safekeeping. 4) The Foreign Ministry and the Interior Ministry are to tighten control over issuance of entrance visas to foreigners and over the permission for foreigners to visit the Lithuanian S.S.R. The Interior Ministry and the U.S.S.R. Procurator's Office are to take all essential measures to suppress violations by foreigners staying in Lithuanian S.S.R. of the regulations concerning the stay of foreign nationals all the way to their deportation in keeping with the U.S.S.R. law on the legal status of foreign nationals in the U.S.S.R. 5) The decree becomes effective immediately after signing.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Book Collection Seized From Home Rivals Libraries, Curator Says
DOC.TEXT: The collection of thousands of rare books and manuscripts worth up to $20 million seized from a home in southeastern Iowa rivals many libraries, a university curator said. ``It was like walking into a very, very good rare-book store,'' said David Schoonover, curator of rare books at the University of Iowa who was called in by the FBI to help with the investigation. The home's owner, Stephen Carrie Blumberg, 41, who lists his address as St. Paul, Minn., was arrested at the house Tuesday and charged with interstate transport of stolen property. The FBI Wednesday appealed to universities and libraries for help in locating the owners of the estimated 11,000 publications seized from the 14-room house in the community of Ottumwa. Authorities valued the collection at $10 million to $20 million, and said the antiquities included a Bible published in 1568. FBI agent Dennis Aiken said the items were stolen from universities and private collections across North America, including Harvard University, the College of William and Mary, and the University of Notre Dame. He said agents recovered a suitcase full of library stickers bearing the names of numerous colleges and universities. Blumberg has been under investigation by numerous law enforcement agencies for two years, said Aiken. The basis of the search of the house was a complaint that manuscripts and books valued at $662,000 were missing from the University of Oregon in Eugene, according to a federal affidavit filed in Des Moines. Larry Holmquist, an FBI agent based in Omaha, Neb., said inquiries about missing books should be made in writing to Charles Lontor, the senior agent in charge of the Omaha FBI office. The FBI said the items would be transferred to a warehouse in Des Moines for inventory and cataloging. Schoonover said Wednesday he's unsure how many books were in the house or the total value. ``I do believe whoever brought them to the house was very clever indeed,'' Schoonover said. He said if the house in Ottumwa were a library, it would be considered a good one. ``They (the publications) were in very good condition. They were carefully arranged by subject and category of authors,'' he said. ``I was astounded at the range and quality and number of books.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: ``I have not ordered it off Air Force One. I have just said, `Don't you dare bring me another sprig of that vegetable.''' _ President Bush on the broccoli thing.

``It's a brand new world and unless we throw off old ways of thinking rooted in Cold War mentality, we risk being left behind.'' _ House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., on the need for U.S. participation in a proposed European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

``Yes, this is a war of nerves, but we are not nervous. We have the motivation, we have our country, and we know where we are going.'' _ Lithuanian legislator Algimontas Cekuolis on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's warning to Lithuania to rescind its call for independence.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Say Menem's Reform Plan Betrays His Political Backers
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of members of President Carlos Menem's governing party stopped work and marched to Congress, accusing him of betraying his political roots by imposing a drastic anti-inflation plan. ``Menem, You Cheated Us. Get Out,'' read an 82-foot-long banner carried by employees of the state telephone company as about 60,000 people rallied outside Congress on Wednesday. The Peronist Party candidate was elected in May with the support of organized labor after a campaign in which he made no mention of the painful austerity program. The broad support of Wednesday's strike, which disrupted airline flights, mail delivery, classes and other public services, indicated growing difficulties for Menem to try to stop 12,000 percent inflation and more than four decades of economic decline. ``Today begins the first step in the struggle against the privatizations and so-called restructuring of the state,'' Saul Ubaldini, a leader of the General Labor Confederation, told the crowd outside Congress. In trying to stop inflation, Menem has said he would sell the airline, telephone, railroad and many other money-losing state companies that were nationalized or created beginning with the presidency of Juan Domingo Peron in 1946. ``Menem betrayed us. He betrayed the people and Peronism,'' said Celina Morturi, 45, who works for the state gas company. The strike was carried out peacefully by 22 unions that represent about 1.5 million state employees. The leader of the 22-union Coordinating Board, Victor de Gennaro, said: ``We believe the Peronist government should listen to the people whose support brought Carlos Menem to the presidency.'' Union leaders say the move to sell state enterprises, along with spending cuts to balance the fiscal budget, will throw tens of thousands of people out of work in an economy already beset by inflation, recession and unemployment. The rally and march took place on a warm first day of fall in this Southern Hemisphere nation of 32 million. Menem, 59, tried to avoid the strike, and an open break with organized labor, by offering a modest increase in public wages and doubling retirement pensions to about $80 a month. However, he said Tuesday: ``They can stage a thousand strikes, but the economic plan is totally irreversible.'' Government officials say they have no choice but to reduce the budget because the printing of money by the Central Bank to finance the deficit fuels inflation. For years, Argentina financed the fiscal deficit by borrowing abroad, but it can no longer do that because it stopped repaying its more than $60 billion foreign debt. It also sold bonds to Argentines, who stopped buying them after the government froze withdrawals from savings accounts in January. Argentines wary of their currency, which has lost 99 percent of its value in the past year, have billions of U.S. dollars in savings, including an estimated $50 billion invested overseas. Uncertainty about the economy has raised fears that the military may again try to seize power, something it has done six times since 1930. Such fears were heightened further following the death Tuesday of army chief Gen. Isidro Caceres after a heart attack. Caceres, who was 55, had helped put down three mutinies since April 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Plan To Try Vietnamese Youth Again
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese youth who spent four years in prison after being illegally sentenced to 38 years in prison will be tried again on robbery charges, Dallas County prosecutors say. The announcement Wednesday came only a week after the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals ruled that Luan Van Hoang had been illegally sentenced to an adult prison. The prosecutors' strategy potentially could expose the teen-ager to three life sentences in prison. ``I think it's appropriate that he be held accountable, whether it's in juvenile court or felony (adult) court, for the action he committed, if he is adjudged guilty,'' said Janice Warder, chief of the juvenile division of the Dallas County district attorney's office. Luan, who records show was only 13 when he was convicted of armed robbery in 1986, was sentenced by a Dallas jury to adult prison after lying to police about his age. Luan said he told officials that he was 17 to avoid return to a California juvenile facility from which he had fled. The state's highest criminal court ruled March 14 that District Judge Jack Hampton lacked jurisdiction because Luan was underage. Prosecutors say they planned to retry Luan not just on the case that was thrown out but on three other robberies. In 1986, Luan agreed to a plea bargain for three 10-year sentences only after a jury had sentenced him to 38 years on the first robbery. Prosecutors said they were preparing to handle all four cases together, which could result in three life sentences for Luan. But defense lawyer Bruce Anton questioned the legality of the prosecution's plans. ``If the district attorney's office intends to have the other three convictions voided, at this time I intend to contest that matter,'' Anton said. Anton said he believes that state parole officials will release Luan soon because the four years he has served probably have discharged his concurrent 10-year sentences. Anton said he also doubts that prosecutors could prove their contention that Luan was 16, not 13, at the time of the robbery and retry him as an adult.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Advertisement Is Removed From Billboard After Protests
DOC.TEXT: An advertising firm has covered a billboard after residents and town officials protested the gun ad on it because of escalating violence in the Boston area. ``When you're finding dead bodies in the streets, to advertise guns is awful,'' Norwood Selectman Thomas Riolo said. ``People think it's bad taste.'' The ad featured a single Browning shotgun stretched across the billboard with the words ``ARMCO Gun Sales'' and several gun manufacturers' names. Ackerley Communications Inc. announced Tuesday that it also was removing similar billboards in Boston, Cambridge and Watertown. The same advertisement will remain at Framingham, Worcester, Fitchburg and Marlboro locations, because no complaints have been received from those places. The advertisement was paid for by Armco Gun Sales and the gun featured is one primarily used for shooting skeet, Armco manager Harold Carter Jr. said. ``It's hard to understand how some of these billboards ... that are sexually centered can run,'' he said, ``yet a skeet-gun used for nothing more than shooting clay pigeons can't.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Review of `Birmingham Six' Bombing Convictions
DOC.TEXT: The government has ordered a review of the convictions of six men who claim police forced them to confess to two Irish Republican Army bombings that killed 21 people in 1974. Home Secretary David Waddington said Wednesday he had asked police to review points raised by lawyers for so-called Birmingham Six. Their cause has been taken up by Amnesty International, the Irish government and most recently by Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, the Roman Catholic primate of Ireland. Waddington previously had resisted calls to review the case, but said Wednesday that his decision was based on new submissions from attorneys. ``In the light of the outcome of those investigations I will give further consideration to whether my intervention in the convictions of the six men would be justified,'' Waddington said in a written statement to the House of Commons. Asked at a news conference whether the inquiry centered on allegations of police misconduct, Waddington said: ``I am not prepared to go into detail as to what the various questions are.'' He indicated the case would be referred to an appeal court if the new investigation raised any questions about the convictions. Gareth Peirce, an attorney for the six, said she hoped Waddington's decision would be ``the beginning of the end of the ordeal of the men and their families.'' All six were sentenced to life in prison in 1975 for the bombings in Birmingham. In 1988, the Court of Appeal affirmed the convictions. Lord Lane, the Lord Chief Justice, said at the time that ``the longer this hearing has gone on, the more this court has been convinced the jury was correct.'' Pressure for a review of the Birmingham Six case grew in October after a court set aside the convictions of four people for IRA bombings in Guildford and Woolwich in 1974. In that case, prosecutors admitted police had tampered with documents relating to interrogations. Supporters of the Birmingham convicts have argued their confessions contradict each other, police tampered with logs to make statements appear consistent, forensic evidence was flawed and no witness testified to seeing any of the men in the two pubs. The explosions on Nov. 21, 1974 at the Mulberry Bush and the Tavern in the Town killed 21 people and injured 162, the most deadly IRA attack in England. Waddington formally requested the new review from the West Midlands police force, which developed the cases against the six: Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan, Richard McIlkenny, Gerry Hunter and Billy Power. Waddington said West Midlands Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear had delegated the actual investigation to the Devon and Cornwall force. The West Midlands force is itself under investigation. In August, Dear suspended two detectives and reassigned all 53 other members of the Serious Crime Squad. He acted following allegations, supported by detailed technical evidence, that detectives had falsified confessions since January 1986. Waddington's announcement came one week before the broadcast of a documentary on the Birmingham bombings, which Granada Television says will identify five other men as the bombers. One of those men is said to be in prison and the other four are at large.

DOC.HEAD: South African Leader Says World Accepts His Government's `Good Faith'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa said today that Namibia's independence and reforms in South Africa have shown the world his government is serious about ending apartheid. De Klerk was present at ceremonies Wednesday when South Africa relinquished control of Namibia after 75 years of colonial rule. He also has met with numerous world leaders during his visit, the latest sign that South Africa's international isolation has eased. ``South Africa's bona fides (good faith) is accepted,'' de Klerk said this morning before returning to South Africa for talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``The international community in general now accepts that drastic change is going to take place'' in South Africa, de Klerk said. The South African president, who has initiated a series of reforms since assuming power in August, held talks in Namibia with the country's president, Sam Nujoma, U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze as well as the presidents of six African nations and the foreign ministers of several European countries. ``I informed the leaders with whom I met that our aim was a new constitution in South Africa which will have the support of the majority of all South Africans,'' de Klerk said. ``While white domination should come to an end, care should be taken to avoid a situation where one form of domination was replaced by another.'' De Klerk wants the country's whites to share political power with South Africa's 28 million blacks, but he opposes outright black majority rule. He envisions some mechanism that would give the country's 5 million whites veto power on major policy decisions. De Klerk said his talks went well with Nujoma, who led the guerrilla movement that waged a 23-year war against South African rule. ``There is a wish that we should remain good friends,'' de Klerk said. He said the exact level of diplomatic relations between the two countries remained to be worked out. South Africa has full diplomatic relations with only one African country, Malawi, but has trade missions in several others. De Klerk said the protracted civil wars in Angola and Mozambique were discussed at his meetings with foreign leaders. In both those countries, leftist governments have been fighting since the 1970s against rebel movements that were backed by South Africa until a few years ago. Relations between South Africa and the governments of Angola and Mozambique have improved recently, but heavy fighting persists in both countries. There have been a series of meetings in Windhoek this week in an attempt to arrange a cease-fire and peace talks between the warring sides in Angola. The Soviets back the Angolan government while the United States supplies an estimated $50 million in assistance to guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Say Court Ruling Undermines Grand Jury Concept
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors say a U.S. Supreme Court ruling letting grand jury witnesses disclose their testimony undermines the centuries-old concept of a secret panel that deciding es if criminal charges are warranted. ``It's another chink in the armor of the grand jury,'' said Buddy Jacobs, head of the Florida Prosecuting Attorneys Association. ``We feel like the system's worked well enough to last 800 years.'' But Mike Smith, the former news reporter who brought down Florida's law barring disclosure of grand jury testimony, said Wednesday's unanimous ruling will prevent prosecutors from abusing the system. ``The grand jury itself is kind of an inquisition process,'' Smith said. ``If witnesses aren't allowed to say what they did or heard in there, then you not only have an inquisition but an inquisition operating in the dark.'' The Supreme Court upheld an appeals court decision striking down a law that prohibited grand jury witnesses from ever revealing their testimony after the case ends. Fifteen other states have similar laws. The ruling does not affect laws barring witnesses from revealing the testimony while the grand jury investigation is in progress. ``The court did limit its ruling, and we're pleased with that,'' Jacobs said. ``They could have ruled that the testimony could be made public during the investigation.'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the court, said the state failed to prove that prosecutors' interests in secrecy were enough to overcome a reporter's First Amendment rights. ``The potential for abuse of the Florida prohibition, through its employment as a device to silence those who know of unlawful conduct or irregularities on the part of public officials, is apparent,'' Rehnquist wrote. Smith, now a National Guard sergeant at Fort Indiantown Gap in Annville, Pa., was a reporter for the Charlotte Herald-News in 1986 when a grand jury in Charlotte County called him to testify about stories he wrote alleging corruption in the sheriff's and state attorneys' offices. In a telephone interview Wednesday, Smith said during his testimony he noticed that prosecutors were directing the jury foreman to take certain actions and controlled whether jurors would hand down any indictments. ``The grand jury was not able to be the sword and the shield of the law it was supposed to be,'' Smith said. After the investigation ended and no indictments were returned, Smith wanted to publish a news story and possibly a book about the case but was barred by law. A federal judge upheld the law when Smith challenged it, but it was struck down by the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, and the state appealed. George Waas, the assistant attorney general who handled the case, said allowing publication of completed grand jury proceedings by witnesses could harm a future investigation that might occur if more evidence came to light. ``There are instances where grand jury investigations are concluded only to be picked up again years later,'' Waas said. ``It's quite possible that details about what occurred before the jury might compromise the jury's ability to do its job.'' Waas also said the Florida law, which had been on the books for 40 years, properly balanced the need for secret testimony and the First Amendment. But the Supreme Court sided with Smith, who said the ruling reduces the omnipotence of prosecutors in grand jury proceedings. ``The prosecutor basically did whatever he wanted to do. The significance of this case is that he's lost a little bit of that control,'' Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan's Largest Student Demonstration Ends Peacefully
DOC.TEXT: The country's largest student demonstration ended peacefully today when thousands of protesters left a downtown park, agreeing to give President Lee Teng-hui a chance to implement democratic reform. The weeklong sit-in had attracted as many as 6,000 students to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park. ``We cherish the achievement of this movement. We will return to the campus to continue our efforts,'' said student leader Fan Yun. ``We will give the governing Nationalist Party some time for the reforms.'' She said students across the island would form a coalition to monitor the progress of the political and economic reforms that Lee has vaguely promised. Applauding and shouting ``We Want Democratic Reforms,'' many of the students gradually left the park early in the morning. About 100 stayed to clean up the square, which was filled with garbage from the seven-day occupation. The protest was triggered by the election of Lee by the National Assembly, which is dominated by elderly Nationalist politicians who last faced election on the Chinese mainland more than four decades ago. The assemblymen fled to Taiwan with the rest of the Nationalist government after losing a civil war to the Communists in 1949. They were frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim to still be China's legitimate government. Students want the National Assembly to disband and for the people to choose the president by direct ballot. In another development today, Presidential Advisor Li Yuan-zu, 66, was elected vice president by the assembly. He was the hand-picked nominee of President Lee and was the only candidate. President Lee, who also is chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party, was elected to six years in office on Wednesday and hourse later met with 53 leaders of the student protesters. Lee told students he would accept any suggestions that will benefit the nation. ``I will certainly do my utmost to solve all problems,'' Lee said. ``But it takes time.'' He has promised to convene an emergency conference before July to discuss changing the country's political system in response to widespread calls that Taiwanese have a greater say in choosing their leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Preservationists Get Savvy, Expand Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Historic preservationists are tossing their sneakers in the closet and donning pinstripes to take an expanded message of community planning, urban renewal and affordable housing to a broader audience. ``I'm rather interested in acquainting a broader variety of professionals in the business of shaping cities with the broader concerns of historic preservation,'' said J. Jackson Walter, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. ``We would like to preach beyond the choir.'' A national conference beginning today in Pittsburgh is one of the first attempts to link the common interests of preservationists and planners, organizers said. Jerold S. Kayden, a visiting faculty member at the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy in Cambridge, Mass., called the two-day conference of historic preservationists and professional planners, public officials and developers ``their debutante party.'' ``Before, they were walking down the same aisle, but they didn't recognize each other,'' he said. About 250 people _ from historic preservationists to land-use attorneys _ are expected to attend the conference. Preservationists have joined the political process in ways they traditionally were absent a decade ago, said Elizabeth Waters, mayor of Charlottesville, Va. ``Historic preservation has moved much more toward community planning and development,'' she said. Preservationists are traveling ``in pretty heavy company,'' Walter said. For example, he said, in President Bush's most recent budget proposal, efforts to preserve America's heritage rate high on the national agenda _ in the same realm as protecting the environment and improving the infrastructure and transportation system. The conference also will focus on past successes and failures in burgeoning suburban areas, many of which are turning into small cities that are home to more than 60 percent of the nation's offices. Sponsors decided to hold the conference in Pittsburgh because of its renaissance from a economically depressed city to one of the country's most livable, said Constance Beaumont, spokeswoman of the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington, D.C. ``There just seemed to be a lot of innovative things going on,'' Ms. Beaumont said. ``We thought it would be an interesting laboratory.'' One example of the result of little preservation or planning is Tyson's Corner, Va., near Washington, D.C., where there is heavy traffic with limited pedestrian areas, Walter said.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Market Plunges Another 900 Points, Dollar Sharply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The main index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell 3.13 percent today, three days after the third-worst drop in its history, and the yen fell sharply against the dollar. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 963.85 points, ending a hectic day at 29,843.34, its lowest closing since Dec. 24, 1988. Today's drop put the Nikkei's losses so far this year at 23 percent, or 9,072.53 points. During the morning session, a rush of sell orders met with virtually no buyers, driving the index down 1,836.05 points, or 5.96 percent, by the lunch break. Monday's 1,353.20-point decline was the third biggest in history. There was no trading Wednesday because of a national holiday. Dealers blamed the market pessimism on the yen's continuing depreciation against the dollar, despite this week's 1 percent rise in Japan's official discount rate to 5.25 percent. Higher interest rates tend to boost currency values while discouraging stock investors. The massive sell orders came mainly from institutional investors who were desperate to offset earlier losses, dealers said. ``It seems investor uncertainty and pessimism, which has been building over the past three months, suddenly emerged when the Nikkei index broke the psychological 30,000-point barrier,'' said Kenji Maeshiro, a stock analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``The market pessimism intensified as the index fell,'' he said. The Nikkei index recovered somewhat in the afternoon as market players decided it had fallen as much as it could for the day after breaking the 29,000-point barrier, said Hisao Yasuda, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. ``We don't understand why the situation is this way,'' said Yaruo Yamaguchi, president of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., whose share price closed at $6,903, down $452 from Tuesday. ``NTT's performance has not weakened at all. It's not NTT's stock price alone that is down. I think we are just in the middle of a major current,'' he said. The market has not hit bottom, Maeshiro said, but ``the bottom is almost here.'' ``It took the market one year to gain 10,000 points, but it's gone in only three months. It will take a while for the market to recover,'' he said. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 580 million shares. Testifying before a parliamentary committee hearing, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said the stock drop stemmed from the Japanese currency's rapid decline, Kyodo News Service reported. He said it will take time for the effects of the discount rate increase to emerge, and the increase in the key interest rate would not have a serious adverse impact on the economy. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told the hearing that the stock and currency markets were influencing each other, sending both yen and stock values down. He said his ministry was monitoring the markets ``with anguish.'' Japan's main securities companies have temporarily stopped underwriting new stock issues, bonds and warrants in an attempt to support stock prices. In currency dealings, the dollar ended the day at 154.83 yen, up 1.18 yen from Tuesday's close of 153.65 yen, despite repeated dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan, currency traders said. The U.S. currency opened at 154.50 yen and ranged between 154.50 yen and 155.45 yen. Currency dealers blamed the yen's weakness on the stock market drop.

DOC.HEAD: Cosby Producers Asked For $100 Million Bonus
DOC.TEXT: Producers of ``The Cosby Show'' asked NBC for a $100 million signing bonus to renew the top-ranked comedy series for a seventh season, but have dropped their request to $25 million, a newspaper reported today. Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner have spent the past eight weeks in negotiations with Brandon Tartikoff, entertainment chief for the National Broadcasting Co., the Los Angeles Times reported. David Brokaw, a spokesman for Carsey-Werner, said it is ``the company's policy not to comment on matters of this kind.'' Tartikoff also declined to comment, but said money is the main dispute in the final rounds of renewal negotiations. ``When you're talking about renewing the No. 1-rated show in television, it's a question of how high you're willing to go. They have one level and we have another level,'' Tartikoff said. He made the comments last week after presenting NBC's fall development projects to advertisers. ``Cosby'' has reportedly earned $575 million so far for NBC, and that amount is expected to increase substantially each year the show is on the network, the newspaper said. The series is filmed in New York and centers around the Huxtable family: an obstetrician, his wife and their five children. Sources close to the seesaw negotiations said they began initially with Carsey-Werner asking for a $100 million signing bonus, and NBC seeking a two-year renewal, the newspaper reported. The producers then countered with a request for a $75 million bonus and a one-year renewal. They also wanted NBC to pay $1 million an episode to cover all ``direct costs'' associated with the show, the Times reported. Carsey-Werner then considered dropping the bonus request, if the network agreed to hike its license fee to $3 million per 30-minute show, but NBC declined. More recent discussions have returned to the signing bonus request, now reported at $25 million. The lower figure takes into consideration network commitments to other Carsey-Werner programs. The producers still want NBC to pick up the $1 million cost to make each episode.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against all other major currencies in moderate trading in Europe this morning. Gold prices were up slightly in European trading, but lower in Hong Kong. With concerns about unrest in Lithuanian and Romania, investors were turning to the dollar as a safe haven, dealers said. Traders said continued confusion over how long unification between East and West Germany will take is discouraging interest in the Deutsche mark. But the dollar is unlikely to rise much higher, dealers said, with fears of another round of coordinated central bank intervention. ``I can't see the dollar moving ahead much today,'' said Pat Magill, head of corporate trading at Daiwa Bank Ltd., in London. The Bank of Japan intervened heavily to support the yen earlier today but had little impact on the markets, traders said. There was concern, however, that other central banks, like the West German Bundesbank and the U.S. Federal Reserve, would join in to slow the dollar's advance, they said. ``The charts are pointed to a bullish direction for the dollar, but there's a lack of conviction for buying,'' said Manfred Totzauer, senior trader at Citibank AG in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.18 yen to a closing 154.83 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _ 1.7123 West German marks, up from 1.7070 _ 1.5205 Swiss francs, up from 1.5192 _ 5.7720 French francs, up from 5.7575 _ 1.9255 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9230 _ 1,260.50 Italian lire, up from 1,257.25 _ 1.1810 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1769 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.5952, compared with $1.5965 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $392.50 a troy ounce, up from $391.75 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $392.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $392.10, up from $391.50 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 99 cents to close at a bid $393.52. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.08 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.06.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Dips Across Northern Plains; East Coast Stays Warm
DOC.TEXT: A cold front was moving across the northern Plains today, threatening livestock with a blast of winter, while farmers in the highlands of the Carolinas assessed extensive frost damage to peaches and other early crops. A cold front pushed by strong northerly winds may drop temperatures in northern North Dakota and Minnesota to 10 below by late tonight. Snow was expected, with gusts reaching 45 mph likely to leave drifts. Livestock stress is expected to reach the danger level in eastern Wyoming late tonight and Friday, the National Weather Service said. Freezing temperatures early Wednesday destroyed up to half of the peach crop in South Carolina's Upstate and extension agents say such early crops as tobacco, corn and watermelons also suffered devastating blows. Growers blamed the damage on temperatures that dipped into the low 20s just before dawn Wednesday. More frost was possible later this week. Rain fell in South Dakota on Wednesday night ahead of the developing storm front. A few thundershowers were also over western Nebraska and northeastern Colorado. The Southwest was expected to bask under clear skies and temperatures into the 80s and 90s, while showers were forecast for Northwest. Rain fell in Minneapolis early today. Clear skies were expected over much of the East, but showers were likely in New York, Vermont and New Hampshire. Flood waters in the Florida panhandle from swollen Georgia and Alabama rivers were expected to recede in some places today. But some other rivers were not expected to crest until Friday or Saturday. The high for the nation Wednesday was 98 degrees at Borrego Springs and Palm Springs in California. DOC.HEAD: Gates on Iran-Soviet Border Opened after 73 Years
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Azerbaijanis poured across a bridge into Iran after the Soviet Union opened a frontier crossing for the first time in 73 years, Iran's official Tehran Radio reported. The people who crossed the Araks River bridge Wednesday were Iran's first officially sanctioned visitors from the Soviet republic under an agreement reached after violent demonstrations in January over opening the border. The gates on the bridge swung open to mark the Iranian Moslem new year of 1369, which started Wednesday, the radio said. Relatives from Iran and the Soviet Azerbaijani region of Nakhichevan met at the crossing in the city of Jolfa, said the report, monitored in Cyprus. ``Many of the people were ecstatic with joy, and warmly embraced their relatives,'' Tehran radio said. It gave no figures for the number of those crossing. The Iranians showered the arriving Soviet Moslems with gifts, including flowers, sweets and beverages as well as the Koran, the Moslem holy book. The radio said that an agreement between Tehran and Moscow allowed for all residents living within 2{ miles of the border to cross unimpeded. Nakhichevan is a mostly Moslem enclave surrounded by Soviet Armenia but governed by mainly Moslem Azerbaijan. The border between Iran and the Soviet Union was shaken by violence starting in December, when Moslems protesting its closure tore down fences and burned border posts. The Tehran radio report indicated the bridge gates had been closed since the 1917 Russian Revolution, although the Red Army did not assert complete control over Azerbaijan until 1920. Last month, the Soviet Union and Iran signed an agreement to allow citizens from either side to cross four times a year and travel in designated territories for up to 15 days. The estimated 20 million Azerbaijanis in the Soviet Union and Iran, mostly Shiite Moslems, share the same religion, language and culture.

DOC.HEAD: European Experts Ponder Boston's Art Theft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to CORRECT name to ``Stewart,'' sted ``Steward.'' Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: High-profile works of art like those stolen from a Boston museum are difficult to protect and unlikely to be recovered, according to some European experts. Interpol, the international crime clearing house, says only 5 percent to 10 percent of the stolen artwork it tries to track is recovered. The United States has requested help from the organization on the theft Sunday at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, said Elisabeth Gams, an Interpol inspector. Ms. Gams said it was too soon to guess the motive for the thefts or what might happen to the works, which include paintings by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Degas and Manet. ``If there is no (ransom) demand in the coming days, one could suppose the paintings are with someone,'' she said, referring to a theft by contract. ``But we can imagine everything. Works of such value are unsalable.'' Europe leads the world in stolen art works, with Italy then France the prime victims, Ms. Gams said. The chief targets are churches, then private collectors, followed by museums. Experts say everything from petty banditry to terrorism is behind thefts. ``Every time it happens, we wonder what these people want to do with those lovely paintings,'' said Margreet Kolkman, spokeswoman for Amsterdam's renowned Rijksmuseum. ``The problem is they're worthless and priceless at the same time.'' Such artworks ``can't be sold anywhere. That's absolutely impossible,'' she said. ``Probably some idiot wants to keep them in his safe and sometimes cast a glance on them.'' In 1988, the Dutch art world was hit by two spectacular thefts. In June, three paintings, including a Van Gogh and a Cezanne, were stolen from Amsterdam's Municipal Museum. In December, three Van Goghs were stolen from the Kroller-Muller Museum in Otterlo. The first three paintings were recovered as they were about to be sold to an undercover law enforcement agent. The Kroller-Muller thieves demanded an undisclosed ransom, but the Van Goghs were recovered after police set up a trap. Pictures can go underground for years, ``sleeping'' in police parlance. Or, ``They pass through various hands on the black market until they find a home with a fervent collector,'' Anthony Russell of Scotland Yard's arts and antiques squad was quoted as telling The Times newspaper. ``When these people see a picture they want, they go after it, come what may. They want it for themselves and nothing else matters.'' Paintings stolen in Europe or the United States have been recovered in Asia and the Middle East. Authorities do not exclude terrorism as a possible motive in art thefts. In 1974, sympathizers of the Irish Republican Army stole Vermeer's ``The Guitar Players,'' but the painting eventually was recovered in a rural churchyard. Museum officials often feel helpless and say it is impossible to adequately secure a public place such as a museum. ``We have the most sophisticated security,'' said Marianne de la Fond, the assistant curator of the Marmottan Museum in Paris. Nine impressionist paintings were stolen from the museum in 1985, including Claude Monet's ``Impression Soleil Levant'' (Impression Sunrise). ``It's like in a bank. If an armed person enters a public place, there is nothing you can do,'' she said. The tactics used for the Marmottan theft were unique, Marianne de la Fond noted, recalling that it was carried out in daylight by five armed men. ``I have always believed that if a burglar wants to steal something, he will. The more you arm yourself with sophisticated devices, the more it becomes a challenge to thieves,'' said Philip Rylands, curator of the Peggy Guggenheim Museum in Venice. ``There are things against which you can't protect yourself,'' said Ms. Kolkman of the Rijksmuseum. ``A museum is a public building, not a fort. We have to admit people. That's our function.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Libya Received 1,000 Tons of Semtex Explosive
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's former Communist rulers sold tons of Semtex plastic explosives to Libya but its new non-Communist government has stopped all such exports, President Vaclav Havel said today. Havel, in Britain on an official visit, made his comments at a news conference at the Czechoslovak Embassy. ``The past regime exported 1,000 tons to Libya,'' he said. ``If you consider that it takes 200 grams (7 ounces) to blow up an aircraft, this means world terrorism has enough Semtex to last for 150 years.'' Semtex was used in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988, killing all 259 on board and 11 people on the ground. ``We ceased exporting this explosive some time ago,'' Havel said, speaking through a translator. He did not give a date or any other details. The former dissident playwright said Tuesday that his country's considerable arms industry would no longer sell weapons to totalitarian regimes, but would continue to sell arms to democracies. Czechoslovakia has long been a major arms manufacturer. It produces hand grenades, automatic rifles, tanks and armored personnel carriers, in addition to explosives. Published reports say that the export of such weapons and components accounted for between one-quarter and one-half of Czechoslovakia's foreign-exchange earnings. The nation, strapped for hard currency, may find it difficult to stop the trade. Czechoslovakia, under the hard-line Communist regime of Milos Jakes and Gustav Husak, found a market among nations too poor to afford expensive Western weapons or those denied access for political reasons. In addition to Libya, clients have included Angola, South Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Havel stopped short of saying that Czechoslovakia would no longer manufacture Semtex, but defended its production for peaceful use. ``This is an industrial explosive necessary for various industrial uses. It is not an explosive made especially for terrorists,'' he said. But, ``now we want to mark Semtex so it will be detectable,'' he added. Semtex is odorless and can be molded into any shape, making it almost undetectable by conventional anti-terrorist devices. On Wednesday, the first day of his three-day visit, Havel had lunch with Queen Elizabeth II, then had talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. He said they discussed the future of Europe and German unification. ``I told her that the process of unification should be understood as a sort of engine propelling the unification of the whole of Europe,'' he said. ``No new European order can be built on a permanent fear of any one nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Cabby Sets World Record
DOC.TEXT: Carmen ``Irish'' Fasanella first outfitted the back of his Buick truck in 1919 with two planks that served as benches to ferry Princeton University students to campus from the local train station. Fasanella, 87, who retired in October after logging 68 years, 243 days as a cabby, was told last week by the Guinness Book of World Records that he is the world's longest licensed taxi driver, breaking the previous mark by more than a decade. The former record-holder, Francis Edward Kenyon of Manchester, England, held his taxi license 57 years-plus, from 1924 to 1981. Fasanella has driven for Jimmy Stewart, Adlai Stevenson and F. Scott Fitzgerald, but his favorite rider was Albert Einstein, who lived in Princeton and worked at the Institute for Advanced Studies. The scientist enlisted the cabby as a sort of bodyguard for his morning walks. ``He was a terrific guy and a wonderful, wonderful man,'' Fasanella said. ``People used to scare him half to death. People would be riding up Mercer Street 40 or 50 mph, throw their breaks on, jump out of the car and run towards him to get an autograph. They used to scare the poor old man to death.'' Fasanella said sometimes he would walk with Einstein, and sometimes he would follow behind in his cab to ward off curiosity seekers.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Mathiason, Prendergast; removes garble before Lord Rothschild entry, Subs 1st graf of Lesher obit to tighten. No separates moved for the PMs cycle.
DOC.TEXT: Lord Rothschild, the millionaire banker and decorated World War II intelligence agent, died Tuesday at age 79. His family declined to disclose the cause of death. Lord Rothschild was born Nathaniel Mayer Victor Rothschild into a famous family of German-Jewish coin collectors who founded a banking dynasty. He succeeded his uncle as the 3rd Baron Rothschild in 1937, taking his seat in the House of Lords, the non-elected upper chamber of Parliament, as a member of the Labor Party. During World War II, Rothschild served as a senior officer with MI5, the British counterespionage service. Responding to what he said were years of innuendo in the press, Rothschild wrote The Daily Telegraph in 1986 urging MI5 to state publicly that it had ``unequivocal evidence'' disproving rumors that he was the ``fifth man'' in the infamous Soviet spy ring formed by Guy Burgess, Kim Philby, Donald Maclean and Anthony Blunt. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the government had no evidence that Rothschild was ever a Soviet agent.

Elaine Jackson Shevchenko, the wife of a prominent Soviet defector, died Tuesday of cancer at age 50. She married Arkady Shevchenko in 1978, shortly after he quit his job as undersecretary-general of the United Nations. His first wife committed suicide after the widely publicized defection. Mrs. Shevchenko helped her husband write a book, ``Breaking with Moscow,'' about his work for U.S. intelligence before he decided to leave the Soviet diplomatic corps and settle in the United States.

Movie director Maurice Cloche, best known for his Oscar-winning film, ``Monsieur Vincent,'' died Tuesday of Parkinson's Disease at age 82. ``Monsieur Vincent,'' a dramatization of the life of St. Vincent de Paul starring Pierre Fresnay, won the Academy Award in 1947 for best foreign film. It also was honored as the best film in France that year. Cloche's 50-year career included spy thrillers as well as films with religious and social themes. His best known films include a ``La Cage aux Oiseaux,'' (The Bird Cage); ``Le Docteur Laennec,'' the story of the inventor of the stethoscope; ``Ne de Pere Inconnu,'' (Father Unknown); and ``La Cage aux Filles'' (The Girl Cage). In 1940, Cloche founded a film society for young talent. It later became France's leading film school, the Institute of Advanced Film Studies.

T. Roland Berner, chairman and president of the Curtiss-Wright Corp. for the past three decades, died Sunday of a heart attack at age 80. In 1948 and more than a decade before he took over what then was a leading maker of aircraft engines, Berner led a group of dissident stockholders seeking to oust the company's management. As head of the diversified aerospace components producer in the late 1970s and early 80s, Berner waged an unsuccessful three-year battle to control the Kennecott Copper Corp. The struggle ended in 1981 when both parties agreed that neither one would try to take over the other for the next 10 years. However, Kennecott came away with Curtiss-Wright's pollution-control subsidiary, Dorr-Oliver Inc.

Dorothy Spence Illson, an arbiter of prose style at Life and then Fortune magazines, died Tuesday of lung cancer at age 70. She taught high school English in Iowa, served with the Red Cross in the Pacific during World War II and was a copy reader for Dance Magazine before joining Life in 1947. Mrs. Illson became chief of the Life copy room in 1972 and moved to Fortune in 1973, where she was instrumental in converting the magazine to electronic typesetting and twice-a-month publication in 1978. She retired in 1986. Mrs. Illson was survived by her husband, Murray Illson, a retired employee of The New York Times; three sons, Richard, of Lakewood, Ohio; James of Seattle, and John, of Lakewood, Colo.; and a brother, Dexter Spence, of Roswell, Ga.

Ron E. Kramer, a reporter and photographer for The Daily News in Iron Mountain for 25 years, was found dead Monday of a heart attack at age 49. Kramer joined the News editorial staff November 1965 after being discharged from the U.S. Army where he worked in public relations and broadcasting. Kramer loved sports and often photographed football games from the sideline for the News. Survivors include a sister, Kay Antonissen, and a niece, Amy Antonissen, both of Marinette.

Jason Boe, a former four-term Oregon Senate president who dominated the Legislature during the 1970s, died Tuesday of a heart attack at age 61. Boe, a Democrat, served in the state Legislature from 1965 to 1981. A Reedsport optometrist, he first served three terms in the House and in 1970 was elected to the Senate. He presided the Senate during the 1973, 1975, 1977 and 1979 sessions _ a record four times. He ran unsuccessfully for the U.S. Senate in 1974, and he gave up his state senate seat in 1980 to run unsuccessfully for treasurer. Boe owned an international consulting firm on government affairs, Jason Boe & Associates Inc., with offices in Taiwan and Korea.

George Y. Lesher, an internationally known scientist in medicinal chemistry, drowned Saturday in a canoeing accident. He was 64. Lesher worked 38 years for Sterling Research Group, and was the holder or co-holder of more than 140 patents. He was named the Sterling-Winthrop Research Institute's first fellow in 1982, a position he held at the time of his death. Lesher held numerous positions with Sterling, including senior research chemist, senior research associate, assistant director and section head. Among his accomplishments was the discovery of two new classes of therapeutic agents from which three commercial drugs for the treatment of heart disease and bacterial infections were developed.
DOC.HEAD: Geneva Mathiason
DOC.TEXT: Geneva Mathiason, the former executive director of the National Council on the Aging, has died at age 91. She died Tuesday of heart failure at a nursing home in Suffern, N.Y. Mathiasen was a delegate to the first White House Conference on the Aging in 1950. She was appointed executive secretary of the National Committee on the Aging, which had just been established to provide information and consultation services. With the help of a Ford Foundation grant, the national committee became the independent National Council on the Aging, with Mathiason as its first director in 1960. She retired in 1969.
DOC.HEAD: Michael H. Prendergast
DOC.TEXT: Michael H. Prendergast, a former chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee, died Tuesday at age 76. He died of complications resulting from Parkinson's disease at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. Prendergast led the New York delegation at the Democratic national conventions that chose Adlai Stevenson and John F. Kennedy as presidential nominees. He served as state chairman from 1955 until 1962, when he was ousted for not supporting New York Mayor Robert F. Wagner in a re-election bid. He left national politics after Kennedy's election, forming a public relations firm. He was appointed to the New York State Commission on Cable Television in 1972 and retired in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Soap Actress Allegedly Used Stolen Credit Card
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf to include time element.
DOC.TEXT: An actress on the TV soap opera ``All My Children'' was arrested for allegedly using a stolen credit card, police said. The 20-year-old actress, Tichina Arnold, plays the character Sharla Valentine on the ABC show. Arnold was arrested Tuesday night at an A&S department store in the New York City borough of Queens after she charged perfume, cosmetics and a typewriter to a stolen American Express card, authorities said. She told police she paid a stranger $25 for the card, said Richard Piperno, spokesman for Queens District Attorney John Santucci. According to the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, a contract star like Arnold would make at least $525 an episode. A spokeswoman for the show was surprised to hear of Arnold's arrest. ``How strange. My goodness.
