I'm shocked,'' spokeswoman Alice Serrano told the New York Post. ``She's a lovely young girl, very articulate and very talented. I don't know anything about this.'' Arnold's number was not listed in the telephone book and she could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Opposition Groups Demand Provisional Legislature
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single names for some officials are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's new, vocal opposition groups demanded today that the Communist government set up a provisional legislature with equal representation from all parties to oversee democratic elections. In several letters to the legislature, the Great People's Hural, oppostion parties also demanded the government shut down the Marda uranium mine, but Energy Minister Batkhuyag reported it had already been closed. The mine in Eastern Mongolia produced 100,000 tons of uranium last year for export to the Soviet Union, Batkhuyag said. Numerous newspaper articles recently have clamored for it to shut down. Mongolia's only functioning Buddhist monastery, meanwhile, petitioned the Great People's Hural to abolish government control on religion. The demands were the latest by pro-democracy groups that sprang up four months ago, modeling themselves after similar movements in the Soviet bloc. Mongolia, sandwiched between the Soviet Union and China, has been a Soviet satellite since 1921 and allows Red Army soldiers to be based on its soil. The letters from Gandan monastery and the opposotion parties were read to the Hural by J. Gurragchaa, a deputy who became Mongolia's first cosmonaut when he served as a crew member in a Soviet space mission in 1981. Opposition groups were allowed to send observers to the annual Hural session for the first time ever, but they were not allowed to speak. The Mongolian Democratic Association and its affiliate, the Mongolian Democratic Party, are seeking legal guarantees that the Communist Party won't end the country's latest political thaw. They are also demanding legalization of opposition parties and a provisional legislature. The Mongolian Democratic Association has suggested several formulas for setting up such a legislature with the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party holding at most one-third of the seats. Currently, the comunists account for 93 percent of the Hural's 370 deputies. ``The main thing is for us to have our own vote there, but we have little hope,'' Galsandorg, a lawyer and association member, said earlier in the week. Several Hural deputies expressed concern in speeches today about the proliferation of opposition groups and called for a law to regulate them. ``I think Mongolia doesn't need so many meetings and political forces,'' said Batzul, an elderly delegate from Western Mongolia. ``They press the (Communist) party and government and demand things, and if these demands are not met they organize demonstrations and hunger strikes. I am against that,'' said a woman delegate, who won warm applause. ``Even families have leaders, and we must, too,'' she said. A military dlegate who spoke Wednesday nght also suggested laws to regulate demonstrations and set conditions for imposing a state of emergency. Another delegate, Zayat, said demonstrations have occurred in rural areas as well as Ulan Bator, but gave no details. The opposition groups, especially the Mongolian Democratic Association, say thay have set up branches nationwide, although their bases are in the capital. The ruling party has replaced its top leadership and the Hural elected a new president and prime minister on Wednesday as steps toward reform. But opposition groups say more than personnel changes are needed. The letter from Gandan monastery in Ulan Bator was the first time Mongolia's tiny but influentual community of monks had called for religious freedom. A few monks have joined opposition ralies and they held a joint rally with the Mongolian Democratic Association on March 11 at a former temple to demand its reopening. But so far, they have moved cautiously in asserting a political role. Historically, Buddhist monks held great wealth and power in Mongolia, but in the 1930s and 40s the Communists shut down Mongolia's more than 700 monasteries and forced the monks, who accounted for nearly half the male population, to take secular jobs. Gandan was allowed to reopen in 1944, but its fewer than 160 monks are not allowed to preach outaside monastery grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Dumps Ms. Maples, Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, the alleged other woman in the ballyhooed breakup last month of Donald and Ivana Trump, has been given the billionaire brush-off, according to a published report. Trump told Ms. Maples in a brief phone call Monday that it was over, according to today's editions of the New York Post. The paper said it got the information from ``a reliable source.'' The source said Ms. Maples was ``totally'' devastated, sobbing and begging the real estate tycoon not to abandon her, the newspaper said. The Daily News reported that Trump told friends last week, ``She's on her own'' and that he didn't leave his wife to be tied down, the paper said. ``What relationship between me and Marla? The fact that someone happens to like me, that's her problem,'' the News quotes Trump as saying to friends. The Post said Trump changed his private number so Ms. Maples can no longer ring him at home, the Post said. Trump's spokesman did not comment on the reported breakup of the alleged affair. A spokesman for Ms. Maples said there has been no change in the relationship, which he said was never more than a friendship. ``He has not cut off communication,'' said Chuck Jones, the spokesman. ``Some people are going to have egg on their face if they say that.'' Jones said Ms. Maples, an actress and model, has turned down offers of up to $1 million from magazines to tell her story.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Seriously Wound Presidential Candidate in Colombia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Jaramillo in serious condition, background on Galan assassination. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Attackers shot and seriously wounded a leftist presidential candidate today at Bogota's international airport. It was the second attack on a presidential candidate in seven months. Bernardo Jaramillo, candidate of the Patriotic Union, was shot by two gunmen and rushed to a nearby clinic to undergo surgery, party President Diego Montana told Caracol radio network. A spokeswoman at the clinic told Caracol that Jaramillo was in serious condition, shot twice in the throat and twice in the abdomen. Montana said one of Jaramillo's assailants was shot and killed by bodyguards, but Caracol said that the man, identified as Jairo Restrepo, 21, was only wounded. Police were searching for the other gunman, Caracol said. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the shooting. However, the Patriotic Union has been targeted by Colombian right-wing death squads. Since the party's founding in 1984, 1,044 of its members have been assassinated. Drug traffickers were blamed for the August slaying of leading presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan of the governing Liberal Party. The shooting prompted President Emilio Barco to launch a crackdown on drug lords. The presidential election is May 26.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Ready to Talk But Set Condition
DOC.TEXT: The political party that finished second in East Germany's first free election said today it is ready to begin talks with the winning conservatives on building a broad coalition government. But the party, the Social Democrats, set an important condition that could hinder the negotiations. Meanwhile, the winners of Sunday's parliamentary election, the conservative Alliance for Germany led by the Christian Democrats, said that it would carry out its campaign pledge and forge ahead with quick reunification. The statement by the Social Democrats excluded any cooperation with the German Social Union, the most right-wing of the three parties in the Alliance for Germany, which also includes the Democratic Awakening. A two-thirds majority in the new 400-seat Parliament is needed to approve unification with West Germany, and the conservative alliance needs the votes of the Social Democrats to assure passage. The Communists, who ruled the country for more than 40 years, finished third in the balloting. Richard Schroeder, Social Democratic member of Parliament, read a statement to reporters saying his party decided on the move to negotiate ``in view of the serious problems of our country.'' The party earlier this week rejected an offer by the conservative alliance to form a governing coalition. No date was set for the start of the talks, which the Social Democrats described as preliminary discussions to find out whether there is enough common ground with the Christian Democrats to enter formal coalition talks. A Christian Democratic spokesman quoted by the government-run ADN news agency welcomed the decision. In Bonn today, leaders of the Alliance for Germany said the three conservative parties will work closely in Parliament but would not build a common bloc of deputies. This was seen as a formula that could leave the door open for the Social Democrats to join in a coalition without formally having to cooperate with the German Social Union. Lothar de Maiziere, head of East Germany's Christian Democrats, met late Wednesday in Bonn with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. Kohl backs the alliance and campaigned vigorously on its behalf. De Maiziere denied allegations he collaborated with the Communist secret police that was disbanded after the hard-line Communist government of Erich Honecker was ousted in October amid massive demonstrations. Concern is growing over whether the new, freely elected Parliament is riddled with members who once cooperated with the hated Stasi secret police. The West German newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung said today that pro-democracy groups received an anonymous tip in January that de Maiziere had collaborated with the secret police. The Christian Democratic Union had been a puppet party maintained by the ousted Communist government, but it worked to establish its independence after the peaceful revolution late last year. De Maiziere became its leader after the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino General Claims U.S. Agency Supported Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd, ``In his...'' to ADD background on Defense Intelligence Agency. Pickup 4th graf pvs: ``Galido said...'' ^By ROBERT H. REID
DOC.TEXT: A Filipino military general claims the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency supported a coup attempt in December that was put down with the help of American jets. The U.S. Embassy today denied the allegation, made by Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido in a sworn statement released Wednesday by the Department of Justice. In his statement, Galido said an American who claimed to be an Air Force colonel and the representative of the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency in the Philippines told him in July that his agency ``favors the overthrow of the Aquino government and the return of the Marcoses to the Philippines.'' The Defense Intelligence Agency is an information gathering division of the U.S. Department of Defense and Joint Chiefs of Staff. Galido said the American, Harold Magleo, promised ``to deliver ... shipments of firearms, ammunition, anti-tank missiles'' and other weapons for the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt ``provided Marcos or the loyalist group will give them $20 million for their group to produce these war materials.'' He also said U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt held a party at his home in August during which conspirators received written instructions from Filipino Brig. Gen. Edgardo Abenina, who was held at a military camp for involvement in a coup attempt in 1987. In its denial, the U.S. Embassy statement said there was no Col. Magleo on its staff. Galido, former military commander in southern Luzon, said he was aware of plans for the coup attempt, and he implicated numerous military officers and civilians in the plot. He said Abenina suggested assassinating President Corazon Aquino, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos and the military chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa. Abenina was arrested in January. ``The U.S. Embassy states categorically and absolutely that press stories suggesting the U.S. government's involvement in the December coup attempt are totally without foundation,'' said U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Victoria Middleton. ``Any allegation that Ambassador Platt was somehow involved in contacts with persons plotting against the government is totally false and without foundation,'' she said. Platt was out of the country and unavailable for comment. ``The United States demonstrated its support for President Aquino and Philippine democracy during the coup attempt. That support was absolutely firm then and continues to be firm today,'' Ms. Middleton said. She said the party at Platt's residence Aug. 16, 1989, was a ``normal diplomatic function'' and among those invited were Cabinet and military officials, including Galido. The latest coup attempt was launched shortly after midnight on Dec. 1, when thousands of mutineers attacked military and media facilities, seized aircraft at Villamor Air Base and staged air strikes on the presidential palace. U.S. F-4 Phantom jets from Clark Air Base flew air cover in support of government forces and prevented the mutineers from continuing their air strikes. At least 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured before rebels surrendered their last stronghold Dec. 9. Mrs. Aquino's spokesman, Adolfo Azcuna, said the government would not comment on Galido's statement until a presidential commission established to investigate the coup attempt submits its final report. De Villa told reporters today the filing of the charges against the alleged conspirators ``will eventually determine'' whether Galido's report is credible. Asked why the government and the military, if previously warned of the coup plot, appeared to have been caught off guard when the mutineers struck, de Villa said: ``We did not know the time.'' He said the Galido's statement of U.S. involvement is ``an allegation that has to be looked into,'' and which the military is ``certainly'' investigating. ``There are many Americans here in the Philippines,'' de Villa said. ``There are Americans who come and go.'' Defense Undersecretary Leonardo Quisumbing said other military officers gave statements that supported Galido's allegations. ``I am saying that we have witnesses, including officers, to that effect,'' Quisumbing said. ``Well, in effect that there were others involved. As it is now coming out in the sworn statement, they involve some foreigners.'' Quisumbing noted that Galido ``did not involve the entire U.S. government,'' only the Defense Intelligence Agency and a certain American officer.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Slaying Similar to Boston's Stuart Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `Police now...', to CORRECT that Stuart weapon thrown into a river, not the harbor.
DOC.TEXT: When Charles Stuart's claim that a black man killed his wife and wounded him as they sat in their car in Boston turned out to be an apparent hoax, it sounded familiar in the Atlanta suburb of Marietta. Police here, too, were in the midst of a case of murder pinned on a black _ and non-existent _ scapegoat. Neva Veitch told police two black men abducted her and her husband, Bobby Joe Veitch, from a motel bar the night of Nov. 20, 1987, shot her husband to death and attacked her. Police made composite drawings of the alleged killers and interviewed more than 20 suspects. But authorities made no arrests and declared the case inactive. Then, in November, David Lee Craig, leader of a Ku Klux Klan splinter group, walked into the police station and said Mrs. Veitch, his mistress at the time of the slaying, was the true culprit. But when Craig taped telephone calls to her for police, she implicated him, his lawyer says, and a grand jury indicted both of them on murder charges. Testimony in Craig's trial began Wednesday in Cobb County Superior Court and is expected to last through the week. Mrs. Veitch's trial will come later. In Boston, police apparently had accepted at face value the story Stuart called in on his car phone on Oct. 23: that he and his pregnant wife had been shot by a black man who jumped in their car and robbed them after they left a birthing class. Police reportedly closed in on a black man, William Bennett, as the lead suspect until Jan. 3, when Stuart's brother, Matthew, told police Charles had plotted to kill his wife, collect insurance and blame the killing on blacks. The next day, Charles Stuart jumped to his death from a bridge. Police now speculate that Stuart shot himself and his wife and that his brother took the gun and threw it into a river, where it was recovered. The brother, who has not been charged, said he went to police because he feared Bennett would go to jail. ``Both the Boston and Atlanta cases played on racial stereotypes,'' says Derrick Bell, a Harvard University law professor. ``We cannot ignore the fact there is a lot of black crime in cities like Atlanta. What (their story) did was play on that fear of black crime.'' Robert Friedmann, criminal justice professor at Georgia State University, said Craig and Mrs. Veitch ``knew the media and the public are fascinated with a fear of crime, particularly black-on-white crime.'' District Attorney Thomas Charron accused Craig and Mrs. Veitch of ``preying on prejudice.'' He acknowledged similarities with the Stuart case. Charron called the Veitch case ``a classic love triangle'' _ Billy Veitch a truck driver and often away from home, Craig and Mrs. Veitch falling in love through his Klan splinter group. Craig was imperial wizard of the True Knights of the Ku Klux Klan; she was the group's secretary-treasurer. ``David and Neva were in love and they agreed that Billy Veitch had to be killed,'' Charron told the jury in Craig's trial. Mrs. Veitch initially told police she and her husband were abducted at a motel bar at gunpoint by two blacks and taken to an isolated warehouse district, where the two told her they were going to rape her and make her husband watch. She said her husband lunged at them, and she closed her eyes and heard three shots. Her husband lay on the ground, bleeding from back wounds. After that, she said, they drove her away, beating her with a flashlight. She said one of them sodomized her before she escaped, ran to an all-night diner and called police, who found her beaten and bloodied. In November, however, Craig told Cobb County Police investigators there had been no black men. Mrs. Veitch, he said, was the killer, and he offered to help prove it. But Mrs. Veitch implicated Craig in taped telephone conversations, said Craig's court-appointed defense lawyer, Ronnie Knighton. Knighton denied that his client had anything to do with the killing. He said she had asked Craig on previous occasions to kill her husband but he refused. Knighton claimed Mrs. Veitch rejected the idea of getting a divorce to marry Craig because she wanted her husband's insurance money. Craig, who also was married, left his family and moved in with Mrs. Veitch soon after the killing. He said he went to police because she had a new boyfriend and he feared for his own life. He said he had been shot at twice. Mrs. Veitch's attorney has asked that she be tested to determine if she is mentally competent to stand trial and has indicated he may use an insanity defense, the Journal and Constitution of Atlanta reported Sunday. The paper did not name the attorney.

DOC.HEAD: German Businessman Charged With Helping Build Libyan Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with businessman charged with helping build the Libyan plant. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A West German businessman was charged today with helping to build a plant in Libya that was suspected of producing chemical weapons before it was damaged in a fire earlier this month. The indictment against Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, former head of the Imhausen-Chemie chemical company, charged him with violating West Germany's export laws and tax evasion. Also today, a West German official said Libya cut off trade with West Germany after accusing it of setting fire to the chemical plant. West Germany made a formal protest today to the Tripoli government, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Prosecutor Peter Wechsung charged that Hippenstiel-Inhausen played a ``decisive role'' in the planning and construction of the chemical complex in Rabta, Libya, 60 miles southwest of Tripoli. Wechsung said Hippenstiel-Inhausen shipped to Libya ``documents on production'' as well as ``measuring and regulating instruments'' to be used by the chemical complex. He said investigators had concluded that the Libyan plant was ``solely intended'' for the production of poison gases. Wechsung also disclosed that West Germany's federal police had created a special ``Rabta'' unit consisting of 20 officials who took part in the investigation. Speaking to reporters in Mannheim, Wechsung said about 3,000 files containing documents, plans and other material had been confiscated in the investigation and that statements were taken from more than 200 witnesses. Wechsung did not say whether other arrests were expected. Hippenstiel-Imhausen stepped down as head of the company in March and was arrested on Oct. 5. A number of West German companies were raided a little more than a year ago after U.S. charges that German firms had helped build the plant. However, only Hippenstiel-Imhausen has been arrested. Relations between Bonn and Tripoli have badly soured since Libya alleged that West Germany and the United States had a hand in the March 14 fire at the Rabta plant, which U.S. officials charge produced poison gas. Washington and Bonn have denied Libya's allegations, and Libya says the plant produces pharmaceuticals. Before the fire, West Germany had launched an international initiative to find a way to keep the plant from producing chemical weapons. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German foreign minister, had proposed putting together an international team to inspect the plant. The Bonn government official said Libya barred a ship carrying Libyan oil to proceed to its destination in West Germany and stopped payments to West German companies doing business in the North African nation. ``I don't know the amount of money involved,'' said the official, who gave no further details. On Tuesday, West German Ambassador Joerg Helmer went to the Libyan Foreign Office in Tripoli ``to express our displeasure'' with the Libyan actions regarding trade, said the Bonn government official. The Frankfurter Rundschau newspaper, quoting government officials, reported Libya has ``blocked trade with the West Germany since last week.'' West Germany is one of Libya's major trading partners. Libyan exports to West Germany last year amounted to $1.85 billion, most of it oil. West German exports to Libya last year were valued at $780 million. West German government officials say it appears Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has decided to single out West Germany because of Bonn's public pronouncements against the plant in Rabta, and Genscher's international initiative aimed at keeping the factory from making poison gas. The Rabta plant caused a scandal in West Germany a little more than a year ago, after the United States alleged German firms helped build it. West Germany at first denied the U.S. claims, but later acknowledged them and launched its own investigations. The main company under investigation is Imhausen-Chemie of the southern West German town of Lahr. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen stepped down as head of the company last March and was arrested on Oct. 5. He remains in investigative custody. Since the scandal, West Germany has taken steps to crack down on companies or individuals that violate export regulations, and beefed up its export laws.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Experts Say Much Was Learned From Alaska Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with reports.
DOC.TEXT: One year after the nation's worst oil spill hit Alaskan waters, many U.S. coastal areas face similar threats and need tighter standards for tankers, pilots and tug escorts, two environmental groups said today. The Natural Resources Defense Council and the Center for Marine Conservation said in independently prepared reports that there are many measures not now employed that would help prevent such disasters. ``We have the know-how to prevent accidents before they happen, especially in our most sensitive waters,'' said Roger McManus, president of the Center for Marine Conservation. The studies were undertaken after the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground and spewed more than 11 million gallons of toxic crude oil into Prince William Sound one year ago Saturday. The Natural Resources Defense Council analyzed three of the nation's busiest ports _ San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles _ each of which handles at least 1,000 tanker visits each year. Among the principal recommendations in the two reports are: _ Requiring oil tankers and barges to have double hulls and double bottoms. _ Requiring tug escorts for tankers in difficult waters and biologically sensitive areas. _ Establishing tanker-free zones in environmentally vulnerable areas. _ Requiring licensed pilots for all tankers and barges over a minimum size within harbors. The groups also recommended that the federal government take responsibility immediately for cleanup of major spills and that contingency plans be drawn up to prepare for the worst spill that could happen. ``To date Exxon has spent more than $2 billion when a fraction of that would have prevented not only the disaster at Prince William Sound, but the succeeding spills and groundings in New York, the Florida Keys, Houston, and California's Huntington Beach,'' McManus said. The Center for Marine Conservation report urged that the Coast Guard control traffic within 15 miles of the Florida Keys, where a series of vessel groundings late last year extensively damaged coral reefs. It said tankers should avoid certain areas along the California coast to protect sensitive wildlife and ecosystems, such as sea birds, kelp beds, sea otters and other marine mammals. In a news conference on Wednesday, wildlife experts said they learned much after the Alaska spill, but still don't have the facilities they will need when more such spills occur. ``If there is an oil spill tomorrow, we really aren't that much further ahead in advanced planning than we were a year ago,'' said Randall Davis, co-director of International Wildlife Research in San Diego. ``Certainly it will happen again in some form,'' said Jay Holcomb, director of the International Bird Rescue Research Center in Berkeley, Calif. ``Oil spills never seem to stop.'' Davis was in charge of efforts to rescue sea otters and other marine mammals after the Exxon Valdez spill a year ago Saturday and Holcomb led the effort to rescue birds. They appeared together at a luncheon Wednesday at which the Izaak Walton League of America, one of the nation's oldest conservation groups, presented an award to Procter & Gamble for the company's support of the wildlife rescue efforts. ``I never want to experience what I saw when we first took our boats out in Alaska, to find birds in a foot deep of oil with their heads sticking out, yelling, and otters crying on the rocks because they were covered in oil and were already suffering from the ingestion problems,'' Holcomb said. Davis said, ``Even today we really don't have any permanent facility nor any permanent organization to respond to another oil spill if it should occur, with regards to treating marine mammals.'' Both said they learned valuable lessons from the Alaska experience, however. ``We had never been able to work with some of the species, such as the horned and tufted puffins, beautiful yet nasty birds,'' Holcomb said. ``We handled 200 or 300 and released quite a few. We learned some new techniques.'' Davis said the Alaska accident was ``the first spill to ever involve large numbers of marine mammals and sea otters in particular. We learned a tremendous amount working on that spill.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Coax Bamboo To Flower In Lab, A First
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to delete redundancy.
DOC.TEXT: A team of Indian scientists has induced bamboo plants to flower in the laboratory, a first for one of the world's most important timber and fodder crops. The breakthrough promises to pave the way for improved breeding of bamboo stock and provide a perennial source of bamboo seed, according to an article published today in the journal Nature. ``It's a breakthrough that could have real significance for a quarter of the world's population,'' David Hanke, a Cambridge University botanist, told The New York Times. Throughout the tropics, bamboo is a vital source of lightweight, rot-resistant wood for houses and furniture. It even provides scaffolding used in building skyscrapers and supertankers. Domestic uses include tools, baskets, musical instruments and pulp for paper. Bamboo hay has up to four times the protein of other fodder grasses, and is a staple for livestock. The versatile plant's reproductive quirks make it a difficult plant to grow and harvest. Most of the over 500 species of bamboo flower only once in their lifetimes, between the ages of 12 to 120 years. A bamboo thicket flowers simultaneously _ and then dies, leaving behind a thick carpet of seeds. To insure a dependable supply of seeds, A.F. Mascarenhas and two colleagues at the National Chemical Laboratory in Pune, India, suspended tiny cuttings of bamboo in a test tube cocktail of coconut milk, plant growth hormones and other nutrients. After two more applications of the cocktail and a few weeks, adult-size flowers began blooming. The researchers have yet to plant the seeds, but expect them to be viable.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Challenges Bhutto, Boycotts Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Opposition politicans boycotted the opening session of the federal legislature today, charging that a legal technicality had ended Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's term in office. Members of Ms. Bhutto's party said the opposition would have to go to court to try to unseat her. Only eight lawmakers took their seats on the opposition bench and demanded that Ms. Bhutto face re-election among the members of the National Assembly, the lower lawmaking house of Pakistan's Parliament. ``We regret we cannot participate (in this session),'' said Abida Hussein, an influential member of the 16 mainly right-wing parties that make up the alliance known as the Combined Opposition Parties. The opposition's demand centers around a clause in Pakistan's Constitution that empowered the president to appoint the prime minister. That clause expired Tuesday, and opposition leaders contend Ms. Bhutto must be re-elected by secret ballot in the 237-member assembly. Ms. Bhutto so far has ignored the demand. Newspaper reports had speculated she might call for a vote of confidence in her 16-month-old government when the assembly convened. But Tariq Rahim, the parliamentary affairs minister, dismissed the suggestion and called the boycott ``totally unjustified.'' ``This parliament was eleced for five years and God willing this Parliament will complete its tenure,'' Rahim said in a stern response. ``If you have any questions about the constitution, go to court.'' The prime minister listened to the arguments from the house leader's chair at the front of the dark wood chamber but made no comment. Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party controls about 111 seats in the National Assembly but rules mainly with the help of smaller parties and independents. The combined opposition parties have 86 seats. Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning government has been buffetted by charges of corruption and inaction on a host of social and economic problems that grew under a decade of martial law. She narrowly survived a no-confidence vote put forward in November by the opposition. But supporters say her troubles with the Islamic and nationalist opposition parties are behind her, pointing to a show-of-strength rally Tuesday in the eastern city of Lahore, the heartland of the opposition. Others contend Ms. Bhutto only looks stronger because the opposition is divided and weaker. The 36-year-old prime minister was appointed to a five-year term by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan after her party captured the most seats in the November 1988 parliamentary elections. But the president's constitutional authority to appoint Pakistan's prime minister expired Tuesday, and opposition politicians have been arguing for months that Ms. Bhutto must be re-elected by a secret National Assembly ballot. ``We believe she is no longer the prime minister. She has no power to convene the house so any session would be illegal,'' said Shaukat Abassi, spokesman for the Combined Opposition Parties. Opposition leaders claimed Ms. Bhutto convened the assembly to deliberately spoil preparations for their show-of-strength rally on Friday in Lahore.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Philippine Government Turning Americans Against Mrs. Marcos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `More jury ...' with one graf to UPDATE with jury selection resuming today.
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for Imelda Marcos said the Philippine government is trying to turn Americans against his client, who is being tried on fraud charges involving $325 million. The lawyer, Gerry Spence, gave the judge on Wednesday what he said were documents describing Philippine government lobbyists' efforts ``to instill bias and prejudice'' in this country against the former Philippine first lady. Judge John F. Keenan said he would examine the papers but expressed doubt about their relevance to the trial. Twenty-one prospective jurors were selected Wednesday for the trial of Mrs. Marcos and Saudi Arabian financier Adnan M. Khashoggi, who is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice. The Philippine government, through a New York public relations firm, released on Wednesday the text of a letter from Mrs. Marcos to President Bush, sent March 5. The letter asked for Bush's help to assure that money and property that she said her late husband intended for the Filipino people be turned over to an independent five-member commission. ``Your government has publicly lamented the gross corruption, the widespread irresponsibility and fragile hold on power of the Aquino government,'' Mrs. Marcos wrote. ``Therefore you must understand my own apprehension over any agreement by which this property would be given over to the possession of that government since the likelihood of it ever reaching our people is little or nothing.'' Mrs. Marcos also asked that Bush help arrange for her husband's body to be returned home. Copies of the letter also went to former President Reagan and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The White House said Tuesday that Bush would not respond to the letter during the trial. Keenan resumed his screening of jurors today. The judge has said he expects the preliminary winnowing of prospective jurors to take about a week. The 54-year-old Khashoggi, once described as the world's richest man, is accused of helping the late Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife conceal a series of New York real estate deals allegedly financed in part with money stolen from the country's treasury. Mrs. Marcos, 60, has denied that she took part in an illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Manila government and the defrauding of banking institutions of another $165 million. Marcos also was named in the original October 1988 indictment but died in Hawaii on Sept. 28. Khashoggi said Wednesday that the jury selection process gives him a chance to meet ordinary citizens. ``I think it is a good way to get to know the American people,'' Khashoggi said during a break at U.S. District Court.

DOC.HEAD: World Chess Champ Takes On New York's Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Top chess master Gary Kasparov gamely pretended to play a match with the mayor to promote the return of World Championship Chess to the city for the first time since the turn of the century. The first 12 games of the tournament will be played here beginning Oct. 7. In the mock match Wednesday, Mayor David Dinkins took his time before moving a pawn, and then placed it in jeopardy. ``I never make decisions quickly,'' Dinkins said, in a joking reference to criticisms that he has been slow to fill key posts. Bob Burkett, senior vice president for Interscope, an organizer of the event, said at the City Hall news conference the games will open with a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel. The early matches will be played at the new Mackelow Center in Times Square. The remaining games will be played in Lyons, France. The winner gets nearly $1.9 million of a $3 million pot; the loser gets the rest.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: List Says He's Innocent by Reason of Mental Defect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: L'E. in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: An accountant accused of killing his mother, wife and three children 18 years ago says he is innocent because of a mental defect, the judge in the man's trial said. Jury selection was completed Wednesday evening after John E. List's attorney, Elijah L. Miller, exhausted the 20 challenges he can use to remove potential jurors. Superior Court Judge L'E. Wertheimer refused to grant him additional challenges. ``Mr. List denies he is guilty of murder,'' Wertheimer told a panel of potential jurors. ``He says, as a result of a mental disease or defect, he committed (the crime).'' Miller hinted at such a defense Tuesday when he asked a prospective juror if he could still follow the judge's instructions to be impartial if, ``for instance,'' List acted out of ``insanity or a mental defect.'' When asked what List's defense would be, Miller replied: ``What the judge said.'' Miller is expected to appeal Wertheimer's rejection of his juror challenges and the selection of some jurors, claiming that they are biased. None of the 16 jurors live in Westfield, where the slayings took place. Some have said they read or heard about the murders. All told Wertheimer they had no opinion regarding List's innocence or guilt. More than 130 Union County residents were interviewed since jury selection began Tuesday. The trial is scheduled to begin March 30, after a week of pre-trial hearings. List, 64, is accused of killing his mother, wife and three children in their Westfield mansion in November 1971. Authorities said the former accountant spent most the last 18 years in Denver, where he remarried. He was arrested by the FBI on June 1, shortly after moving to a suburb of Richmond, Va. His case also was featured on a nationally televised anti-crime program.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Turner Stars in a Revival of `Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, ``Big Daddy ...'' to CORRECT spelling of lascivious. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Yes, Kathleen Turner is a tough, sexy and even funny Maggie in the respectable, occasionally riveting, revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' that opened Wednesday at Broadway's Eugene O'Neill Theater. But the heart of Tennessee Williams' Southern-fried Gothic melodrama belongs to Big Daddy, the dying patriarch of ``28,000 acres of the richest land this side of the valley Nile.'' Big Daddy is an amazing role, maybe the best Williams ever wrote. The character contains all the colorful peculiarities that people, mostly Yankees, love to associate with the South. Yet he's more than a brutal, money-grubbing, lascivious mountain of a man. Played with remarkable control by Charles Durning, Big Daddy is a seeker of truth, and truth is what ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is all about. Everybody else in the play, including Maggie, is afraid of it. The truth has kept Maggie and her alcoholic husband, Brick, apart. Brick, Big Daddy's favorite son, is an aging golden boy whose luster has begun to tarnish. He drinks his days away, hoping to hear ``the click'' that will help him forget a promising football career and the relationship he had with Skipper, his now-dead best friend. The truth is what everyone is trying to hide from Big Daddy who has been told his stomach troubles are nothing more than a spastic colon. But reality is revealed in a long second act confrontation between Brick and Big Daddy. The father forces his son to look into the past and the son inadvertently tells the father about the future. It's a powerful moment, particularly as played by Durning and Daniel Hugh Kelly as the doomed Brick. Brick is something of a cipher, a difficult character to get a handle on, but Kelly manages to make him a sympathetic person. That's no mean feat. And Durning is at his best, alternatively flamboyant and ultimately sensitive to his son's problem. It's a remarkable juggling act. Turner controls the play's first and third acts. The woman is a star, and it's not easy to take your eyes off her as she sashays around the stage, particularly in designer Patricia Zipprodt's lavender lace slip. There's an intelligence and a steely determination to her portrayal of Maggie, particularly when she is defending her own interests. You can see the combative character plot her attack, trying to stop brother-in-law Gooper and his wife, Mae, from getting control of Big Daddy's will. Director Howard Davies' approach to the play is traditional, nothing as startling or eccentric as Sir Peter Hall's distinctive examination of Williams' ``Orpheus Descending'' early in the season. There are no surprises or revelations but then nothing goes wrong either. Polly Holliday as Big Mama starts in high screech but gradually calms down so that by the time the play ends she has become a woman of strength. Kevin O'Rourke and Debra Jo Rupp teeter on caricature as Maggie's greedy family opponents but pull back before turning into cartoons. And their gaggle of children, those celebrated ``no-neck monsters,'' are appropriately _ and hilariously _ repulsive. ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' was Williams' personal favorite among his own works. He loved the play's unity. Its action over the three long acts is continuous. He loved its impeccable construction. And he loved those characters, particularly Big Daddy. ``I reached beyond myself, in the second act, to a kind of crude eloquence of expression in Big Daddy that I have managed to give no other character of my creation,'' Williams says in his ``Memoirs.'' Watching Durning on stage, you can perfectly understand that statement.

What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: It takes nothing away from Kathleen Turner's radiant Maggie in ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' to say that Broadway's gripping new production of Tennessee Williams' 1955 play will be most remembered for Charles Durning's Big Daddy. Howard Kissel, Daily News: We find ourselves seeing the play clearly but dispassionately. Detachment is not what Williams had in mind. Clive Barnes, New York Post: Turner, mocking yet fearful, sassily funny yet itchy with desires that go beyond sex, and the all but innocent victim of a family in perpetual and hateful crisis, is giving a performance to cherish, in a play to revalue.

DOC.HEAD: Despondent Mother Shoots Sleeping Children, Self
DOC.TEXT: A woman apparently despondent over marital and financial troubles shot her three sleeping children to death, then killed herself after scrawling ``God please forgive me'' in crayon on a wall, police said. The bodies were found Wednesday by a friend of two of the children, who said she entered their house by squeezing through a pet door when she saw through a window that messages had been written on the dining room wall. ``The family had been having some financial and personal problems of late, and that appears to be the motive,'' Detective Rick Swanston said. The detective identified the victims as Roxanne Fernandez Jones, 32, and her children, Brandy Fernandez, 16, Leticia Fernandez, 13, and Jeremiah Jones, 7. Also dead was the family dog, Wolf. Detectives found a .22-caliber rifle and a lengthy suicide note from Mrs. Jones, Lt. William Gaida said. ``She wrote a several-page suicide note asking for her loved ones to forgive her,'' he said. ``The note basically had stuff like, `God forgive me' and things of that nature.'' Crystal Erickson, 15, a friend of the sisters, found the bodies in the Reseda home about 20 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles. She said when she got inside the house she found the words ``God please forgive me'' and ``My loved ones please forgive me'' written on a wall. On the table was a suicide note that read in part: ``If we're not dead don't call the paramedics,'' she said. It also said Mrs. Jones loved her children and hated to put them through living in a world full of strife, the girl said. The sisters' bodies were found in their bedrooms. The bodies of the mother and boy were in the master bedroom, Gaida said. Each child had been shot in the chest and in the head, he said. Neighbors said Mrs. Jones had separated four months ago from her second husband and had been unable to find steady work. The mother baby-sat and worked several odd jobs, including distributing flyers for a pizzeria where one her daughters worked until getting laid off a week ago, said Derek Shelton, Brandy Fernandez's boyfriend. ``I can't believe she did this,'' said Joyce Pacheco, who lives around the corner. ``Roxanne never seemed depressed about anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Reward Offer, Composite Drawings Boost Pace of Tips in Museum Theft
With PM-Art
DOC.TEXT: The FBI issued composite drawings of the two thieves who pulled off one of the biggest art thefts of the century, and the number of tips coming from the public has stepped up, an official said today. Clad in police uniforms, the pair talked their way into the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum early Sunday, then overpowered the two guards on duty and took 11 paintings, drawings and prints by such artists as Rembrandt and Degas. They also swiped an ancient Chinese vase and a gilded eagle from the flagpole of a Napoleonic flag. Lyle Grindle, director of museum security, said this morning that since the composites went out Wednesday afternoon, the pace of calls from tipsters seemed to have increased. A $1 million reward has been offered for information for the return of the pictures. ``We're getting information,'' he said. ``We're getting lots of calls, from all aspects.'' Even before the $1 million reward was posted and the pictures were issued, tipsters began calling the Gardner Museum and the FBI, hinting they knew where the artworks could be found, officials said Wednesday. At the same time, with two of the museum's looted rooms now behind police barricades, the public was allowed inside Wednesday for the first time since the crime. Considered too well-known to be sold on the open market, the five paintings and other works from Mrs. Gardner's collection has been estimated to be worth in the hundreds of millions of dollars. The international auction houses Sotheby's and Christie's are underwriting the $1 million reward, offered with no questions asked, for safe return of the works. ``You're generally talking about thieves that are going to be in contact with others in criminal circles and that's where it (tipsters' information) generally comes from,'' said FBI agent Dennis O'Callaghan. While he would not comment on whether staff at the museum had been given lie detector tests, he said former employees were being questioned, a standard practice in such cases. The thieves took two paintings and an etching by Rembrandt, three prints and two charcoals by Edgar Degas; one painting each by Edouard Manet, Jan Vermeer and Govaert Flinck, and a bronze beaker dating from the Chinese Shang Dynasty, 1,200-1,100 B.C. The museum discovered Tuesday that a gilded eagle atop a Napoleonic flag was also stolen. The composites showed two white men in policemen's hats. One was depicted with gold wire-rimmed glasses, a strong jaw, dark hair and eyes and was described as being in his late 20s to early 30s, of medium build and 5-foot-7 to 5-foot-10. The other suspect, shown with pronounced cheekbones and dark hair and eyes, was thought to be in his early to middle 30s, 180 pounds and 6-feet or 6-foot-1. The composites showed the suspects both with mustaches and without because authorities believe they might have worn fake mustaches during the robbery.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Watching Reagan Videotape
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs with Reagan videotape nearing conclusion; picks up 2nd graf, When he ...; deletes last 9 grafs to tighten
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Jurors at John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial watched the last of President Reagan's videotaped testimony today as the former president displayed annoyance at a prosecutor's question. The jurors watched closely, but didn't react when Reagan became visibly irritated at prosecutor Dan Webb, who said Reagan wasn't answering a question. Webb asked Reagan whether the presidentially appointed Tower Commission concluded Oliver North was assisting the Contras militarily. Webb objected when Reagan launched into a description of the commission and brought up diverting Iran arms sale money to the Contras. ``That answer ... is completely unresponsive. Completely,'' Webb told the judge. ``I don't think it is unresponsive to state what I appointed the commission to do,'' Reagan retorted. The playing of the videotape, which began Wednesday morning, was to conclude at midday today. Poindexter, Reagan's former national security adviser, is charged with five felony charges of conspiracy, making false statements and obstructing Congress in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. Meanwhile, Poindexter's lawyers say the jury should be told that North was called a liar by prosecutors at his own trial. When he testified at his own trial last year, North implicated a number of other Reagan administration figures, including Poindexter. ``Few criminal defendants have attempted to blame so many others for so many lawless acts,'' prosecutors told the judge in the North case last year. They said he committed ``perjury on the witness stand.'' At the Poindexter trial, however, North is the government's star witness, although a reluctant one, and prosecutors are placing great reliance on his testimony. ``Fundamental fairness requires'' that the jury be told what prosecutors ``previously has had to say about Lt. Col. North's credibility,'' Poindexter's lawyers said in court papers. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene has not indicated when he will rule on Poindexter's request to introduce the prosecutors' contention that North committed perjury. Poindexter's trial continues today with the jury scheduled to finish watching eight hours of videotaped testimony by former President Reagan. When North testified in Poindexter's trial, he said he could not recall details he provided at his own trial. Prosecutors responded by repeatedly referring the witness back to his damaging statements last year about Poindexter. ``It would be totally unfair to allow the prosecutor to argue that Lt. Col. North's testimony at his own trial was more believable than his testimony at this proceeding,'' the defense said in its court papers. In 1989, North testified in detail about Poindexter sending him to a meeting with congressmen, where North lied about his Contra-related activities. North denied that he was assisting the rebels militarily or raising money for them. ``I felt like a pawn in a chess game being played by giants,'' North testified. At Poindexter's trial, North's testimony on the meeting with congressmen was more equivocal and the former White House aide emphasized that nobody had told him to lie. Meanwhile, Poindexter lost a court fight Wednesday over Reagan's diaries as the defense began showing Reagan's videotaped testimony to the jury. Greene said Reagan does not have to produce diary entries sought by his one-time national security adviser. Poindexter said he needed the excerpts because Reagan, in his taped testimony, ``professed a total inability to recall'' the diversion of Iran arms sale proceeds to the Nicaraguan Contras and a 1985 Hawk missile shipment. Greene said the entries, which he has read, ``offer no new insights about these events.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today declined to criticize Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order that Lithuanians surrender arms and said there are ``certain realities'' that govern Moscow's control over the rebellious republic. ``I am convinced the answer is peaceful discussion between the parties...I believe they can talk and work out these problems,'' Bush said. The president, at an impromptu news confernce on the South Lawn, also prodded Congress to move more quickly on his proposal for $800 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua. Bush, noting that his request appeared to be bogged down in the Democratic-controlled Congress, appealed to lawmakers to give him the authority to decide how to pay for the program if they can't. He has said that he wants the money to come from Pentagon programs. Bush took questions from reporters after participating in a tree-planting ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Baker Tells South African Officials to Lift State Of Emergency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Baker meeting with de Klerk. Pickup 5th graf `Baker said...'
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today told South African officials they must end a nearly 4-year-old state of emergency before Washington lifts sanctions against the white-led government. Baker met with an African National Congress delegation, which criticized the first visit in 12 years by a U.S. secretary of state on the ground that it gives the government's reform program legitimacy that the black anti-apartheid group feels has not been earned. Despite protest by the ANC, Baker then met with President F.W. de Klerk, who said he did not consider Baker's visit a reward for recent reforms but ``proof of the interest which America has in this region.'' De Klerk said he and Baker discussed civil wars in neighboring Angola and Mozambique as well as developments inside South Africa, but not sanctions. Baker said de Klerk told him Pretoria wants to end the national state of emergency in effect since June 1986 and free political prisoners. After an earlier luncheon meeting with Foreign Minister Pik Botha, Baker said he discussed the emergency, noting that its lifting was one of the conditions set by the U.S. Congress for ending economic sanctions. Baker said the U.S. government hoped that the state of emergency would be ended ``at an appropriate time, consistent, of course, with the maintenance of law and order. ``We approve of the direction that the government has recently been moving in,'' Baker said. The Pretoria government last month released black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela after 27 years of imprisonment and legalized the ANC and other groups. The state of emergency, however, allows police to detain people indefinitely without trial, outlaw certain forms of protest and subject the news media to various restrictions. Botha said the South African government wants to end the state of emergency as soon as the level of political violence in the country is brought down. ``We don't want it,'' he said of the nearly 4-year-old state of emergency. ``It is bad for us, our name abroad, our reputation.'' Govan Mbeki, a member of the ANC's National Executive, said after his delegation's 90-minute meeting with Baker today: ``We are not happy with the fact that he has come here to consult with the South African government.'' Mbeki said the ANC wants a complete cut in diplomatic contacts with the South African government. Mandela on Wednesday asked Baker not to meet with de Klerk. The African National Congress deputy president said the meeting would send an inaccurate message that South Africa has made meaningful changes. The secretary met with Mandela in Namibia because Mandela refused to meet with him in South Africa. But Mbeki and two of Mandela's other co-defendants sentenced to life in prison with him met with Baker in Cape Town. And Walter Sisulu, the internal leader of the ANC in South Africa, planned to meet with Baker on Friday in Soweto, outside Johannesburg. Baker said the meeting today with 11 members of the African National Congress and its ally, the United Democratic Front, produced more agreement than disagreement. ``The fact is, we share the same goals,'' said Baker. Mbeki said, ``The United States is probably the most powerful country in the world and would necessarily have a great impact on happenings in South Africa, depending on how it uses that position of power.'' ``The American government and the American people should continue to impose pressures on the South African government and not relax at all until such time as the position will have to be made clear that the South African government has no way of going backwards,'' said Mbeki, who was freed in 1987 from a life prison term for planning the ANC's guerrilla-sabotage campaign. Sisulu and the other co-defendants were freed in October, and Mandela was freed in February after de Klerk legalized the ANC and 59 other organizations to encourage black leaders to negotiate with the government on a new constitution and an end to apartheid. Mandela will lead an ANC delegation in talks with de Klerk in Cape Town on April 11.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: White House
DOC.TEXT: Bush was asked about Gorbachev's order the day before requiring Lithuanian citizens to turn over their guns to Soviet authorities in seven days. He passed up an opportunity to criticize the order, and said he was certain neither side in the conflict wanted to see force used. Bush said he takes Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at his word in his assurances earlier this week that the Kremlin would not use force to block Lithuanian independence. ``We do not recognize the incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Uniin. However, there are certain realities in life. Lithuanians are well aware of them. And they should talk, as they are, to the Soviet officials, about these differences,'' Bush said. The administration has steadfastly underscored its position that the United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania and the other Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia. However, the United States has not extended formal diplomatic recognition to Lithuania in the aftermath of its March 11 declaration of independence. The president, at a wide-ranging news conference that lasted half an hour, also said he would like to see all Soviet troops removed from Poland. Bush said he will not go to Nicaragua on April 25 for the inauguration of Violeta Chamorro, but that he hoped to visit a number of Latin American countries in the fall. The president also said he hopes to be able to accept an invitation from Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke to visit Australia, although he did not indicate when he would take the trip.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Disagreement Among Democrats Delays Action on Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops and updates with Foley describing bill and setting schedule; edits throughout to conform and tighten
DOC.TEXT: Speaker Thomas Foley said today he expects the House to approve legislation next week that would provide federal assistance to families for child care, including care provided by church-sponsored centers. Foley, D-Wash., said House debate had been set for Wednesday on a child-care bill, which had been held up while Democratic leaders worked in private to resolve differences within the party over church-sponsored care. Although Democrats still have not produced a written version of their bill, Foley said lbbying on its behalf. Rep. Bob Walker, R-Pa., said the Christian Broadcasting Network televised a number for its viewers to call members of Congress to lobby against such a ban during a show hosted by former Republican presidential candidate Pat Robertson. ``It's working,'' Walker said. That bill is more ambitious than what President Bush has proposed, but the administration's endorsement did not come as a surprise to Democrats. The White House had backed Stenholm in similar debates last year. The Stenholm-Shaw version would cost an estimated $19.3 billion over its five-year phase-in period. That is less than more ambitious Democratic versions would cost, although Democratic leaders have yet to produce their latest version in writing. Democratic leaders earlier agreed to combine competing proposals to expand tax credits for low-income families for day care and increase funding for day-care services under a block grant program. Other provisions would expand Head Start and increase a school-based program of before- and after-school care. The Stenholm-Shaw version backed by the White House is similar to one narrowly defeated by the House last fall. It would increase money for Head Start and the Social Security block grants and expand the earned income tax credit for low-income families. It would not include the school-based program, however, and would eliminate the existing child-care tax credit for high-income families. It would scrap requirements for government child-care standards. The House last year gave tentative approval to competing versions, one emphasizing block grants and the other establishing new direct aid programs. House and Senate negotiators agreed later on the new direct aid programs, but supporters of block grants balked and Foley refused to allow a party-dividing fight over the issue on the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Names Acting Head of DEA
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today named Terrence Burke to be acting head of the Drug Enforcement Administration after Jack Lawn retires this week as the agency's director. Burke, 51, currently the agency's acting deputy administrator, previously served as deputy assistant administrator for operations and head of the DEA's Phoenix office. Lawn, who has been DEA administrator since 1985, retires on Friday to become vice president for operations of the New York Yankees. A former Marine, Burke worked for the Central Intelligence Agency from 1960 to 1970 and was awarded the CIA's intelligence star of valor. Burke also served as assistant special agent in charge of the DEA's Denver office. He was named acting deputy administrator last October. The permanent job of DEA director is a presidential appointment subject to confirmation by the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Commissioner Acknowledges Mistakes Billing Americans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOP 5 grafs new with testimony; picks up 2nd graf pvs, `Money magazine...
DOC.TEXT: Your chances of getting a telephoned tax question answered correctly by the IRS are considerably better this year _ but you will have more difficulty getting your call answered at all, auditors said today. ``This year, IRS assistors have responded accurately to 78 percent of our tax-law questions, compared to 66 percent for the same questions last year,'' Jennie S. Stathis of the General Accounting Office told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee. ``But taxpayers are having more difficulty reaching an IRS assistor,'' she said. ``This year IRS is answering one out of three calls; last year it answered almost two of three.'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. blamed the problem on the fact the Internal Revenue Service is under a hiring freeze and has been forced to cut training and the number of toll-free telphone lines. ``It bothers the hell out of me that taxpayer service has declined that way,'' he said. Earlier today, Goldberg acknowledged the IRS is making mistakes when it bills Americans for additional taxes and penalties but denied the problem is as big as a magazine story indicates. Money magazine suggested there is a 50-50 chance the Internal Revenue Service will make a mistake the next time it sends out a bill for additonal taxes and penalties. The magazine said there is evidence that $7 billion of the $15.3 billion collected as a result of such letters last year was not really owed. ``That $15 billion, I think, is pretty much due and owing,'' Goldberg said today on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' But, he added, ``Sure, people pay money they may not owe. We make mistakes.'' The commissioner agreed with the magazine's advice _ that if the IRS makes a mistake, the taxpayer should fight it. ``Grab us by the neck and tell us,'' Goldberg said. In the cover story of its April edition, Money cited a report by the General Accounting Office, interviews with tax lawyers and accountants and a survey of its subscribers to conclude that half the 36 million bills for taxes and penalties mailed out last year contained errors. The form letters generated $15.3 billion last year, an average of $425 per notice, Money noted. ``Yet, behind that apparent triumph of tax law micro-enforcement lurks a sloppy little secret: a convincing case can be made that at least $7 billion of that money should never have been collected at all because around half of those imposing official notices were inaccurate,'' the magazine said. ``Clearly, individuals are caving in to questionable demands for more money that would propel them to the phone in a second if the bill came from some bank or credit-card company.'' Although IRS officials quarreled with Money's figures, the agency acknowledges wholesale employee errors in answering taxpayers' telephoned questions and in processing returns. In fact, IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. cited the processing errors in testimony before a House subcommittee earlier this month while pleading for money to modernize the agency's 1960s-vintage computer system. ``The net result will be fewer erroneous notices and levies (property seizures) which cost both IRS and taxpayers time and money to resolve, and will allow us to devote our resources to truly delinquent accounts,'' Goldberg said. More than 35 percent of the IRS notices of additional taxes and penalties allege mathematical errors, late returns, failure to pay tax on some wages, interest or dividend reported by an employer or bank; or underpayment of quarterly estimated taxes. Last month, Money polled 300 of its subscribers with a median income over $52,000 a year and found that at sometime in their lives, half had received IRS bills for more taxes and penalties. Seven of 10 fought back. ``A stunning 45 percent of those who contested their notices report that the IRS claims were totally incorrect and an additional 24 percent said that they were at least partially wrong,'' the magazine wrote. ``What's more, of those who challenged the IRS on their own, 53 percent wound up paying nothing and another 17 percent succeeded in getting the bill reduced.'' The telephone poll had an error margin of plus or minus six percentage points. Money blamed the IRS error rate on outmoded computers and poorly trained, low-paid workers: the clerks who type data from tax returns into computers at the agency's 10 regional service centers, and the examiners who manage the notices and followup letters. The magazine said squalid working conditions in some IRS facilities, including the big Andover, Mass., service center and the Manhattan district office, cut deeply into employee morale and increase the error rate. The story suggested three reasons why taxpayers coughed up the money they did not owe: _``Simple undifferentiated fear of fighting. The IRS is infamous for star-chamber audits, summary confiscation of property and all-seeing, imperious independence.'' _``The notices tend to be confusing, compounding the maddening complexity of tax law itself.'' The magazine quoted IRS Ombudsman Damon O. Holmes as saying the notices are intelligible only to the people who wrote them. _``Tax professionals attest that all too many intimidated taxpayers fear that if they don't pay, they will suffer far worse. They begin to imagine that the IRS will come to audit them and perhaps end up questioning all sorts of deductions in the process.'' The magazine offered this advice for taxpayers unfairly dunned by the IRS: never ignore an IRS notice, respond quickly in sharp but simple terms, follow up forcefully and get outside help if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Presumed Leftist Guerrillas Assassinate Congressional Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Attackers believed to be Maoist guerrillas broke into the home of a congressional candidate Thursday morning and shot him to death as his wife and children watched, police said. The victim, Jose Gerardo, was a candidate of the center-left Aprista party of President Alan Garcia. He was 38. Police said the four gunmen escaped in a waiting car after the attack in Huancayo, an important agricultural center 120 miles east of Lima. Police said no group took responsibility for the assassination, but the Mao-inspired Shining Path guerrilla group is active in the area. In their effort to undermine the government, the rebels have threatened candidates and urged people not to vote in the April 8 elections for president, congress and regional assemblies. On Monday, Shining Path rebels killed two independent candidates for congress in Huanuco, 165 miles northeast of Lima. The Shining Path launched its armed insurgency in 1980 and operates through most of the highlands and in the northeastern jungle of Peru.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Fighter Accidentally Drops Dummy Bomb
DOC.TEXT: An American fighter pilot accidentally released a dummy bomb near the construction site of a nuclear waste reprocessing center, news reports and U.S. military officials said Thursday. The accident caused no injuries or damage, said Capt. Phillip Delaney, a spokesman at the U.S. Misawa Air Base in northern Japan. Delaney said the pilot ``inadvertantly released'' the 25-pound dummy bomb over a field about 1.5 miles from the base bombing range. Dummy bombs are for practice and do not explode. He said there were no technical problems with the F-16C jet fighter, which was conducting routine runs with three other planes assigned to Misawa's 14th Tactical Fighter Squadron. A report Thursday in the nationally circulated newspaper Mainichi Shimbun said the field is about four miles south of the Rokkasho nuclear waste reprocessing center, which is under construction. Delaney could not confirm the distance from the range to the reprocessing center construction site. He said the circumstances surrounding the accident were being investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Ambush Kills Five People, Including Military Officer and Boy
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels firing from two vans killed a lieutenant colonel and four other people, including a young boy, in a daring ambush Thursday during the morning rush hour, the military said. A police sergeant was also killed in a separate ambush in the capital. The military said rebels may have been responsible for that killing as well. Lt. Col. Francisco Flores and three enlisted men were shot to death while riding to work at about 7:30 a.m. Five gunmen in two vans opened fire at them in suburban Pasig, said police Sgt. Archangel Estacio. A boy inside a passing car was hit by stray bullets and died at a hospital. The boy's father, three bystanders, and a sergeant in the targeted vehicle were injured, hospital staffers said. The boy's age was not known. The gunmen, armed with M-16s and .45-caliber pistols, fired more shots at the fallen military officer and warned the crowd at the busy road not to interfere, a witness said. They fled in a car stolen from the slain boy's father. About the same time in Valenzuela, six miles north of Pasig, five men shot to death Sgt. Dionisio Bongkito of the Capital Regional Command's Special Operations Group, local police said. Bongkito, who was driving in his car, slowed down at an intersection on his way to work when the gunmen appeared and fired at him with .45-caliber pistols. The gunmen then took the sargeant's M-16 rifle and his pistol and fled aboard a commandeered passenger jeep. Police Sgt. Ponciano Casile said the local police still do not have any suspects in the attack, but the jeep driver quoted the gunmen as saying they were from the Communist New People's Army. The New Peoples Army, the military wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines, has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Leaves 4,000 Homeless in Burma
DOC.TEXT: A fire burned down 763 houses and left almost 4,000 people homeless in Burma's capital, Rangoon, according to a report seen Thursday. It took three hours to control the blaze, said the report from Burma. According to the report, the fire began Tuesday in a house and quickly spread, destroying homes, a monastery, a shop, and other buildings. There was no mention of casualties.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Curtails Monkey Imports As Virus Spreads
DOC.TEXT: The national Centers for Disease Control today halted imports by three of the nation's largest monkey dealers over concerns about a spreading virus. Ebola virus, which was the deadliest known virus in the world before AIDS, was spotted in the United States in November in three monkeys at the Hazleton Research Products Inc. facility in Reston, Va. In January, an Ebola-related virus turned up in a monkey in a Pennsylvania laboratory. In notices to Hazleton, Worldwide Primates of Miami and Charles River Primates Corp. of Port Washington, N.Y., CDC Director William Roper said CDC inspectors had found inadequate isolation and quarantine conditions at the three facilities this week. Effective today, ``your registration to import nonhuman primates into the United States will be revoked,'' Roper told the three importers. The three are among four importers who handle 90 percent of U.S. monkey imports, according to CDC officials. The fourth facility was inspected and found to be in compliance with CDC guidelines, and no action has been taken there. Meanwhile, New York state officials announced that effective Thursday, no monkeys will be allowed into New York through John F. Kennedy International Airport unless accompanied by written documentation that they have been quarantined for at least 60 days and tested negative for filovirus _ the family of virus that includes Ebola virus. JFK is the airport of entry for about 80 percent of the 20,000 monkeys imported into the United States each year, according to New York health officials.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Won't Elaborate on Advice for Running Against Women
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he's got some opinions about running against women candidates, but he won't say what they are. Bush called himself an ``expert in the field,'' referring to his 1984 vice presidential race against then Rep. Geraldine Ferraro. He was asked at a news conference if he had any advice for Clayton Williams, the Republican gubernatorial candidate in Texas whose opponent will be decided in a runoff between Democratic state Treasurer Ann Richards and Attorney Gen. Jim Mattox. Williams has said he would feel less comfortable running against a woman. As for presidential advice, Bush retorted: ``I have none at all, but I know exactly what he means and I refuse to elaborate on it,'' because it could end up ``complicating his life,'' he said. ``Remember 1984. I can't forget it.'' Williams, he said, is, ``entitled to his opinion. Maybe he's drawing on my experience.'' Bush had a hard time competing with the wave of positive feeling Ferraro's candidacy initially generated among women. When at last he felt he had made a strong showing against her in a televised debate, Bush stated he had ``kicked a little ass'' with his performance.

DOC.HEAD: Downstream Florida, Georgia Towns Brace As Bulge Of Water Moves Toward Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Rivers in flood-torn southeastern Alabama continued to recede today, but towns on the Florida Panhandle and in southern Georgia prepared for the bulge of water from last weekend's storms working its way downstream. President Bush on Wednesday cleared the way for federal aid in Elba, the hardest-hit town in Alabama, where residents are finding a muddy mess as they return to homes and businesses that for the most part were uninsured for floods. The town was inundated Saturday when a levee along the Pea River burst after the region was pummeled with up to 16 inches of rain. Across the South, the flooding forced hundreds to be evacuated and was blamed for at least 11 deaths. Bush declared Coffee County, which includes Elba, a disaster area, making citizens eligible for loans and other aid. ``Now that the flood waters in Coffee County have receded, we have a big job ahead of us,'' Gov. Guy Hunt said. The White House took no immediate action on Hunt's request for disaster declarations in 25 other Alabama counties. In Florida, flooding along several rivers across the Panhandle caused about 2,500 residents to flee. The latest evacuations were on the lower Choctawhatchee, not expected to crest until later today. In Caryville, Fla., and surrounding Washington County, about 100 miles west of Tallahassee, 1,200 were forced to flee their homes since the weekend. ``There's not one place dry in town that I've seen,'' said Caryville resident, Hershel Carnley. ``There's not much you can say. It's a mess. Everybody in town is hurting.'' In Hawkinsville, Ga., Civil Defense Director Sam Clark said the last family was evacuated by boat from one threatened area before dawn Wednesday. National Weather Service forecasters predicted the Ocmulgee River will crest at 7 feet above flood stage Friday in the south-central Georgia town. ``I had talked like a madman trying to get them to leave, but they wouldn't,'' Clark said. ``They called about 3:30 for us to come get them.'' Rescuers in southeastern Alabama today found two missing servicemen along the rain-gorged Pea River, where the pair had launched a canoe Wednesday to view flood damage. The search continued to the northeast in Dale County for a third soldier missing for four days. All three were based in Fort Rucker, Ala., the U.S. Army's main flight training base. Officials said the missing soldier, Mary Helen Garrison, 21, apparently drove around a barricade and tried to ford a flooded-out section of highway U.S. 84. Her car was found Tuesday. Many of the 2,000 people who evacuated Elba were at their homes and businesses Wednesday, raking mud from floors and sorting through the remains of their shattered lives. Most found little to salvage. ``There's three generations of antiques and family heirlooms in there,'' Becky Hayes said Wednesday as she stood outside a mud-covered warehouse her family owns near the town square. ``Now it's all upside down like scrambled eggs.'' National Guardsmen set up checkpoints to allow in only residents and business owners. At night, they continued to enforce a 7 p.m. curfew. Gene Malfer, a spokesman for the American Red Cross, said the organization estimated that 239 homes in Elba were destroyed, 286 suffered major damage and about 70 had minor damage.

DOC.HEAD: Mysterious Turtle Deaths Raise Fears of Pacific `Red Tide'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-7 bgng, Colombian fishermen ...' with four grafs to move up first reference to Mast
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: A toxin similar to red tide could have caused the mysterious deaths of as many as 680 endangered sea turtles off Colombia, officials said. Only a few thousand adult Pacific green turtles are known to exist, so the beaching represents the loss of a substantial part of the population, said Jack Woody, national sea turtle coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in Albuquerque, N.M. Some have suggested that the turtles beached themselves as whales sometimes do.
