Colombian fishermen attributed the deaths to a curse put on them for over exploiting the sea's resources, said Roderic Mast, director of species conservation at Conservation International in Washington, D.C. The turtles eat plant material, and some could have contained toxins, Mast said Wednesday. ``Maybe they were affected by a red tide, or something like that,'' he said. Another explanation could be that the turtles were caught in fishermen's nets and drowned, Mast said. ``The local fishermen, who are the people who of course know the area best ... are claiming they've never seen anything like this before,'' Mast said. ``The likely cause, in my opinion, is probably drowning in trawlers' nets,'' with the carcasses thrown overboard. On the other hand, he said, ``these things don't add up, because if they were poor fishermen, you would expect them to keep the turtles. There is a lot of good meat and oil there.'' If the turtles died of natural causes, the conditions that killed them could threaten other endangered turtles in the Pacific, Mast said. Unconfirmed sightings suggest that might be happening. ``There are reports of turtle die-offs for no apparent reason in other parts of the Pacific, indicating that something may be going on that needs further research,'' he said. Some of those reports are coming from The National Marine Fisheries Service, which is taking a count of dolphins and porpoises in the Pacific, said Woody. ``This year they have seen some number of dead turtles floating at sea,'' he said. ``Losing these animals and not knowing why is a worrisome problem.'' Ninety-eight percent of the turtles that washed ashore in Colombia were Pacific green turtles, Mast said. They are the second most endangered sea turtles in the world, after the Kemp's ridleys, said Woody. ``They're in tough shape,'' he said. Anne Meylan, a specialist with the Florida natural resources department in St. Petersburg, said the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama has received reports from fishermen of dead turtles washing up on the Pacific coast of Panama and floating at sea. The deaths occurred about early December, said Argelis Ruiz Guevara, a biology student at the institute who has been monitoring the reports. She said she could not determine how many had died. The Colombian turtle beaching occurred in February, according to Mast, who has just released details of a preliminary investigation of the beaching. He said he has been receiving regular reports from Diego Amorocho, a biologist with the Nature Foundation in the Colombian capital, Bogota. Amorocho, with the financial backing of Conservation International and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, reported taking a census of some of the dead turtles along 200 miles of beaches in northwestern Colombia. Amorocho estimated that 360 to 680 turtles had washed ashore over a period of one or two days. Conservation International and the Fish and Wildlife Service are paying for studies to try to determine the cause of death, Mast said.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's ``Today'' Rises at Dawn in Afternoon
AP Television Writer
DOC.TEXT: NBC's ``Today'' show, temporarily in Los Angeles and bathed in sunshine, may be making some viewers wonder how it got the sun to rise so early _ since it is 4 a.m. on the West Coast when the show starts in the East. It did it through the magic of videotape. Each morning's show actually was taped the previous day at 3:30 p.m. PST, spokeswoman Mary Neagoy said Thursday. Only its news segments were live. ``Today,'' normally seen live in Eastern and Central times zones, originated on tape Wednesday and Thursday from a sunny beach location at Venice, Ca. It will appear Friday, again on tape, from a historic Spanish section in downtown Los Angeles. In the two broadcasts so far, co-host Bryant Gumbel has advised viewers the shows were taped a day earlier ``to take advantage of the California sunshine,'' Neagoy said. He will repeat the tape-delay advisory on Friday's show, she added. The shows planned for Monday and Tuesday _ each centers on the Oscar Awards ceremonies that ABC will televise Monday night _ will be broadcast live, although not in the pre-dawn darkness. The shows will originate from inside Mann's Chinese Theater in Hollywood, Neagoy said. Despite its taped sunshine this week, ``Today,'' once the leader in morning show ratings, found a continuing cause for gloom when last week's audience estimates for morning shows became available Thursday. The show, which in January dropped to second place after the replacement of co-host Jane Pauley by Deborah Norville, trailed ABC's first-place ``Good Morning America'' for the 11th consecutive week. ABC's broadcast averaged a 4.5 rating, ``Today'' was a full ratings point behind, and ``CBS This Morning'' had a 2.5 average, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Police Can't Stop Driver Despite Slow Speeds
DOC.TEXT: A police pursuit lasted 90 minutes _ but only covered four miles _ after a man took off in a construction tractor and refused to stop. Police say Mark David Lyman, 24, was walking home early Wednesday when he passed a tractor parked at a construction site. Lyman climbed into the driver's seat and started home, said Officer Jim Doty. Police cruisers responding to the theft came upon Lyman, who was driving at less than 20 mph. Although they had their lights flashing and sirens wailing, the cars were unable to pass the tractor and were forced to follow at ``very low speeds,'' Doty said. At one point, a few police cars managed to pull in front and form a roadblock but retreated when they realized Lyman would not stop, Doty said. Lyman was arrested as he pulled up to his grandmother's home. He was charged Wednesday with grand larceny and driving under the influence.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Libby Swindle's idea of a 40th birthday celebration is to climb a mountain. Ten times. In one day. ``I thought of a half-marathon or a cruise, but I thought this would be more fun,'' Swindle, of Hot Springs, said after completing her eighth circuit of the 1{-mile trail up Pinnacle Mountain. The climb began at 5:45 a.m. Wednesday, part of her tradition of climbing the west summit trail at Pinnacle Mountain State Park at sunrise. Each time she returned to the base, more friends and relatives had arrived, some from as far as San Antonio, to cheer her on. At the foot of the trail, friends decorated a picnic table and placed a dozen roses in a grill. Nearby, a white sheet was strung between two trees with balloons and messages from well-wishers. ``It's all downhill from here,'' said one. ``You're nowhere near your peak,'' said another. Ms. Swindle said she had fallen and injured her ankle Tuesday night. ``I was feeling pretty bad about the fourth time,'' she said after lap No. 9. ``It feels good now. I think that it's numb.'' She completed the 10th climb 12 hours after she started. Ms. Swindle said she began training in January and set a goal to climb Pinnacle 40 times by her birthday. Wednesday's climbs topped that by three.

If Grand Island can't be the biggest, then it says it's going to be the best. After Grand Island's claim of being the ``World's Largest Freshwater Island'' was shot down a few weeks ago by a Buffalo newspaper columnist, town officials found a solution: They crossed out the word ``largest'' on a recently erected roadway sign and replaced it with ``best.'' Take that, Ilha de Marajo. The controversy began when the columnist saw the sign, did some research and found that the Brazilian island, in the mouth of the Amazon River, is 500 times larger than Grand Island, and that the Great Lakes alone have 10 larger freshwater islands. ``Let the island in the Amazon dispute this,'' Robert W. Weaver, a Grand Island Chamber of Commerce director, said after the sign was edited Wednesday. Weaver said he wasn't remorseful about the original mistake. ``I would do it all over again. It created a lot of controversy and interest, and I think it brought Grand Island to the minds of many people who don't think about it.'' The 27-square-mile island lies between the two branches of the Niagara River a few miles northwest of Buffalo.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Names Envoy to Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Thursday named a 31-year veteran of the diplomatic service as its ambassador to Argentina, following the resumption of diplomatic ties that were severed during the 1982 Falkland Islands war. Humphrey Maud, 55, has served Britain at various levels in Spain, Cuba, France and Luxembourg. He has been ambassador to Cyprus since 1988, the Foreign Office said. He will take up his Buenos Aires post in July. Maud, married with three children, is also an accomplished cellist. Diplomatic ties were severed after Argentina, which claims the Falklands and calls them the Malvinas, overran the south Atlantic archipelago. Britain sent a naval task force and recaptured the islands after a 74-day war.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Secretary-General Accepts Invitation to Visit Moscow
DOC.TEXT: NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner has accepted a Soviet invitation to visit Moscow in the coming months, the Western alliance said Thursday. It would be the first trip to the Soviet capital by the top official of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. A brief statement from NATO said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had invited Woerner to make the trip. No date has been set. Shevardnadze made an unprecedented visit to NATO headquarters in December in a dramatic sign of the thaw in relations between East and West. Since then, the foreign ministers of Czechoslovakia and Poland have traveled to NATO headquarters to meet with Woerner and the ambassadors of the alliance nations. Both foreign ministers invited the secretary-general to their capitals, and it was considered likely he would accept their invitations later.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Groups Warn of More Oil Spills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs `The tanker ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that nearly 11 million gallons spilled, sted more than 11 million gallons
DOC.TEXT: A major oil spill such as the one that devastated Alaska's Prince William Sound a year ago could strike New York or Los Angeles harbor, two environmental groups said Thursday. One group, the Center for Marine Conservation, also said spills are almost inevitable in the ecologically rich Florida Keys. The center and the Natural Resources Defense Council, in separate studies undertaken after the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska, called for tighter standards governing tankers, pilots and tug escorts. The center suggested that the Coast Guard establish a network, much like the air-traffic control system, to monitor traffic off the Florida Keys and the central California coast and advise mariners of danger spots. The tanker Exxon Valdez spewed nearly 11 million gallons of toxic crude oil into the sea when it ran aground in Prince William Sound a year ago Saturday, soaking 1,100 miles of scenic coastland. Searchers found 34,400 dead birds and believe at least 1,000 sea otters and countless other animals died. ``An Exxon Valdez-size spill could occur in New York Harbor,'' the Natural Resources Defense Council concluded, saying 18 billion gallons of oil are brought into the harbor each year and large spills have dumped more than 2.4 million gallons into harbor waters in the last 13 years. The report drew the same conclusion about Los Angeles Harbor, where it said supertankers regularly arrive carrying 33 million gallons of oil. It said more than 1.3 million gallons of oil and fuel have spilled into the Los Angeles Harbor area from major and medium spills since 1976. In a case study of San Francisco Bay, the center said the Coast Guard regards it as more difficult to navigate than Prince William Sound and noted that it contains 90 percent of California's coastal wetlands. The entrance to the bay is ringed with national parkland and existing and proposed marine sanctuaries. The study said tanker traffic is heavy and rising and will increase by at least 25 percent if federal plans to lease Northern and Central California offshore areas for oil drilling are approved. The Center for Marine Conservation said there have been no major oil spills in the Florida Keys for many years, except for a spill off the Marquesas in 1975, from which oil was driven ashore on a 30-mile stretch of the keys. ``Yet the great number of tankers and other vessels transiting the Florida Straits makes spills a near inevitability given historical patterns of tanker casualties,'' the center said. The center urged that the Coast Guard control traffic within 15 miles of the Keys, where a series of vessel groundings late last year extensively damaged coral reefs. ``We have the know-how to prevent accidents before they happen, especially in our most sensitive waters,'' said Roger McManus, president of the center. Among other principal recommendations in the two reports are: _Requiring oil tankers and barges to have double hulls and double bottoms. _Requiring tug escorts for tankers in difficult waters and biologically sensitive areas. _Establishing tanker-free zones in environmentally vulnerable areas. _Requiring licensed pilots for all tankers and barges over a a minimum size within harbors.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks to Quiet Polish Fears on German Reunification
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts lead; picks up 4th graf pvs, `Mazowiecki left ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today there is just ``a nuance of difference'' with Poland over its demands for a signed treaty guaranteeing its border before the two Germanys unite. Bush, in a news conference shortly after a second round of talks with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, said the Poles and Germans ``are very, very close now'' to an understanding that the current borders must remain intact. ``Let them sort it out. It's going very well,'' Bush told reporters. He said again that Poland will have a voice at the two-plus-four talks on questions affecting its borders, and stressed that those talks are not ``going to determine the fate of all of Europe.'' Mazowiecki left the White House saying ``there are no problems between us'' on Poland's demand for an early treaty with the two Germanys guaranteeing its borders. Bush said he had not gotten any assurances from Mazowiecki that the new non-communist government in Warsaw will press for withdrawal of Soviet troops from its territory. ``There isn't any need for Soviet troops in Eastern Europe, and the sooner they get out of there the better,'' said Bush. Mazowiecki has said he wants the Soviet troops to stay until the German question is resolved. The prime minister, speaking with reporters as he left the White House, said, ``We've stated publicly we're going to start talks about that that will eventually lead to total withdrawal'' of the Soviet forces. On the so-called two-plus-four talks on German unification involving the two Germanys and the four Allied victors from World War II, Bush said, if the talks involve Polish issues, ``Poland should be there. Poland should be involved.'' ``We don't see this as the group that is going to determine the fate of all of Europe. ... But if two-plus-four starts talking about Polish borders, for example, clearly the Poles should be involved,'' the president said. Mazowiecki said he was ``very pleased'' with his talks with Bush. ``There are no problems between us'' on Poland's demand for an early, swift treaty with the two Germanys guaranteeing its borders, the prime minister said. ``The only problem is to persuade both our German partners that it needs to be done swiftly and finally,'' said Mazowiecki, who wants a guarantee in writing that a united Germany will not seek to reclaim territories ceded to Poland after World War II. Asked if he and Bush had solved disagreements over how large a role Poland should have in the talks, Mazowiecki replied, ``It is well known that we will participate in the conference and we will take part in everything that will affect and concern ourselves.'' Poland has been assured a seat at the table when the two Germanys and the four Allied victors from World War II _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ discuss issues affecting the Polish border. Mazowiecki said the Poles want a treaty with the Germanys ``initialed prior to the German unification and finally reaffirmed after the unification.'' ``We do not really see any major reason why that should not happen, because we want that to happen to make sure that the whole debate would not have to be started all over again afterwards. We would like to avoid this,'' he said. ``We know that after all we're going to live as neighbors with a unified Germany from now on and we would like to see it as a good neighborly relationship,'' he said. Mazowiecki then left for Capitol Hill and talks with leaders of both the House and Senate. At a state dinner Wednesday night, Mazowiecki pressed his insistence on a new treaty guaranteeing Poland's border and urged a new political structure to free Europe of military rivalry. Earlier Wednesday Bush sought to assure Mazowiecki of U.S. support for Poland's demand that its current western border not be breached when the two Germanys unite. Both in private talks and in a poignant toast at the state dinner, Mazowiecki stressed the issue's importance to Poles now emerging from ``a long night of totalitarian oppression'' under the Nazis and then communist rule. At the state dinner, Mazowiecki invoked Alexis de Tocqueville's words about ``the unstoppable march of democracy.'' ``Nowadays, we're witnessing an enormous acceleration of that march _ in Nicaragua, Chile, even Mongolia, but most of all in Eastern and Central Europe,'' he said. ``Democracy is a system which secures the freedom of the individual, the freedom without which no normal life is possible.'' He recalled how Poland was ``ravaged by the Nazi invasion'' in 1939. ``Our people suffered more than any other on earth. Poland lost 6 million of its citizens, half of them Polish Jews,'' he said. After World War II, he said, ``for the next 45 years we were forced to live under an alien political system, a totalitarian one, which was imposed on the whole Eastern and Central Europe. The Poles never accepted their fate and were the first to challenge it.'' Mazowiecki said, ``a need is emerging for a new structure ... to gradually free Europe of military rivalry and bring the two separated parts closer together.'' ``Reconciliation between nations is possible only when they do not fear either for their present or their future. For this reason, an important component of the building must be the recognition of the Polish border along the Oder-Neisse Rivers in the form of a treaty,'' said the prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: Public Works Systems in Bad State of Disrepair, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: America is postponing the day of reckoning with its deteriorating road, bridge and water network, driving the eventual repair pricetag even higher, Congress was told Thursday. While there's little argument it will cost billions of dollars to fix the system, no consensus has been reached on how to raise the money, said the Office of Technology Assessment. ``As a country, we must face the fact that there is no free lunch,'' said Edith P. Page, the study's project director. ``The bad news is, we found no silver bullet.'' ``The choices are clear,'' the report said. ``All levels of government will have to raise taxes and a variety of fees to pay for public works improvements or they will have to eliminate or reduce services.'' The House and Senate public works committees commissioned the study, and the congressional research office produced a 140-page report painting a grim picture of transportation and water systems. ``We've had a series of reports on this subject, each of which has been greeted with massive indifference,'' said Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., who joined OTA officials at a news conference. ``I am baffled by this. We're on the edge, at least, of disinvesting in public works,'' he said. The report described a public works network fallen into disrepair _ making it difficult for people to get to and from work, discouraging new plant construction and generally stifling the easy movement of products to the marketplace. A variety of circumstances has conspired to leave the system in poor shape, the study said, including a declining political consensus for public works expenditures at all levels of government. The problem has worsened over the last decade as federal grants to states have waned, local officials have been reluctant to hike taxes and Washington has imposed costly new environmental and health regulations on industry, it said. Two weeks ago, President Bush announced a national transportation policy that would shift more costs to state and local governments, calling for more toll roads, local gas taxes and user fees. The plan was criticized by some local government officials who said their budgets already were stretched to the limit. ``Breaking the logjam created by these issues is no simple matter,'' Ms. Page said, adding: ``Although states have increased their investments in public works as federal support has dwindled for a variety of reasons, no state has filled the gap between its infrastructure needs and reductions in federal support.'' ``We don't understand that running down the capital infrastructure adds to the costs of production,'' she said. Said Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho: ``We concentrate on efforts in raising the costs of doing business in the United States instead of lowering the costs of doing business by rebuilding the infrastructure.'' ``This disinvestment is going to cost us a lot of money as it causes sagging productivity,'' he said. The study said the nation's roughly 83,000 local governments ``are in an unenviable position _ they take the direct political heat generated by public works issues.'' The OTA report made no effort to say how much it would cost to repair and modernize aging and deteriorating public works facilities. But it noted one recent economic projection that if spending were increased by $50 billion in the first year _ 1 percent of the gross national product _ ``productivity would rise by $26.5 billion.''

DOC.HEAD: Singer Gloria Estefan Undergoes Surgery For Crash Injury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with quote from hospital president saying surgery seems a success so far. Picks up 6th graf, `Known for...'
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan, whose back was broken when her tour bus was hit by a truck, underwent apparently successful surgery today to have her spine stabilized with metal rods, hospital officials said. The star of the Latin-pop group Miami Sound Machine was on the operating table from 8:30 a.m. until shortly after noon. Dr. Michael Neuwirth, her orthopedic surgeon, inserted the two rods into her fractured vertebrae. ``So far things are going extremely well. It's been successful,'' said Dr. Victor Frankel, president of the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was not involved in the surgery. Miss Estefan will need three to six months to recover from injuries she suffered in the crash Tuesday in Pennsylvania, medical experts said. State police said today the truck that hit the group's bus had faulty brakes. The singer's ``prognosis is excellent for a return to normal function,'' Neuwirth had said Wednesday. Known for her energetic dancing on stage, Miss Estefan felt numbness and weakness in her legs after the accident. Besides being fractured, the two vertebrae were slightly dislocated, doctors said. ``Ms. Estefan has a serious spinal injury. It is a fractured subluxation of the spine. It requires an operation to stabilize her spine,'' Neuwirth said. Miss Estefan, 32, initially was taken to the Community Medical Center in Scranton, Pa., but she was flown by helicopter Wednesday to New York for the operation. Dr. Harry Schmaltz of the Scranton medical center said the singer will have to wear a device to restrict her movement during recovery. ``She's not going to do much in the way of entertaining for three to six months,'' he said. ``She's in a lot of pain, but her spirits are up,'' said her sister, Becky Fajardo. Miss Estefan asked for a copy of the New York Post ``so she could see her face on the cover,'' said hospital spokeswoman Mary Costello, who classified the singer's condition as good. At the time of the accident, the Cuban-born singer and her group were headed to Syracuse, N.Y., for a concert. The accident occurred Tuesday on Interstate 380 near Tobyhanna in the Pocono Mountains in eastern Pennsylvania. The tour bus was stopped for a jackknifed tractor-trailer when a second tractor-trailer hit, throwing Miss Estefan from a couch where she was sleeping. Her husband and 9-year-old son also were injured, but less seriously. Pennsylvania State Police said this morning that an inspection of the truck that hit the band's bus turned up faulty brakes. Trucker Heraldo E. Samuels, already cited on charges of driving at an unsafe speed, will face additional charges related to the brake problem, police said. Fans flooded the switchboard of Community Medical Center and sent her flowers and notes. Elton John sent flowers; well-wishers who called included Madonna, Bruce Springsteen, Jon Bon Jovi, John Denver, Ryan O'Neal and Frankie Avalon, associates said. President Bush, who met the singer Monday to discuss her anti-drug work, talked to her twice since she was hospitalized. Miss Estefan was nominated in February for a Grammy for her vocal performance on the single ``Don't Wanna Lose You.'' Her new album, ``Cuts Both Ways,'' a collection of dance songs and ballads, was 26th on the Cashbox magazine pop chart last week. Miss Estefan and Miami Sound Machine have attracted listeners worldwide with salsa, samba and conga for more than a decade. Their hits include ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You'' and ``Anything for You.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Demands End to Volunteer Force
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev demanded today that Lithuania stop a sign-up of volunteer forces to protect the Baltic republic's declaration of independence. In another move to increase pressure on officials who led the republic to declare independence on March 11, Gorbachev told Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis to report back on the matter in two days. In a telegram, the text of which was read on the evening TV news program ``Vremya,'' Gorbachev that volunteers must not be signed up in Lithuania to take the place of Soviet border guards and police. He called on Landsbergis ``to take urgent measures to stop all activity aimed at creating these kinds of organizations,'' and called for a response in two days. On Wednesday, Gorbachev ordered Lithuanian citizens to turn in all their firearms, and ordered a strengthened border regime around the republic.

DOC.HEAD: Exodus Easing in Wake of East German Elections
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The daily number of East Germans resettling in West Germany has dropped in half in the past week, apparently as a result of the national elections held in their homeland, the Interior Ministry said Thursday. The ministry said 931 East German resettlers registered with federal authorities on Wednesday, compared with 2,248 one week ago. It was the lowest figure in several months, the ministry said. On Tuesday, 1,156 East Germans applied for permanent residence in West Germany, and on Monday the number was 1,539, said the Interior Ministry. In recent weeks, the daily number of new arrivals often surpassed 2,000. About 150,000 East Germans have arrived in West Germany since the beginning of the year, joining more than 340,000 who made the trip last year. The exodus sparked the revolution for democratic reform that led to elections Sunday in East Germany. At the same time, it has bled East Germany's struggling economy and placed severe burdens on West Germany's social services net and housing and job markets. But the constant stream appears to be ebbing as a result of Sunday's vote, in which an alliance favoring quick reunification with West Germany won the most votes. The decrease may also be a result of West Germany's decision Tuesday to end a 40-year-old program that provided shelter, low-interest loans and ``starting-out money'' for East German resettlers. On Thursday, the government took yet another step to discourage East Germans from heading permanently West. Starting next week, East Germans who quit their jobs at home to move West will have to wait three months before they can qualify for West German unemployment benefits. Previously there was no waiting period for the unemployment money.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Movements in Lithuania; Gorbachev Orders Volunteer Force Disbanded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev demanding volunteer force be scapped. Pickup 3rd graf `A convoy...'; SUBS 11th graf `Vytautas Landsbergis...' with 1 graf to CONFORM. Pickup 12th graf `Gennady Gerasimov...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: A column of Soviet armored personnel carriers and army trucks drove through the center of the Lithuanian capital today in the Kremlin's latest show of force in the breakaway republic. Lithuanian officials protested increased Soviet military activity and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree Wednesday ordering citizens to turn in their guns, saying the republic's independence movement has been non-violent. Gorbachev today also demanded that Lithuania stop signing up volunteer defense forces. The request came in a telegram to Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis and was read on the evening TV news program ``Vremya.'' A convoy of 15 personnel carriers and five trucks, towing military equipment, rolled through Vilnius this afternoon. The action came just hours after Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene complained of the increasing activity of Soviet soldiers and demanded an explanation from the Kremlin. During a break in today's Supreme Council session, she told reporters an estimated 30,000 Soviet troops were stationed in the republic, whose Parliament declared independence from Moscow on March 11 after the ruling Communists were removed from power in free elections. ``But, it changes daily,'' she said, explaining why she sent a telegram to Gorbachev on Wednesday night demanding to know the number of Soviet troops and amount of military equipment sent to Lithuania over the past few days. Gorbachev has called Lithuania's declaration of independence illegal but has also said he would not use force to keep it from seceding from the Soviet Union, which annexed the republic after assuming control under terms of the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1940. Ms. Prunskiene called Gorbachev's decree to turn in weapons within a week ``an expression of mistrust in the whole population'' of the Baltic state. Lithuanian Interior Minister Marionis Myasyukonis told The Associated Press, ``There are about 30,000 officially registered shotguns, mostly in the possession of hunters and collectors.'' ``There has not been one case of aggression, so why confiscate shotguns?'' said Lithuanian legislator Algimontas Cekuolis. ``The laws of Moscow are not valid in the sovereign state of Lithuania. No guns will be returned.'' Landsbergis said Gorbachev's decree shows ``the ghost of Stalinism is walking in the Kremlin'' and that it could be enforced ``only by brutal military force.'' Gennady Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, reiterated today that Moscow had no plans to use force but declined to say whether the Kremlin might order the arrest of Lithuanian leaders. ``We want to solve this problem as peacefully as possible and according to the laws of the country,'' he told reporters during a news briefing. The Soviet general who commands Lithuania's volunteer civil defense agency said he has partially complied with orders to turn over to the Soviet military the weapons and 16,000 vehicles under his command. Gen. Ginutis Taurinskas told the Lithuanian Parliament he was ordered ``to give all small caliber weapons to military units so there won't be any eventual theft of arms for inappropriate use.'' He said firearms remained scattered among 500 to 600 units of volunteers who carry out air raid drills and train young people for military service. He gave no figures. Gorbachev, using the powers he gained when the Congress of People's Deputies elected him the Soviet Union's first executive president last week, said Lithuanians had a week to turn in their firearms. If they fail to do so, he said the Soviet Interior Ministry should be prepared to confiscate them. Gorbachev also told KGB border troops to tighten their watch over the republic and told officials to reduce the number of visas issued to foreigners seeking to visit the republic. His decree was the latest in a series of increasingly tough moves taken by Moscow in an attempt to discourage secession by the republic of 3.8 million people. It came less than 24 hours after a strong protest from Lithuania's government over stepped up maneuvers by the Soviet military in the state. Lithuania's was independent from 1918 until 1940, when it was forcibly annexed along with Latvia and Estonia. So far, no foreign country has officially recognized Lithuania as independent. Lithuania had rushed to declare its independence before Gorbachev could gain broad powers that include authority to impose direct presidential rule on areas of the Soviet Union. Asked late Wednesday whether Gorbachev was conducting psychological warfare on the small republic, Cekuolis said, ``Yes, this is a war of nerves, but we are not nervous. We have the motivation, we have our country, and we know where we are going.'' Most firearms are tightly controlled in the Soviet Union, so Gorbachev's directive primarily touched hunting weapons. Relatively few people own firearms, and they must be registered with authorities. Also Wednesday, Moscow lawmakers gave initial approval to a draft law that would make secession from the Soviet Union illegal without a republic-wide referendum and a five-year transition period. One of two chambers in the Supreme Soviet standing legislature gave the bill preliminary approval and sent it to the other chamber. Deputies said its prompt passage was needed to dissuade other republics from copying Lithuania, as fellow Baltic republics Latvia and Estonia are expected to do. A group of conservative deputies to the Congress appealed to Gorbachev to impose direct rule on Lithuania, charging that the republic was about to pass legislation making it illegal to speak out against the independence movement. Senior Lithuanian legislators confirmed such legislation existed, but said it was unlikely to be approved by Lithuania's Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Ruined Environment One of Stalinism's Legacies in Eastern Europe
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Every building, street, leaf or scrap of earth in this town of 10,000 is black, shrouded in the soot of some of Eastern Europe's worst pollution. Each year, Copsa Mica's two factories spew out about 30,000 tons of pollutants. Some of it is soot from a factory that puts dye in rubber. Some is dust from a plant for nonferrous metals. Everybody has known for years it was bad to live here, but under the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, nobody dared say so. Residents say the pollution problem was acknowledged only when Ceausescu's son, Nicu, visited the town for two days last fall and the factories were shut down. The situation in Copsa Mica is in some ways typical of industrial areas in other Eastern European countries, where Communist governments eager for industrial development ignored environmental damage. Now, millions of people in East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Hungary and Romania are using their new freedoms to expose one of the legacies of Stalinism: destruction of the environment in economies run by decree rather than logic. As Eastern Europe rediscovers its political voice, ecological movements and Greens parties are becoming important. In Czechoslovakia, for instance, where an estimated 35 percent of all forests are damaged by pollution, sulfur dioxide emissions are double those in neighboring West Germany. The Greens party ranks second in the polls behind Civic Forum and Public Against Violence, movements that led the peaceful revolution against Communist rule. In Romania, too, an emerging National Ecology Movement claims at least 40,000 active supporters. Even before May's scheduled elections, the provisional government has set commissions to battle the blight imposed by Ceausescu's rule. ``Ceausescu ordered the building of big factories, but when it was a question of buying anti-pollution devices, he never accepted that,'' said architect Serban Popescu-Criveanu, chairman of one of the new national bodies. ``He said `Let's start, and we'll do that later.' And that later meant never.'' Similarly haphazard planning and the resulting pollution helped bring about last fall's revolt in East Germany, home of some of central Europe's dirtiest industrial towns. In Bulgaria in 1988, it was environmental dissent and a government crackdown on it that sowed the seeds of today's broader opposition to the Communists. In Hungary, Poland and the Soviet Union, environmental awareness helped start political reforms that in turn have heightened public consciousness of pollution. It is a touchstone issue in traditionally rural countries whose folklore values the peasant customs, forests, lakes and clean air that vanished under communism. Despite the East's growing environmental awareness, the cost of cleaning up the mess, lack of international cooperation and a threat of unemployment mean that any improvement will take decades. Hungary, for instance, decided in 1982 to become the first East bloc country to control toxic waste that previously was buried in unregulated dumps, which environment official Robert Reiniger calls ``ticking timebombs.'' The one waste burner put into operation since 1982 cost $36.7 million, including more than $2 million in hard currency in a country that needs every cent to repay its $20 billion foreign debt. On the international scale, costs are far higher. A recent study by the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis near Vienna estimated that $18 billion a year would be needed to cut by 50 percent the sulfurous emissions eating at Europe's forests. Even that huge investment won't arrest the acidification of Europe's soils unless the money is used chiefly to curb the air pollution from its chief sources in Eastern Europe, the institute's experts say. Yet cross-border cooperation is hard to achieve. Czechoslovakia and Hungary, for instance, still cannot decide the fate of a giant, half-completed plan to dam and re-channel the Danube river for hydroelectric plants. But both countries now agree potential energy gains should be weighed against possibly lasting damage to land and wildlife. While governments seem to fear losing the huge sums already spent on projects such as the Danube dam, workers worry about losing their livelihood if industries are closed. When Romania's new government closed a well-known national eyesore, a synthetic materials plant in the northern town of Suceava, hundreds of its workers traveled to Bucharest to protest. Communism's failure to keep its promises of a better life for its people mean that many of Eastern Europe's new voters, like the East Germans last weekend, favor parties who offer economic growth. While new wealth may help curb some existing pollution, it could create new environmental damage by increasing demands for energy in countries with few natural fuel resources and growing appetites for consumer goods. In Budapest, for instance, the growth in private car ownership means clogged city streets. But it also means the incidence of asthma has doubled in the last 10 years in one busy district where lead content in the air is 18 times what it should be.

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Seeks Record Fourth Term in Weekend Election
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke seeks a record fourth consecutive victory for his governing Labor Party in the election Saturday, which he says will set Australia's course into the 21st century. When he set the date Feb. 16, Hawke said it was the most important election in more than 40 years. Hawke, in office seven years, is the most enduring and popular Labor Party leader. Polls forecast a close vote between Labor and the opposition Liberal-National Party coalition, but no contest when it comes to the prime minister's personal popularity. Bulletin magazine said a survey conducted last weekend indicated 43 percent of the voters supported Labor and the opposition alliance, led by Andrew Peacock of the Liberal Party, had edged up a point to 39 percent. It said 14 percent supported the centrist, environmentalist Australian Democrats, the greatest following the party has achieved. Australia has 10.6 million eligible voters among its 16.5 million people, and voting is compulsory. The magazine said 2,492 people across Australia were questioned. It did not give the margin of error. Foreign policy is unlikely to change regardless of who wins the election. Labor and the opposition alliance have similar positions and support continued close relations with the United States. Little controversy arose during the campaign and newspapers described it as the dullest of recent times. The liberal Sydney Morning Herald said Hawke and Peacock ``have the combined charisma of a wet salad sandwich.'' The tabloid Daily Telegraph of Sydney asked: ``Excuse us, but has anyone seen the election campaign?'' Labor ran on its record of economic management, despite a foreign debt equivalent to $100 billion and record 18 percent interest rates that hurt home buyers and small businesses. A Daily Telegraph editorial said: ``The federal election campaign is drifting on an ocean of apathy because so many Australian families are drowning in a sea of debt and feel they are living in a sinking country.'' ``I believe the election is the most important one since 1949,'' the 60-year-old prime minister said when the campaign began, referring to a Labor loss that began 23 years in power for the Liberals. ``The election will essentially determine the character of the nation that we are going to have in the 21st century,'' Hawke said. Peacock, 51, predicts a 16-seat victory in the 148-seat House of Representatives. He has asked Australians to dump Labor for a government that will help the ``battlers,'' as Australians call poorer working people. In the current house, Labor has 85 seats, the Liberal Party has 45 seats, and its coalition partner, the National Party, has 18 seats. A former foreign minister, Peacock is making his second attempt to become prime minister. A poll conducted by the newspaper Melbourne Age indicated he trailed Hawke in personal popularity, with 23 percent to Hawke's 52 percent. Hawke became prime minister in 1983. He won elections the following year and in 1987 and hopes to carry a fifth for Labor before retiring. The term in Australia is three years.

DOC.HEAD: German Businessman Charged With Helping Build Libyan Plant
DOC.TEXT: A West German businessman on Thursday was indicted on charges he helped build a Libyan plant, which the United States says produced chemical weapons before it was damaged by fire last week. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, former head of the Imhausen-Chemie chemical company, was charged with violating West Germany's export laws and with tax evasion. Also Thursday, a government official said Libya had stopped payments to West German firms and interrupted trade, claiming West German intelligence was involved in the fire. West Germany denied the accusation and issued a formal protest over the suspension of payments. Mannheim prosecutor Peter Wechsung charged that Hippenstiel-Inhausen had a ``decisive role'' in the planning and construction of the Rabta complex, about 60 miles outside Tripoli. Court officials said the trial may begin in the summer. Wechsung said the businessman sent Libya ``documents on production'' as well as ``measuring and regulating instruments'' to be used at Rabta. He said investigators had concluded that the plant was ``solely intended'' to produce poison gases. Libya has said the plant was only making pharmaceuticals. Wechsung also said that West Germany's federal police had created a special ``Rabta'' unit consisting of 20 officials who took part in the investigation. Speaking to reporters in Mannheim, Wechsung said about 3,000 files containing documents, plans and other material had been confiscated in the investigation and that statements were taken from more than 200 witnesses. Wechsung did not say whether other arrests were expected. Hippenstiel-Imhausen resigned as head of the company a year ago and was arrested Oct. 5. A number of West German companies were invesitigated a little more than a year ago after U.S. charges that German firms had helped build the plant. Only Hippenstiel-Imhausen has been arrested. The Frankfurter Rundschau newspaper, quoting government officials, reported Libya has ``blocked trade with West Germany since last week'' to protest the fire, which caused severe damage to the plant. Libyan exports to West Germany last year amounted to $1.85 billion, most of it oil. West German exports to Libya last year were valued at $780 million. West German Ambassador Joerg Helmer went to the Libyan foreign office in Tripoli ``to express our displeasure'' with the Libyan actions, said a government official in Bonn. The official, speaking on condition of anonmymity, said Libya had also barred a ship carrying Libyan oil from reaching its destination in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Speaker Gives Extra Emphasis to Annual ``Get Serious'' Speech
DOC.TEXT: The speaker of the Legislature broke his walnut gavel, but he still needed the attention of his 48 colleagues. So, he wielded a meat cleaver Thursday. And members of the unicameral Legislature paid attention. After two days of heated debate, a school financing bill had just been passed Wednesday when Speaker Bill Barrett began his annual ``get serious speech'' about what he expected during the last 10 working days of the two-month session. He banged the gavel to quiet the noisy chamber and the handle of the walnut hammer split, throwing the heavy head to the floor with an extra crash. Undaunted, the ever businesslike Barrett continued. ``There are those of you who are concerned that your priority bills may not be handled, and that's entirely possible, even likely,'' he said. ``I ask you to exercise self-discipline. The clock is running very rapidly. I ask you to use discretion and pull amendments you might have to bills ... use some restraint in asking to be excused from the floor. ``Consider your colleagues in these final few days,'' he said. He cautioned that the last few days could be long. ``I ask for your consideration. The session still has some possibilities,'' Barrett said. Attempting to lighten things up, he added, ``I do this in a spirit of Christian love and all that. We're all concerned. I had hoped I wouldn't have to give this speech this year.'' On Thursday, after he raised the meat cleaver, lawmakers decided to work through the lunch.

DOC.HEAD: Chances Are IRS Will Give You the Right Answer _ If Your Call Is Answered
DOC.TEXT: IRS employees are answering correctly 78 percent of telephoned tax questions they address this year but barely one-third of calls are being answered at all, government auditors said Thursday. The accuracy rate is up significantly from 66 percent last year, the General Accounting Office told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee. But at this time a year ago, 61 percent of callers were getting through to the IRS, compared with 34 percent this year. ``It makes me sick'' that taxpayer service has declined, IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. told the subcommittee. He blamed a budget squeeze and a sharply higher number of calls for the problem. Goldberg said service will deteriorate further and tax collections will suffer unless Congress approves the full $6.1 billion IRS budget that President Bush proposed for the 12 months that begin Oct. 1. ``If they cut our budget $200 million, it's going to cost the federal government $550 million in 1991,'' Goldberg said. Further overhaul of the IRS' 1960s-era computers is essential, he said, and the 1991 budget will not make up for shortages of previous years. ``I am afraid that the tax system will continue to pay the price of the 1989-1990 hiring freeze and failure to provide adequate training and support for our employees for years to come,'' Goldberg said. Goldberg and Jennie S. Stathis, tax-policy director of GAO, an arm of Congress, agreed that the IRS is having a generally successful return-filing season despite a lack of money. Ms. Stathis cited these figures: _GAO telephoned 20 tax questions to 29 IRS offices and scored 1,261 responses; 78 percent were correct. _Through March 17, taxpayers had called the IRS 31.5 million times and the IRS had answered 10.7 million of the calls. During a similar period last year, the number of attempted calls was far less _ 19.3 million _ but 11.8 million were answered. _Chances of getting through on the first try have dropped to 55 percent from 69 percent last year. _Processing of returns is 12.5 percent ahead of last year's pace; returns received are up 3.5 percent; the number of refunds is up 16.7 percent. _The number of returns with taxpayer errors or IRS processing mistakes is dropping, from 16 percent last year to 14 percent this year. The IRS says taxpayers are responsible for about six of every 10 errors. _IRS forms and publications are more readily available this year. A check of 13 walk-in sites found 10 were missing five or fewer of 82 required items; the worst case was one site missing eight items. _Ordering forms and publications by phone can be as troublesome as telephoning a tax question. But once a caller connects, the IRS is prompt in mailing requested items within the promised 14 days. The agency is not as reliable for items ordered by letter. Members of the Ways and Means subcomittee were concerned that the percentage of taxpayers being audited continues to decline, to only about 9 per 1,000 returns this year. ``Congress may be forced to mandate a minimum audit level,'' said Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, chairman of the panel. Goldberg argued against any minimum level but said that with a larger budget, the IRS might be able to boost the current level to about 13 per 1,000 by 1993. He noted that about 40 million individual returns, whose incomes are solely from wages, interest and dividends, receive the equivalent of an audit every year through a computer matching program. The commissioner said the IRS computer system and a complex tax law are imposing an intolerable burden on the public. ``The greatest challenge of the coming decade is to make the system more workable for the tens of millions of taxpayers who are willing to pay what they owe, but cannot abide the complexity, uncertainty and administrative hassles they face in complying with the law and in dealing with the IRS,'' Goldberg said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS fifth item to UPDATE with Mondale quote from magazine article; MPLS.ST.PAUL is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Eleanor Mondale, daughter of the former vice president, resigned from her job as a TV entertainment reporter just days before a local magazine was due to publish an article called, ``Walter and Joan's Wild Child.'' Ms. Mondale denied she was forced out after only eight months at WCCO-TV, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported Thursday. ``I'm not upset,'' she said Wednesday. ``I had to make some decisions on how I want to live my life (with) people in my face.'' ``The resignation is definitely her choice,'' said WCCO news director John Culliton. ``She may have a lot of reasons mixed in there about how she feels about us, but it is her choice.'' ``There is a lot of nervousness at WCCO about what it says and how it portrays her,'' said MPLS.ST.PAUL magazine editor, Brian Anderson. ``I've done a lot of stuff,'' Ms. Mondale is quoted as saying in the article. ``I like to get wild. But it's not murder, and I don't do drugs. I hear stuff about me dating everyone in town, and that's really unfair. I'm new in town, I'm single, and my job is to know this city and know people. So what am I supposed to do? Never go out?'' ``I think she's portrayed very positively,'' Anderson said of the article that hits the streets next week. ``It looks at her career and some of the rumors about her and her performance.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Newspaper Reveals Soviet Role in Katyn Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Wartime records concealed for decades show that Soviet secret police, not German invaders, murdered thousands of Polish officers in the Katyn pine forest of western Russia, a newspaper reported. The weekly Moscow News used information from official records in a two-page article about the Katyn Forest massacre, one of the grisliest chapters of the Stalin era. Official Soviet accounts have said it was the Germans who mowed down the cream of the Polish officer corps, held prisoner just south of Smolensk. Articles published previously have demanded the truth about Katyn, but none documented the Soviet role in the deaths of thousands of Poles. Katyn fostered a deep distrust of the Soviets in Poland, even during the four decades it spent as a client state of the Kremlin. A Polish-Soviet commission investigated the massacre but did not issue a formal report. Moscow News concluded the Polish officers were killed in the spring of 1940, well before the Germans invaded the region, not in 1941 as the official version has claimed. ``Familiarity with the whole set of documents allows one to come to the conclusion that the Polish officers and police were shot in April and May by units of the NKVD,'' a precursor of the KGB, it said. The article was based on research by historian Natalia Lebedeva. Hitler's army invaded western Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, starting World War II. Weeks later, the Red Army marched into eastern Poland and remained there until the Germans pushed them out in 1941. The newspaper indicated up to 15,000 Polish officers were killed when the NKVD evacuated three prison camps. Most estimates of the number of victims at Katyn hover around 4,000. Lebedeva's reference apparently was to a general operation that included execution sites other than the forest. ``Soon I came to understand that this was not a coincidental action but a well-thought-through and carefully planned operation,'' said Lebedeva, who used central national archives and Soviet Army records in her research. She said it appeared the camps were needed to hold thousands of people who would be deported from the three Baltic states _ Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia _after Soviet troops moved into them. The Soviet Union absorbed the Baltic republics, to the northwest of Katyn, in 1940 under a secret agreement with Germany that divided Eastern Europe into Soviet and German spheres of influence. In the past year or two, Katyn Forest has become a pilgrimage site for Poles and a group calling itself Families of Katyn Victims has thousands of members. Lists published in the Moscow News implicate dozens of Soviet secret police, army and government officials in the massacre, including Stalin and Lavrenti Beria, head of the NKVD. Stalin appeared to have held a special grudge against the Polish officers, the article said, because ``his vanity was hurt'' by the Polish defeat of Soviet troops two decades earlier. Lebedeva said older archivists told her the NKVD tried to take over the Katyn files in the 1940s, but failed. She acknowledged finding the name Katyn only once in the files, but said the routes to the points where mass graves have been found were laid out clearly. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland has said the full story of the massacre must be told if there to be true friendship between Poland and the Soviet Union. A monument at the site of the mass grave in Katyn gives the official Soviete version of events, honoring the ``victims of fascism _ Polish officers shot by the Nazis in 1941.'' The Germans found the mass graves in 1943 and immediately blamed the Soviet Union, but the Soviets said the Nazis murdered the men in 1941, during the German march on Moscow. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, established the commission of Soviet and Polish historians in 1987. Last year, the Polish members said documents indicated there was no doubt the Soviets were responsible for the Katyn massacre.

DOC.HEAD: Government Unions Reject Performance Payment Idea
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of the three largest unions representing government employees criticized on Thursday a Bush administration proposal to link pay raises to job performance. ``I believe that we have been performing since 1977 without any consequent pay,'' said Robert M. Tobias, president of the 140,000-member National Treasury Employees Union, after testifying before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. The committee is considering legislation by Committee Chairman John Glenn, D-Ohio, aimed at closing the gap between lower-paid government workers and their higher-paid counterparts in private industry. A 1989 report by the government puts the gap at 29 percent. Tobias was referring to a 1970 law that requires the administration to keep federal salaries in line with private pay. A Congressional Research Service Report that was released at the Glenn hearing said the ``process broke down in 1978.'' Tobias testified, and the report said, that Presidents Reagan and Bush have consistently authorized amounts lower than recommended by the Labor Department, Office of Management and Budget and Office of Personnel Management. ``As a result I can't trust the administration to come up with a fair and just pay-for-performance situation given its past behavior,'' Tobias said in the interview. Bush said Thursday that he has not formally approved the proposal to link raises to performance. But he said the notion has his ``strong support.'' The OPM, which handles personnel matters for the federal bureaucracy, plans to ask for congressional authority to do away with the ``step'' salary system that awards a pay increase every year, OPM spokesman Richard McGowan said Wednesday night. James N. Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees, and James M. Peirce, president of the 150,000-member National Federation of Federal Employees, both said the notion of pay-for-performance has been around for a long time. ``We thought we were going to have some substantive proposals from the administration to reform federal pay,'' said Sturdivant in an interview after his testimony. ``Instead we basically get warmed-over proposals that ... have nothing to do with the pay problems were dealing with.'' Elaborating on his committee testimony, Sturdivant said the administration cannot improve pay for federal employees without budgeting money for increases. The administration, he said, has been taking pay out of agency budgets. ``You can't reform the federal pay system without putting more money into it,'' he said. ``And basically what they're saying is, `We're going to reform it but we're going to save money.''' Peirce said a merit pay system exists to reward performance. ``All we need to do is follow what we're supposed to be doing and we'll have it, pure and simple,'' he said. The administration proposal would divide government employees into two classes: one covering professional and administrative workers and the other including technicians and clerks, McGowan said. Technicians and clerks would get annual step increases until they reach the average local salary for their jobs, after which they would have to win merit increases just like professional and administrative employees. Federal pay ranges from $10,600 to $87,000 a year and is generally uniform regardless of whether an employee lives in Boston or Cleveland, on the East Coast or in the Midwest. Glenn has introduced legislation that would make government pay comparable to private pay, index annual raises to an employment cost formula, and assure that the budget earmarks money for pay.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Congress to Back $35 Million for Tree Planting Projects
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked Congress Thursday to approve a $35 million National Tree Trust to promote community tree planting projects and ``knock Johnny Appleseed out of the Guinness Book of Records.'' Bush publicized his legislation by joining his wife Barbara at a ceremony to plant a tree on the South Lawn of the White House. Bush sent Congress legislation to implement part of his ``America the Beautiful'' proposal that seeks $175 million overall for a National Tree Planting and Forest Improvement Program. The program's goal is to plant 1 billion trees a year on private lands. The private foundation the president proposes would use $35 million in federal funds and would help raise private contributions for tree preservation and planting projects. Other parts of the tree plan include use of Agriculture Department technical resources to help state forestry agencies and others plant and maintain trees in rural and urban areas. ``By planting trees in all 50 states, we'll knock Johnny Appleseed out of the Guinness Book of Records,'' Bush said at the tree-planting ceremony. He planted a eastern red bud blossoming tree near a sturdy tree planted by President Eisenhower in the 1950s. Bush noted the enviromental benefits of trees, saying his act would plant trees to help clean the air, prevent erosion, consume carbon dioxide and purify the water. ``This act can preserve the heritage of trees: their beauty that is breathtaking, and their bointy that is breathgiving,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Airport, Eagles on Collision Course
DOC.TEXT: A pair of bald eagles is on a collision course with Denver's new $2.3 billion airport, and conservationists say the eagles and 330 other bird species that nest at Barr Lake State Park could be in danger. Conservationists and wildlife officials want Denver International Airport to establish a buffer-zone nature sanctuary to prevent houses, offices and shops from sprouting up on its northwestern fringes near Barr Lake. The airport, which opens up in 1993, won't pay. ``We don't feel we should,'' said airport director Bill Smith. ``We aren't adding anything to the problems in the area, and we're not increasing any problems that exist.'' Wildlife experts are surprised that the birds chose to nest just 18 miles from downtown Denver, and 3 miles northwest of the airport. The eagles were the first on record to nest and to colonize on the Rocky Mountains' eastern slopes in 1986. Previously, the eastern Colorado Front Range served only as a resting stop for eagles migrating south from Canada toward Mexico, New Mexico and Texas for the winter. The birth of two eaglets last year drew numerous bird watchers. The eaglets later flew off, and wildlife officials are hopeful they will soon return to nest. ``There are only 10 bald eagle nesting sites in the whole state, and only one along the Front Range,'' said Mike Carter, director of the Colorado Bird Observatory. ``Don't airport officials understand the principle of the straw that broke the camel's back?'' Carter worried that the airport will destroy a unique opportunity for the endangered bald eagles to grab a foothold if it refuses to help out. If the worst happens, the construction of the airport's fringe developments would at least enable observers to document the destruction of a bird refuge, he said. ``There have been very few studies with 80 to 90 years of records, and this could be our first chance to document these changes,'' Carter said. ``I don't see that as a benefit. This could destroy 100 years worth of resources.'' The airport already has concluded in a $35,000 study that, because of the airport's noise regulations, incoming planes won't pose a threat. But construction near Barr Lake may drive the birds away, Carter said. Barr Lake Park is made up of 2,000 acres of water and two narrow strips on land on each side that measure 700 acres. Wildlife records from the area have been kept since 1909, and 330 species are documented. Warning signs prohibit entry to the eagles' nesting area, and violators face a $20,000 fine and a year's imprisonment. But outdoors enthusiasts can cross a narrow ridge and watch the birds through binoculars. The Denver Audubon Society and Colorado Department of Natural Resources wants the airport to put aside some of its discretionary funds for wildlife conservation to buy a 2,000-acre buffer zone around the lake, or buy development rights to prevent construction there. The land's cost has not been determined. ``All the buffer zone will do is keep developers away from the lake,'' said its chairwoman, Polly Reetz. ``In addition to the eagles, we have a lot of animals that move in and out, and raptors that hunt in fields adjacent to the park.'' Carter, of the Colorado Bird Observatory, would prefer a wildlife sanctuary on the airport grounds, a 2,000-foot-wide zone stretching from the airport to the nearby Rocky Mountain Arsenal, which already serves as a wildlife refuge. Denver planners are negotiating with the Army, which owns the arsenal, to move fences and allow bike trails in the area to take advantage of Arsenal wildlife, which include antelope, deer and coyotes. The airport is being constructed to replace Denver's Stapleton International, one of the nation's busiest. It will occupy 50 square miles, and its main terminal will be heavily landscaped with greenery to promote the image of an oasis on the Plains. Indoor waterfalls and fountains also are planned. Carter said that without action, development will occur around the lake because of plans to complete a beltway around Denver. But he thinks the state and conservation groups should share with the airport the cost of protecting the birds and other wildlife. Park spokeswoman Carol Leasure said farmers and landowners should not be penalized if airport-fringe developments are deferred. ``We want to see that they're fairly compensated, too,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Probes Transer of Soviet Missiles to Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: The United States is investigating the possibility that Soviet SS-23 medium-range missiles, banned by a 1987 treaty, may have been illegally transferred to Czechoslovakia, the State Department said Thursday. The department earlier had disclosed it is looking into the possibility that SS-23 missiles may also have been transfered to the East German armed forces. Spokesman Richard Boucher said the key question is whether the missiles, if any, were transfered before or after the signing of the Intermediate Nuclear Forces or INF treaty in December 1987. If the weapons were transferred before the treaty was signed by former President Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev they are not covered by the pact, Boucher said. If they were transferred after it was signed, the transfer violates the treaty, he said. ``That's the point that we're looking into,'' Boucher said. ``I don't have a judgment on that. That's the key point as to whether they are covered by the treaty or not, whether they were transfered before or after. And that's where we have to satisfy ourselves in order to make a judgment.'' ``We've asked the Czech government for further information on the possible presence of SS-23 missiles in Czechoslovakia,'' Boucher said. ``As we've said before, we regard this as a serious matter.'' The treaty applies to U.S. and Soviet medium-range missiles and specifically prohibits the transfers of such weapons after the treaty was signed. He said the United States has raised the question of the possible illegal transfer and possession of banned medium-range missiles not only with the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and East Germany but with certain other nations as well. He did not identify them. Asked if the Soviets had ever pledged not to transfer missiles before the treaty was signed as a gesture of good faith, Boucher said the department is ``still analyzing records of the discussions.'' Although Boucher said the United States is not prepared to disclose how many suspect missiles may be involved, The Washington Times reported that the Czech government told the United States two weeks ago that more than 70 SS-23 missiles with a range of about 310 miles are deployed within its territory and are being dismantled. The INF treaty bans all U.S. and Soviet missiles with a range of between 300 and 3,400 miles. The possible presence of prohibited SS-23 missiles in East Germany and Czechoslovakia has caused alarm among administration officials who fear the incidents could damage prospects for succesfully ratifying a treaty making sharp reductions in long-range, intercontinental missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Drug Lowers Death Risk After Heart Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Verapimil sted verapimil in grafs 2, 5, 9, 10 and 11
DOC.TEXT: A drug that eases the heart's workload can cut the risk of new cardiac attacks and death by 20 percent in people recovering from heart attacks, according to a major study released Thursday. The study, conducted in Denmark, found that the drug Verapamil, known as a calcium channel blocker, was effective for the 1{ years after a heart attack. Calcium blockers are among several classes of medicines commonly prescribed to relieve high blood pressure. ``This is the first trial that indicates that a calcium blocker may be beneficial after an acute myocardial infarction,'' or heart attack, said Dr. Carl J. Pepine of the University of Florida. Several other studies of calcium blockers, including one large U.S. study published last year, failed to find any benefit from using the medicines after heart attacks. According to the Danish study, Verapamil is about as effective as another variety of blood pressure medicines known as beta blockers at protecting people after heart attacks. While calcium blockers may not replace beta blockers after heart attacks, the researchers said these drugs still should have a role in treatment. ``We feel it is important to have alternatives. Many patients do not tolerate beta blockers,'' said Dr. Kresten Mellemgaard of Central County Hospital in Hillerod, Denmark, a co-author of the study. Beta blockers are generally not recommended for people with asthma and emphysema. This means the drugs often cannot be given to cigarette smokers, who are frequent victims of heart attacks. In the study, conducted at 20 community hospitals, doctors compared 897 patients who got Verapamil after heart attacks with 878 people who took placebos. After 18 months of followup, there were 146 deaths or recurring heart attacks among the Verapamil patients, compared with 180 in people who got the dummy medication. ``We wanted to see if an effect would be observed with Verapamil,'' said Dr. Forgen Fischer Hansen of Copenhagen Municipal Hospital. ``If it had an effect, it should be seen in the first 12 to 18 months, because there is a big increase in mortality in myocardial infarction in this period,'' he said. ``Then it levels off. That's what we demonstrated. It worked.'' The researchers believe that by reducing the amount of work needed by the heart to sustain circulation, calcium blockers lowered the chances of ischemia, episodes in which the heart's own muscle is deprived of oxygen. They said they were unsure why earlier studies failed to show any benefit from calcium blockers after heart attacks. However, they noted that some studies enrolled patients who were also taking beta blockers. And this might have obscured any benefits from calcium blockers. The results were presented at a meeting of the American College of Cardiology. Among other research described at the meeting: _Dr. James H. Chesebro of the Mayo Clinic said a five-year study found that aspirin does not stop the continued buildup of existing blockages in the arteries feeding the heart, although it may modestly protect against the development of new deposits. However, like other studies, this one found that aspirin signficantly cut the risk of heart attacks. _Dr. Eugene Braunwald of Harvard Medical School said the next phase of a large study of clot-dissolving drugs will see what effect they have in unstable angina. This is a condition in which people suffer spontaneous chest pain that is not triggered by work or stress. Until now, the drugs have been used only to treat heart attacks.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Participation in New `Marshall Plan' Hinges on Soviet Role
With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is counting on the Soviet Union to limit its borrowing from a development bank being proposed to finance a Marshall Plan-type rebuilding of Eastern Europe, administration officials said Thursday. The administration has said the United States will participate in the $12 billion European Bank for Reconstruction and Development only if Soviet borrowing is limited to what Moscow contributes in capital and then only for loans to develop private enterprises. Under Secretary of the Treasury David Mulford said the Soviets are aware of U.S. concerns after meetings between the top finance and banking officials of the two countries here last week. He said the administration was eagerly awaiting counterproposals from Moscow before an April 8-9 meeting in Paris to put the final touches on chartering the $12 billion multinational development bank. ``We've said that if the Soviet position cannot be worked out, we will not join the bank,'' Mulford told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee. ``Our ability and willingness to make any further compromises would be extremely limited and perhaps nonexistent.'' The administration already has made several concessions in establishing the bank. When the idea was first proposed in January by French President Francois Mitterrand, the United States wanted a $5 billion bank devoted solely to lending for private enterprise in Eastern Europe _ with the Soviet Union excluded from participation. In six negotiating sessions since then, administration officials have bowed to allowing the proposed bank to lend 40 percent of its funds for government infrastructure improvements such as roads. The administration also has softened its demand that the borrowing countries must turn state-run enterprises such as utilities into private businesses to qualify for loans financing their improvement. House Democrats have criticized Bush's insistence on a diminished Soviet role in the bank as a continuation of ``Cold War politics'' that will only decrease U.S. ability to shape events in the region and freeze American companies out of the newly freed markets. In the Senate, Democrats have muted their criticism while including $1.2 billion as the United States' 10 percent share of the new bank as part of legislation to provide $2 billion in new aid to seven East European countries. ``There are going to be big problems up here on the Soviet issue,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. and chairman of the Senate Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee, told Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on Thursday. ``Frankly, it's going to happen whether we join or not and we need to be in on it if we are going to influence how things go over there.'' While both Brady and Mulford expressed optimism that an accord can be reached for U.S. participation in the European bank, new challenges to it surfaced Thursday from the president's own party. Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., said he and Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas would introduce a bill to, instead, establish a new facility in the World Bank devoted to lending for private enterprise in Eastern Europe. ``The U.S. should boycott the Eastern European bank altogether if the bank's charter allows any Soviet borrowing,'' Kasten said. ``This bank will be dominated by European policy makers ... (who) still believe that socialism can be reformed ... and that government action raises living standards.'' Brady expressed skepticism at Kasten's plan, saying the United States would have less leverage both politically and economically under such a scheme. He also acknowledged that a bank without a U.S. role could become a public relations fiasco for the administration. ``Could you imagine what the headlines would read all over the world'' if the United States pulls out of the bank? Brady asked at one point.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill Two Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians in the West Bank city of Nablus on Thursday, firing on them when one pulled out what appeared to be a grenade, an army spokesman said. The object turned out to be a tear gas canister, the spokesman said. Witnesses told Arab reporters an army unit fired on the men during a raid organized to capture Palestinian militants in the city's Casbah, a market area of twisting, narrow passages where activists in the 27-month Palestinian uprising often evade troops. Two Palestinians were captured in the raid, including one suspected in the deaths of seven Arabs accused of collaborating with Israel, the military said. The two deaths raised to 669 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. An army statement said an army patrol opened fire on the men after they refused orders to stop. ``One of the two killed drew a grenade and the other charged an (army) force. No weapons were found on them afterward, but they tried to attack the force,'' an unidenitified army officer said on army radio. After the shootings, masked youths stoned soldiers in the city of Nablus and three nearly Palestinian refugee camps. The army put Nablus and the camps under curfew, Arab reports said. Palestinians said soldiers also carried out a three-hour search of apartments and shops, dumping rice, sugar and flour on the floors of some homes and forcing families to stand outside. Also in the West Bank, Havakuk Levinson, a photographer for the Reuters news agency, was beaten by soldiers when he tried to photograph troops firing on stone-throwing youngsters in Ramallah. Nachman Shai, the army spokesman, issued an official apology for the attack. Arieh Goos, a reporter for Israel radio who witnessed the attack, said soldiers beat and kicked Levinson and shouted ``You have to kill all the journalists and then kill the Arabs!'' The Palestinians shot to death were identified by the army as Nasser Al Kaneer, 28, and Ibrahim Abu Ghadib, 19.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Mann Resigned Because WHO Chief Blocked Programs
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Jonathan Mann said in an interview published Thursday that he quit as director of the World Health Organization's AIDS program because his superior's attitude slowed or blocked work intended to combat the disease. ``The lack of commitment of the director-general in putting into action the world program in the fight against AIDS became a fundamental question for me,'' Mann was quoted as saying by the newspaper Le Monde. He said he was constantly confronted by an ``administrative wall'' in trying to carry out programs. On Wednesday, WHO named Dr. Michael H. Merson, another American, as Mann's replacement. Mann headed WHO's program on acquired immune deficiency syndrome since 1986. In his March 16 letter of resignation to WHO's director-general, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, Mann cited ``a great variance between our positions on a series of issues,'' but he did not elaborate.
