The outgoing director was quoted by Le Monde as saying the 61-year-old Nakajima's attitude ``completely paralyzed our efforts.'' ``Today, it is practically impossible to translate words into concrete action,'' Mann contended in the interview. ``The action of the director-general is not at the level of the principles established by WHO,'' Mann was quoted as saying. Mann, 42, said he believed WHO should play a leadership role on the issue of access by all AIDS patients _ not just those with the economic means _ to medication. He noted that in Brazzaville, Congo, a global commission on AIDS adopted such a program in May. ``Since then, nothing. So many times I begged the director-general _ I use the word by design _ so that he would take action toward this end. No, no, no reaction. Great principles are good, but one must know how to put them into action,'' Mann said. Responding to suggestions that competition between the two men may have been at the center of the conflict, he told Le Monde: ``Perhaps that is the case. All I know is there are other ways to avoid hampering the action of a global program for two years.'' When Mann joined WHO nearly four years ago, its AIDS program consisted of him and a secretary, with funds coming from the regular WHO budget. The program now has a staff of close to 200 people and a special budget that has tripled in the past three years to $109 million. He traveled widely to push a worldwide campaign to inform people of the dangers of AIDS and the methods of protection. Since the resignation was announced, Mann and Nakajima have declined requests for interviews with The Associated Press. In a statement last week, Nakajima said he regretted Mann's resignation. He said it ``happened without previous consultation at a time when the organization is confronted with new challenges concerning the fight against AIDS.''

DOC.HEAD: Whites Life Expectancy Greater Than Blacks, Report Shows
DOC.TEXT: High homicide rates, AIDS and lack of medical care are continuing to cut short the lives of black Americans, while the health of whites is improving, a government report said Thursday. While whites can expect to live to the age of 75.5, life expectancy for blacks is 69.5, and for black males it is 65.1, according to the study. ``This concerns us greatly,'' said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``We need to move toward equal health opportunity for our citizens _ including the good health information and the family and community support that will help every American make the right choices for health and productive lives,'' he said. Healthier living _ quitting smoking, using seat belts, reducing violence and eating more nutritiously _ is the key to improving health, since more than half the causes of premature death are related to lifestyle, he said. ``We have the data to show this pays off. This will have more effect than any of our (medical) research,'' he said. However, he added that while ``lifestyle changes are easily articulated as a goal, ... what we don't have enough information on yet is how do we most effectively get the information across and have people act on it.'' The study, Health United States 1989, is the 14th annual report of the health status of the nation. Overall, the country improved its infant mortality rate slightly to 9.9 deaths per 1,000 live births in 1988, although this rate still ranks the United States behind 21 other nations and the gap between whites and blacks is widening. White infants died at the rate of 8.6 per 1,000 live births in 1987, down 0.3 points from 1986. During the same period, the rate for black babies dropped only slightly and at 17.9 per 1,000 births is more than twice as high as for whites. Dramatic declines in deaths from heart disease, down 33 percent between 1970 and 1987, and stroke, which was cut in half during the period, contributed to the increased longevity of Americans. But the gains weren't shared equally: The decline was greatest among white men, 35 percent, followed by 31 percent for white women, 28 percent for black women and 24 percent for black men. And in 1987, the death rate for stroke was twice as high among blacks as whites. Health experts say the gaps are not always explained with behaviors, such as smoking, diet, homicide and other lifestyle factors. Indeed, studies show that regardless of the age, education or marital status of the mother and whether she had early pre-natal care, black woman are generally twice as likely to have a low birth-weight baby, a key factor in infant mortality, Sullivan said. Also, some of the disparity in deaths from stroke cannot be explained by lifestyle, he said. The decline in cigarette smoking is accelerating, Sullivan said. From 1985 to 1988, cigarette sales dropped about 2 percent a year, but decreased 6 percent from 1988 to 1989. However, from 1970 to 1987, lung cancer _ the leading cause of death among women _ increased by 31 percent for white women and 25 percent for black women. In 1987, homicide took the lives of seven times more black males than white males, while the homicide rate for black females was more than four times that for white females. Blacks were also lagging in the proportion of mothers receiving prenatal care in the first three months of pregnancy. For blacks, the proportion was 61 percent in 1987, compared with 60 percent for American Indians, 76 percent of Asian and Pacific Islanders and 79 percent for white women. A growing number of blacks are being diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, increasing from 25 percent to 29 percent of all AIDS cases between 1984 and 1988. As of last September, blacks made up 55 percent of all AIDS cases among children under age 13, and Hispanics accounted for 21 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pushes Bid to Aid Panama, Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Adds 4 grafs with comment on Contra demobilization
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, acknowledging congressional resistance to freeing $800 million for his Panama and Nicaragua aid program, urged lawmakers Thursday to let him make the Pentagon cuts needed to provide the money. He said several members of Congress have told him it would be difficult to get Congress to pass the aid package in the face of other budgetary priorities. ``But I am going to continue to reiterate the importance, not just to the United States but to the whole hemisphere, of the aid package that I have requested,'' Bush said. His request includes $300 million in economic assistance for Nicaragua, long suffering under a U.S. trade embargo.That includes $30 million to help resettle the U.S.-backed Contra rebels, who fought for a decade against the leftist government just voted out of office. The other $500 million would go to help Panama recover from the U.S. military invasion in December and the economic sanctions imposed by the United States against the regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush decried sentiments that aid to Panama and Nicaragua should take a back seat to helping the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. ``There are those that argue that Panama and Nicaragua are not as vital as Eastern Europe. They're wrong,'' he told a news conference. ``This is our hemisphere. And we have a strong aid program for Eastern Europe and will continue to do so. And we can do no less for our own neighbors.'' However, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign aid, has said that Congress should look at the president's request in terms of a choice between two small countries, on the one hand, or all of Eastern Europe, on the other. Bush said one senator told him, ``It would be a very difficult sell.'' ``I don't understand it,'' the president added, ``because I think the United States has a disproportionate role ... in the evolution of democracy'' in Panama and Nicargua. ``We've got a lot at stake in both countries.'' Bush sent Congress the aid request last week, saying that the money should be taken from the Defense Department budget. He directed his Office of Management and Budget and representatives of the Defense Department to negotiate with the defense appropriations subcommittees of the House and Senate on where the cuts should be made. So far no resolution has been reached. ``If we are unable to to resolve our differences regarding offsets, then I would be happy to have Congress authorize me to select the offsets from the defense budget in order to get economic assistance moving in the region,'' Bush said. Meanwhile, at the State Department, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher criticized the Sandinista government for refusing to allow Contra leaders to fly to Managua for discussions on demobilization and repatriation. ``We find this refusal inconsistent with the Sandinistas' own professed desire for national reconciliation and for a successful demobilization process,'' he said. Boucher said the rebel leaders want to arrange talks with church leaders and with aides to President-elect Violeta Chamorro but that the Sandinista Interior Ministry has not given them permission to enter Nicaragua. Thousands of Contra rebels remain at camps in Honduras near the Nicaraguan border.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Lithuania, Corrective
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0661 or a0702 of March 18, 1990 under a Moscow dateline are requested to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: In a report on Lithuania on March 18, The Associated Press erroneously said at least 1 million Soviet troops are believed to be stationed in Lithuania. Although the Soviet Union does not provide figures, many Western sources estimate the Soviet Union has 300,000 military, including naval forces, stationed in the entire Baltic region. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania said on March 22 an estimated 30,000 soldiers are stationed in Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: The Stuart Shooting Six Months Later: The Sounds of Silence
DOC.TEXT: The small white madonna is still nestled outside the brown-shingled duplex where Carol DiMaiti Stuart grew up and where her parents and aunt still live. But six months after her slaying, no one answers the door. The same is true a few miles away on Lowe Street in Revere, where the parents of Charles Stuart have maintained a silence about the horrifying crime that riveted the nation. Boston police, citing an ongoing grand jury investigation, have remained almost as closemouthed as the families. The case that took a shocking twist Jan. 4, when Charles Stuart apparently jumped to his death from the Tobin Bridge, remains a mystery. ``There are a hell of a lot more holes in this story than solid information,'' said Ken Englade, an Albuquerque, N.M.-based writer whose paperback, `Murder in Boston,' is due in bookstores at the end of the month. ``It doesn't help that nobody is talking.'' Englade said he was frustrated by the refusal of Boston police and Suffolk County District Attorney Newman Flanagan to disclose information about the case. They also have withheld medical reports. More baffling is the prosecutor's refusal to release tapes of the lineup where Charles Stuart allegedly identified William Bennett as his assailant. And even though life insurance money was thought to be Stuart's motive, only $280,000 in life insurance money was apparently taken out on his wife's life. The two $100,000 policies purchased by Stuart were ``barely enough to cover the mortgage on their house,'' Englade said. Carol Stuart was insured for $80,000 through her work. Based on his research, Englade said he is not convinced Stuart actually killed his wife or even if he jumped off the bridge voluntarily. He cited numerous contradictions in the case _ even in the hours before Stuart's apparent suicide when he left instructions with a hotel clerk to rouse him at 4:30 a.m. ``Who leaves a wake-up call to commit suicide?'' Englade asserted. The only person associated with the tragedy who is willing to talk is Carol's 37-year-old brother, Carl DiMaiti, a former high school teacher who has taken over the family's pizza dough business. He heads the scholarship foundation established in Carol's name for residents in Boston's Mission Hill district where she was shot. So far, the foundation has received more than $340,000. This week found him in a familiar setting: accepting a donation for the foundation at an inner city outreach center. He is usually accompanied by two public relations agent who monitor his remarks. DiMaiti said Thursday his family's ordeal has been eased considerably by their work with the foundation. ``I'm amazed that people have gone out of their way and responded like this,'' he said. ``It shows the deep well of goodness in people. It's been a very difficult time for us. This has especially helped my mother and father through a very tough time.'' Their ordeal began the night of Oct. 23 when Boston police received a frantic call over a car phone from Stuart. He said he and his wife had been shot by a black gunman who robbed them shortly after they left a childbirth class at a hospital in Mission Hill. Carol Stuart, a 30-year-old tax attorney who was seven months pregnant, was shot in the head. She died a few hours later after her son, Christopher, was prematurely delivered. The baby died 17 days later. Stuart, 30-year-old manager of a fur store, was shot in the stomach and remained hospitalized until December. His body was recovered from the waters of Boston Harbor the day after his younger brother, Matthew, told police he had been enlisted by Charles to aid in the crime. Since then, a grand jury has met seven times to hear testimony in the case, according to Dave Rodman, spokesman for the district attorney's office. Stuart's siblings and his mother have appeared before the grand jury. Sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said several witnesses are still scheduled to testify. The families have picked up the pieces of their lives in various ways. Carol's mother, Evelyn DiMaiti, 58, has returned to her job in a state office. Mrs. DiMaiti's husband, Giusto, 64, is retired but can often be found at the family bakery in nearby Chelsea. Charles Stuart Sr., who suffers from Parkinson's disease, and his wife, Dorothy, remain in seclusion at the home they share with sons, Matthew and Mark. Matthew reportedly still holds his job as a mixer at a paint factory and is a familiar figure on the streets of Revere in his stone-washed jeans and leather jacket. In addition to the soon-to-be published paperback, at least two hardback books and a CBS television movie are planned. Paul Corkery, a freelance writer and former editor of Boston Magazine, has rented an apartment in Revere to work on his book for Simon and Schuster. He said he has 50,000 words of notes, culled mostly from interviews with friends and relatives outside the two families. ``It's not a typical whodunit,'' said Corkery. ``It's the story of a hero who turned out to be the villain.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Princess, Early Fighter for Women's Rights, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Iranian Princess Safiyeh Firouz, an activist for women's rights in her country under the Pahlavi dynasty, died this week and was buried Thursday, family members said. She was 87. The princess, widow of Prince Mohammad Hussein Mirza Firouz of the Qajar dynasty, died after being hospitalized Monday night with heart trouble, a family member said. She was interred outside the French capital, where she had lived in exile since the 1979 Iranian revolution. Princess Firouz fought in the 1940s for the right to vote for Iranian women, at one point leading a march on the Majlis, the Iranian Parliament. Opposed to wearing the veil, she established the Council of Women in Iran in 1943. The princess' husband, a general, was the grandson of Qajar King Muzaffar ud-Din Shah. The dynasty was overthrown in 1925 by Reza Shah, father of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and founder of the Pahlavi dynasty. The dynasty was toppled by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in 1979. Prince Mirza Firouz died in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Remark Did Not Affect Events in Israel
With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday denied that a remark by him had affected events in Israel, where the government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir fell last week. ``I do not think it contributed to the fall of the government. These are highly complex, internal matters in the state of Israel,'' Bush told a news conference on the White House lawn. His comment March 3 about Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem touched off a firestorm of controversy because U.S. officials have previously shied away from including East Jerusalem when complaining about Jewish settlements in the West Bank area. Bush, however, told reporters that ``the foreign policy of the United States says we do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or in East Jerusalem.'' He was asked Thursday if that statement had contributed to destabilizing the Shamir government or the overall peace process. ``I don't believe it made a contribution because I think if you look at the issues, both the domestic economy and the question of the peace talks, that those were the key issues in the campaign. Because most people in Israel understood that I was simply reiterating a standing United States policy, one that I feel very strongly about,'' Bush said. Most anaylsts believe his remark about East Jerusalem disrupted progress in the fragile talks on Middle East peace. A key issue in trying to get Israel to the table with the Palestinians has been who can represent the Palestinians and whether some should be from East Jerusalem and the occupied West Bank. Prospects for the talks are up in the air because political crisis in Israel following Shamir's fall in the parliamentary no-confidence motion last week. Shimon Peres, head of the left-leaning Labor Party, is trying to form a new government.

DOC.HEAD: Add Energy to What Students Don't Know
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to energy education, most students know only how to save it, a poll showed Thursday. The National Energy Education Development Project said a poll of 25,000 American students in 32 states found most characterized themselves as energy savers. Yet the results showed most of the students have great difficulty understanding and identifying such basic concepts about energy and the environment as estimated costs, efficiency factors, predominant uses and properties of the nation's various fuel sources. ``Students should know and care as much about the debate over clean air as they do Air Jordans,'' said Gerard Katz, director of the NEED Project. ``The assessment will provide a starting point so we can better educate young people to make informed decisions about the many complex energy issues facing our society.'' The poll _ described as the only census of its kind _ was released by the National Assessment Committee of the NEED Project to mark the 10th anniversary since Congress and the White House launched the project as a means to boost energy awareness among consumers. The 11-question survey involved 12,326 middle grade students and 11,921 high school students, as well as about 2000 educators from 15 states. Students consistently scored about 10 Hazelwoods,'' Devins said. The spill showed that industry does not have the technology to deal with oil spills of that magnitude, and that prevention must be stressed, he said. ``The bad judgment and behavior of Joe Hazelwood in the initial accident was eclipsed by the inept behavior, arrogance and bad judgment of Exxon in their cleanup effort,'' said Ann Rothe, Alaska regional representative for the National Wildlife Federation. It is Exxon that was to blame for the spill, not the captain, she said. ``They let a man who couldn't get a driver's license to drive an automobile captain one of their tankers. That's just negligence,'' said Rothe.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Strike Out in Different Directions in Search of Strategy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs Ron Brown statement after 9th graf pvs, Last year, Deletes last graf to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party officials, searching for a winning strategy in the shadow of President Bush's formidable approval ratings, are ready to endorse a cut in the Social Security payroll tax. A resolution to put the party on record in support of a proposal on that subject by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., is on the agenda Friday for the Democratic National Committee, meeting in Indianapolis. The resolution, pushed by Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, is part of a broad effort to persuade voters around the country that the Democrats are the party that represents the middle class. But, as usual, the party is far from united. The Democratic Leadership Council, dominated by elected officials, is gathering half a continent away in New Orleans with its own avowed purpose of setting the party's agenda for the 1990s and beyond. Before leaving for New Orleans, congressional Democrats released what they called ``The New Orleans Declaration.'' The statement of principles was aimed at moving the party from the left toward ``the mainstream of America,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the DLC. It also calls for a reduction in the Social Security payroll tax, but without specifically naming Moynihan's proposal. It also refers to another touchy issue, abortion, without mentioning it by name: ``We believe government should respect individual liberty and stay out of our private lives and personal decisions.'' Nunn said that was not a definitive statement on abortion ``but certainly points in the direction of people making their own choice on that.'' Last year, the party won several important races, including governor of Virginia, in campaigns emphasizing much clearer stands in support of abortion rights. Striving to present a united Democratic front, party Chairman Ronald Brown issued a statement from Indianapolis praising the declaration put out by those headed for New Orleans. ``The ideas and principles in this document put Democrats squarely on the side of working people,'' Brown said. ``On their behalf, Democrats are leading this nation's most important debate _ shaping and designing America's future.'' Officials of the DNC and the DLC insisted the scheduling conflict that saw both groups meeting on identical days was an accident. But the conflicting sessions reflected the internal struggle for the future of the Democratic Party. The Democratic Leadership Council was formed by elected officials, largely from the South and West, after Ronald Reagan's 49-state landslide re-election in 1984. The group's founders wanted a counterweight to what they saw as the leftward drift of the national party. The two meetings were certain to generate a lot of rhetoric but whether any voters would hear it or care was another matter. ``Too often Democrats miss the mark by talking in the language of the District of Columbia that is abstract and inside and doesn't affect people either intellectually or touch them personally,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md. Not only were the Democrats having trouble settling on a program that would attract voters, they also were at odds over whether they had anything to worry about. ``We've got real problems,'' said former party chairman John C. White. But Robert Beckel, a Democratic political consultant, said, ``It's amazing there's this much handwringing going on when I think things are trending considerably in the Democrats' direction.'' In the meantime, Democrats are hardly showing enthusiasm for the party's 1992 presidential nomination. At this stage in recent presidential campaigns, the Democratic field was already well established and crowded. Beckel said of Bush, ``They say he's 80 percent in the polls. If you don't take him on, he's gong to stay 80 percent in the polls.'' Pollster Peter Hart said Democrats who were making their 1992 plans based on Bush's 1990 poll ratings ``are making a dreadful mistake. It's all going to change.'' The Democrats' search for a message is typical of the agony of a party out of power in the White House, where the president can set the national agenda. ``They're having a very tough time because they don't have a well-known figure,'' said Charles Black, a Republican consultant. While the two groups hold their rival debates, the Democratic-controlled Congress has to deal directly with the president and his administration, looking to put its stamp on current issues. Moynihan's proposal was greeted with a flurry of criticism from the White House and many Democrats decided it was best to keep their distance. But the DNC has its eye on the voters, and in Moynihan's plan those Democrats sniff an issue that just might catch hold.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plea to Soviets: Don't Use Force on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Cheney warning, Bush desire to go to Australia by end of year; tops with 4 grafs and subs 15th graf, Responding to
DOC.TEXT: President Bush implored the Soviet Union Thursday not to use force to block Lithuania's secession, but also urged the breakaway republic to recognize ``certain realities'' of Moscow's control. Commending the Kremlin for dealing peacefully with changes in Eastern Europe, Bush said, ``Please continue to exercise that kind of restraint. And remember _ no use of force.'' He said both sides should negotiate their differences. Separately, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said any resort to military might ``would do great violence'' to the reforms being championed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The president's comments came as Soviet armored personnel carriers and trucks drove through the Lithuanian capital in a show of force. Bush declined to criticize Gorbachev for demanding that Lithuanians surrender their guns. ``They should talk about that,'' Bush said. Bush also refused to say how he would react if force were used. ``What possible good would come from the president of the United States, standing halfway around the world, speculating on something that he doesn't want to see happen.'' He issued his plea for restraint during a 20-minute news conference on the White House lawn. Bush stood beneath a towering oak tree and next to a flowering eastern redbud tree that he and his wife, Barbara, had just planted. Commenting on two days of talks with visiting Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Bush said there was no need for Soviet troops to be stationed in Poland or anywhere else in Eastern Europe. ``And the sooner they get out of there, the better,'' he said. Bush acknowledged ``a nuance of difference'' with Mazowiecki over the prime minister's demands that the two Germanys sign a treaty guaranteeing Polish borders before they unite. But he said the Poles and Germans ``are very, very close now'' to an understanding that the current borders must remain intact. On another sensitive foreign policy issue, Bush disputed contentions that he contributed to the fall of the government of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir with comments linking Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem with those in the West Bank and Gaza. ``Most people in Israel understood that I was simply reiterating a standing United States policy, one that I feel very strong about.'' On other issues, Bush: _Said he wants a treaty to cut Soviet and American troops in Europe to be ready by the time of his summit this summer with Gorbachev in Washington. Another oficial said Bush had meant to say he wanted to have a strategic-arms treaty ready by the summit. Bush said the summit date had not been set but should be pinned down soon. _Said he will not attend the April 25 inauguration of U.S.-backed president-elect Violeta Chamorro in Nicaragua but wants to visit the country sometime. Responding to another question, Bush said ``I'm dying to go'' to Australia and wants to make the trip before the end of the year. He declined to say he would go to New Zealand during such a trip, noting U.S. unhappiness over its refusal to permit American warships carrying nuclear weapons in its waters. _Refused to discuss Texas Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams' concerns about running against a woman. Calling himself an expert on the subject because of his race against Democrat Geraldine Ferraro in 1984, Bush said, ``I know exactly what he means and I refuse to elaborate on it for fear of complicating his life.'' _Prodded Congress to speed approval of $800 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua. In recent days, the United States has expressed concern about Soviet moves in Lithuania, which declared independence from Moscow on March 11 after the ruling Communists were removed from power in free elections. However, the United States has not extended formal diplomatic recognition, saying Lithuania does not control its territory. In his remarks, Bush noted that the United States had never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania or the other Baltic states of Estonia and Latvia into the Soviet Union in 1940. ``However, there are certain realities in life,'' Bush said. ``The Lithuanians are well aware of them. And they should talk, as they are, with the Soviet officials about these differences.'' He said he was pleased that Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had said Moscow would not use force. ``It is very important that force not be used,'' Bush said. ``But I believe that they can talk and work out these problems.'' Asked if he thought Gorbachev was guilty of intimidation by demanding that Lithuanians surrender their arms, Bush said, ``I would prefer to put emphasis on his statement that there will be no use of force. And that's where I'm going to keep the emphasis and keep reminding every party to this discussion over there _ no use of force.'' Meanwhile, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said that Moscow's order to tighten visa controls in Lithuania and expel foreigners ``contradicts the Soviets' commitment to a more open society and to contact between countries.'' ``We're concerned by the order to have internal security and secret police troops seize private sporting guns unless they are surrendered,'' he said, adding that the Soviets are trying to suggest there is a threat to public order from Lithuanians. ``We believe, however, that the Lithuanians are committed to a peaceful resolution of their differences with the Soviet Union. The Lithuanian people have shown their commitment to non-violence and democracy,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Tryptophan Recall Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about L-tryptophan dietary supplements, which have been linked to a blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS: _SYMPTOMS: Breathing difficulties, cough, skin rashes of varying severity, swelling of the extremities, joint pain, muscle weakness and fever. In some instances, there might be signs of congestive heart failure and paralysis. _USES OF L-TRYPTOPHAN: Insomnia, premenstrual syndrome, stress reduction, appetite control, depression, and others. _MANUFACTURERS: Two largest are P. Leiner Nutritional Products Corp. in Torrance, Calif., and Pharmavite Corp. in Arleta, Calif., according to the Council for Responsible Nutrition. Both the FDA and an official at P. Leiner said a list of brand names could not be provided because hundreds of products were invovled. Large manufacturers had taken the products off the market before Thursday's expanded recall, the council said.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Maintained Stoic Demeanor, Silence Throughout Trial
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, AM-Hazelwood Verdict
DOC.TEXT: He is not as notorious as Captain Bligh or Captain Ahab, but Captain Joseph Hazelwood, former skipper of the Exxon Valdez, has sailed unwillingly into America's lore of the sea. While cartoonists sketched him as a liquor-swigging villain and TV comics parodied the infamous grounding of his ship, the passionately private Hazelwood returned to Alaska this winter, a year after the nation's worst oil spill, determined to clear his name. ``I'd like to get rid of the misconception that I got drunk, ran the ship aground and just shrugged my shoulders and walked away, because that's just not what happened,'' he said after the grounding of the Exxon Valdez had tarred his reputation along with hundreds of miles of rocky shore. On Thursday, a jury found Hazelwood innocent of the most serious charges against him, convicting him only of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He faces up to 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. He was acquitted of charges of second-degree criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only person charged criminally in the environmental calamity. He was accused of being drunk on duty and being away from the ship's bridge when it rammed a charted reef. He came back to Alaska with some trepidation and kept a low profile outside court. Many nights he stayed in his hotel room watching old movies about sea captains rather than risk being recognized in public. In court, the balding, bearded Hazelwood sat mute, watching in stoic silence as his crew members told their stories. His demeanor was not unusual. Joe Hazelwood had always been a man of few words. ``His actions always spoke louder than his words because his words were not that many,'' said attorney Michael Chalos, Hazelwood's former maritime college classmate who put together his defense team just days after the Exxon Valdez grounding made headlines. In school, says Chalos, the low key Hazelwood was ``a natural leader ... very quiet but very determined.'' He was captain of the lacrosse team and did well academically, Chalos recalls, but was something of a rebel when it came to military authority. His rebelliousness later would bring him into conflict with Exxon executives over company policies. When he graduated from New York State University Maritime College at Fort Schyler, Hazelwood signed on with Exxon Shipping Corp. ``It was a plum appointment,'' recalls Chalos. ``If you got a job with Exxon, you'd made it.'' He rose in the seagoing ranks, obtained his master's license, won the fleet award for efficiency in 1986 and, in 1987, was given command of the brand new Exxon Valdez, the most advanced, high-tech vessel in the Exxon fleet. He rarely spent more than three or four months at a time ashore. But between voyages he returned to Huntington where he and his wife, Suzanne, live with their teen-age daughter, Alison. ``I get stark crazy when I am too far from the salt water,'' he has said. If there was a fatal flaw in Hazelwood's smooth history of achievements, it was his drinking. He lost his New York motor vehicle driver's license after two drunken driving convictions and in 1985, with Exxon's knowledge, he went through a 28-day voluntary alcohol rehabilitation program. Was he drunk aboard the Exxon Valdez on the fateful night? His crew members testified they saw no signs of intoxication although they had seen the captain put away a few drinks in town. His blood alcohol reading was .061 in a test taken 10{ hours after the grounding. Evidence was inconclusive on what his blood alcohol was earlier. Hazelwood, true to his taciturn nature, chose not to testify and never commented on the intoxication issue. Why didn't he testify? Attorneys said they were confident about their case and did not want to subject Hazelwood to unnecessary, grueling cross-examination. They had another reason, too. ``Sitting here at the defense table, he's still the captain, someone special,'' said Chalos. ``If he had gotten up on the witness stand, he wouldn't be special anymore. He'd be just another witness.''

DOC.HEAD: 17 Killed in Northern India Avalanche, Flash Flood
DOC.TEXT: An avalanche and flash floods in northern India have left at least 17 people dead, including 10 border guards, a government spokesman said Thursday. The border guards, on routine patrol in Budgaon village in Kargil district, and a civilian were buried under an avalanche late Wednesday in the remote mountainous area of Jammu-Kashmir state, said the spokesman who cannot be identified under briefing rules. Kargil is 150 miles northeast of Jammu, the state's winter capital. The spokesman also said a bus was swept away by flash floods Thursday morning at Bilol Nala near Jammu, and six passengers drowned. Witnesses said another five also were feared drowned but there was no immediate confirmation. The spokesman said three people survived. The bus was going from Jammu to Katuha when a rivulet, gorged with four days of rain, burst its banks.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Convicted of One Minor Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines bulletin series. Picks up 4th graf a0676, `The panel ...'
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood was acquitted today of three major charges and convicted of one misdemeanor in the nation's worst oil spill. The single charge of which Hazelwood was convicted _ negligent discharge of oil _ carries a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, far less than the 7\ years and $61,000 fine he could have faced. There were bursts of applause in the court room as Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone read the first three verdicts of ``not guilty.'' Hazelwood's lawyers patted him on the back, and for the first time in the long trial, the normally solemn defendant smiled broadly. The jurors, delivering their verdict two days before the first anniversary of the disaster, absolved Hazelwood of all charges alleging that he was drunk and reckless when the tanker ran aground, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound. The jurors reached their verdict after only 10{ hours of deliberations. Earlier, the jury signaled they were close to a unanimous decision by deciding to skip going out to lunch. They ordered food sent into the jury room so they could continue their talks through the lunch hour. But at noon, Johnstone emerged from his chambers and told reporters the panel has reached its verdict. The panel, which ended its first day of deliberations Wednesday without reaching a verdict, sought a series of blood alcohol charts and graphs used by a defense expert to illustrate his testimony. Johnstone, after conferring in a hurried session with attorneys, sent the jury a note saying: ``You have received all of the evidence. The exhibits you have requested are not in evidence.'' The jurors returned to their task today, checking in promptly at 8:30 a.m. A bailiff escorted them to their jury room and they began their talks for a second day. The trial is in its seventh week. Meanwhile, an alternate juror who was dismissed once the regular jury began its deliberations told the Alaska Public Radio Network she would have acquitted Hazelwood of all charges. Terry Turner, an Anchorage bookkeeper, said she doubts the skipper was drunk while in command. ``There were 21 witnesses who said there was no sign of impairment,'' she said. She added that she believed Hazelwood had expected ``a normal transit'' of Prince William Sound on the night of the March 24 grounding, which might explain his decision to leave the ship's bridge. Asked whether she believed Hazelwood was drunk, she said: ``No, I don't think he was. ... There was a lot more to it than that we had a drunk captain running into a reef. They really didn't have evidence of it.'' Ms. Turner said she felt Hazelwood's loss of his job and the impact on his life was sufficient punishment for whatever role he had in the disaster. ``I don't think he was totally to blame,'' she said. ``I hope a lot of the other jurors feel that way.'' Saturday will be the first anniversary of the disaster, in which the 987-foot tanker rammed the charted reef in Prince William Sount, gushing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil. The spill wreaked devastation on birds, fish and wildlife, and coated hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. The exhibits sought by the jury Wednesday were used by defense lawyers during the trial to help illustrate testimony by Michael Hlastala, a physiologist who discussed blood testing for alcohol. They showed the various absorption and burnoff rates of alcohol in the human body. Defense attorney Dick Madson said the charts were not placed in evidence because jurors might have been unable to decipher them without the accompanying testimony. Hlastala of the University of Washington in Seattle had branded as ``nonsense'' prosecution efforts to figure out Hazelwood's blood alcohol level based on a blood test taken 10{ hours after the March 24 grounding. The prosecution sought to prove that the fired Exxon skipper was drunk when his ship went aground at Bligh Reef while Hazelwood was below. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony, second-degree criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could receive 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted. The jury's note disclosed that they chose an insurance broker to serve as forewoman in deliberations. The jury includes homemakers, a real estate agent, an accountant, a postman and an air traffic controller. Johnstone said he would allow the jurors to continue their talks over the weekend if they should fail to reach verdicts by Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Banking Committee OKs Money-Laundering Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House Banking Committee on Thursday approved plans designed to crack down on banks that allow themselves to be used in the money-laundering operations of drug pushers. ``Money is the vehicle that drives the drug trade,'' Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said as the committee approved the bill 48-0. The measure would require federal regulators to hold a hearing on whether to close any bank convicted with its directors and officers of money laundering or related offenses. The charter could be revoked or regulators could appoint a conservator to operate the bank. Federal officials already have the power to close banks convicted of money laundering. However, the hearings outlined in the bill would set the machinery in motion, sponsors said. Lawmakers have expressed heightened concern about money laundering, under which huge drug profits are hidden by transferring them through Caribbean tax havens and other centers of banking secrecy before they are returned to the United States and invested in legitimate businesses. A similar bill was introduced in the Senate on Wednesday. ``Banks that knowingly handle dirty drug money should not be permitted to do business in this country,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. Gonzalez described the House plan as a compromise that would not only punish those who ignore money laundering but also provide due process for bankers. He hailed Reps. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., Thomas R. Carper, R-Del., and Bill McCollum, R-Fla., for working out a compromise. Annunzio cited estimates that worldwide drug profits could total $300 billion a year. ``The vast quantities of cash may provide drug dealers with their greatest vulnerability to detection,'' he said. ``The drug dealer is caught in a never-ending blizzard of cash every day.'' The bill calls for removal of bank officials convicted of money laundering or structuring transactions to evade requirements of the Bank Secrecy Act. Those convicted would be prohibited from affiliating with other financial institutions. The measure would require the Treasury Department to establish regulations aimed at halting money laundering by wire transfer. It would raise the fine for negligent non-compliance with money-laundering reporting requirements from $500 to $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
ANCHORAGE, Alaska: late Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: After a year of accusations against faceless villains _ Exxon and oil-related agencies _ the Hazelwood trial provided a human side to the Exxon Valdez calamity, focusing on frailties of captain and crew. Although 150 civil suits were filed and Exxon was indicted in federal court, Hazelwood was the only individual charged criminally. His lawyers complained he was a ``scapegoat'' in a disaster with many culprits. His trial in Anchorage Superior Court had the elements of an engrossing sea story with a dark subplot involving liquor, troubled crew members and a star-crossed captain whose battles with the bottle were well known. But the skipper, who had been painted as a liquor swigging brigand, turned out to be a quiet figure intent on nothing more than blending into the woodwork. He sat back, stroking his beard, while others addressed the trial's key questions: Was the skipper drunk on duty and was he reckless to leave the ship's bridge? Whether Hazelwood was drunk when his ship grounded remained a muddled issue because authorities failed to do a timely blood alcohol test. When they got around to it 10{ hours after the grounding, Hazelwood had a .061 alcohol reading, lower than the Alaska standard of .10 for drunken driving. A prosecution expert witness tried to calculate backward and concluded that Hazelwood had a blood alcohol reading of .14 when the ship grounded. But defense experts ridiculed the figures as ``nonsense,'' saying results could not be conclusive because there was too long a wait before the test and too many variables, including whether Hazelwood drank after the grounding. Hazelwood, who chose not to testify, never explained. In six weeks of testimony, witnesses came forward to tell what they knew of the day the Exxon Valdez and Hazelwood sailed into history. It was the Thursday before Good Friday, and the tanker had pulled into its namesake port of Valdez to pick up a load of oil. Hazelwood went ashore for lunch with two crew members and a local pilot; they remember that he sipped iced tea. Then they separated to do shopping. Later in the day _ the hour remained in dispute _ Hazelwood met with his pals at the Pipeline Club, a bar where they said he drank three vodkas in about three hours. A woman patron of the club, wife of a Coast Guard investigator in the case, placed Hazelwood there much earlier, drinking for seven hours. But her testimony never was corroborated. On the way back to the ship, the men stopped and bought pizza for the crew, and Hazelwood had another drink, either beer or vodka. When they arrived at the Valdez terminal about 8:20 p.m., they learned that the sailing time, originally set for 10 p.m., had been moved up to 9 p.m. The prosecution would maintain that Hazelwood's tardiness in boarding his ship showed recklessness. Was the skipper intoxicated? He showed no signs of it. During the trial not a single witness said he appeared drunk. ``Did he stagger?'' defense attorneys would ask. ``Did he slur his words?'' Inevitably, the answers were, ``No.'' Pilot William Murphy, who guided the tanker through the Valdez Narrows, said he noticed a trace of alcohol on Hazelwood's breath. After a half-hour on the bridge, he said the skipper went below and remained there for an hour. When Murphy left the ship at about 10:30 p.m., he conferred with Hazelwood: ``I reminded him there was ice reported ahead.'' The crucial period, recounted repeatedly in testimony, began at 11:53 p.m. when Hazelwood decided to leave the bridge in control of third mate Gregory Cousins after discussing maneuvers that would take the Exxon Valdez out of shipping lanes to avoid ice, then turn back to the lanes before leaving Prince William Sound. ``He asked if I felt comfortable with what we were going to do and I said, `Yes,' recalled Cousins. ``He said, `Do you feel comfortable enough that I can go below and get rid of some paperwork?' I said I felt very comfortable.'' The prosecution would note that Cousins did not have the special endorsement Hazelwood had for piloting in Prince William Sound, a license the defense claimed was mere formality and had been waived by the Coast Guard. At the helm was Robert Kagan, a seaman who had problems with steering in the past. Many witnesses would blame Kagan for ramming the oil-filled tanker into a charted reef. Cousins said he ordered Kagan to make a 10-degree right rudder turn, a routine order. But he failed to check until it was too late to see if the turn had been made. By then, the Exxon Valdez was steaming toward Bligh Reef. Ten minutes after Hazelwood left the bridge, Cousins glanced at the rudder indicator and, ``I could tell we hadn't turned. ... I think Mr. Kagan didn't really understand the command.'' Cousins called Hazelwood in his cabin. ``I told him that we were getting into serious trouble ...,'' the third mate recalled. ``That was then we suffered the first shock and we were hard aground.'' Deep holes were gashed in the ship's underbelly. She was impaled on a rock the size of a Volkswagen, and warm oil was bubbling into the cold, clear waters of Prince William Sound. In all, the ship belched out nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil in a hemorrhage that killed countless birds, fish and wildlife on the richly populated sound. The rocky shore turned black for hundreds of miles. ``What's the problem?'' a Coast Guard investigator asked Hazelwood upon boarding the crippled ship. ``I think you're looking at it,'' said the captain in a comment which planted the idea that the skipper was accepting blame. His lawyers would say that was his training talking _ a captain always takes responsibility for his ship. One issue which consumed half the trial was whether Hazelwood, in the frantic moments after grounding, tried to drive his ship off the reef. He denied it, but prosecutors tried to show he risked capsizing the tanker and killing the crew. The issue became moot when the defense proved the ship was immovable, and the judge agreed Hazelwood could not be convicted of trying something that was impossible.

DOC.HEAD: List of Charges Against Hazelwood
With PM-Hazelwood Trial, AM-Hazelwood Verdict
DOC.TEXT: Here are the four charges on which the Joseph Hazelwood jury returned verdicts: _Second-degree criminal mischief, a felony. Alleges that the defendant ``created a risk of damage to the property of others in an amount exceeding $100,000 by widely dangerous means, i.e., the spilling of crude oil.'' Maximum penalty: five years in prison and-or $50,000 fine. Innocent. _Operating a watercraft, the Exxon Valdez, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Maximum penalty: one year and-or $5,000. Innocent. _Reckless endangerment. Alleges the defendant ``did recklessly engage in conduct that resulted in the Exxon Valdez being run aground on Bligh Reef and created a substantial risk of serious physical injury to another person.'' Maximum penalty: one year and-or $5,000. Innocent. _Negligent discharge of oil. Alleges that on March 24, 1989, Hazelwood ``did unlawfully and negligently discharge, cause to be discharged or permit the discharge of petroleum into or upon the waters of the State of Alaska.'' Maximum penalty: 90 days and-or $1,000. Guilty.

DOC.HEAD: Trading MX for SS-24 A Piossibility
DOC.TEXT: A senior Pentagon official on Thursday refused to rule out giving up the rail-garrison MX nuclear missile if the Soviets give up their SS-24 missile as part of the negotiations to reduce strategic weapons. ``This is obviously a serious proposal advanced by serious people and needs to be given serious consideration,'' Stephen Hadley, assistant secretary of defense for international security policy, told a House Armed Services subcommittee on defense policy. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of both the subcommittee and the parent committee, criticized the Bush administration's current proposal in U.S.-Soviet strategic arms talks, the START talks, that would keep the B-2 stealth bomber and two land-based nuclear missiles. Aspin and subcommittee members of both parties warned that the chances were slim of Congress approving all 132 B-2 bombers the Air Force wants as well as future funds for two missiles _ the single-warhead Midgetman on the drawing boards and the rail-mobile, multiple-warhead MX missile now deployed in underground silos. ``We're not going to buy 132 (bombers) and I maintain it's not a responsible position for the U.S. government to pursue arms control based on buying 132,'' said Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio. ``I can't tell you how many we're going to buy; I can't tell you the plane's going to work.'' Aspin asked Hadley and Lt. Gen. G.L. Butler, director of strategic plans and policy for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, for their opinions of a scenario in which the Untied States had 15 B-2 bombers and no Midgetman or rail-garrison MX missiles. ``I don't want to leave the impression here that we walk away from START,'' Hadley replied. ``If there are some things that disrupt that linkage then we have to go to the bottom line, take a look and see if there are some adjustments.'' Aspin replied: ``Save some time and make the adjustments now Steve, ... trade on the missile,'' to get rid of the Soviet SS-24. Earlier, Aspin had suggested trading the Soviet's SS-24 missile for current U.S. plans to move the MX missile to railroad cars, and pressed Hadley for a response. ``There are a lot of proposals and ideas that are being considered. A lot of them around town. This is obviously one of them that's being offered and will be considered seriously,'' Hadley said. Aspin later pressed the officials about possible revisions in the nearly 10,000 Soviet targets the United States would likely attack in the event of nuclear war. Citing unclassified information, Aspin said the sites are 2,000 nuclear targets, 1,600 conventional weapons targets, 4,400 economic targets and 750 aimed at the Soviet leadership. The chairman stressed that with the reduced threat from the Soviet Union, the target number should be changed. Hadley said the targets are reviewed regularly. But Aspin said the number remains constant and ``is being used up here to argue for the B-2.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Gold Mine Accident
DOC.TEXT: Ore carts careened out of control in a gold mine west of Johannesburg, killing five miners and injuring a sixth, officials said Thursday. Gold Fields Ltd. said the accident at the Deelkraal gold mine in Carletonville occurred about 1{ miles underground, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuits Blooming In Wake Of L-Tryptophan Blood Disease Problems
With AM-Tryptophan Recall, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Randy Simmons is a quadriplegic because he tried what he thought was a safe, non-prescription food supplement to deal with pain and sleeplessness, his lawyers say. The food supplement was L-tryptophan. The 41-year-old owner of a small accounting company is one of more than 1,400 people nationwide who contracted a rare blood disorder, eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome or EMS, after taking the product once touted in vitamin catalogs as ``nature's tranquilizer.'' Researchers at the federal Centers for Disease Control have recorded 19 deaths. Simmons and dozens of others have sued retailers, suppliers and manufacturers of the amino acid, which has been on the market for years. Cases of EMS started showing up last summer, but experts say the problem previously may have been misdiagnosed. CDC has reports of 1,411 cases in all 50 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. California has the most cases with 239. New York has reported 140. Twelve states have more than 30 cases. They are: Texas, 72; Ohio, 72; Florida, 71; Minnesota, 63; Oregon, 61; South Carolina, 53; Pennsylvania, 52; Arizona, 46; Washington, 43; Colorado, 38; Illinois, 38; and New Mexico, 33. L-tryptophan was recalled by the Food and Drug Administration in November. On Thursday, Louis Sullivan, Health and Human Services secretary, issued a strong warning against continued use, calling the EMS outbreak a ``major public health problem'' and warning that even small doses of L-tryptophan could be harmful. Simmons is surviving thanks to a machine that breathes for him and a feeding tube that runs into his stomach. He has limited use of his right arm and hand, but his mental faculties are sharp and he still has feeling in his body and limbs. His prognosis is uncertain. ``We've talked to quite a few of the lawyers handling these cases nationwide and we haven't heard of another case as serious'' in an EMS survivor, said Arden Bradshaw, Simmons' attorney. Bradshaw has filed suit in Sedgwick County District Court seeking unspecified damages from six businesses _ retail stores and their suppliers for brands of L-triptophan that Simmons took over the years. Four to six Japanese manufacturers made the food supplement. Some investigators believe most of the people who have been stricken with EMS took L-tryptophan that can be traced to one manufacturer. The CDC has not pinpointed the source of the problem. One lawyer handling L-triptophan cases, Gayle Troutwine of Portland, Ore., argues that Showa Denko Co. of Japan is responsible for the outbreak because its product became contaminated. A suit filed by Troutwine last month on behalf of Helen Jones, 52, of Portland also claims Showa Denko has refused to cooperate with U.S. officials investigating the supplement. At the time the lawsuit was filed, Shotaro Kawakatsu, a spokesman in Japan for Showa Denko, noted that the FDA was investigating the illness and said the company was awaiting the results of the study. Kawakatsu said his company had exported L-trytophan to the United States but declined to say how much. Showa Denko is not named as a defendant in Simmons' suit. Bradshaw said he is still doing research to determine what company or companies manufactured the products his client took. L-tryptophan was touted as an aid for problems including high cholesterol, high blood pressure, tooth pain and depression. Simmons began taking it about 2{ years ago because he was having trouble sleeping, in part because of recurring pain from injuries suffered in a 1983 auto accident. Simmons found he was able to sleep better, but last September, he realized something was very wrong. He was losing weight _ eventually, more than 80 pounds _ and experiencing severe muscle pain. Doctors looked for cancer, parasites and other diseases before finally diagnosing EMS, which is characterized by an abnormally high white blood cell count. On Nov. 6, Simmons went to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., for treatments that included chemotheraphy and a blood cleansing process. He's now back in a Wichita hospital; it hasn't been determined whether the effort stopped his decline. Linda Simmons, his 35-year-old wife, said her husband has been too ill to become angry about his situation. But she has fought depression and other problems as she struggled to take care her husband of seven years, their son, 3, and their daughter, 1. ``I've had a good deal of anger about it,'' she said. ``But there are no boundaries or definitions for what's going on. What should I be angry at?''

DOC.HEAD: Singer Undergoes Successful Surgery For Broken Back
LaserPhoto NY55
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan, whose back was broken when her tour bus was hit by a truck, underwent successful surgery Thursday to have her spine stabilized with metal rods, a doctor said. Dr. Michael Neuwirth, an orthopedic surgeon, said he implanted two steel rods onto Estefan's fractured vertebrae during a four-hour operation. He expects her to make a full recovery in three to six months and to be released from hospital in a week to 10 days. ``She'll be able to do everything, including dance,'' Neuwirth told reporters at Manhattan's Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases. ``We were able to accomplish all our initial goals of surgery, which was to restore the normal line of the spine and remove the pressure that existed against the spinal cord.'' Estefan, 32, of the Latin-pop band Miami Sound Machine was flown to New York by helicopter Wednesday from a hospital in Scranton, Pa. Also recuperating from serious injuries in the crash was her personal assistant, Jelissa Arencibia, who was being treated in Pennsylvania. In an interview, Ms. Arencibia recalled the moments after Tuesday's crash in the Pocono Mountains. ``I heard her voice screaming out for mine, but there was nothing I could do,'' the assistant said. Known for her energetic dancing on stage, Estefan felt numbness and weakness in her legs after the crash. Doctors said that, besides being fractured, the two vertebrae were slightly dislocated. During the surgery, monitors recorded ``substantial improvement in the electrical conduction of the nerves to her left leg,'' Neuwirth said. The singer will need to undergo therapy and wear a plastic brace when she leaves the hospital, he said. Her husband, Emilio Estefan Jr., thanked the doctors and fans for their concern and support. ``I don't care if she never danced again,'' he said. ``I'm just happy she's alive.'' He suffered minor injuries in the accident and appeared at the hospital news conference with a bandaged right hand. Their 9-year-old son, Nayab, broke his collarbone. The Cuban-born singer and her group were headed to Syracuse for a concert when their tour bus was struck from behind by a tractor-trailer on a highway near Tobyhanna, Pa., authorities said. Estefan was thrown from a couch where she was sleeping. Pennsylvania state police said Thursday that an inspection of the truck showed it had faulty brakes. The trucker was cited for driving at an unsafe speed and will face additional charges, police said. Fans sent dozens of floral bouquets and arrangements, which Estefan asked to be distributed to other patients. Well-wishers included President Bush, who met the Estefans on Monday to talk their anti-drug work, and singers Elton John, Madonna, Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi. The Miami Sound Machine has attracted listeners worldwide with salsa, samba and conga for more than a decade. Its hits include ``Rhythm Is Gonna Get You,'' and ``Anything for You.'' Estefan was nominated for a Grammy in February for ``Don't Wanna Lose You,'' a cut from her new album, ``Cuts Both Ways.'' Ms. Arencibia said from a hospital bed at Community Medical Center in Scranton that the accident ``happened so quick.'' ``I couldn't move. I was already paralyzed from my neck to my back and I heard Gloria screaming. I heard her voice screaming out for mine, but there was nothing we could do,'' she said, her voice cracking. She said they both struggled to help each other, but their hands wouldn't reach and their legs couldn't move. After a while, she said, they began to pray. Ms. Arencibia, 25, is listed as stable with broken ribs, neck and back injuries, but is not paralyzed. Shortly before the accident, the band was discussing the meeting with Bush. ``We were talking about the fact the day was so wonderful and how exciting it was to meet the president, and then Gloria and I decided to get a little nap,'' she said. About 40 minutes later, the women were hurled from their bus beds. Band members covered them with blankets because the windows of the bus were smashed and the temperature was near freezing. ``I've been wanting to talk to her,'' Ms. Arencibia said. ``I'm having a lot of trouble sleeping. I still hear her voice, her little voice inside my mind.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern, ALPA Agree to Interim Contract
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines and its pilots union have agreed to an interim contract that calls for a 25 percent wage cut, but does not call for rehiring pilots who went on strike, the company said Thursday. And the carrier insisted it needs twice that amount in concessions by the time the contract expires on July 1 to emerge successfully from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The wage cut applies to Eastern pilots still being paid at the pre-strike wage rate. Eastern had 3,600 union pilots who honored picket lines when a sympathy strike with Machinists began in March 1989. Since then, many pilots have returned, replacements have been hired at lower wages and the airline has sold many routes. Time to resolve the dispute ``regrettably has just about run out, in light of the reorganization timetable,'' said Thomas J. Matthews, senior vice president of human resources for the carrier, which is owned by Texas Air Corp. Eastern Air Line Pilots Association spokesman Edward Breen charged that the company intends to use the temporary agreement, which was negotiated with the help of the National Mediation Board, as a device to crush the union. He said by demanding more concessions in advance, Eastern hoped to push the talks into a final impasse. ``Their first preference would be to have the NMB put us in a cooling-off period,'' Breen said Thursday. ``After that, they can impose their own conditions.'' Breen said ALPA executives had agreed in principle to the contract, but it will not be signed until after a formal vote of the Master Executive Committee on Saturday in Washington. He said the union leaders reluctantly went along with the interim contract to show they were bargaining in good faith and to persuade the mediation board to pressure Eastern to do the same. The wage cuts applies to about 850 Eastern pilots still working at the pre-strike average of $72,000 a year. A 25 percent cut would bring that average down to $54,000. But it excludes about 950 replacement pilots hired at an average $27,500 when the strike began. The new wage levels are among the lowest in the country for major carriers, Breen said. ``An Eastern pilot after this will make about 50 percent of what a United Airlines pilot makes _ and they still can't make a profit,'' he said. There was no agreement on the key sticking point of hiring back more of the pilots who went on strike. ``The agreement does not cover that _ it covers only wages and benefits,'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said. ``And the simple fact is that no jobs are available now.'' The intertim agreement calls for a reduction in the airline's contribution to the pilots' pension plan, increased pilot contributions to their medical and dental insurance, and the preservation of tougher work rules in effect since the strike. Eastern insisted federal mediators would have to continue efforts to reach a permanent agreement to cut costs further. ``If expedited mediation is not successful in leading to such an arrangement, Eastern ... will have to promptly seek bankruptcy court permission to achieve full cost reductions on a long-term basis,'' Eastern said in its statement. Eastern's ALPA contract expired in June 1988, but its provisions had remained in effect under the Railway Labor Act. Eastern lost $282.6 million in the last quarter of 1989, bringing total losses for the year to $852.3 million, or almost all of Houston-based Texas Air's $885.6 million loss.

DOC.HEAD: Train Collision in Station Kills 5, Injures 50
DOC.TEXT: An express train rammed into another passenger train parked at a station near Halle on Thursday, killing five travelers and injuring about 50, the East German news agency ADN said. The express train was traveling between the northern port of Rostock and Dresden when it crashed into the other train at 4:45 p.m. in Groebers, near the southern city of Halle, the agency said. No other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Collider Will Provide New Information
DOC.TEXT: A pair of prominent physists who said the super collider would let scientists learn more about the Big Bang failed Thursday to win over some House Republicans who can't get past the project's Big Price. ``I find a number of Americans regard the (super collider) as a super-expensive super hole, money pit of the '90s,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. The $8 billion super collider is a 54-mile underground tunnel, to be built south of Dallas, in which streams of protons, guided by powerful electromagents, would be hurled into each other at almost the speed of light, breaking up into exotic smaller particles in the collisions. Tsung-Dao Lee, professor of physics at Columbia University, testified the high collision energy of the super collider _ 20 times what is available today _ would ``recreate the physical state that existed in our universe'' about one millionth of a billionth of a second after the Big Bang, in which scientists believe the universe was created some 20 billion years ago. ``Our aim is to understand that set of laws which governs everything,'' Lee said. The super collider ``makes a direct route toward achieving this understanding. It will be our contribution to the civilization of the next century.'' ``What I don't understand is why the physics community considers the (super collider) such an urgent project,'' Conte said. ``Have physicists run out of things to do?'' Conte also questioned whether the super collider would be obsolete before it's operational in 1998. Sidney D. Drell, deputy director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, said he did not think so. ``There's no way we can miss getting fundamental information,'' Drell said. Rep. Tom Bevill, chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on energy and water development, called the scientists to Capitol Hill to explain the importance of building the super collider as he seeks congressional approval of second-year construction funds for the project. Originally said to cost $4.4 billion, the Energy Department later increased the price to $5.9 billion and now says design changes and higher labor costs are pushing the total closer to $8 billion. Congress agreed to spend $225 million on the project in the current fiscal year and the Bush administration is seeking $318 million in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Rep. John Myers, R-Ind., ranking Republican on the Appropriations energy subcommittee, complained about the latest cost increase and said the collider, if it survives, ``can't survive another one. I think it could be jeopardized now.'' Opponents of the super collider have suggested the United States join a European consortium building another accelerator but Drell said that $1 billion collider would have one-third the science, one-third the energy, and would go one-third of ``the way we want to go'' with the super collider.

DOC.HEAD: AM-S&L Bailout, 1st Ld-Writethru,a0693,590
Administration Appeals Order Blocking S&L Acquisition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-14, beginning `The thrift...' with 2 grafs to ADD first references for Resolution Trust Corp. and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Picks up last graf pvs `He said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration asked a federal appeals court Thursday to dispel a legal cloud that could delay the president's savings and loan bailout and cost taxpayers millions of dollars. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision is appealing an order from U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth blocking the takeover of a suburban Chicago savings institution with $1.1 billion in assets. Lamberth sided with Olympic Savings and Loan Association, Berwyn, Ill., in ruling Wednesday that acting thrift office director Salvatore R. Martoche and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, were unconstitutionally appointed. Government attorneys said Lamberth's preliminary injunction could unleash a flood of similar challenges. They asked the U.S. Court of Appeals to stay the order and then consider their appeal on an expedited basis. ``Institutions that are rapidly losing money and fear that they might be placed into receivership are likely to follow Olympic's lead ... thereby ... adding millions of dollars to the already costly thrift crisis,'' the administration said in a memo to the appellate court. ``On a more sinister level, management that may be looting some thrifts may sue to block anticipated enforcement action,'' it continued. ``In short ... the district court's ruling places a cloud over the agency's authority to conduct its operations, a cloud that will likely have a profound impact on the (thrift office's) ability to deal effectively with the continuing thrift crisis.'' About 600 of 2,600 S&Ls nationally fall short of capital requirements and may eventually be seized. Late Wednesday, within hours of Lamberth's ruling, the parent company of Imperial Savings Association, a $10 billion thrift in California, asked the U.S. District Court in San Diego to overturn its Feb. 23 seizure. Franklin Savings Association, a large S&L in Ottawa, Kan., filed a similar suit last week in federal court in Topeka. Olympic contended, and Lamberth agreed, that Wall was improperly appointed when Congress dismantled his old agency, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and transferred many of its duties to the new thrift office. The S&L law automatically gave Wall the thrift office job. Lamberth said Wall should have been nominated by President Bush and confirmed by the Senate, as required by the Constitution. Bush appointed Martoche on an acting basis after Wall resigned March 5. Martoche had been confirmed by the Senate as an assistant secretary of the treasury and normally could temporarily fill in as thrift office director. In this case, however, Lamberth said Martoche cannot do that because he succeeded someone who had not legally held the job. The thrift office regulates solvent S&Ls, turning them over to the Resolution Trust Corp. when they fail. The RTC, created in August by the bailout law, has taken control of 402 S&Ls so far, disposing of 52 of them. RTC Chairman L. William Seidman said his agency's attorneys were studying the matter but said the two situations were different because the RTC is, in effect, a subordinate agency to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. He said RTC attorneys were also looking into whether the agency can proceed with sales of S&Ls already in government control, but he conceded that buyers may be wary, even if the RTC concludes it can.

DOC.HEAD: House Leaders Close To Agreement On Child Care Bill
DOC.TEXT: House leaders reported being close to reaching a bipartisan agreement Thursday on a bill to help families with child care, including care provided at church-sponsored centers. Closed-door negotiations between Democrats, Republicans and the White House cleared away most differences on the legislation, prompting both sides to hold out hope an agreement could be reached by next week. ``We are very close,'' said Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., one of the sponsors of a Democratic version. ``We've been hearing for some time we're just inches away _ just a smidgen away from agreement,'' said the House Republican leader Bob Michel, who was not participating in the direct negotionations. Rep. Clay Shaw, R-Fla., sponsor of a conservative alternative, called the progress toward an agreement between the administration, House Republicans and House Democrats ``nothing short of incredible.'' House Speaker Thomas Foley said the negotiations, if successful, would produce ``a landmark bill.'' He said House debate was scheduled for next Wednesday and predicted passage before the end of March. Competing versions of the legislation would expand tax credits to families for child-care expenses, provide vouchers for use by parents to subsidize care, and provide more aid for Head Start and other programs. Democratic leaders have yet to produce their version in writing. But in negotiations, they agreed to provisions permitting federal support go to church-sponsored day care centers, including those where sectarian instruction was offered. Congressional sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Democratic leaders also agreed to provisions sought by Republicans and conservative Democrats to require states adopt a program issuing vouchers to low-income families for child-care subsidies. In return, they were seeking Republican acceptance of a new program of before- and after-school child care based in schools. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu met again Thursday with House Democrats and Republicans in negotiating on the bill. Cost of the legislation was estimated at around $20 billion over a five years.

DOC.HEAD: Acid Rain Negotiator Promoted To Ambassador Rank
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday accorded the personal rank of ambassador to Richard J. Smith for his role as special negotiator for acid rain talks with Canada. Smith, 57, is a career State Department officer. The White House also announced the promotion of three policy aides to be special assistants to the president for policy development. They are: Lawrence B. Lindsey an economics professor on leave from Harvard University; Marianne McGettigan, a former legal aide to Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., and Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash.; and Stephen P. Farrar, a former National Security Council and Office of Management and Budget official.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Approves Ragsdale Abortion Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge approved a settlement Thursday that keeps the state from restricting abortions to women less than 18 weeks pregnant. U.S. District Judge John Nordberg agreed to the settlement between Illinois Attorney General Neil Hartigan and the American Civil Liberties Union. ``The court finds the proposed consent decree lawful, fair, reasonable and adequate,'' the judge wrote in the 13-page opinion. Anti-abortion groups opposed the settlement, calling it ``unconscionable and unconstitutional.'' Ragsdale vs. Turnock was settled Nov. 24, just days before the U.S. Supreme Court was scheduled to hear the case. It was one of several that anti-abortion groups had hoped would be used as a test case for the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. The settlement permits the state to regulate abortion clinics without removing the availability of abortions to women who are less than 18 weeks pregnant. Under the agreement, access to abortions cannot be restricted by substantially increasing the cost of the procedure or reducing the number of clinics. The lawsuit was brought by Rockford physician Richard Ragsdale, who objected to regulations requiring abortion clinics to be equipped and staffed like small hospitals. He said the regulation was a veiled attempt to restrict access to abortions. One of the requirements deleted from the settlement mandated that patients receive counseling about birth control and adoption and that counselors be people who wouldn't profit from abortions. The settlement also eliminated a requirement that all abortion clinics go through a public hearing process and obtain a ``certificate of need'' from the state verifying that they do not duplicate similar services in their areas.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Army on Alert After Soviet Troop Movements in Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sweden has put its military on a higher state of alert after reports of Soviet troop movements in the republic of Lithuania, defense officials said Thursday. ``There have been changes in the frame of our basic alert,'' which marginally increase the state of preparedness, said defense spokeswoman Kari Hansson. Among other measures, she said more pilots than usual were on call. Lithuanians complained of increased Soviet military activity after the republic declared itself independent from Moscow on March 11. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday ordered Lithuanians to turn in their firearms within seven days and Soviet armor rolled through Vilnius streets on Thursday. Civilian authorities on the island of Gotland in the Baltic Sea said they were preparing for a possible influx of Lithuanian refugees escaping by boat in case the situation deteriorates. Gotland, a summer holiday island for many Swedes, is 100 miles northwest of the Lithuanian port of Klaipeda. ``There is an unusual military activity in the Baltics right now,'' Maj. Gen. Bertel Osterdahl told national news agency TT. He said the Swedish defense was closely following the changes of deployments, including a paratroop unit in the Lithuanian city of Kaunas. ``There are already a total of 50,000 Soviet soldiers in the Baltics, '' he said. ``In Lithuania there is about 10,000 members of the national militia.'' Reports from Lithuania put the number of Soviet troops at 30,000.
