Osterdahl said the Soviet troop movements seemed to be a show of force, but added, ``The Baltics are so important for the Soviet Union that it would never give up its bases there.''

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Fearful After Ax Murder in Seattle Home
DOC.TEXT: People are buying guns, security systems and forming community watches in the neighborhood where an intruder hacked to death a woman in her home. Fear set in after the body of Geneva McDonald was found in her upstairs bedroom in the home she had lived in for 20 years. She was bludgeoned, and police said they believe the weapon was an ax. Officials know of three other incidents in days before her death in which a prowler or prowlers used axes or mauls to try to break into homes in the upscale Queen Anne Hill neighborhood, just north of downtown Seattle. ``I would love to move out of the city, the state, the country right about now, but I can't,'' said Lisa Hawes, 33, who lives with her husband and 2-year-old son four houses away. ``It's been a rough week up here. It's the buzz at all the stops you go _ the grocery store, the cleaners,'' she added. ``Right now this is not a fun place to be living.'' McDonald's two-story yellow house is roped off with police tape. Authorities believe the 63-year-old secretary for a shipbuilding company was killed as she slept during the night of March 11-12. Ten detectives are investigating and 10 officers cruise the neighborhood that had been patrolled by two officers, said Maj. Joe Tolliver, commander of the police department's criminal investigation division. Burglary is the only suspected motive but police haven't determined that anything was taken even though the house was ransacked. They're comparing fingerprints found at the house with those in a crime computer, checking the whereabouts of recently released convicts and trying to develop a profile of the killer. Police informed a crowded neighborhood meeting Tuesday evening about the progress of the investigation but did not yet have a suspect, Hawes said following the meeting. Tolliver said he couldn't recall another Seattle homicide involving an ax. But between March 1 and 3, someone used a wood-splitting maul in an attempt to break into a nearby condominium, smashing the knob on a storage room door. On March 4, a man living in a nearby home heard his basement door window being broken. He turned on a floodlight and frightened away the prowler, who left behind an ax. Hawes said the homeowner and his wife, both in their 80s, were so frightened they began staying with a relative. On March 9, a man in another nearby home awoke to discover his back door open and found an ax that had been on his back porch in his living room. Nothing was taken and police found no fingerprints. Right after McDonald's death, there was panic, neighborhood residents said. Then there was hope the killer knew his victim, which at least would mean there was no random psychopath terrorizing the neighborhood. There was no sign of forced entry. Police don't know whether McDonald, divorced and living alone, normally left doors and windows unlocked or hid a key outdoors. She had been the captain of a small block watch program among neighbors who shared the same alley, Hawes said. Some residents have bought guns, said a widow in her 60s who spoke on condition of anonymity because of fear of reprisal. Others have installed security systems. Many are organizing new block watch programs, with the help of police. ``Now there's no place to go _ no place to move in Seattle,'' the woman said. ``That creep will strike someplace else. ... He will do it again.'' Kirk Robbins, chairman of the Queen Anne Community Council, said he had not heard of particular person buying guns since the slaying but added that it wouldn't surprise him. Neighbors now say they have cleared their yards of dangerous tools. Exterior lights remain on all night. Families no longer leave keys hidden outdoors. ``We used to be able to leave doors open,'' Hawes said. ``Now you feel isolated, like your house is a fortress or something.'' McDonald had planned to retire soon, her neighbor said. ``She was the nicest, nicest woman,'' said Hawes. ``She was a great gardener, always throwing out botanical names and losing me. ``I try to remember Jenny walking down the street, not lying in bed butchered.''

DOC.HEAD: Plea Scrawled at Scene of Family Slaying: `God Please Forgive Me'
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old girl who squeezed through a dog door at her friend's house found the message scrawled in black crayon on the dining room wall: ``God please forgive me.'' Elsewhere, she found the bodies of an out-of-work single mother and her three children, all shot to death in what police described as an act of desperation by a woman overwhelmed by her marital and financial difficulties. The family dog also had been shot and killed. ``We're about 99 percent complete with the initial investigation and we're pretty sure what happened there was a murder-suicide,'' Detective Rick Swanston said Thursday. ``There isn't anything pointing in any other direction.'' Crystal Erickson discovered the bodies in suburban Reseda after school Wednesday afternoon. She also found a five-page suicide note by Roxanne Fernandez Jones, 32, who said she loved her children and hated to put them through living in a world full of strife, the Daily News reported. Investigators found Brandy Fernandez, 16, and her sister Leticia, 13, in their beds, each shot in the head and chest, Swanston said. Jeremiah Jones, 7, was shot to death in his mother's bed, and her body was found nearby with a small-caliber rifle. For police, the remaining task involves examining evidence and tying up a few administrative loose ends, Swanston said. But for Jones' relatives, friends and neighbors, there remain questions that may never be answered. ``People suffer behind closed doors,'' said Gloria Allred, an attorney involved in women's rights issues. ``It's a common problem with single parents after separation and before legal proceedings to be in a financial and emotional crisis.'' Jones had been receiving support from her first husband, Joaquin Fernandez, and she was recently separated from Jeremiah's father, police said. ``If there was an informal arrangement for him to pay some of the bills, I don't know,'' Swanston said. Studies by Harvard sociologist Lenore Weitzman have shown that single mothers tend to suffer the most in the first year after divorce, experiencing a 73 percent decline in their standard of living. By contrast, men typically experience a 42 percent improvement in living standards. Jones recently had stopped working for the Salvation Army and apparently had been unable to find steady work, friends and neighbors said. She had been baby-sitting and picking up odd jobs for extra money, and recently asked neighbors for small amounts of money. Brandy, her eldest, had contributed her pay from a pizzeria to help feed the family before she was laid off from her job a week ago, said her boyfriend, Derek Shelton, 18. ``Everything just wasn't going well for her,'' Lance Johnson, a neighbor and friend, told the Los Angeles Times. ``I can't believe she did this,'' said Joyce Pacheco, who lives around the corner. ``Roxanne never seemed depressed about anything.''

DOC.HEAD: News on the Health Front
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Includes AM-Tryptophan Recall, a0697; AM-US-Health, a0652; AM-Heart Attack, a0648; AM-Rare Monkeys Saved, a0645; AM-Beached Turtles, a0592; AM-Diet-Arteries, a0685. ^ By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Among the developments on the health front reported Thursday:

High homicide rates, AIDS and lack of medical care are continuing to cut short the lives of black Americans, while the health of whites is improving, a government report said Thursday. While whites can expect to live to the age of 75.5, life expectancy for blacks is 69.5, and for black males it is 65.1, according to the study. Healthier living _ quitting smoking, using seat belts, reducing violence and eating more nutritiously _ is the key to improving health, since more than half the causes of premature death are related to lifestyle, said Health and Human Sercies Secretary Louis Sullivan.

A drug that eases the heart's workload can cut the risk of new cardiac attacks and death by 20 percent in people recovering from heart attacks, according to a major study released Thursday. The study, conducted in Denmark, found that the drug Verapamil, known as a calcium channel blocker, was effective for the 1{ years after a heart attack. Calcium blockers are among several classes of medicines commonly prescribed to relieve high blood pressure.

The government expanded its recall of L-tryptophan Thursday because of fears that a sometimes fatal blood disorder can be caused even by small doses of the dietary supplement used for insomnia, depression and weight control. L-tryptophan is an amino acid that occurs naturally in some foods that are high in protein, such as milk, beef, turkey and beans. But it is also sold over the counter as a manufactured dietary supplement. It has been linked to a blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS.

Lowering the amount of fat in one's diet even by a little can go a long way toward reducing risk of developing new clogs in the arteries of the heart, say researchers who studied 82 middle-aged men. ``These were all free-living citizens who selected their own diet,'' said Dr. David H. Blankenhorn, director of the Atheroslerosis Research Institute at the University of Southern California School of Medicine in Los Angeles. The two-year study examined 82 middle-aged men who had undergone heart bypass surgery and were counseled to reduce their total fat consumption to 26 percent of total calories, including saturated fats, polyunsaturated fats and monounsaturated fats. In the typical American diet, fat accounts for 40 percent of total calories consumed. The results of the study were reported in Friday's Journal of the American Medical Association.

Alcohol is responsible for more than 100,000 deaths annually in the United States, stealing 2.7 million years from drinkers' lives, federal health officials reported Thursday. But while alcohol is a major health concern, more research is needed to determine which drinkers are at how much risk, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control said. In 1987, the latest year for which projections are available, 105,095 Americans died from alcohol-related causes _ either drunken injury or diseases linked to drinking, the CDC said. And when the victims' life expectancy was figured in, alcohol robbed them of more than 2.7 million years of life _ or about 26 years each.

A fire that threatened to destroy the world's first project to restore rare captive monkeys to the wild has been brought under control, saving the animals and their rain forest habitat, officials said Thursday. ``We were probably days away from the extinction of a species,'' said Benjamin Beck, associate director of the National Zoo in Washington. The National Zoo has been coordinating a project to breed the highly endangered golden lion tamarins and return them to the Poco das Antas reserve in Brazil, about 75 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro. Fire broke out about Feb. 2 at Poco das Antas, which is home to about 400 tamarins. They make up about 80 percent of the remaining wild population, Beck said.

A toxin similar to red tide could have caused the mysterious deaths of as many as 680 endangered sea turtles off Colombia, officials said. Only a few thousand adult Pacific green turtles are known to exist, so the beaching represents the loss of a substantial part of the population, said Jack Woody, national sea turtle coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in Albuquerque, N.M. Colombian fishermen attributed the deaths to a curse put on them for over exploiting the sea's resources, said Roderic Mast, director of species conservation at Conservation International in Washington. The turtles eat plant material, and some could have contained toxins, Mast said.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Keep Up in Romanian City Hit by Ethnic Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with crowd disperses, quotes from deputy prime minister, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of anti-Hungarian demonstrators rallied on Thursday for a fourth straight day of protest in this Transylvanian city where ethnic clashes have left seven dead and 300 wounded. They dispersed peacefully in the evening after Deputy Prime Minister Gelu Voican promised them that Transylvania would remain part of Romania. ``Nobody is going to take Transylvania away from us. Don't let yourselves be fooled by rumors,'' he told the crowd of about 3,000 as troops and tanks made a show of force on the Square of Roses, focal point of Tuesday night's carnage, when most of the casualties occurred. Earlier Thursday, about 3,000 Romanians and 1,000 ethnic Hungarians gathered at opposite ends of the square to shout slogans, separated by soldiers. Voican was in Tirgu Mures, a city of 165,000 northwest of Bucharest, to lead the central government's efforts to defuse the worst crisis since the December revolution. Long suppressed under former Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, the ethnic Hungarians have demanded greater autonomy and wrung some concessions from the current provisional government of President Ion Iliescu, including reopening Hungarian-language schools closed by Ceausescu. Many Romanians resent the concessions as favoritism. They believe that nationalistic ethnic Hungarians, supported by the Hungarian government, are trying to engineer the transfer of Transylvania to Hungary. Voican's committee of inquiry met with Hungarian and Romanian community leaders and then put together a communique, which Voican outlined in an interview with The Associated Press. ``The Hungarian side agreed that there could be no talk of secession,'' Voican said, adding that the communique contains a guarantee by the Romanian side to the Hungarians. He did not specify the nature of the guarantee. The communique called for an end to the work stoppages that hit nearly all major factories in the area on Thursday. It also provided for formation of a mixed commission to investigate all intercommunal complaints and settle them. But Voican said ``the final and definitive guarantees to both sides cannot be given until after the coming elections. Both sides have accepted that.'' Romania's first free elections since 1937 are set for May 20, and will establish a parliamentary system of government. Until then, the country will continue to be led by the Council of National Unity, an amalgam of the National Salvation Front that took power during the revolution and dozens of opposition parties that have sprung up or revived since then. Voican told the Romanians in the square, ``The representatives of the Hungarian people have gone on record that they don't want to secede from Romania.'' ``Liars, liars!'' the crowd roared back. He appealed for calm, and told the crowd, ``Conflicts can only be solved through dialogue.'' But emotions still ran high. In nearby Ungheni, former political detainee Ioan Hodos, a Romanian, told The AP, ``In this part of Romania, racial discrimination is just like in South Africa.'' History teacher Dumitru Botos, also a Romanian, said, ``People in the south of the country perceive things differently than we do here. They do not see the dangers posed by the Hungarians, who in fact want privileges.'' Mountainous Transylvania has about 2 million ethnic Hungarians and about 5 million Romanians. In Budapest, the capital of Hungary, the Hungarian government and political parties issued statements condemning the bloodshed in Tirgu Mures. The government statement accused the Romanian government of hesitating ``to take resolute action to put down the revival of chauvinism in Romania.'' It asked the Bucharest leadership to condemn the violence and protect ethnic Hungarians. Hungary ruled Translylvania for centuries before 1920 when the region was ceded to Romania by the victorous Allied powers in return for its siding with the Allies in World War I. On Thursday, the army appeared to be the only factor keeping the two sides apart in ths city, despite the presence of the commission of inquiry. ``The army is here to keep the peace. ... Without this no man's land, they would tear each other apart,'' said a captain of the parachute regiment that flew in Wednesday. He spoke on condition that he remain anonymous. The army has cordoned off the city, searching cars and checking identification papers of anyone entering.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Department Issues Ban on Capture of Bottlenose Dolphins
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has ordered a temporary halt to the capture of bottlenose dophins in the Gulf of Mexico as scientists attempt to determine the cause of an unusually high string of stranding deaths since early January. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced the ban on dolphin collections late Wednesday and said it would remain in effect through at least June 15. William W. Fox Jr., NOAA's assistant administrator for fisheries, said the National Marine Fisheries Service ``will not hesitate to obtain agreement for an extension of the non-capture period or to protect further the dolphins as the situation demands.'' According to NOAA, more than 190 dolphins have been stranded and died since Jan. 1 in five Gulf States _ 118 in Texas, more than 40 to 45 on the barrier islands of Louisiana and Mississippi, 21 in the Alabama-Florida panhandle, and 10 in Florida's Tampa Bay. The dolphins have been stranded at four to five times the usual rate for the time of year and the die-off continues, a NOAA spokesman said. Although cold weather is believed responsible for the deaths of 26 dolphins in Texas' Matagorda Bay, the NOAA spokesman said ``this thing could involve a number of reasons.'' Until the past week or so, adult dolphins have been the victims, but scientists are now watching to assess how the calving season will be affected. During the calving season, which began during the second week of March and goes into April, some pups and females die. ``We're going to try to keep as close track on it as possible. A number of tissue samples are in laboratories for analysis and we don't know how long it will take to analyze them or whether we'll be able to draw any sort of conclusions,'' the spokesman said. Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, the bottlenose dolphins are considered a protected _ but not endangered or threatened _ species. According to NOAA, 11 organizations hold permits to collect live dolphins, but only three do the actual collecting. The dolphins can be taken for educational purposes such as aquariums or marine-type theaters. The National Marine Fisheries Service contacted dolphin collectors for the 11 permit holders and they volunteered to suspend collections during the time period, Fox said. The quota on live dolphin collections was 91 last year and was to be 91 this year, although the government had considered reducing it to 35. ``Everything is on hold now,'' the spokesman said. ``They're not going to capture any dolphins until June 15 and there could be an extension,'' the spokesman said. ``A lot depends on whether the die-off continues, whether it slows down or halts. We have to figure out what caused the die-off.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Deny Misconduct in Espionage Case
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors denied they engaged in any misconduct in the espionage case against former FBI agent Richard Miller, saying a motion for dismissal of charges ``is wholly without merit.'' Miller, 52, was tried on espionage charges twice. The first trial ended in a hung jury in 1985. The next year, a jury convicted him of trading a secret FBI manual to Soviet informant Svetlana Ogorodnikov in exchange for sex and money. The conviction was overturned by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last April, and Miller was released on bail last October. His third trial is scheduled to begin July 10 before U.S. District Court Judge Robert M. Takasugi. Defense lawyers claimed in a motion filed in January that charges against Miller should be dismissed because prosecutors intentionally withheld information that could have benefited them. The nature of the information was not disclosed. But two Justice Department lawyers told the court in briefs filed Wednesday that the defense has conveyed ``a false sense of conspiracy and wrongdoing on the part of the government.'' Assistant U.S. Attorneys Russell Hayman and Adam Schiff described the defense motion as ``a rehashing of ... old issues with a new face'' that was ``wholly without merit.'' They said defense contentions were rejected by U.S. District Judge David Kenyon, who presided over Miller's trials and the trial of Mrs. Ogorodnikov, with whom Miller had an affair in 1984. Kenyon removed himself from the case and Takasugi took over.

DOC.HEAD: Electrical Problem Shuts Down Long-Delayed Reactor
DOC.TEXT: Operators briefly shut down the Seabrook nuclear power in only its third day of operation because of a false alarm Thursday, but a federal inspector called the move conservative. Noel Dudley, resident inspector at Seabrook for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said plant operator New Hampshire Yankee shut down the reactor because of a spurious alarm received intermittently from one of five banks of electronic controls for the reactor's control rods. Dudley said each bank of controls has multiple power supply units, and that nuclear power plants can operate safely for months with one unit out of service. He agreed that the decision to shut down was conservative. ``They could have continued to operate,'' he said. Dudley said in a telephone interview from Seabrook that the reactor was shut down about 8:30 a.m. It was put back in operation at 2 p.m. A plant spokesman twice declined to confirm that the reactor had been shut down. Rob Williams said he didn't know and would not bother the control room to find out. ``We said all along that there would be shutdowns, and I don't know whether there have been,'' Williams said. He said he wouldn't call the control room because ``we have made a conscious decision that we are not going to be distracting the control room staff for updates about the power level.'' Plant officials have said reaching full power could take two to three months, and that they expect problems. ``They're progressing with their startup very deliberately,'' Dudley said. ``They've not made any attempt to maintain their schedule. They're identifying problems ... and resolving those problems before they continue.'' Other problems encountered during the first three days included a steam leak from a valve in the plant's turbine building and a ``slight hydraulic leak,'' Dudley said. He said replacing sealing rings fixed both problems. He said the problems were not surprising. ``A plant that's been sitting idle for over eight years, even with the best of maintenance, you would expect that when you began to operate ... you would identify some components of some systems that would require work,'' he said. The delay was caused by regulation changes and court battles by opponents of the plant. Seabrook foe Robert Backus, lawyer for the Seacoast-Anti-Pollution League, said the problems confirm ``that this plant is not ready and the license should not have been issued.'' ``If you went and bought a car _ this is supposed to be a Cadillac, right? _ and you couldn't drive it the first mile because there was a problem that required you to shut it down, you might want to take it back,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's an Expert on Running Against Women; Ferraro Disagrees
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that he's an expert when it comes to running a political campaign against women, but at least one female politician took exception to the contention. ``I don't know how he'd call himself an expert,'' former Rep. Geraldine Ferraro said from New York. ``Only in politics does one little meeting an expert make.'' Ferraro was Walter Mondale's vice presidential running mate in the 1984 race against incumbent President Reagan and Vice President Bush. Bush's comments at a news conference were prompted by a question about the Texas gubernatorial race that may pit Democrat Ann Richards against Republican Clayton Williams. Williams has said he would feel less comfortable running against Richards than Attorney General Jim Mattox. Richards, the state treasurer, and Mattox will battle for the Democratic nomination in an April 10 run-off election. Bush said he had some opinions about running against women, calling himself ``an expert in the field'' because of his contest against Ferraro. But Ferraro said Bush's memory of the race is flawed, and that the only time they went head-to-head was in one televised debate. ``We did not run against each other. It was Fritz Mondale and Ronald Reagan who were running against each other,'' Ferraro said. ``If we were both running against each other, if we were both at the top of the ticket, then I think his comment about being an expert would be valid.'' Bush was asked if he had any advice for Williams. ``I have none at all, but I know exactly what he means and I refuse to elaborate on it,'' Bush said. Ferraro, meanwhile, said Richards didn't need any advice from her. ``Ann has run against men before. I'm sure she's not uncomfortable with it,'' Ferraro said, suggesting Williams' problem may be a common male ailment. ``The only way I can see it, being uncomfortable, is when you lose to a man it's humiliating enough,'' she said. ``But if you're a macho guy and you lose to a woman, it has to be devastating.''

DOC.HEAD: Literacy Postcard Unveiled
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush joined the postmaster general Thursday in unveiling a 15-cent postal card that promotes the fight against illiteracy. The card depicts a globe atop a book and the legend, ``The world is an open book.'' It also shows a computer with this message on the screen: ``Literacy: a stronger future, a better world.'' Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said the card ``marks the start of an intensified on-going program by the Postal Service ... to help stamp out illiteracy.'' ``If reading was not an integral part of our lives, the Postal Service would be out of business,'' Frank said. Mrs. Bush said President Bush was commited ``to wipe (illiteracy) out before the end of the century.'' The Postal Service has printed 15 million of the four-color cards.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviets Reach New Grain Agreement
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 12-15: ``Farmers welcomed,'' with reaction
DOC.TEXT: American farmers have been guaranteed a major portion of the Soviet Union's grain import market for another five years, officials announced Thursday. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills said a tentative agreement in principle was reached during negotiations in Vienna. The current pact, which has been in effect since 1983, expires Dec. 31. The new accord will increase the annual minimum shipments of U.S. grain to the Soviets to 10 million metric tons from 9 million tons _ a guarantee of 50 million tons over the five years, compared with 45 million tons under the old terms. Soviet purchases in most years have exceeded the required minimums. In 1988-89, for example, sales were more than double the specified minimum. ``We think this is a good deal, that it assures U.S. farmers of a stable market over the life of the agreement,'' Julius Katz, deputy U.S. trade representative, said in Vienna. Katz said details of the pact would be disclosed after it is signed at the June summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Howard Lyman, a lobbyist for the National Farmers Union, said the pact was in line with the group's support of such long-term agreements. ``We think it's great,'' he said. However, economist John A. Schnittker questioned whether the agreement was needed. ``I've never considered these agreements to be necessary for continuation of trade,'' he said. ``In my opinion, we would be selling just as much. They need the stuff, we've got the stuff, they're going to buy it when they need it.'' Farmers welcomed the announcement but some restrained their enthusiasm until they could learn more. ``I'm not going to jump up and down and say this is great stuff until I have all the details,'' said Gary Rees, who farms 550 acres at Crawfordsville, Iowa. ``I really don't know how big a deal it really is,'' said Dick Naeve of Humboldt, who works 750 acres at Humboldt, Iowa. He observed, ``Their people want a better diet, so they're probably going to have to import more over the next couple of years.'' Commodity markets barely reacted at all; traders said the news had been epected. Wheat futures closed { cent per bushel lower to 1{ cents lower; corn was { cent to 1{ cents higher. The Kremlin will have some greater year-to-year flexibility under the new arrangement by being allowed to choose between wheat and feed grains, although over the life of the pact the minimums will be met, officials said. Under the agreement, the Soviets will be committed to buying at least 4 million tons each of wheat and feed grains. However, in any one year Moscow may substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. For the first time, the agreement includes barley and sorghum as well as corn under the definition of feed grains. Additional flexibility also was provided by giving Moscow automatic permission to buy up to 14 million tons of grain annually without further discussion with Washington. The automatic limit under the current pact is 12 million tons, although the United States has routinely increased that to fit Soviet needs. As of March 8, the Soviets had bought more than 13.8 million tons of U.S. wheat and corn under the current agreement for delivery this year. Last year's sales totaled a record 21.7 million tons. Effectively, over five years, U.S. farmers will be assured a Soviet market for at least 20 million tons of wheat and 20 million tons of feed grains, with an additional 10 million tons that can be made up of wheat, feed grains, soybeans or soybean meal. Although it makes up a hefty share, the Soviet Union's grain purchases by no means tell the whole story of U.S. grain exports. Total wheat shipments in 1989-90 are forecast at 35.4 million tons, and so-called coarse grains, or feed grains, at 66.4 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Astronauts Ready To Deploy Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: Five astronauts who will deploy the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope from the shuttle Discovery said Thursday excitement is mounting at NASA as the April 12 launch date draws closer. The astronomical observatory, nearly seven years late in lifting off, will be placed in orbit 370 miles above Earth and enable scientists to see things so distant that their light has taken almost since the beginning of the universe to reach Earth. ``I think I can speak for everybody in that we can feel the excitement building quite a bit now in these last few weeks. We're just glad to be finally this close to launch,'' said Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver, the crew's commander. ``We'll all feel a little bit of disbelief that we're finally getting to do this. We'll probably all feel a certain amount of pride,'' mission specialist Steven A. Hawley said at a news conference. Hawley is scheduled to use the shuttle's robot arm to deploy the telescope on the second day of the five-day mission. ``I can't even begin to imagine how good we're going to feel because it's been so long,'' said Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., the mission's pilot. The Hubble, the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built, originally was scheduled for launch in late 1983 but technical problems postponed liftoff until 1985 and then 1986. The Challenger explosion on Jan. 28, 1986, delayed the mission until 1989, and concern over the shuttle's solid fuel booster rockets pushed it back yet again. From its orbit, the 25,000-pound, 43-foot-long telescope will be able to detect light of all wavelengths, including ultraviolet, before it is absorbed or distorted by the atmosphere. The telescope will look seven times more deeply into space and detect objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Its eight-foot primary optical mirror is the most precise ever made. Astronomers will be able to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has taken 14 billion years to reach Earth. Scientists believe the universe is 15 billion years old. The other crew members are mission specialists Kathryn D. Sullivan and Bruce McCandless II, a Navy captain, who both said they are ready to go on a spacewalk if necessary to repair or retrieve the observatory if necessary after deployment. Shriver said he is not concerned about damaged axle nuts found on the nose wheels of Atlantis and Columbia and suspected to be the same on Discovery. NASA temporarily delayed Discovery's move to the launch pad last week until technicians concluded there was no threat to the mission. Because of their prestigious payload, the astronauts have found themselves the subject of considerable attention and even a little envy within NASA. ``There's no such thing as a bad mission,'' Hawley said. ``But I think there are a lot of people who would like to trade places with us.''

DOC.HEAD: South African Clashes Kill 20, Injure 56
With AM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: Twenty people were killed and 56 injured in South Africa in black factional fighting and protests against the white-dominated government, police and news reports said Thursday. Authorities also arrested or fired 109 police and prison officers who mounted strikes and protests Wednesday to demand equality with white employees. The violence was reported the same day U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with President F.W. de Klerk to encourage more reform by his government. De Klerk said he would like to lift the national state of emergency as soon as political violence subsides. Six people were killed and 34 injured when a vehicle plowed through a mob blocking the main road between East London and the black township of Mdantsane in eastern Cape province, the South African Broadcasting Corp. said Thursday. It gave no details, but there have been numerous incidents of white drivers speeding up their cars or firing guns when they were attacked by crowds of blacks on the roads. A police statement Thursday reported widespread unrest during the previous 24 hours. It said police riot squads using shotguns, rubber bullets and tear gas broke up groups of black protesters. Tens of thousands of blacks mounted a 24-hour strike Wednesday to mark the 30th anniversary of the 1960 ``Sharpeville Massacre,'' when police killed 69 blacks during a protest march. Some of the victims reported Thursday were killed in black factional violence that has killed more than 300 people in the past month. Police did not give a breakdown on the reasons for all 14 deaths listed in official reports. But they said a 12-year-old boy was hacked to death Thursday in a battle between township residents and migrant workers living in hostels at Ikegeng, 62 miles southwest of Johannesburg. The hostels and 20 cars were destroyed in a fire that caused $380,000 damage, police said. Thousands of people went on strike or stayed home Thursday in the nominally independent homeland of Bophuthatswana north of Pretoria to mark the funeral of six people killed by police in a protest earlier this month. Some police and prison officers held strikes or protests Wednesday to demand equality with white officers, including equal pay. About half of the South African Police is non-white. Police commanders said 41 police officers were dismissed for striking or conspiring to strike. Among those dismissed was Lt. Gregory Rockman, a mixed-race officer suspended in November after organizing the new union for police and prison guards. Police also said, without elaborating, that 68 striking prison officers were arrested at Pollsmoor Prison near Cape Town after they took part in a protest meeting Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Government Expands Recall of Dietary Supplement Linked to Blood Disorder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf;' ``L-tryptophan is,'' to add detail on products containing L-tryptophan; moves up grafs 26-28 pvs bgng: ``The recall,'' to be grafs 7-8 and INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``It was not,'' to explain that FDA will issue further clarification on recall; minor reorganization and editing below that to trim
DOC.TEXT: The government expanded its recall of L-tryptophan Thursday because of fears that a sometimes fatal blood disorder can be caused even by small doses of the dietary supplement used for insomnia, depression and weight control. ``We are confronted with a major public health problem,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan warned in the announcement by the Food and Drug Administration. ``I urge everyone to stop taking these supplements immediately.'' L-tryptophan is an amino acid that occurs naturally in some foods that are high in protein, such as milk, beef, turkey and beans. But it is also sold over the counter as a manufactured dietary supplement, and it may be contained in various diet and weight loss products. It has been linked to a blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS. So far, 1,411 cases of EMS _ including 19 deaths _ have been reported, the FDA said. Cases have been reported in every state. The recall applies to all L-tryptophan products in tablet, capsule, caplet, powdered or liquid form, as well multi-ingredient, non-protein supplements that contain L-tryptophan, the FDA said. The only products containing L-tryptophan not being recalled are some protein supplements, infant formulas, special dietary foods, intravenous and oral solutions, in which small amounts of L-tryptophan are needed for nutrition fortification, the FDA said. No cases of EMS have been linked to any of these uses, the agency said. It was not clear whether certain products like diet weight loss and body-building supplements containing L-tryptophan would have to be recalled. Some of these are formulated according to FDA regulations. The FDA said it would issue a clarification further defining what is subject to the recall. L-tryptophan is not an FDA-approved drug ingredient and has not been considered a drug. L-tryptophan dietary supplements are sold in health food stores, drug stores and supermarkets. Retail sales are estimated at $50 million to $75 million a year. Buyers use the supplement for insomnia, appetite control, depression, premenstrual syndrome, stress reduction and other problems. The Council for Responsible Nutrition, which represents manufacturers of nutritional supplements, endorsed the FDA's action. Its president, J.B. Cordaro, said ``I wish they'd done it a month ago.'' The council has been recommending for more than a month that its members stop distribution of all products that contain L-tryptophan and that consumers stop using it, he said. Cordaro said that the largest manufacturers of L-tryptophan products have taken them off the market, ``and if there are a few of the smaller ones that still have it, it's insignificant.'' The council identified the two largest manufacturers of L-tryptophan dietary supplements as P. Leiner Nutritional Products Corp. in Torrance, Calif., and Pharmavite Corp. in Arleta, Calif. Kevin Lanigan, senior vice president at P. Leiner, said that a week before the FDA's initial Nov. 17 recall, the company stopped manufacture and shipping of all its L-tryptophan products. The company also notified all of its customers and advised them to remove it from their shelves, he said. Neither Lanigan or the FDA could provide brand names of the products since hundreds of products are involved. Kenneth Rosenberg, chief executive officer of Pharmavite Corp., said his company distributed L-tryptophan dietary supplements under about 20 different brand names, including its own brand, Nature Made, as well as store labels for various retail chains. Pharmavite also stopped shipping its products before the FDA's initial recall last November, and notified its customers and provided them with signs warning consumers about the problem, said Rosenberg. FDA spokesman Chris Lecos said the L-tryptophan recall is unusual in that normally the FDA identifies a specific hazard or contaminant and knows who the manufacturer is, how much was made, and where and when it was distributed. EMS is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash, fatigue, cough and sometimes fever. In some cases, victims show signs of congestive heart failure or develop a condition that causes progressive weakness and sometimes leads to paralysis. Sullivan warned: ``EMS can cripple. It can cause great pain. It can kill. It has had long-term effects on some unfortunate individuals, and some patients are not responding to treatment.'' The FDA initially recalled only the larger dose forms of the product, those that would result in daily intake of 100 milligrams or more a day. That was based on evidence from the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta that EMS victims had taken L-tryptophan in doses that ranged from 150 to 17,000 milligrams a day. Most were taking 1,000 to 2,000 milligrams daily. However, at least one case of the disorder has been reported on less than 100 milligrams a day, the FDA said. The rate of EMS has slowed dramatically since the initial Nov. 17 recall, but officials said some of the recent victims apparently had continued using L-tryptophan products after the recall began. The FDA earlier was investigating whether L-tryptophan itself or some contaminant introduced during manufacture or distribution was causing the syndrome. FDA investigators visited plants in Japan, a leading supplier of the raw L-tryptophan to U.S. manufacturers. However, investigators have been unable to identify any contaminants that could be responsible, nor have they linked the illness to any single lot, brand, manufacturer or supplier. The FDA's action was taken after its Health Hazard Evaluation Board advised that ``the risk of contracting EMS due to the consumption of any dietary L-tryptophan product far outweighs any perceived benefit that may be derived from the continued marketing of this product in any dosage form.''

DOC.HEAD: Artificial Heart Recipient Dies After Transplant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, `The agency...' with 1 graf to include later FDA modification of its order.
DOC.TEXT: One of the last persons to receive a Jarvik artifical heart before federal approval of the device was withdrawn died after surgery to replace the pump with a donor organ. He spent 87 days on the device. Carl E. Bryant, 43, of Louisville, died Wednesday, eight hours after the transplant operation, said doctors at Louisville's Jewish Hospital. ``We did everything we could for Carl Bryant,'' said Dr. Laman A. Gray Jr., who transplanted the heart. Physicians said the donor heart, which became available late Tuesday, met the criteria for transplantation. But the left ventricle, or main pumping chamber, failed to function once the heart was inside Bryant. The Jarvik 7-70 assist device was implanted Dec. 22 at Humana Hospital-Audubon by Dr. William DeVries, who pioneered use of the artificial heart. ``The transplant surgery offered Carl's only real chance for survival,'' DeVries said in a statement Wednesday. Bryant was the second-to-last person to receive a Jarvik pump in this country before the U.S. Food and Drug Administration withdrew its approval of the device Jan. 8, said Gary Cole, an executive vice president with Symbion Inc., the Arizona manufacturer of the pumps. The agency said its inspections uncovered ``serious deficiencies'' in the way Symbion was carrying out studies with the device. In February, the FDA said it would allow use of the device as a last resort, but only when all other available treatments had failed and when no other life-saving device could be used. The device was last implanted in the United States in Columbus, Ohio, on Dec. 31, Cole said Thursday. He said two Jarvik pumps have been implanted in other countries since the FDA withdrawal. Cole said 159 Jarviks have been implanted as bridges to transplants since 1985. He said the longest-surviving patient to use the Jarvik while awaiting a donor organ was a French woman. She lived 603 days on the device. Dr. Barney Clark, the first person implanted with a Jarvik heart, died in 1983 after 112 days on the device. He received a Jarvik-7, which was supposed to be a premanent replacement for his heart. Bryant had a massive heart attack in July and underwent cardiac catheterization and angioplastic surgery in his left coronary artery. His wife, Cynthia, took him to the hospital Dec. 16 after he complained of chest pains. Three hours before he was to undergo triple bypass surgery, Bryant suffered a second massive heart attack. DeVries implanted the Jarvik device during a six-hour procedure. ``I have no qualms about Carl being on the assist device at all,'' Cynthia Bryant said. ``It worked wonderfully and may further research to help someone else. And we had three good months together that we would not have had otherwise.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Leader Says He Staged Coup
DOC.TEXT: Lesotho's military ruler, who sent the king into exile last month claiming he needed a vacation, said Thursday he had staged a coup in this tiny southern African nation. It was the first time Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya characterized what he did as a coup. On Feb. 19, Lekhanya dismissed all ministers who supported King Moshoeshoe. Then, on March 10, he sent the king himself into exile in England, saying the monarch needed a rest. Lekhanya's statement Thursday came in an affidavit to the High Court. Former Health Minister Strong Makenete has filed a case with the court challenging his dismissal as invalid. Lekhanya said Makenete's application was frivolous because he and other ministers were ousted in a coup. The ruler said the Council of Ministers no longer exists. Lekhanya and his Military Council have held the government in sway since a January 1986 coup against leftist strongman Leabua Jonathan. The military initially helped Jonathan keep power after he lost a post-independence election. Lekhanya said the king retained legislative and executive powers after the 1986 coup, but was supposed to govern with the advice of the Military Council. Last month, Lekhanya dismissed two high-ranking relatives of the king and other supporters of the monarch. When Moshoeshoe refused to approve replacements, Lekhanya stripped the king of authority and deported him. Lekhanya said he and his remaining supporters on the Military Council would govern until Lesotho returns to civilian rule. He has said that will take place in June 1992. A statement signed by 14 of the country's 22 traditional chiefs was published Thursday objecting to the treatment of the king. Lesotho, which became independent from Britain in 1966, is completely surrounded by South Africa.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 new grafs with House action and Senate proceedings; picks up 4th graf pvs: ``The Byrd,'' editing to trim throughout
DOC.TEXT: A House committee approved a compromise Thursday on tougher smog controls in a clean air bill, while a proposal for financial aid to coal miners still held up movement on similar legislation in the Seante. The 38-2 vote by the House Energy and Commerce Committee created one areas of likely conflict when the Senate and House versions of the two bills eventually have to be reconciled. The Senate earlier in the week rejected some of the same smog controls. Meanwhile, Senate leaders worked with the White House and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., in an attempt to find a way to resolve the dispute over the coal miner assistance. A vote on the amendment, brought to the floor by Byrd nearly two weeks ago, has been postponed at least twice. Senate leaders are fearful that Byrd has the votes to get it passed. That could unravel the compromise legislation worked out with the White House, they fear, because of the temptation it would pose for lawmakers to claim similar aid for other industries. By evening the coal aid amendment had yet to surface again, though Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, had said earlier in the day the matter would ``be resolved one way or another'' Thursday. The House committee vote came after two days of negotitions among committee leaders, including Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the chairman. Many members voted only minutes after having first seen the inch-thick document. The House provisions would continue to allow the Environmental Protection Agency to impose an air pollution control plan if local officials fail to act, would bring many small businesses under smog-control regulations in cities with the dirtiest air, and would eliminate certain waivers now possible on grounds that compliance would cost too much. These were provisions the Senate rejected earlier in the week. The Senate spent much time on marginal amendments. The Byrd proposal calls for a $500 million program to help miners who lose their jobs from tougher acid rain pollution controls. The White House calls the plan too expensive and has lobbied hard against it. But Byrd, one of the Senate's most influential and most powerful members as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, returned to the Senate floor Thursday to plead his case. ``The coal miners are being asked to pay a very high price. ... They will lose their livelihood,'' declared Byrd, calling the assistance program essential to help 5,000 miners who are likely to lose their jobs. Mitchell, meanwhile, was working with Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, to try to get the White House to produce a compromise aid package that might be agreeable to Byrd. Mitchell and Dole have said they are concerned that passage of the assistance program would cause the White House to drop support for the compromise clean air legislation that was agreed to in lengthy closed-door negotiations between Senate leaders and the Bush administration. If the deal falls apart there likely will be no clean air bill from the Senate this year, Mitchell maintained earlier in the week. On Wednesday night, Byrd offered to lower the package's expected cost from $700 million over four years to $500 million over three years. Now, he said, he would retreat no further. ``I'm not going to stand here and say I've got 51 votes (needed for passage), but I can tell you, `You don't have 51 votes either.' And I can tell you I'm very close,'' Byrd told Mitchell as debate on the issue continued late into the night Wednesday. Byrd complained that the White House had been unwilling to negotiate with him, so ``I've negotiated with myself.'' Originally Byrd had sought a much broader aid package, which could have cost $1.6 billion over six years. Byrd argued that coal miners should be singled out for help because the bill, which calls for reducing sulfur dioxide emissions from electric utilities by 10 million tons a year by the end of the decade, takes ``direct aim'' at these workers. Industry has argued forcefully among senators in recent weeks that the tougher proposed controls on toxic industrial chemical releases would cost thousands of jobs in the steel, chemical and petroleum industries.

DOC.HEAD: More Violence Buffets Haiti, Politician's Wife Shot
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Slum-dwellers reportedly beat to death a Duvalier loyalist and gunmen wounded a political leader's wife Thursday on the fourth straight day of street violence blamed on opponents of Haiti's new government. A group of civic and political leaders fingered loyalists to the ousted Duvalier family regime as inciting violence in the hopes of destabilizing the interim civilian government of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot. Since Sunday, dozens of people have been wounded and at least 21 killed in a rash of attacks. Civic activists say most responsible for the unrest are thugs angered by last week's shift of power from the ruling military. Marie-Michele de Ronceray, wife of conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray, was shot in the left shoulder by assailants as she was being driven home in suburban Fontamara, a member de Ronceray's Mobilization for National Development party told The Associated Press. Mrs. de Ronceray and her driver ``saw the aggressors, two armed men,'' said party member Dieudonne Laroche. ``They deliberately aimed at Mrs. de Ronceray,'' who was hospitalized in a nearby Adventist clinic. De Ronceray, a prominent conservative politician, was one of seven critics forced into exile by the military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril during a crackdown in January. De Ronceray, his wife, and their 7-year-old son returned from exile in Miami last week after Avril fled the country March 10. In the Bolosse slum, an angry mob Thursday beat to death and burned the remains of Romer Deruisseaux, a former member of ex-dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier's dreaded militia, Radio Antilles and Radio Metropole said. In another attack in suburban Delmas, a money-changer was shot to death and robbed by unidentified men riding a motorcycle, the radio stations said. Leaders of the Unity Assembly, a coalition of civic and political groups that led protests that brought down Avril's regime this month, said the violence was the work of Duvalier loyalists. ``The only political sector excluded from the caretaker government is that of the hard-line Duvalierists. They are making a last-ditch effort to dash to pieces our hopes for democracy,'' said center-left politician Jean-Claude Roy, a coalition member. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, sworn in as provisional president March 13, has vowed to turn over power to an elected government this year. The army has pledged to support her government. Haiti has had four short-lived regimes since Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, son of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, was swept from power in a popular uprising and fled to France in February 1986. His father ruled from 1957.

DOC.HEAD: Old Communists in Hungary Hail Anti-Reform Calls
DOC.TEXT: Communists who refused to follow the reformist trend applauded warnings on Thursday that a market economy and ``bourgeois'' ideas would destroy their hard-won welfare. About 2,000 people attended a rally in Budapest's Peoples' Stadium to show support for the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party _ Communists who refused to embrace reform that led others to renounce their Stalinist past and opt for democracy. The rally was held three days before Hungary's first free national elections in 42 years and was attended by mostly elderly Marxists. The audience presented a marked contrast to the rollicking crowd gathered at the stadium Wednesday to show support for FIDESZ, the iconoclastic League of Free Democrats who have poked fun at the Communists for much of the campaign. After decades of assured single-party rule, the Communists find they must scramble for votes if they hope to gain any seats at all in the new parliament. ``We can bring back socialism with our vote,'' appealed the splinter party's new leader, Gyula Thuermer, to rousing applause. Many of the crowd appeared to be blue-collar workers. FIDESZ draws much of its support from college-educated adults. ``There will be great unemployment if the capitalists take over,'' the 36-year-old Thuermer warned. ``Let's preserve the unity of the workers. ... Don't believe what the bourgeois parties promise you.'' The orderly audience applauded rhythmically in response to his promises of increased pensions, free education and prospects for betterment. He said that was all threatened by the coming democracy and market economy most other parties pledge to institute as the only way to pull Hungary out of an economic slump.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-General, Spy Chief Lew Allen Jr. to Retire From Jet Propulsion Lab
DOC.TEXT: Lew Allen Jr. will retire Sept. 30 as director of Jet Propulsion Laboratory, capping a career in which he guided NASA's unmanned space program, the Air Force and the supersecret National Security Agency. ``I'm delighted to be able to leave at a time when the future of the space program looks very bright and the activities at JPL in connection with the exploration of the solar system look very promising indeed,'' Allen said Wednesday. JPL's Magellan spacecraft will reach Venus in August, the Galileo spacecraft is bound for a 1995 rendezvous with Jupiter, Mars Observer is set for launch in 1992, and the lab is gearing up for future lunar and Mars explorations under President Bush's space initiative. Allen, 64, a physicist, said he and his wife ``would like to travel some and smell the roses a bit'' when he retires on his 65th birthday. He has spent eight years as JPL director and vice president of the California Institute of Technology. Caltech operates the laboratory for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Allen oversaw the Voyager 2 spacecraft's explorations of Uranus in 1986 and Neptune last summer, and the completion of the 1982-83 survey of heat-emitting objects in space by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite. Allen retired in 1982 as a general and Air Force chief of staff, a post that made him a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the president's principal military advisers. President Carter named Allen to that post in 1978. In 1973, President Nixon appointed Allen director of the National Security Agency, which reportedly has the largest budget of any U.S. intelligence agency and operates much of America's network of spy satellites and electronic surveillance. He held that post until 1977, when he was named head of Air Force Systems Command. Journalist Frederick Kempe's recent book ``Divorcing the Dictator'' said that in 1976 Allen urged prosecution of Manuel Antonio Noriega after the Panamanian general bribed U.S. officials to obtain secret intelligence tapes. But the book said then-CIA Director George Bush balked, allowing Noriega to go unpunished and continue receiving $110,000 per year from the CIA for his supposed cooperation with the agency. Bush ordered the recent invasion that ousted Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Meese Strongly Defends Poindexter, Says Doesn't Think Admiral Lied
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 23-25: ``Why was,'' with judge's question and answer
DOC.TEXT: Former Attorney General Edwin Meese III testified Thursday he never became suspicious of John Poindexter, even when evidence suggested Poindexter covered up the U.S. role in a missile shipment to Iran. Appearing as a defense witness at Poindexter's trial, Meese told the jury that ``everything I know'' suggests the former national security adviser tried to give him an accurate account of the November 1985 delivery at a meeting a year later. ``Did Admiral Poindexter ever tell you a lie?'' asked defense attorney Richard Beckler. ``Not to my knowledge,'' responded the former attorney general. Poindexter tried to ``convey an accurate'' story on the missile shipment? asked Beckler. ``Everything I know about it is he did,'' said Meese. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb questioned Meese about a Nov. 20, 1986, meeting in Poindexter's office during which several participants, including Oliver North, adopted a false cover story about the shipment. The story was that no one in the U.S. government knew at the time of the shipment that Hawk missiles were aboard. Meese was asked if he knew then that Poindexter had been ``involved in that Hawks shipment'' ``No, I did not know that then and I do not know that today,'' Meese replied. Webb showed Meese a copy of a Nov. 20, 1985, computer message from North to Poindexter about the impending shipment. Meese responded by saying he didn't know whether Poindexter received the message. After the meeting in Poindexter's office, Meese was told by a political aide the U.S. government may have known about the missile shipment after all. Two days later, Meese first learned that then-President Reagan had signed a document, known as a finding, authorizing CIA assistance in the shipment, according to testimony at the congressional Iran-Contra hearings. Wasn't Meese suspicious about the assertions of no U.S. knowledge when there was a presidential finding ratifying the shipment? asked Webb. ``No I was not suspicious of that,'' said Meese. The CIA said it had found out about the missiles only as the shipment was under way, and the finding was signed by Reagan a week and a half after the delivery, explained Meese. The politically embarrassing finding depicted the U.S. role in Iran arms sales as an attempt to trade arms for hostages. Poindexter tore up the document on Nov. 21, 1986, hours talking with members of Congress about the missile shipment. The former national security adviser is accused of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements by saying that he didn't learn of the delivery until January 1986. When Meese told the president on Nov. 21 a fact-finding inquiry was being started on the Iran initiative, did Poindexter ``jump up'' and say he had a copy of the finding ``in my safe?'' asked Webb. ``No, he did not,'' said Meese. ``During this time ... did John Poindexter ever tell you he had destroyed this finding that had been signed by the president of the United States?'' asked Webb. ``No,'' replied Meese. At the Nov. 20 meeting at which Poindexter presided, did Meese hear any discussion of a false cover story? asked Beckler. ``No I did not,'' replied Meese. ``I am sure nothing like that was ever said in my presence at that meeting.'' Meese said he had no reason to doubt the accuracy of the information being presented by the CIA and North. Why was it necessary for `everybody ... to get together'' at the Nov. 20, 1986 meeting? asked U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene. To prepare CIA director William Casey for his congressional testimony the next day on the Iran initiative, responded Meese. Poindexter had asked Meese to come to the meeting to ensure that Reagan administration officials could testify ``truthfully and accurately,'' Meese said at one point. Earlier Thursday, Poindexter's lawyers finished the courtroom showing of nearly eight hours of videotaped testimony from Reagan. In it, Reagan suggested that it might have been all right to destroy documents or withhold information from Congress in order to safeguard the lives of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. Reagan said that if there were leaks from Congress about aspects of the Iran initiative, the hostages could be endangered. Poindexter is accused of deleting 5,000 files from his computer system to keep Congress from knowing the U.S. role in the missile shipment. Poindexter also is accused of conspiring with North to destroy and alter memos that showed North's military assistance to the Contras. ``Is it ... fair to say that at no time in November of 1986 did you ever authorize ... any one at the National Security Council to destroy or alter any record that related to the Iran-Contra controversy?'' asked prosecutor Dan Webb. ``I don't know,'' replied Reagan, saying that he had ``pointed out that there were things that could not be made public because of the risk of death to a number of people.'' ``There were times and experience that told us that Congress was not in many instances capable of the kind of security that we required,'' Reagan said at one point.
