DOC.HEAD: Meanwhile, Senate, 3rd graf
Psychologist for Murder Defendants Seeks Return of Tapes
DOC.TEXT: A psychologist for two brothers charged in the shotgun slayings of their millionaire parents asked a judge Thursday to retrieve tape recordings that police seized from his office. Attorney Brad Bunnon said the recordings and other records taken from psychologist Jerome Oziel's office after police served search warrants March 8 ``were not turned over voluntarily'' and should not be admissible in a trial. Los Angeles County Superior Judge James Albracht said he would consider the request at an April 4 hearing. Neither the prosecution nor the defense has revealed what is contained in the recordings. Attorneys for Joseph Lyle Menendez, 22, and his brother Erik, 19, have argued that the recordings are confidential doctor-patient records. The tapes were seized before police arrested Lyle Menendez on March 8. Erik Menendez, a 19-year-old tennis pro, surrendered the following weekend after returning from playing a tennis tournament in Israel. The brothers have been charged with two counts of homicide each in the slayings of Jose Menendez, 45, and Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44. They were to be arraigned Monday on two counts of murder each at Beverly Hills Municipal Court. The couple were shot to death Aug. 20 in their $5 million Beverly Hills mansion. The sons reported finding the bodies upon returning from a night on the town. The young men are heirs to the $14 million estate of Menendez, an executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution company. Police have said two killers committed the crime, then picked up shell casings from the 12-gauge shotguns they used before fleeing. Prosecutors have said the tapes constitute key evidence. ``The prosecution will go on in this case with or without the tapes,'' Deputy District Attorney Elliott Alhadeff said Thursday. State law allows psychologists' patient records to be used as evidence if there is a threat of continued violence. Alhadeff said earlier this month that Oziel was threatened. Defense attorney Gerald Chaleff has said he was aware of no threat against Oziel or anyone else.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Vows No More Sales of Semtex Explosives to Libya
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel said Thursday that Czechoslovakia sold Libya 1,000 tons of Semtex explosive but will not be exporting any more of the virtually undetectable substance favored by terrorists. Security experts say Semtex was used was the terrorist bombing of a Pan Am Boeing 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, which killed 259 people on board the plane and 11 on the ground. Semtex, made exclusively in Czechoslovakia, is an odorless, orange-yellow explosive that looks like children's play-dough. It can be molded into any shape and is 1,000 times more powerful than conventional explosives. It is almost undetectable to conventional anti-terrorist devices. Havel, speaking through a translator at a news conference at the Czechoslovak Embassy on the second day of a three-day official visit, said, ``If you consider that it takes 200 grams (7 ounces) to blow up an aircraft, this means world terrorism has enough Semtex to last for 150 years.'' Havel did not say Czechoslovakia would stop making Semtex, but defended its production for peaceful use. ``This is an industrial explosive necessary for various industrial uses. It is not an explosive made especially for terrorists,'' he said. But, ``Now we want to mark Semtex so it will be detectable.'' ``The past regime exported 1,000 tons to Libya. ... We ceased exporting this explosive some time ago.'' Havel, who became president last Dec. 29, gave no date or details. But Jiri Novy, director of the plant northeast of Prague that makes Semtex, told The Associated Press that exports stopped in 1988. He said Libya received ``over 900'' tons of the explosive in 1981 and that additional exports were made to Eastern Europe until 1988. The British Foreign Office said formal exports of Semtex continued to Hungary and East Germany until 1989. Britain's Press Association said Semtex has been the Irish Republican Army's chief weapon against British rule in Northern Ireland since late 1986, and was used in the September bombing of the Royal Marines School of Music in Kent, which killed 10 people. The news agency, quoting unidentified security officials, said the explosive was smuggled into Ireland from Libya in 1985 and 1986. Traces of a chemical constituent of Semtex were found in the wreckage of a UTA DC-10 that blew up over Niger in 1989, killing 170 people. Czechoslovakia has long been a major arms manufacturer. It produces hand grenades, automatic rifles, tanks and armored personnel carriers. Published reports say the export of such weapons and components accounted for up to one-half of Czechoslovakia's foreign-exchange earnings. The nation, suffering from a crumbling economy and strapped for hard currency, may find it difficult to stop the trade. Under the hard-line Communist regime of Milos Jakes and Gustav Husak, Czechoslovakia found a market among nations too poor to afford expensive Western weapons or those denied access for political reasons. Besides Libya, clients included Angola, South Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Havel promised on Tuesday that Czechoslovakia's arms industry will no longer sell weapons to dictatorial or totalitarian regimes. ``We are studying reconversion of our military industry,'' he told a news conference in Paris, where he met with President Francois Mitterrand, before coming to London. ``Don't hold it against us if we continue to furnish arms for a little while to democratic governments.'' Havel met with business people and business organizations Thursday, exploring possible areas for economic cooperation. He arrived Wednesday to a red-carpet welcome and luncheon at Buckingham Palace with Queen Elizabeth II, then had talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at her 10 Downing St. office and residence. He said they discussed the future of Europe and German unification. ``I told her that the process of unification should be understood as a sort of engine propelling the unification of the whole of Europe,'' he told reporters. Havel returns to Prague on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Official: De Klerk's Reform Efforts Parallel Those of Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `There are' to CORRECT day to Thursday sted Friday. Picks up 3rd, `The official...'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk's attempts to abolish apartheid in South Africa can be compared to the reform efforts of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a senior U.S. official said Thursday. ``There are some parallels,'' he told reporters traveling with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who met with de Klerk for more than an hour Thursday in the first such high-level encounter in 12 years. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said President Nelson Mandela of the African National Congress and other leading black nationalists told him ``de Klerk is a man of integrity and so far his word has been good.'' Baker had ``not believed de Klerk's government 13 months ago when it said it was going to run on a program of abolishing apartheid,'' the official said. He said Baker ``now believes these people are quite serious and that they are committed to an irreversible process and that they are anxious to move quickly.'' Baker told de Klerk during a 75-minute meeting that ``what he had done so far was courageous in light of the obvious political pressures and restraints he is subject to,'' the official said. A second U.S. official said skeptics should recall that Gorbachev's sincerity and ability to make radical changes also were questioned when he first came to power in 1985. The praise marks the latest in a series of diplomatic successes this week for a government that has been isolated by most nations for more than a decade. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd met de Klerk on Monday and invited him to visit Britain in May for a meeting with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. President Bush has invited de Klerk to Washington. On Wednesday de Klerk held an unprecedented meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Namibia, where they attended independence ceremonies for the territory formerly ruled by South Africa. After meeting Baker on Thursday afternoon, the South African president met with President Siad Barre of Somalia, government-controlled television reported without fanfare. A visit by an African head of state to South Africa would have been treated as a major event a few months ago. Foreign Minister Pik Botha said no South African head of state had been in such demand since Jan Smuts at the end of World War II. Baker met de Klerk despite opposition from Mandela and other leaders in the fight against South Africa's racial segregation policy. Flanked by de Klerk and Botha on the steps of the president's official residence, Baker said, ``De Klerk told me we are engaged here in South Africa in an irreversible process and we will follow it to its logical conclusion.'' De Klerk was asked whether blacks would be granted equal voting rights and a black could become president in his lifetime. ``I have just won an election asking for a mandate to attain exactly that,'' he replied. ``We are working toward that, yes, where all South Africans will have a vote, where that vote will be of equal value ... (with) proper protection of minority rights so there won't be domination built into the system. Not minority domination but also not simple majority domination.'' Baker arrived Thursday from Namibia and met a delegation of 11 anti-apartheid leaders at the U.S. ambassador's Cape Town residence before seeing de Klerk. The ANC members repeated Mandela's criticism of the Baker visit, saying it would give the world the impression fundamental progress had been made in moving toward a non-racial democracy. But no demonstrations against the visit occurred, and the activists laughed and smiled as they walked out of the meeting. Mandela cautioned reporters Wednesday, after meeting Baker in Windhoek, the Namibian capital, to concentrate on areas of agreement between black nationalists and the United States. Baker repeatedly said he did not believe the dispute over the meeting would cloud future negotiations or the U.S. government's standing with anti-apartheid groups. The secretary said he told de Klerk that lifting the state of emergency, which gives police wide powers to restrict protests and detain people, would be an important symbol that the reform process was moving forward. Botha said the government wants to end the emergency as soon as possible, but a recent upsurge of violence was holding up its cancellation. More than 300 people have died since Mandela was released from prison last month. Thursday's meeting with de Klerk included talks on Angola, de Klerk told reporters. Baker is to meet soon in Kinshasa, Zaire with President Mobutu Sese Seko and Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi in a bid to arrange a new cease-fire in the 15-year-old war across Namibia's northern border. Baker has expressed hope that new flexibility on the part of Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos may speed implementation of a cease-fire, but it appeared unlikely a truce could be arranged before the secretary returns to Washington on Saturday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Comedian Richard Pryor in Aussie Hospital After Mild Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Richard Pryor is being treated in an Australian hospital after suffering a mild heart attack three days ago, doctors said Friday. The Wesley Hospital in a brief statement described Pryor's condition as stable and said the 49-year-old probably will be discharged early next week. It said he was admitted three days earlier with chest pain and he was diagnosed as having suffered a minor heart attack. ``His condition from the time of admission has been very stable,'' the hospital added. It did not say when Pryor arrived in Australia and for how long he would stay. Pryor has appeared thin and in poor health in recent public appearances. He is best known as the star of several movies based on his stand-up comedy performances, including ``Richard Pryor Here and Now,'' ``Richard Pryor Live in Concert'' and ``Richard Pryor Is Back Live in Concert.'' Pryor's agent in Los Angeles, Guy McElwaine, did not return repeated phone calls late Thursday. The comedian was nearly killed and burned severely in 1980 while ``freebasing'' cocaine. He recounted that experience and other hardships in his life in the films ``Richard Pryor Live on the Sunset Strip'' and ``Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life is Calling.'' Other film credits include ``Harlem Nights,'' ``Stir Crazy,'' ``See No Evil, Hear No Evil,'' ``Brewster's Millions,'' ``Critical Condition'' and ``Moving.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Rain in the West and the Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow stretched from Idaho to Minnesota on Thursday and rain dampened sections of the Midwest as a surge of cold air kept noontime temperatures as low as the teens in the upper Midwest. Snow fell in the Idaho Panhandle, Montana, northern Wyoming, much of South Dakota, North Dakota and northwest Minnesota. Gusty winds prompted advisories for blowing, drifting snow in western Montana, northeastern North Dakota and Spokane, Wash. Snowfall in the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1 inch in Lewiston and Miles City, Mont. Rain fell on eastern Upper Michigan, lower Michigan, Indiana, northern Illinois and southeast Wisconsin. The northern Pacific Coast recieved scattered rain. The cold air kept the midday mercury in the teens and 20s across much of Montana, North Dakota, northern South Dakota and the northwest half of Minnesota. In Kansas, an advisory was issued warning for cold, wet weather more like mid-winter and dangerous to young livestock. It was a bit warmer south of the cold air mass. In Alamosa, Colo., the temperature hit 66 degrees, tying the record high for the date set in 1971. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 8 degrees in Cutbank, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 13 degrees in Lewistown, Mont., to 89 degrees in Phoenix, Gila Bend, Ariz.; and Palm Springs and Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: More than 400 Yugoslav Children Felled in Mystery Poisoning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to RECAST, minor editing. Picks up 4th, `Gasi said...'
DOC.TEXT: More than 400 ethnic Albanian teen-agers were hospitalized Thursday in Podujevo, a town in restive Kosovo province, after being felled by a mysterious illness that officials said may be poison. Official Radio Belgrade said about 4,000 ethnic Albanians gathered in the streets of Podujevo upon hearing the news. Some of them beat up 15 Serbs and Montenegrins, accusing them of poisoning classrooms of Albanian pupils. Professor Aljus Gasi, the dean of Pristina University, said he was informed that 417 schoolchildren were taken to hospitals, mostly in Pristina, the capital of the ethnically divided province. Gasi said doctors who examined the most serious cases reported such symptoms as reddened eyes and breathing problems. An anticipated official statement from authorities was never released Thursday. Radio Belgrade said angry Albanians broke into the local town council, shattering windows and rampaging through offices. Police moved in Thursday to head off an open nationalist conflict in the streets of Podujevo, considered a center of Albanian protest in the past. The state news agency Tanjug said authorities denied rumors that drinking water had also been poisoned in the province, where 85 percent of the population are ethnic Albanians. It said the provincial government was in session, but had not issued a statement to explain the suspected poisoning. A medical team from Belgrade was on its way to Kosovo to take blood and other samples for laboratory tests to be made back in Belgrade, it added. ``My daughter who goes to school in Pristina phoned me to say her school was closed Thursday after pupils complained about signs of poisoning,'' one woman told The Associated Press. She refused to give her name. A teacher in Podujevo, Agron Jaha, said she saw people ``dropping on the floor en masse.'' Students were reported hospitalized in Pristina in addition to Podujevo. Symptoms included nausea, coughing and tearing eyes, usually ascribed to the effects of tear gas. Tanjug and a health worker reported earlier that more than 200 people were hospitalized in Pristina. Most of the patients were said to be in fair condition. The provincial premier, Jusuf Zeinulahu, told reporters none of the people hospitalized was dangerously ill. A crowd of worried parents gathered in front of the Kosovo government building in Pristina on Thursday. Ethnic unrest in Kosovo has killed at least 60 people the last two years. The unrest centers on a dispute between ethnic Albanians, who form 90 percent of the population, and the minority Serbs and Montenegrins. The republic of Serbia passed constitutional changes last year to retain greater control over Kosovo, saying this was needed to protect the rights of the minorities. Opposition sources alleged that chemicals were sprinkled on the floors of classrooms of ethnic Albanian children or sprayed into the air. Veton Suroi, an opposition leader, told reporters in Pristina the situation was ``alarming.'' He claimed that more than 1,000 people, mostly children, had been hospitalized in Pristina alone. Zekerija Cana, another opposition spokesman, demanded a federal commission be set up to investigate the circumstances of ``the mass poisoning by an unknown chemical.'' They said the alleged poisoning had begun three days ago.

DOC.HEAD: Many Locals Divided Over Hazelwood Verdict
With AM-Hazelwood Verdict
DOC.TEXT: A few blocks up the street from the state courthouse, Blacky Arbid sat back from the bar at the Pioneer Club and came up with a verdict of his own for former tanker skipper Joseph Hazelwood. ``He was responsible for that ship and that's all there was to it,'' Arbid said, as the television set overheard played re-runs of Thursday verdict, clearing Hazelwood on all but one misdemeanor count in the nation's worst spill. The jury verdict on the former Exxon Valdez captain was in, but the trial by public opinion in bars, barbershops, shopping malls and donut stands continued around town. Housewife Peggy Robinson laughed when she heard that the longest sentence Hazelwood could get is 90 days in jail. ``I think it's a farce,'' Robinson said at the Northway shopping mall. ``I feel he messed up a beautiful playground, and then _ poof _ he ran and hid. He couldn't face what he did.'' Opinion at the Pioneer Club bar was more in line with the jury's decision. There was scattered applause in the court room when Hazelwood was acquitted of one felony and two misdemeanors, including operating a vessel while intoxicated. Jurors found him guilty of negligently discharging oil in wildlife-rich Prince William Sound. ``Geez, I could be convicted of that every day considering the car I drive,'' bartender Jack Doty said. ``No one would say Hazelwood's a great guy, but they over-did it. More people around here feel it was Exxon, the Coast Guard, the state _ it was a combination of all them,'' Doty said. ``I find myself feeling very sorry for him,'' patron Lorena Stoklosa said. ``A misdemeanor is as much as he deserved,'' said Vince Kelleher, who says he scrubbed Prince William Sound rocks last summer as an Exxon seasonal worker. ``For the rest of his life, he'll find it tough to find a job he's trained for. He's paying the penalty.'' A few doors up the street, at Gordon Bort's Richmond Barber Shop, men waiting for haircuts were understanding. ``He shouldn't have been drinking at all,'' Bort said, as he snipped a customer's hair. ``But since Exxon knew, they should have been up on it.'' Chatting over their afternoon donuts and coffee at the shopping mall, four retired women debated the verdict. ``I hated him and I'm the only one sitting here who does,'' said Bess Crawford, a retired clerical worker. ``He was the captain. Twelve hours later, he still had alcohol in him. When you're responsible for something, you're responsible all the way.'' ``I knew he was gonna get off from the beginning,'' Catherine Brodhead said. ``He wasn't guilty. He wasn't even driving the boat when it happened.'' Eighteen-year-old Jean Walton was behind the mall's ice cream counter. The former cannery worker from the coastal town of Soldotna said Hazelwood deserved stiffer punishment. ``They messed up a lot of the fishermen. Exxon didn't even come close to covering what they did,'' she said. ``I hope they throw the book at the oil companies,'' said optical shop manager Beverly Gilfillan. ``I thought Hazelwood was a scapegoat.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Social Democrats Agree to Dicsuss Coalition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with secret police charges may cause new elections. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BON1
DOC.TEXT: In a move that could speed formation of East Germany's first non-Communist government, the Social Democrats agreed Thursday to discuss joining a coalition government with an alliance that won national elections. The left-leaning party, which finished second in Sunday's balloting to the Alliance for Germany, refused to work with a right-wing party in the three-party Alliance. Alliance leaders left the door open to such an arrangement. As the political jockeying continued, the parliament's future was clouded by concerns that many newly elected lawmakers may have helped the hated former secret police, Stasi. Those under suspicion include the man expected to be named as prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, chief of the Christian Democrats. He denied on Thursday ever having been a secret police collaborator. The official supervising the dismantling of the secret police, Werner Fischer, said Wednesday that many of the new deputies may have had clandestine police links. Manfred Stolpe, a respected figure in East Germany and chief administator of the Lutheran church's Berlin district, urged that all parties agree to an investigation into the 400 newly elected lawmakers' past. He raised the possibility such a probe could lead to new elections, saying, ``I can imagine that such a decision could become necessary as a last resort.'' Fischer on Thursday cited continuing suspicions that de Maiziere collaborated. ``There are indications. There is no proof,'' he told West Germany's ZDF television. He said he had received allegations against de Maiziere from citizens' groups sifting through secret police files in East German cities. Asked on television whether he took these allegations seriously, Fischer said, ``Very.'' On Thursday, De Maiziere denied a West German newspaper report, which cited an anonymous tip to pro-democracy groups as saying de Maiziere was a collaborator with Honecker's secret police. De Maiziere said he only had contacts with them on behalf of dissidents he defended when he was practicing law. Berlin Bishop Gottfried Forck warned against rash accusations in trying to uncover suspected Stasi collaborators. In an interview, he said he believed de Maiziere's denial. The Communists used the Stasi to control all walks of life, and many people were intidimated into collaborating. Until the caretaker government began dissolving it this year, the Stasi had 85,000 agents and hundreds of thousands of informers. The Social Democrats' decision Thursday was vital because a two-thirds majority in the new Parliament is needed to approve unification with West Germany, and the Alliance needs the votes of the Social Democrats to achieve that majority. The Social Democrats favor a more gradual path toward unification with West Germany than the Alliance, and earlier in the week it rejected an invitation to discuss forming a broad coalition. But on Thursday, the party said it decided to hold exploratory talks ``in view of the serious problems of our country.'' ``The (nation's) governability has to have priority,'' Richard Schroeder, a Social Democratic member in Parliament, told a news conference. Party officials said meetings with the Alliance would not begin before Monday. The Christian Democratic Union is the largest party in the Alliance. It won 164 seats in the 400-member Parliament. The Social Democrats have 87, and together the two parties would have an absolute majority. East Germany's Communist-led caretaker government formally remains in power until the new democratically elected Cabinet is formed. Before that happens, West Germany will not resume talks on unity. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who heavily backs the Christian Democratic Union, is pressing for a broad coalition in East Germany to ensure a clear mandate for moves toward unification. The Social Democrats ruled out talks with the German Social Union, the most rightist member of the Alliance of Germany. That obstacle appeared to wane somewhat after de Maiziere and other Alliance leaders met Kohl late Wednesday in Bonn. The East German leaders said their parties will not form a common bloc of deputies. This was seen as a formula that would allow the Social Democrats to join in a coalition without formally having to cooperate with the German Social Union. The daily number of East Germans resettling in West Germany has dropped in half the past week, apparently as a result of national elections, the West German Interior Ministry said Thursday. It said 931 East German resettlers registered with federal authorities on Wednesday, compared with 2,248 one week ago. The exodus sparked the fall pro-democracy revolution that ousted the hard-line Communist regime of Erich Honecker and led to the election _ East Germany's first free vote.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Firearms Bureau Investigating Shots Fired at Buses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after the 10th, ``It did not,'' to UPDATE with second Dallas-bound bus shot at.
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound Lines negotiator will meet with a federal mediator in Washington on Friday as new incidents of violence were reported in the 3-week-old nationwide bus drivers' strike. Company spokesman George Gravley said Thursday that the mediator in the stalled contract talks called Greyhound's chief negotiator, Anthony P. Lanney, to Washington. No new talks are scheduled between management and union. Federal mediators are trying to reopen negotiations or to arrange ``shuttle diplomacy'' between the sides, said Jim Power, spokesman for the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. Renewed violence ``is certainly giving the effort a little more pressure,'' Powers said. ``It doesn't provide a sound basis for getting together. They need some level ground to work on. (Violence) is always counterproductive,'' he said. Jeff Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgmated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said he had no knowledge of discussions between union officials and federal mediators. But Nelson called the meeting between the company and the mediator ``a first step. Maybe they'll find it in their hearts to talk to their employees soon. ``We are absolutely ready to meet at any time,'' he added. The meeting comes against a backdrop of more violence aimed at Greyhound buses, including the first in Texas. That happened overnight Wednesday when a bullet was fired at a bus carrying 30 people in San Antonio. The bullet struck but did not penetrate a service door on an entrance ramp to Interstate 35. No one was injured and the bus continued on to Dallas, Travis County sheriff's officials said. ``It did not penetrate the second window of the double window,'' sheriffs Lt. George Meek said. ``It left a hole in one pane but not the second, because it contains thick insulated plastic.'' A second Dallas-bound bus, from New Orleans, was struck in its rear air filter by a bullet Thursday afternoon 15 miles east of Lake Charles, La., on Interstate 10, company spokeswoman Jean Fry said. No passengers were aboard, she said. The driver heard a loud sound and drove to the Lake Charles terminal, Ms. Fry said. Early Thursday, there were two shootings reported near St. Louis. In the first, a bus from St. Louis to Memphis was hit by three bullets that struck the windshield and the front grill, police said. The incident occurred on Interstate 55 about a mile south of the St. Louis city limits. The second shooting, about 2:35 a.m., occurred in Illinois about five miles east of St. Louis and involved a bus that was en route from Chicago to St. Louis. In both cases, the shots seemed to come from a passing car. No one was injured in the shootings, police said. But in Las Vegas, police said an elderly passenger was slightly injured by flying glass Wednesday when a Greyhound bus en route to Los Angeles was pelted by rocks on Interstate 15, west of the Las Vegas Strip, on Wednesday. The shootings bring the total to 20 since the strike began March 2, according to a Greyhound accounting released Thursday. The report added in the three latest shootings in addition to three earlier incidents that Greyhound said hadn't been reported earlier. Union leaders have said they have no reponsibility for the shootings. They released their own list Thursday, saying 55 pickets have been injured over the three weeks by being struck by buses, hit by security guards, or in other incidents. One striker was killed the second day of the strike when he was hit while on a picket line by a bus drive by a replacement driver; no charges have been filed. Gravley said the violence pushes Greyhound away from reopening talks, which the company halted Sunday in Tucson, Ariz. ``It's impossible to reach an agreement while this violence and terrorism is going on,'' Gravley said Thursday. Nelson, the union spokesman, said his organization issued letters Wednesday afternoon asking members to refrain from violence. ``Whoever has committed these crimes should know that the union will support prosecution to the fullest extent of the law,'' Nelson said. ``These are extremely unfortunate incidents.'' Nelson said the idea that violent acts have tacit approval from union leaders is ``absolutely ridiculous.''

DOC.HEAD: Sportscaster Frank Gifford and Wife Kathie Lee Have Baby
DOC.TEXT: Talk-show hostess Kathie Lee Gifford, the wife of ABC sportscaster Frank Gifford, gave birth to a boy Thursday, a spokeswoman said. Gifford, 59, already has three children by a previous marriage, and five grandchildren. Mrs. Gifford, 36, who stars with Regis Philbin on the syndicated ``Live With Regis & Kathie Lee,'' and the child, who was named Cody, are both doing fine, said Kathleen Singer, the show's spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Ronald Reagan Fundraises for Boston Charity, Comments on Iran-Contra
DOC.TEXT: Children suffering from cancer gave gifts to former President Ronald Reagan on Thursday for his help in raising funds for a cancer research institute, and he briefly discussed his former aide's Iran-Contra trial. Ashley Fitzgerald, 5, and Julie Green, 15, both cancer patients, gave Reagan a glass sculpture and a baseball cap for his work for the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute's Jimmy Fund. Young cancer patients in the institute's Jimmy Fund wing also gave the former president a poster bearing all names. ``I was able to tell them it's going to be hung in the presidential library,'' Reagan told reporters. After the brief presentation, Reagan answered reporters' questions about the trial of John Poindexter, his former national security advisor. On Wednesday, the judge in Poindexter's trial ruled that Reagan did not have to turn over portions of his personal diaries as evidence in the case because of executive privilege. ``I think what we had to do was preserve a tradition,'' Reagan said, adding that taking away executive privilege might ``invade'' the presidency. Reagan also commented on his lack of memory about some events, as displayed in his videotaped testimony shown to the jury Wednesday at Poindexter's trial in Washington. ``I had to say `I don't remember' so many times,'' he said, adding that in his eight years in office he had meet over 400 heads of state and attended numerous meetings and events. ``How do you go back and remember who you met on a certain day?'' Reagan asked.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Complains About Statements by Lawyer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 4-5 with 4 grafs to update with number of potential jurors chosen, judge's comments. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Livington stopped...'
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor in the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos complained to the judge Thursday that interviews given by her attorney to reporters could jeopardize the government's case. ``The fair administration of justice is threatened by defense tactics that run afoul of the criminal rules _ as is the government's right to a fair trial,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Debra Livingston said in a letter to U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan. The interviews Livingston referred to were excerpts from an NBC ``Today Show'' broadcast Tuesday and comments made to several newspapers before the trial started. Livingston gave Keenan the letter during a break in jury selection, now in its third day, and the judge took it under advisement. By the end of the day Thursday, Keenan had selected 31 potential jurors; a final panel of 12 jurors and six alternates is expected to be chosen next week. The letter said Gerry Spence, one of the former Philippine first lady's four attorneys, violated a local rule that prohibits lawyers from commenting on pending criminal cases, except to deny the charges or to quote from documents filed with the court. Later in the day Thursday, Keenan jokingly brought up the issue. ``You're not going to be on `60 Minutes' again?'' he asked Spence, who was profiled on the CBS news show several years ago. ``It depends on what you're going to do to me,'' Spence said. Livingston stopped short of requesting a gag order barring any discussion of the case. She asked Keenan to remind defense lawyers of their responsibility to abide by the rule. Spence had no immediate comment on the government's letter. On Wednesday, he told Keenan that he was concerned about negative publicity. ``In this country and in this legal system one doesn't become a criminal by sleeping with one's husband,'' Spence was quoted as saying on NBC. ``The ghost of Ferdinand Marcos is everywhere, everywhere in this case.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged in the alleged illegal transfer of more than $160 million from the Philippine government and defrauding banking institutions of an additional $165 million. Her husband, former Philippine president, was named in the original October 1988 indictment, but died in Hawaii last Sept. 28. Also on trial is Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, who is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal a series of New York real estate deals allegedly financed in part with money stolen from the Philippine treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Bolivia's Cocaine King Shot to Death
DOC.TEXT: Roberto Suarez Levy, son of jailed cocaine baron Roberto Suarez Gomez, died Thursday night following a shootout with police in the eastern Bolivian city of Santa Cruz, officials said. An Interior Ministry spokesman said Suarez Levy, wanted for several years on charges of drug trafficking, died of bullet wounds suffered in the 7 p.m. confrontation. A police source said an officer also was wounded in the shootout, which apparently occurred while police were trying to take Suarez Levy into custody. Further details were not immediately available. The elder Suarez Gomez has been jailed in Bolivia since 1988, serving a 15-year prison term for trafficking in cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Airline Asks Soviets Not To Bring Jews To Budapest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 6th graf, Israel says ... UPDATING with reax of American Jewish group. Picks up 7th graf, Budapest's Ferihegy ...
DOC.TEXT: The state airline Malev asked Aeroflot, the Soviet air carrier, on Thursday to stop flying Jewish emigres to Hungary, the MTI news agency reported. The request followed Malev's decision Wednesday to suspend flights of Soviet Jews to Israel via Budapest because of a terrorist threat. The pro-Iranian group Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine issued the threat this month in Lebanon, saying, ``All airports facilitating the transport as well as airlines, their jetliners and offices, will be direct targets for us.'' ``This is a warning and a threat,'' said the group, which holds Western hostages in Lebanon. Many Arab governments have opposed the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel on the grounds some of them might settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel says it has no policy of directing immigrants to the territories, which it captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. In New York, the American Jewish Committee asked Hungary to reverse the airline's decision. In a statement Thursday, the committee said only 1 percent of arriving Soviet Jews had settled in the occupied lands. The group said, ``Such arguments only serve as smokescreens for a long-standing and much larger Arab aim: to prevent large-scale Jewish immigration to any part of Israel.'' Budapest's Ferihegy aiport, which tightened security to unprecedented levels in response to the threat, is a transit point for many Soviet Jews traveling from Moscow. There are no direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel. Malev began flying to Israel last year in the wake of renewed diplomatic ties. Despite suspension of charter flights for the Soviet emigrants, the official MTI news agency said tourist flights would continue.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Calls Imelda Offer to Return Wealth a Ruse to Escape Trial
With AM-Marcos Trial
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino on Thursday dismissed an offer by former first lady Imelda Marcos to return wealth left by her late husband, saying it was a ruse to escape trial on U.S. racketeering charges. ``I am not convinced of the seriousness, nor of the sincerity behind this reported latest proposal of Mrs. Marcos, coming as it does, at the start of the trial in New York,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement to reporters. ``The Filipino people want the money that Marcos stole returned to them directly, and without onerous conditions.'' Mrs. Marcos went on trial Tuesday in New York, charged with illegally diverting $160 million to buy property in Manhattan and defrauding banking institutions of an additional $165 million to finance the deal. Her husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines, was named in the original October 1988 indictment, but he died in Hawaii on Sept. 28. In New York, the Philippine government released the text of a letter Wednesday from Mrs. Marcos to President Bush offering to turn over money to a five-member international panel which would oversee its transfer to the Filipino people. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater confirmed that Bush received a letter from Mrs. Marcos but gave no details of the amount of money involved. He said the president could not respond during the trial. In Manila, Solicitor General Francisco Chavez also dismissed Mrs. Marcos' letter as a maneuver by her attorneys. ``It seems to be part of the strategy adapted by her lawyer to picture her as a poor, suffering widow who did not know what her husband did when he was alive,'' Chavez said. ``But all of us know this is ludicrous. This is preposterous because our records show that she was very well within the circle that decided the fate of this country during that time.'' In a related development, Emmanuel Pelaez, the Philippine ambassador to Washington, denied that the issue of U.S. bases in the Philippines played any part in Mrs. Marcos' trial. ``The United States has never attempted to use the Marcos prosecution to influence the Philippines on the bases question, nor has the Philippines ever interfered with or tried to influence the prosecution of the Marcoses under U.S. laws,'' Pelaez said in a statement released in Manila. The United States maintains Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities under the agreement that expires next year. Preliminary negotiations for an extension of the bases are set to begin by the middle of next month. Marcos supporters claim the United States is prosecuting Mrs. Marcos to win favor with the Aquino government so that it will agree to allow the bases to remain.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Thatcher's Candidate Routed in a By-Election Thumping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with Labor easily winning Thatcher's candidate's seat, vote tally. Picks up 5th, `People are...' with minor editing thereafter to trim and conform
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's candidate was trounced Friday in a by-election in central England, losing the Conservative Party stronghold to an opposition socialist by a surprisingly wide margin. The result marked the Conservatives' worst rout in a special parlimantary election in 50 years and was likely to fuel speculation that the Tories might try to dump Mrs. Thatcher as leader this fall. The Labor Party captured the prosperous Mid-Staffordshire district with a 9,449-vote majority, overturning a majority of more than 14,000 votes held by the previous Conservative Party legislator. The result, declared early Friday, reflected anger among voters at soaring 15 percent interest rates that have hiked the cost of home loans and an unpopular new local government tax. Labor candidate Sylvia Heal, a social worker, took 49 percent of the vote, way ahead of the 33 percent for the Conservative contender, accountant Charles Prior. The centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party's Tim Jones trailed with 11 percent. Television networks earlier reported two exit polls conducted by Harris and National Opinion Poll as showing a large swing of more than 20 percent from the government to Labor, something Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker called, ``disappointing.'' ``Clearly we are going through a period of unpopularity. I think it will be temporary,'' Baker said. ``The Labor Party is tonight the passive beneficiary of the protest vote.'' ``People are absolutely fed up with Mrs. Thatcher,'' declared Labor Party spokesman Jack Cunningham. ``She is out of touch, she doesn't seem to understand their problems ... and she doesn't seem to care.'' Underlining the bad news for the Tories, a British Broadcasting Corp. survey Thursday night of the four most recent opinion polls across the country showed Labor averaging a 21-point lead nationally. This was Labor's biggest lead since Mrs. Thatcher won a third successive term in 1987. A year ago, the Tories had a 10-point lead nationally. From Mid-Staffordshire, pollsters reported an underlying antipathy toward Mrs. Thatcher personally among many of the people questioned right after they voted in the prosperous, semi-rural district. Harris reported that 84 percent of defecting Conservatives said Mrs. Thatcher should resign before the next general election, which must be held by mid-1992. Among defectors questioned by the National Opinion Poll, 38 percent said she should quit. Harris' exit poll for Independent Television News at the 10 p.m. close of voting showed Labor winning 50 percent of the vote with the Conservatives getting 32 percent and the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party 11 percent. ITN said Harris questioned 2,369 people. The National Opinion Poll of nearly 2,300 voters for the BBC showed Labor with 51 percent, the Conservatives 32 percent and the centrists 10 percent. The margin of error was 3 percent. The polls showed the remainder of the vote scattered among the Greens, a centrist splinter group, the Social Democratic Party, and nine fringe candidates. The election seat became vacant by the suicide in December of the Conservative politician who took 50 percent of the vote to win with a 14,654-vote majority in the 1987 general election. Thatcher aides argued that by-elections traditionally attract large protest votes. However, the vote was likely to be regarded as a barometer of her chances of winning the next general election and a trouncing would renew speculation of a possible attempt to dump her as party leader this fall. Mid-Staffordshire runs from the affluent cathedral town of Lichfield, birthplace of the 18th century poet and dictionary compiler Samuel Johnson, through an industrial town, Rugeley. The voters include a high proportion of skilled blue-collar workers who voted Tory through the '80s, followed Mrs. Thatcher's exhortations to buy their own homes and are now hard-hit by high home loan rates. Interest rates have doubled in under two years in an attempt to curb inflation, now running at 7.7 percent and rising. In addition, Mid-Staffordshire voted while there's a national furor over the new per-head tax, dubbed the poll tax that next month replaces property taxes under a reform of local government financing. The tax, which Mrs. Thatcher says is fairer because everyone pays, is averaging $580 a year and means most families pay about one-third more. The election had no effect on Mrs. Thatcher's overwhelming control of the 650-member House of Commons, where she has a 101-seat majority. Going into the vote, the Conservatives had 374 seats, compared with Labor's 228, and the Social and Liberal Democrats' 19. The remainder are held by minority parties.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Candidate Slain at Bogota Airport, Drug Lord Blamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS three grafs for 15-16th bgng `On Jan....' to UPDATE with Barco reax; pickup graf 17 pvs `Right-wing...
DOC.TEXT: A young man reached out as if to welcome a presidential candidate Thursday and shot him to death with a submachine gun hidden in a newspaper. Police said a notorious drug lord ordered the assassination. Colombia's intellegence police chief, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, said an investigation had determined that the leader of the Medellin drug cartel, Pablo Escobar, ordered the assassination of Bernardo Jaramillo of the leftist Patriotic Union Party. An official communique from the National Security Council said the police had intercepted radio communications between Escobar and one of his subordinates implicating the drug boss in the killing early Thursday at Bogota's El Dorado International Airport. Earlier Thursday, a telephone caller claimed the attack for the Medellin cartel. Bodyguards with Jaramillo shot and wounded the gunman before he was captured. At least two other people were reported wounded. ``A man walked up to him to greet him like a supporter and then began shooting,'' one of the bodyguards told Caracol radio, which also reported Maza Marquez's statement. ``Bernardo fell to the floor and was protected by his wife and bodyguards while we fired on the aggressor.'' Maza Marquez said Escobar's order was confirmed by the gunman during interrogations. The gunman said he was paid $625 to kill Jaramillo. The police chief, who has been targeted by the cartel in two bombings, said the assassin was a 16-year-old boy who carried false identification papers. Police earlier said the assailant was a 21-year-old. The gunman fired on Jaramillo after the candidate and his wife arrived at the airport Thursday morning for an Avianca flight to the tourist city of Santa Marta on Colombia's north coast, officials said. Jaramillo was hit four times, twice in the throat and twice in the abdomen, and died later at a hospital, officials said. Caracol's Bogota station received a telephone call from a man who said the Medellin cocaine cartel had slain the 38-year-old candidate, who was to run in the May 27 election. The caller said four gunmen were involved and that three escaped. He said another presidential candidate, Cesar Gaviria of the Liberal Party, would be assassinated next. Maza Marquez said the captured gunman told police other politicians were on the drug cartel's hit list. Drug traffickers in August killed another presidential hopeful, Luis Carlos Galan of the governing Liberal Party. That killing sparked a government crackdown on drug lords and the extradition of 14 drug suspects to the United States. Late Thursday, President Virgilio Barco said in a letter to Patriotic Union president Diego Montana that in light of the ``new offensive by the violent ones,'' the party should join the country's efforts to defend democracy. On Jan. 18, the Medellin cartel said in a communique that the government had won its war with the cartel and appealed for an end to extraditing suspects to the United States. The caller Thursday said it was renewing the war because Barco would not accept an offer for the traffickers to give themselves up to be tried in Colombian courts. Right-wing death squads also have been blamed for previous slayings of Patriotic Union members. Authorities say some of them are be run by drug traffickers. The Patriotic Union, though, has claimed that Colombia's army and police are involved in the death squads. The government permitted the Communist Party and former guerrillas to organize the Patriotic Union in 1984 to persuade rebel groups to end three decades of violence. The party on Thursday said Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds had caused the latest killing with a statement last week, and it called for him to resign. Lemos had accused the Patriotic Union of acting as the political arm of the country's largest guerrilla group, the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces. A submachine gun attack by four men in the Bogota airport's main terminal on March 3, 1989, killed a member of the executive committee of the Patriotic Union and wounded a Liberal Party presidential candidate, Ernesto Samper. Americas Watch, a human rights group based in New York, said Thursday that such attacks in the past had been mounted by both drug groups and paramilitary organizations supported by army officers. ``Mr. Jaramillo's murder highlights the fact that the targetting of the Patriotic Union and other leftist organizations ... has nver stopped in Colombia, even though international attention continues to be focused on the violent acts of the drug cartels against ... public officials,'' said Juan Mendez, Americas Watch executive director. As word spread of Jaramillo's death, disturbances flared in downtown Bogota. People burned a bus and shattered windows of a few stores. The Patriotic Union called for a national strike. The body of Jaramillo was taken to the national Capitol building while police reported several battles between people throwing rocks and security forces firing tear gas in the streets of Bogota. An official communique said one police officer was shot and wounded by one protester before riot police restored order. At the State Department in Washington, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``The killing is yet another outrageous assault against the democratic aspirations of the Colombian people, and we condemn those who would attempt to force political change through violent acts such as this.'' Jaramillo was the 1,044th member of the Patriotic Union Party to be killed in the last six years. He resigned as president of the Patriotic Union in February 1989 and fled the country, citing death threats, but returned six weeks later. Drug traffickers have killed more than 200 people in bombings and other attacks since the Barco government began cracking down on drug lords after Galan's slaying.

DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev stepped up his war of nerves with Lithuania by demanding the surrender of all firearms, but the breakaway republic's leaders said they were not intimidated and would not bend. President Vytautus Landsbergis of Lithuania, which declared itself independent on March 11, said in a statement that the Soviet leader's Wednesday decree showed ``the ghost of Stalinism is walking in the Kremlin.'' Landsbergis said the Baltic republic would remain ``serene and united'' despite the decree, which he said ``could be enforced only by brutal military force.'' Gorbachev has called Lithuania's declaration of independence illegal but has also said he would not use force to keep it from seceding.

Senate Democrats are outlining a new $2 billion aid package for Eastern Europe _ far more than President Bush wants to spend and several times what Democrats themselves proposed just two months ago. The draft bill escalates a Democratic argument that Bush has been too timid in aiding the emerging democracies and establishing a foothold for U.S. companies in their newly free economies. The bill by Sens. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., includes a $1.2 billion U.S. share in a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, proposed by France to finance public works and new private enterprises in former communist economies. A copy of the draft was obtained Wednesday by The Associated Press.

The Bush administration is moving swiftly to appeal a judge's order that threatens a costly delay in the president's savings and loan bailout. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth barred the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Wednesday from seizing Olympic Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill. Lamberth said thrift office director Salvatore R. Martoche and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, were unconstitutionally appointed. He said the government may not seize the suburban Chicago thrift until a new director is nominated by President Bush and confirmed by the Senate. The judge rejected a last-minute plea from government attorneys to stay his order. They said they would ask the U.S. Court of Appeals to overturn it.

Households across the nation will receive census forms in the mail starting Friday, as the head count shifts its focus from the homeless to the rest of the U.S. population. The most ambitious effort ever to count the homeless wound up early Wednesday, with Census Bureau Director Barbara Everett Bryant proclaiming success. ``We can now move on to the rest of America,'' she said, urging people to complete their census forms and send them back promptly. Nearly 85 million census forms already have been trucked to bulk distribution centers of the U.S. Postal Service. They will go into the hands of letter carriers Friday for delivery to homes nationwide.

The Senate is approaching a showdown over whether to provide aid to coal miners who lose their jobs because of new pollution controls, and the outcome could determine whether a clean air bill passes this year. The coal issue has placed two of the Senate's most powerful members at odds: Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who was Mitchell's predecessor as Senate leader and still wields immense power as chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Byrd has been pressing an assistance program for miners in his state and elsewhere if they lose their jobs because of tougher acid rain controls at coal-burning power plants in the Midwest. On Wednesday night, he offered to lower the package's expected cost from $700 million over four years to $500 million over three years.

President Bush says he still won't eat his broccoli and not even his ``totalitarian'' wife can make him. Bush expressed delight Wednesday that California growers were shipping 10 tons of the green vegetable to feed the hungry in the nation's capital. ``I am not going to rethink my position,'' a puckish president insisted on his way home from the Oval Office. Barbara Bush has publicly bemoaned the difficulty of getting her husband to eat his vegetables, but Bush said later he didn't really ban broccoli from the presidential plane.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Women Guerrillas Moving Into the Open
DOC.TEXT: Women guerrillas of the Tamil Tigers, cyanide capsules around their necks and assault rifles ready, have moved out of the jungles and into the towns since Indian peacekeeping troops went home. The emergence of the Tiger women, who were talked about often but seldom seen, is jolting society in the Jaffna Peninsula of northern Sri Lanka, where the Tamil minority predominates. Violence has been a way of life here since the revolt by Tamil separatists began in 1983, but warfare was considered men's work. ``Our social fabric and lifestyle have been completely destroyed,'' said Velupillai Kanapathipillai, a Tamil schoolteacher. ``It will never be the same after seeing these young girls carrying guns.'' Kanapathipillai was echoing traditional beliefs that Tamil women should be demure. Lt. Imelda, a 26-year-old commander of the Female Tigers of Tamil Eelam, has little time for that. She and the other women in her outfit can handle T-81 Chinese assault rifles and machine pistols, rocket launchers and anti-aircraft guns, she said. Stanley Dominic, district leader of the male Tigers, spoke with pride of the women. ``They do everything we do,'' he told an interviewer in Jaffna. ``They man checkpoints 24 hours. They drive heavy trucks captured from the Indian army. They take part in active combat, and they are willing to bite their cyanide capsules to avoid being captured.'' The Tigers say more than 300 of their men have used cyanide to commit suicide rather than submit to capture and interrogation. Imelda said she did not know how many women Tigers had used their capsules. About 25 Tiger women in camouflage gear guarded her two-story headquarters during a recent visit. The women are segregated from the male Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the largest guerrilla force, which has fought both the Sri Lankan army and Indian peacekeeping troops. No men were in sight at the headquarters, and a male visitor was eyed with suspicion. Imelda, who uses a code name like many male Tigers, said 26 women guerrillas died in face-to-face combat with male Indian soldiers in two years. She denied periodic speculation that the female Tigers were created to fight Indian paramilitary policewomen who served in Sri Lanka along with the all-male Indian army. ``No Indian woman soldier can fight me,'' Imelda said, eyes blazing. ``They are powder puffs. I challenge them.'' Neither male nor female Tigers will give the total strength of the guerrillas, who seek a separate homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka to be called Tamil Eelam. The militants claim discrimination by Sri Lanka's ethnic Sinhalese majority. Sinhalese, 75 percent of the 16 million people, control the government and army of this island off the tip of India. Tamils make up 18 percent of the population. More than 11,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old ethnic war. In 1989, the Tamil Tigers began negotations with the Sri Lankan government on a peaceful solution. As Indian troops withdrew, the Tigers took over positions and whole towns once patrolled by the peacekeepers, with no serious opposition from the Sri Lankan military. Male guerrillas patrol Jaffna town, but many residents speak with awe of the female Tigers, who occasionally are seen in the town and nearby villages. Imelda said the women Tigers, like their male counterparts, have a strict code of conduct. ``We are not permitted to have boyfriends, wear makeup or jewelry, not even powder our faces,'' she said. One of her fighters, 20-year-old Valarmathy, said: ``Women have been in the forefront of the liberation struggle all over the world. We are no exception.'' Like Imelda, Valarmathy would not say when she joined the Tigers or what she did before.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Koppel Celebrates 10th ``Nightline'' Anniversary, Quietly
DOC.TEXT: Anniversaries always are big deals in TV. But don't expect a gala edition of ABC's ``Nightline'' tonight to note that it will be 10 years old on Saturday. In fact, don't even expect Ted Koppel to anchor it tonight. ``As a matter of fact, I`m taking the day off,'' says Koppel, the show's anchor ever since it premiered as a 20-minute, Monday-through-Thursday late-night news interview program on March 24, 1980. The celebration of a decade will occur in late April with a prime-time edition of ``Nightline,'' featuring suitable highlights of its existence. The show's honors include two Peabody Awards and general acclaim for Koppel's crisp, to-the-point interviews of a wide variety of guests: world leaders, sports executives, diplomats, AIDS victims, Arabs and Israelis together, generals, and even Gary Hart, a two-time visitor. But his most-watched show concerned what some might call light entertainment, a chat with the since-fallen TV preacher Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy, in May 1987. It got a 41 percent share of the audience, and viewers in more than 12.3 million homes tuned in. True, more cosmic matters tend to draw smaller audiences. The show averages 5 million to 6 million homes each night, ABC says. Sometimes it's even lower _ only about 3.9 million homes in the week ending March 9. But ``Nightline,'' the brainchild of ABC News President Roone Arledge, has proved there is room in late-night TV for news interviews as an alternative to amusements, and it can get ratings even on those nights Johnny Carson fills in for his guest hosts. ``It's the only show of its kind that time at night _ it's really the only show of its kind in commercial television,'' says Koppel, whose program, among other things, has held six world-class ``town meetings.'' The most recent one, set against the backdrop of the freeing of black leader Nelson Mandela, took place last month in South Africa. What has become ``Nightline'' began on Nov. 8, 1979, with a different title and as a single-subject effort anchored by the late Frank Reynolds. Aired four days after 65 Americans were seized at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, the show was called ``The Iran Crisis: America Held Hostage.'' A week later, through Arledge's efforts, ABC began ``America Held Hostage,'' a late-night series on the crisis. The show initially was anchored by Reynolds, then Peter Jennings and finally Koppel. Koppel, with ABC News for 27 of his 50 years, became permanent anchor of the series two weeks after it began, staying at the helm as ``Nightline'' premiered and evolved into its half-hour, five-night format. The anchorman, who now gets Monday nights off, became famous and wealthy. And, in an unusual arrangement nearly three years ago, he also got a new contract under which his own production company makes four prime-time ABC specials a year, which he then can sell overseas. Although he and ``Nightline'' generally have enjoyed critical huzzahs, they have suffered a few shots, too, notably from a media watchdog group, Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting. FAIR, citing its analysis of ``Nightline'' shows from 1985 to 1988, complained about what it said was the show's preponderance of white male guests from government, corporations and the military. ``The larger question here is ... their perception and analysis that we had a great many white male conservatives on the program,'' Koppel says. ``Well, if you look at the 10 years that `Nightline' has been on the air, during those years Ronald Reagan was president, George Bush was president and the policy-makers and decision-makers, the people they put into power, tend to be white male conservatives.'' Koppel, whose current ABC contract ends in December, estimates he and his ``Nightline'' staff work about 13 hours a day on each show, and a 15-hour day isn't all that unusual. But he has no ambitions, he says, to anchor a network newscast. ``I'd rather do what I do now,'' he says. Nor would he like to shift from what is show-time for him _ 11:30 p.m. EST _ to a prime-time news series. Such a series would give ABC three; it already has the veteran ``20@20'' and fledgling ``PrimeTime Live.'' But there would be no joy in weekly prime time for Koppel. ``I just don't think that a `Nightline'-like program would make it in prime time,'' he says. ``We would undoubtedly get more viewers than we get right now at 11:30 at night. But I don't think we'd get enough more to make it a successful prime-time program.''

Elsewhere in television ... OIL AND THE '60s THIS WEEKEND: There'll be another anniversary Saturday _the first anniversary of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. With that in mind, cable TV's Discovery Channel, which last Sunday showed ``Black Tide,'' an hour-long documentary on the spill, is repeating the show late tonight. On Sunday night, Ted Turner's TBS cable superstation will check in with ``Outrage at Valdez,'' another documentary on the massive spill. On the lighter side, ``The Outsiders,'' a new drama series on what it was like to grow up in the '60s, gets a 90-minute premiere Sunday on the Fox network. The young lads in the cast will wear ducktails, of course. The show's publicity shots make them appear victims of a massive Brylcreem spill.

DOC.HEAD: Execution Nears for First Man To Die in Gas Chamber in 23 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Monday in 23rd graf is March 26.
DOC.TEXT: To prosecutors and the families of his victims, Robert Alton Harris is a vicious murderer who laughed about killing two teen-agers and told one to ``quit crying and die like a man.'' To his lawyers and closest friend, he is the product of a violently abusive childhood who, during a decade on death row, has grown into a stable, caring, remorseful man. Harris has become a symbol of the public's anger over violent crime and legal delays in carrying out the state's death penalty law, but April 3, barring a last-minute stay, he will become the first person executed in California since 1967. Harris, 37, was convicted of abducting and killing two 16-year-old San Diego boys 12 years ago to get their car for a bank robbery that netted $3,000. ``It seems to me if anybody deserves the death penalty, it is Harris,'' said San Diego County Superior Court Judge Michael Wellington, who as a state deputy attorney general fought most of Harris' appeals over the past decade. ``Two murders, a pair of kidnappings, a bank robbery by someone who was six months out on parole from a previous homicide _ the crime is horrible, inexcusable,'' Wellington said. Michael Kroll, a writer and death penalty opponent who befriended Harris, agrees the crimes are ``horrendous.'' But he insists the man he has visited weekly for the past eight years is not the cold-blooded monster drawn by prosecutors and should be spared the trip to San Quentin's gas chamber. Harris has admitted shooting the boys, but said he does not know why. On July 5, 1978, he and his 18-year-old brother, Danny, planned to rob a branch of the San Diego Trust and Savings Bank, but needed a getaway car. Harris spotted a green Ford in a parking lot; John Mayeski and his friend Michael Baker sat inside, eating hamburgers from a nearby fast-food restaurant. Harris pulled out a 9mm Luger, climbed into the Ford and ordered John to drive to a deserted spot. Danny Harris, who followed in the brothers' car, later testified that Harris told the boys he would not hurt them and ordered them to walk up a fire trail. But Harris shot John in the back and the head, then ran after Michael, who fled and hid behind a rock, Danny said. When Harris caught up with him, the boy screamed, prayed and pleaded for his life. ``Quit crying and die like a man,'' Harris later boasted of telling the teen-ager, a cellmate testified. ``God can't help you now, boy. You're going to die.'' Harris shot Michael four times, then shot John again in the head. At his girlfriend's apartment, he laughed about the shootings and ate the boys' unfinished meals, Danny said. Among the officers who arrested Harris a short time later was Steven Baker, Michael's father. Baker, who learned only later his son was dead, has waited more than a decade to watch Harris' execution. ``They were good boys, doing well in school, they didn't have any problems, and on that particular day they were going fishing,'' Baker said. ``(And Harris) just executed those boys.'' In exchange for testifying against his brother, Danny Harris was not charged with murder but served 3{ years for robbery. Harris was convicted of murder and sentenced to death in early 1979, but three previous execution dates were dissolved during the appeals process. ``It's just an open sore that never seems to heal,'' Baker said of the delays. In January, the U.S. Supreme Court, in its fourth consideration of the case, refused to hear Harris' appeal. On Feb. 5, a San Diego judge issued a death warrant setting the April 3 execution date. On March 16, the state Supreme Court refused to overturn the death sentence or stay the execution. Harris' lawyers said they would file another appeal Monday in federal court in San Diego, but there are few legal issues left to argue. Last week, Harris withdrew his request for clemency from Gov. George Deukmejian, saying he did not think it would get fair consideration. Deukmejian, a former state attorney general, advocates capital punishment and wrote California's current death penalty law. Harris' attorneys argue his rights were violated and claim his progress in prison disproves a prosecution psychiatrist's testimony depicting him as a ``sociopath'' incapable of remorse or rehabilitation. They also have submitted statements from some of the 273 other death row inmates praising Harris as well-liked, decent, helpful and generous. ``Unlike most men here, we've seen the changes Robert Harris has gone through. We've also seen something you won't see on many faces here _ remorse,'' wrote inmate James A. Melton. The Supreme Court petition also offered ``newly discovered'' evidence of mental disorders stemming from childhood abuse. Harris, the fifth of nine children, was born in South Carolina more than two months prematurely when his father kicked his alcoholic mother, claiming she was carrying another man's child. He was beaten daily and dropped on his head several times as a young child. A sister said in court documents that their father often threatened them, loading his weapons and warning, ``You have only 30 minutes to hide.'' When Harris was 13, after the family had moved to California and broken up, his mother abandoned him as they picked fruit near Modesto. Two years later, he was arrested in Florida for stealing a car and spent 4{ years in prison, then settled in Southern California's Imperial Valley and worked as a welder. His former wife, Cheryl, later testified he beat her and threaten to kill her if she told anyone. At the time of the murders, Harris had been on parole for six months after spending almost 2{ years in prison for manslaughter. His background does not excuse his crimes, but helps explain them and makes life in prison a more appropriate penalty, Kroll said. ``If you treat a child in a way totally devoid of love, totally violent ... you will get pathological violence at the other end, however it's manifested,'' he said. Baker and prosecutors argue that Harris' past was known and considered at the proper time _ by the jury that recommended a death sentence. ``I believe very strongly that you are responsible for your own actions,'' Baker said. ``It's become so easy and so common for people to blame other circumstances.'' Now Baker waits for prosecutors to call him in San Diego and tell him to buy a plane ticket for the execution. ``I think I''ll feel relieved that the entire ordeal is finally over,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Buick Riviera: Re-Redesign Brings Back the Size _ and the Buyers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It doesn't pay to mess with a good thing. Take the 1990 Buick Riviera. Save for some modifications of the instrument panel and more luxurious interior features, the car is virtually unchanged from its 1989 reincarnation as one of America's cherished luxury coupes. Thank heavens. In the 1986 model year, when Buick shrank the Riv, sales plunged from 55,546 the previous year to 25,835. By the 1987 model year, sales were down to 19,838, then to 9,241 in 1988. The signals were clear: Americans wanted their Riv big and luxurious. The 1990 Riviera is that and more. In fact, the Riviera ranked as the top domestic car and No. 2 among imports and domestic cars combined in a study by market researchers J.D. Power and Associates of Agoura Hills, Calif. The study surveyed buyers of 1989 models about initial quality of their vehicles. For anyone with warm memories of earlier Rivieras, the 1990 model doesn't disappoint. Exterior styling retains the traditional Riv look with the cutoff rear roofline followed by swept-back rear end. It's longer, by 11 inches, than the previous model. It's solid _ doors are heavy and close with a decided thud. The interior of the test car exuded traditional luxury. The wide front seats cradled the body, as did the outer seat areas of the back seat. Leather (an $895 option) made the test car even more luxurious. Legroom in back was commendable. Three adults could be accommodated in the back seat, and even the person in the middle had a cushioned resting spot. I liked the handles that Buick installed on the door pillars next to the small rear windows _ they made getting out a lot easier. Oddly, the two front seats offered distinctly different perspectives. On the driver's side, the dashboard and instrument cluster jut out to put the radio and ventilation controls within easy reach and the instruments close for easy viewing. The instruments, by the way, were rather jazzy _ lit up in green circles in an arrangement that seemed befitting an airplane cockpit. This was a simpler design from last year's Riviera, which had an electronic control console that some auto writers criticized as too complex. On the passenger side, however, the dash and glovebox were pushed back against the windshield, offering a roomy seating area that made it easy to cross and uncross legs. The trunk was wide but had a slightly raised area in the center where the spare tire is located. The 3.8-liter, fuel-injectd V-6, coupled with four-speed automatic transmission with overdrive, was nicely responsive and controlled. Suspension and handling were not as mushy as you might expect, thanks in part to the optional Gran touring package ($104) that added stiffer than normal suspension and Goodyear GT-4 radial tires. Still, the ride should appeal even to those looking for a soft ride. The test car also had optional antilock brakes ($925) that worked well but kicked up quite a fuss on ice. As expected in a luxury car, the 1990 Riviera has a host of standard features such as automatic climate control, which includes air conditioning, cruise control, AM-FM stereo cassette, and power steering and brakes. I also appreciated the test car's $865 option package that added a keyless entry system. This niftily lets you lock and unlock the doors, unlock the trunk and turn on the interior lights from within 10 feet of the car by pushing buttons on a control switch on the key chain. It saves having to fumble with keys with an armload of groceries, for instance. The package also includes power seats, a rear-view mirror that automatically adjusts to headlight glare and a heated driver-side mirror. Buick spokesman Gary Witzenburg said women account for 56 percent of the primary Riviera drivers and 41 percent of the purchase decision-makers. Riviera buyers have median income of $60,000 to $65,000 and an average age of 50. Seventy-one percent are married, and 40 percent have college degrees, he added. With the re-redesign of the Riviera in autumn 1988, sales rebounded to 20,000 in the 1989 model year. And while Buick does not make projections for specific models in the 1990 model year, it does look for overall sales of all Buick models to increase 6 percent, Witzenburg said. Despite the high quality rating from J.D. Power and Associates for 1989 Rivieras, earlier models have not fared as well, according to Consumer Reports magazine. It ranked the smaller, 1986-87 Riviera V-6 models as much worse than average in owner reports of trouble. There were no Consumer Reports listings for the redesigned 1988 or 1989 models.
