DOC.HEAD: FDA Looking at Microwave Packages That Pop Corn and Brown Pizza
DOC.TEXT: The special containers that make waffles brown and french fries crisp in microwave ovens have prompted authorities to question whether unsafe levels of chemicals are ending up in food. At issue are heat susceptors, metallized discs or strips built into packaging that absorb microwaves and act as little ``frying pans'' to brown or crisp foods like fish sticks and pizza or pop most of the kernels in a bag of popcorn. At least one consumer advocacy group recommends consumers avoid products containing susceptors until the U.S. Food and Drug Adminstration determines if worrisome levels of chemicals in the packages migrate into food during cooking. ``We need to know what chemicals are getting into foods at what levels,'' said Lester Borodinsky, a chemist with the FDA's Division of Food Chemistry and Technology. Although the package components have FDA approval, the agency did not evaluate them at temperatures above 300 degrees. Heat susceptors can reach 500 degrees. ``Our crystal balls weren't very good back then,'' Borodinsky said. ``If you think back 25 years ago, there were not very many microwave ovens in use. These packages were not envisioned.'' and flowed through cracks and fissures to low-lying areas as far as 400 miles to the north over the next 2 million years, creating the plateau, the theory holds. Another upwelling of lava is responsible for a ``hot spot'' of volcanic activity beneath Yellowstone, the scientists suggest. The origin of hot spots far from the geologic plate boundaries where most volcanos are located is a long-standing mystery in geology. As the Earth's crustal plates drift over stationary hot spots, new volcanos are formed and old ones become extinct.
DOC.HEAD: Conference Told U.S. Should Take Lead in Solar Energy
DOC.TEXT: If the United States fails to become a world leader in solar energy, a trillion-dollar new market could fall to the Japanese, a national conference on solar power was told. ``Frankly, there has been a tendency by energy companies in the past to label solar energy as a joke,'' said S. David Freeman, general manager of the Lower Colorado River Authority. ``If we keep this up, the joke will be on us. We will see the Japanese come in and put photovoltaic cells on our roofs and solar-powered cars on our roads,'' Freeman said in the keynote speech last week at a National Solar Energy Conference. Freeman's agency provides electric power to 33 cities and 11 cooperatives in Texas. He previously was an energy adviser in the Johnson, Nixon and Carter administrations and was board chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority. He told the conference that historians in the future may wonder why solar power wasn't investigated more vigorously during the late 20th century, while nations so heavily used such technologically difficult and environmentally risky sources as oil and nuclear energy. Freeman said a solar-energy breakthrough is crucial to the survival of a high-energy civilization, particularly when U.S. oil imports are soaring and concerns are growing over the environment. ``If one looks at the awesome problems posed by nuclear power, at its best, one must wonder why this nation has not long ago embarked on a `Manhattan'-type project to harness the sun,'' he said. Freeman said he doesn't believe the solar industry needs subsidies. ``But we do need to be advocating pollution taxes to reduce pollution and to reduce the federal deficit,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for March 26

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Plunges in Morning Session
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was down sharply in mid-afternoon trading Thursday and pessimism in the currency market sent the yen tumbling against the U.S. dollar. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average was off 1,629.51 points, or 5.29 percent, at 29,177.68 in mid-afternoon, narrowing huge losses than left the index at 16-month lows at the end of morning trading. In the early session, the Nikkei plunged 1,836.05 points, or 5.96 percent, closing at 28,836.05. It was the Nikkei's lowest level since Nov. 15, 1988, when it ended at 28,829.41. The dollar started the afternoon at 155.20 yen following heavy dollar-buying in the morning. It opened at 154.50 yen, up 0.85 yen and was ranged between 154.50 yen and 155.45 yen during the early session. Its morning close of 155.20 yen was the highest level since Feb. 9, 1987, according to the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank. ``This time, the plunges are really deep. It will take a rather long time to recover,'' said Ikuko Sekiguchi, a dealer with Nikko Securities. The stock plunge extended a series of huge losses on the world's largest stock exchange, which has plunged more than 20 percent since the start of the year. The Nikkei lost a combined 1,809.25 points on Monday and Tuesday. The markets were closed Wednesday because of a national holiday. The usually lively, crowded floor of the Tokyo Stock Exchange was sober and subdued as a rush of sell orders met with virtually no buyers. Almost half of the issues listed on the the exchange trading floor's electronic billboard remained unquoted. Trading was estimated at an exceptionally low 180 million shares. ``Selling came mainly from institutional investors acting prior to the year-end account settlements,'' said Yoshio Shimoyama, a chief dealer at Nikko Securities Co. The sales were intended to offset earlier losses or cash out losing positions, he said. Institutional investors have been selling in an attempt to reduce risk ahead of closing their books for fiscal 1989, which ends March 31. Shimoyama said the yen's continuing weakness, despite the discount rate increase, accelerated selling. Japan's central bank raised its official discount rate Tuesday by one percentage point to 5.25 percent. Analysts blamed a delay in the long-anticipated increase for destabilizing Japan's financial markets. ``Market players were overwhelmingly dumping issues, but that's not panic selling yet,'' Shimoyama said. Kazuto Aizawa, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., said he could not foresee a recovery in the market ``unless the government takes some measure, because the loss is so big.'' Currency dealers said the yen declined further as the stock market's huge loss discouraged currency investors. ``It's like a rat race situation, as the stock and foreign exchange markets are affected by each other's performances,'' said a trader with the Bank of Tokyo, who asked not to be named. The Bank of Japan was seen intervening in the market throughout Thursday morning, but the action had no major impact on the yen, dealers said. Local news reports said the bank sold about $700 million. The central bank does not officially comment on its market interventions. Traders attributed the dollar's higher opening in Tokyo to a strong showing in New York on Wednesday. Multiple factors, including escalating tensions in the Soviet republic of Lithuania, were said to have contributed to the U.S. currency's strength. Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11, but the Soviets have termed the move illegal. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev Wednesday ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons. Investors often regard the dollar as a safe haven in times of international tension. Discouraged by the yen's decline, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond plunged to 85.75 points in the afternoon from Tuesday's close at 86.27 points. Its yield rose to 7.40 percent from 7.29 percent.

The federal budget deficit totaled $97.52 billion for the first five months of fiscal year 1990, just $2.48 billion less than the Gramm-Rudman deficit target for the entire year, the government said. The Treasury Department said Wednesday the deficit last month was $36.42 billion, 30.1 percent above the $27.87 billion imbalance in February 1989. Receipts totaled $65.17 billion in February, up 5.3 percent from the same month last year. But expenditures amounted to $101.58 billion, a 13.2 percent increase over February 1989.

In a case that could derail President Bush's savings and loan bailout, a federal judge has barred thrift regulators from seizing an ailing Illinois institution. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth barred the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Wednesday from taking control of Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association in Berwyn, Ill. The ruling came the same day that a top thrift regulator said the government planned to dramatically increase the pace of the bailout by selling or closing 140 institutions by the end of June.

USX Corp. said takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal to split USX's energy and steel businesses would weaken the company's borrowing power and make it more vulnerable to business downturns. Icahn's plan is ``a simplistic approach to a complicated issue,'' the company's directors said in a proxy statement mailed Wednesday to USX's 144,000 shareholders. The statement concerns issues before the May 7 annual meeting. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, wants the company to incorporate its steel division into an independent, publicly traded company to be known as U.S. Steel Corp. and spin off 80 percent of it.

The Bush administration said that a debt agreement reached with Venezuela proves that its year-old plan for solving the Third World debt crisis is working. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said Wednesday the success in Venezuela would be followed by similar agreements in other debt-strapped countries. Three nations _ Morocco, Ecuador and Uruguay _ may announce agreements with commerical banks within the next six months, Mulford said.

Nearly half the 36 million letters the IRS mailed to taxpayers last year demanding additional tax and penalties were erroneous, Money magazine estimated. Taxpayers confused by the law and afraid of challenging the Internal Revenue Service forked over $7 billion that they did not owe, the magazine said Wednesday in its April edition. The magazine interviewed lawyers, tax accountants and IRS officials in reaching those conclusions.

An advocacy group said it filed a lawsuit against the maker of an allegedly defective heart valve that has been implanted in the chests of more than 80,000 people. Public Citizen asked the court in the suit filed Wednesday to order Shiley Inc. and its parent company, Pfizer Inc., to notify all those who have had the valve implanted about alleged defects and possible life-threatening consequences if it fails. Pfizer, based in New York, said the suit is ``completely without merit'' and will ``frighten cardiac patients unnecessarily and ultimately do much more harm than good.''

The Food and Drug Administration has barred government agencies from buying certain drugs from Abbott Laboratories, charging the company failed to correct violations of quality standards at a suburban Chicago plant. The FDA also said in a letter dated March 14 but not disclosed until Tuesday that it would not approve any new drug applications by the pharmaceutical giant that involve certain products made in the plant.

Two lawmakers who succeeded in snuffing out cigarettes on most domestic flights have announced that Amtrak is about to make it tougher to light up on trains. Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., said Wednesday that Amtrak's new policy will take effect April 1. The new policy will continue to permit passengers to smoke in sleeping compartments.

British conglomerate BAT Industries PLC said it might favor management bids for its U.S. retailers, including the Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field chains, but not at stockholders' expense. The company also posted a 38 percent jump in its 1989 net profit on Wednesday, boosted by record earnings from the group's tobacco interests and a near doubling of earnings at its financial services division.

The stock market finished lower Wednesday in light trading, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 10.81 points to close at 2,727.93. Bond prices retreated. The dollar finished mixed against major currencies. Copper futures prices surged to new five-month highs; precious metals were mixed; petroleum futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Doesn't Support Pension Fund Tax Incentive Bill
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady says he opposes a proposed bill to tax the short-term capital gains of pension funds because it might open the legislative door to other, unwanted taxes. Brady told a Senate panel Wednesday that while the Treasury Department ``does not now'' support the proposed legislation ``we applaud its objectives of promoting long-term investment.'' But Brady told the Senate Finance Committee that ``agreeing to a tax on pension funds might lead to taxes on individuals and other entities to which we would be opposed.'' The bill, sponsored by Kansas Republican senators Robert Dole and Nancy Landon Kassebaum, would tax the capital gains that pension funds make from the sale of securities held less than six months. The bill would tax only funds with $1 million or more in assets. Most funds now pay no tax on any gains. In 1987, pension funds held 24 percent of the securities traded in this country. ``I believe that steps are needed to lengthen the time horizons of investors and corporate executives,'' Brady testified. ``However, I am concerned that we have not thought long enough to be sure (the bill) is the answer.'' Brady said the Treasury wanted to work with Congress to devise a plan balancing the needs for market liquidity, capital and a secure source of retirement income. He suggested working through Bush administration proposals to cut the capital gains tax and encourage family savings through tax incentives. Business executives and critics of the 1980s merger mania have complained that investors, particularly large institutional investors like pension funds, have been concerned only with short-term profit on their shareholdings. They argue that has increased the pressure on corporations to concentrate on the quarterly bottom line at the expense of long-range planning, research and development, and nurturing endeavors that don't promise quick returns. ``That bodes ill for our country's future economic growth and prosperity,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, the committee chairman. Earlier, Kassebaum told the committee the bill ``is not designed to raise revenue. I would be happy if it didn't raise any revenue at all.'' Her bill would impose a 10 percent tax on pension fund profits from the sale of securities held up to 30 days, and a 5 percent tax on gains from securities held between 30 and 180 days. Opposition to taxing pension fund capital gains also came from officials of the National Associations of Manufacturers, the Public Securities Association and the AFL-CIO.

DOC.HEAD: New Economic Cabinet Team Curbing Earlier, Radical Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesdy AMs report
DOC.TEXT: The nation's new economic ministers said Wednesday they would shelve or modify most of the radical economic reforms pushed by their predecessors, including a system requiring use of true names on financial transactions. The nation's largest opposition party warned that any reversal of reform policies would heighten political tension by incurring violent protests by dissidents and underprivileged groups. New Economic Planning Minister Lee Seung-yun declined to discuss details but said he would announce by the end of this month ``new prescriptions'' to help revive the sagging South Korean economy. ``All policies are subject to change as the prevailing circumstances warrant and I think it is feared some landmark reforms being pushed could create a lot of problems,'' he told reporters. The controversial reforms center on a system requiring Koreans to use their true names in all financial transactions beginning next year. Outgoing economic ministers said the new system would promote a fair economic environment by preventing tax evasion on all financial transactions. But the new system is shocking to millions of Koreans who are used to using pseudonyms for secret dealings in stocks, bonds and bank accounts. Government analysts estimate that about 10 percent of all Korean financial transactions are conducted using pseudonyms and about 30 percent of bank accounts are kept under false names. Investors already have begun moving their money to overseas accounts and land speculation. Land and housing prices more than doubled in the past year. Kim Dae-jung, president of the largest and most radical opposition group, the Party for Peace and Democracy, warned that a cancellation or stay of the system would sharpen social and political antagonism. ``The shelving of the system would only benefit big businesses and those who `have.' Those who `have not' will feel frustrated and protest more vigorously,'' he said. Lee, a 58-year-old ex-finance minister, was named to the nation's top economic post in a sweeping Cabinet reshuffle last Saturday that affected 15 of 22 posts. South Korea's economy is experiencing difficulty with slow exports, high inflation and low capital investment. Exports in the first two months of the year shrank 2.5 percent from a year ago, helping create a trade deficit of $1.27 billion. The consumer price index rose 1 percent in January and 0.9 percent in February, threatening the government's plan to curb 1990 inflation to 7 or 8 percent. Unemployment rose from 2.3 percent to 2.6 percent this year after the nation's economy grew only 6.5 percent last year, which compared with annual double-digit growth rates in the three previous years. Last year's Korean growth rate remains high by international standards, but experts say the Korean economy needs to grow at least at least 7 percent a year to absorb 700,000 new people seeking jobs annually. One aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said bank lending rates currently ranging between 10 and 12.5 percent could be cut by at least 1 percent soon as an economic stimulation move.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Expands Service as Nationwide Drivers' Strike Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with shooting incident in San Antonio; picks up 4th graf, `Unions representing ...' Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A gunshot hit a Greyhound bus Wednesday night, cracking a window but leaving the driver and passengers unhurt in the latest violence in the strike against the country's only nationwide bus company, authorities said. In another development three days after Greyhound broke off contract talks with its striking drivers, the company expanded bus service to 70 new locations, mostly between Boston and Washington. The bus, carrying 30 passengers to Dallas, was on an entrance ramp to Interstate 35 in San Antonio around 7:30 p.m. when the bullet hit its service door, said Travis County sheriff's Lt. George Meek. The driver continued about 70 miles north to Austin before reporting the shooting, Meek said. The assailant was unknown. The bullet penetrated the first window of the double-window door, but not the second because it contained thick, insulated plastic, the lieutenant said. The incident brought to at least 15 the number of shooting attacks on Greyhound buses. There have also been 46 bomb threats and numerous other incidents of vandalism or threats, company officials say. State police in Virginia investigated a shooting attack on a Greyhound bus carrying about 50 passengers from Roanoke into Christiansburg late Tuesday. No one was injured. Trooper E.R. Adams said holes in the windshield apparently were made by a small-caliber rifle. Greyhound abruptly ended strike talks Sunday, accusing union leaders of stonewalling and of stepping up attacks on buses and replacement drivers. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions said it would resume negotiations at any time. ``The company walked away from the table about 10 a.m. Sunday, but the union stayed at the table,'' said union spokesman Nick Nichols. ``As far as we are concerned, we are still at the table, waiting for them to come back.'' Frank J. Schmieder, president and chief operating officer of Greyhound Lines Inc., said that as of Wednesday, ``we are running 46 percent of our pre-strike schedule miles. That is an increase of 35,617 miles daily compared to yesterday, or 14 percent.'' That included restoration of service to 70 locations, mostly in the Boston-Washington corrider, as replacement drivers complete training, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said. ``Today, we're up to 1,514'' drivers, Gravley said. ``The first day we had around 300.'' Tuesday's ridership was 45,829 passengers, about one-third of ridership on the same day last year, the company said. The union said it believes Greyhound is operating at 15 percent of pre-strike levels. A restoration of service to 70 communities, when Greyhound served 9,500, ``doesn't say much,'' said spokesman Nichols. In Chattanooga, Tenn., a judge issued a restraining order Wednesday limiting picketing at the city's Greyhound terminal to two people and forbidding acts of violence or intimidation. A similar restraining order was issued Tuesday in Fayetteville, N.C. The company has obtained a total of 17 restraining orders against the union, Gravley said. Greyhound downplayed Tuesday's decision by Standard & Poor's to downgrade the company's credit rating from B to B-. Wall Street's premier bond rating company cited a $380 million debt from a 1987 leveraged buyout and said the strike has ``caused substantial losses.'' ``We feel we have a sound financial position and we're just continuing to operate as we had planned to do all along,'' Gravley said. ``We're not in the market to borrow money right now so it's not going to affect us immediately.''

DOC.HEAD: Ad Campaign to Tout New York as Shopping Mecca
DOC.TEXT: A campaign touting New York as a shopper's paradise is being planned for later this spring in an attempt to counter negative publicity about retailing woes. The advertising campaign, centered on the slogan ``There's a World of Shopping in New York,'' is part of a broader promotion of the positive aspects of New York's businesses. Variations on the ``There's a World of ...'' theme, eventually will be adapted for restaurants, theatre, health care, banking and other industries. Retail was chosen as the subject to kick off the feel-good campaign in part because city government officials and business leaders felt it was time to highlight the pluses because the minuses had been getting a lot of attention. Don Klein, chairman and creative director of the MacNamara Clapp & Klein Inc. ad agency, which is developing the campaign, said Wednesday the retail promotion has a two-pronged mission. It is aimed at attracting customers to the shopping opportunities in the city and attracting retailers to open businesses here. He said the ads aren't meant to refute the widely publized problems that have been plaguing numerous retailers. ``We're not going to be talking about the negative. Those problems have been disproportionately blown up,'' he said in an interview.``This is simply to remind people of the vastness and the diversity that is New York City.'' The plight of several prominent U.S. retailers grabbed headlines over the Christmas season. As the peak shopping season started, B. Altman & Co., a venerable old retailer, went into liquidation. Department stores owned by the debt encumbered Campeau Corp., including Bloomingdale's, slashed prices to boost sales and raise cash, forcing their more financially sound competitors to follow suit. New York, always known for stiff competition in retailing, was the scene of some of the fiercest battling for market share in the country over the holidays. A preview of the new retail promotion was given at a breakfast meeting hosted by the Association for a Better New York, the Fifth Avenue Association and the Mayor's Office for Economic Development. Retailers who recently have opened stores in New York or plan to in the near future spoke optimistically about doing business in the city. Among them were Marashu Isogai, executive vice president and general manager of JUSCO, the Japanese holding company of the Talbots Inc. women's clothing chain, and Ermenegildo Zegna, executive vice president of an Italian menswear manufacturer and retailer. Lewis Rudin, chairman of ABNY and operator of a major property management company, said at the meeting that boosting retail business in New York could help alleviate some of the city's fiscal woes by generating more tax revenue. The city is believed to be facing possibly its worst financial crisis ever. The new mayor, David N. Dinkins, said earlier this week that the city's budget deficit is much larger than the $1.1 billion gap estimated in February. Mary Holloway, executive director of ABNY, said details of the campaign, including costs, still are being worked out and will be unveiled at a news conference probably in late April. The campaign will be spearheaded by the association and the Mayor's Office for Economic Development. Advertisements are expected to appear in newspapers and magazines and be carried on television and radio.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Any further leads on AM-Japan-Markets will move on general news wires only. AP Business News

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Will Eliminate Smoking on Some Trains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Amtrak will eliminate smoking next month on some trains and in some stations under new policies that will more strongly segregate nonsmokers and those who want to light up. No-reservation trains of three or fewer cars will be designated no-smoking, Amtrak spokeswoman Sue Martin said Wednesday. ``This will affect a number of trains in the East, some in the Midwest and one in the Northwest,'' she said. ``Seventeen routes will have some trains that at least on some days have no smoking at all.'' Two lawmakers who led the successful fight to ban smoking on most domestic flights said Wednesday that the nation's passenger railroad would adopt the tougher smoking policies April 1. They jumped the gun on Amtrak's own announcement of the new policy, which had been scheduled for today. ``These new rules are another victory for health and common sense,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on transportation. ``It's further acknowledgement that nonsmokers should not be forced to breathe other people's smoke.'' Lautenberg and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., a member of the House transportation appropriations panel, had said after the airline smoking ban took effect Feb. 25 that they would turn their attention to railroads. ``It is my hope that eventually nonsmokers will be able to ride smoke-free on all forms of public transportation,'' Durbin said. Although passengers will be permitted to smoke in sleeping compartments and lounges on longer trains, smoking will be eliminated in: _First-class cars on all trains in the Northeast Corridor that don't require reservations. Reserved-seat Metroliners will carry smoking cars and will set aside smoking areas in first-class cars. _All areas except a portion of the lounge on other trains requiring reservations. _Coach cars of reserved-seat, double-deck Superliners operating west of Chicago. Currently, Amtrak allows smoking in the last four rows of Superliner coaches. The new policy will limit Superliner smoking to the lower level of the lounge car, Ms. Martin said. _Stations smaller than 1,100 square feet. _At least three-quarters of the area of larger stations. Amtrak's ultimate goal is to separate the 25 percent of its passengers who smoke from the 75 percent who do not, Ms. Martin said. Toward that end, Amtrak will begin locating its smoking cars at the front or rear of unreserved trains so nonsmokers need not walk through smoking areas to reach their seats. The Amtrak policy changes drew fire from the Tobacco Institute, the lobby for cigarette manufacturers. ``Once again we're seeing unnecessary regulation above and beyond what is necessary,'' said institute spokesman Thomas Lauria. ``Train travelers have accommodated each other, smokers and non-smokers alike, ever since we've had trains,'' Lauria said. ``Obviously this is an attempt to put smokers in the back of the bus once again. On shorter trains, it seems mean-spirited to ban smoking altogether.'' Lauria said he anticipated resistance from smokers to Amtrak's intended smoking restrictions in stations. According to Ms. Martin, the changes are part of the national passenger railroad's fine-tuning of its smoking policy as the number of smokers drops. ``We feel it is very important for our marketing effort to continue to permit smoking on longer trips,'' Ms. Martin said. ``It simply doesn't make good business sense to eliminate smoking altogether.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Visitors to Hawaii Go Nuts Over Macadamias
DOC.TEXT: Japanese tourists shell out so much money for macadamia nuts when they visit Hawaii that Agriculture Department trade analysts refer to the nutty souvenirs as suitcase exports. Macadamia nut production is also catching on in California, and in other countries. The U.S. output has more than doubled since the late 1970s to an estimated 5,900 metric tons in 1989. John O'Connell of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said world macadamia production has been growing rapidly, including a 60 percent increase in Australia since 1987. A sharp expansion is also indicated over the next decade in Africa and Central America. ``With trees popping up all over, it has been estimated that the world supply of macadamia nuts will double in five years and triple in 10,'' O'Connell reports in the April issue of AgExporter magazine. That will cause producing countries to ``compete fiercely for export markets,'' he said. O'Connell added Wednesday in a telephone interview that the so-called suitcase exports of macadamia nuts to Japan are almost impossible to estimate accurately, although $15 million annually may be conservative. The value of direct nut exports is approximately $5 million a year, meaning that the suitcase shipments are at least triple the known level, he said. In his report, O'Connell said the Japanese custom of giving gifts after returning from a vacation is behind the macadamia mania. ``Local retailers in Hawaii have observed that a Japanese tourist will often buy several boxes, or even a case of macadamia nut products, while mainland U.S. tourists usually buy only one or two boxes,'' he said. Several other Asian markets are developing, including Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea. But if promoters have their way, the biggest export prize yet may be Europe, where macadamia nuts are a relatively unknown oddity. O'Connell said macadamia trees are native to Australia, but commercial nut production began in Hawaii after World War II. The nuts are similar in size and shape to filberts but have a taste and texture all their own. Harvested nuts are de-hulled, cracked and roasted before being processed into salted, candy-coated or chocolate-coated forms, or used as ingredients in bakery, dairy and other products.

The Agriculture Council of America says it intends to set the record straight about the safety of the U.S. food supply. According to the Washington-based organization, a ``foodwatch'' campaign will involve a nationwide education and awareness program ``to inform the public about extensive health and safety measures currently in place that govern how food is grown and processed.'' The program also will focus on the importance of biotechnology being developed and its role in maintaining and improve the food supply. ``Reflecting on the events of 1989, we saw a year filled with consumer skepticism about the food supply,'' the ACA said in a recent report. ``One news article after another raised new concerns over the integrity of the U.S. food supply and the technology used to produce it.'' The ACA and its education foundation represent a cross-section of farm, commodity and agribusiness interests. Larry Sitzman, a corn farmer from Culbertson, Neb., is chairman of the foodwatch committee. He said farmers should be proud of what they produce. ``We need to be working together to keep our food and fiber system the best, not pulling it apart,'' Sitzman said.

A Californian has taken over as head of the Rural Electrification Administration, an agency of the Agriculture Department. Gary C. Byrne, formerly a banker and financial manager in Sacramento, Calif., was sworn in Wednesday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. He was nominated by President Bush in December and confirmed by the Senate on March 9. As the 11th administrator of REA, which was created in the 1930s to bring electricity to the nation's farms, Byrne will oversee a $37 billion portfolio of loans to rural electric and telephone cooperatives. Byrne's experience included leadership in the Bank of Alex Brown, Sacramento, and financial posts with the company's investment subsidiary, the Alex Brown Financial Group. Byrne is a 1965 political science graduate of the University of Redlands and received a doctorate from the University of North Carolina in 1969.

DOC.HEAD: Telecommunication Giant's Shares Drop 500 Dollars, President Baffled
With PM-Japan-Markets; also moved general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The president of Japan's largest corporation was taking calls from irate shareholders this morning as the price of the company's stock fell more than $500 a share. Like the heads of many other Japanese companies, Haruo Yamaguchi, chief executive of telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., was struggling to find an explanation for the dive. ``NTT's performance has not weakened at all. ... We can't avoid drifting with the general current,'' Yamaguchi told reporters at a luncheon gathering. NTT stock _ Japan's most expensive _ fell $516 a share this morning but recovered slightly in the afternoon, closing at $6,903, a loss of $452 or 6.1 percent for the day. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's leading index plunged nearly 6 percent in the morning but recovered somewhat to end the day off 3.13 percent. ``We are making the utmost efforts to raise the price,'' Yamaguchi said. NTT's stock was first offered to the public at $7,742 a share in February 1987, two years after the former telecommunications monopoly was turned into a private company. It had the largest stock market valuation in the world. He said NTT plans to seek approval at its stockholders' meeting in June to raise the dividend from $32.25 to $38.70, or 12 percent of one share's face value of $322.50. Yamaguchi said he owns 10 shares, adding that he and other directors are not permitted to sell their shares. On the first day NTT stock was listed on the Tokyo exchange in 1987, there were 1.28 million buy orders for the 10,000 shares then offered. Two months later, NTT was trading at $20,516 a share. Most Japanese share prices are in the $6 to $13 range. As more and more Japanese turned to the stock market in efforts to expand their sizable savings, investors saw NTT shares as a safe bet, although then-NTT President Hisashi Shinto expressed worries about a collapse in its price. ``I was a high school student in 1938,'' he said, ``and I still remember clearly the panic of the stock market crash.'' The Tokyo market's key index fell 14.9 percent in the October 1987 global crash, but quickly recovered. It ended 1989 trading with a series of record highs, before turning around this year and falling 23 percent amid worries over higher interest rates and declines in bond prices and the yen's value. NTT stock had its own problems, including declining investor interest in telecommunications. Then, Shinto and other NTT executives were implicated early last year in a major bribery scandal. For the fiscal year ended March 1989, NTT reported a 14.3 percent decline in unconsolidated pretax profits. It cited lower long-distance revenues after competitors were allowed in the market, and lower revenue from data communications services. In September, the government, which still owns 10.2 million of NTT's 15.6 million outstanding shares, put off plans to sell 1.95 million shares to the public. It cited various factors, including a slump in NTT's share price, which was then about $9,678. More recently, investors have been put off by calls by a government advisory committee for breaking NTT into three separate companies _ for local, long-distance and mobile telecommunications. Still, Yamaguchi said he did not understand the latest slump in the stock price, which fell $129 on Monday and $258 on Tuesday. The market was closed Wednesday for a holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Virus Wreaks Havoc at North Carolina State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina State's computer labs have been hit by a virus which is leaving students smoking over its message. ``Your computer has been stoned. Legalize marijuana.'' The virus is known as ``Stoned.'' It first popped up in Wellington, New Zealand in 1988 and slowly has been wreaking havoc on computers across the world. On the North Carolina State campus, the virus has wiped out some students' work in computer labs. ``It has been nightmarish,'' said Tracy Carver, a lab assistant in the Humanities Computer Lab, where ``Stoned'' became such a menace that the lab had to shut down for a day and a half this past week. Computer labs across campus are requiring users to check their floppy disks at the door so they can be scanned for ``Stoned'' to make sure it is kept under control. The efforts have worked so far, but on Tuesday, ``Stoned'' was making its pro-pot pitch known again in the social sciences computer lab. Computer viruses like ``Stoned'' are programs that copy themselves between computers and destroy files, overload the system or otherwise irritate users. More than 70 such viruses are known to be circulating worldwide, with points of origin as far flung as Jerusalem (birthplace of a virus that deletes files at random on Friday the 13th) and the Netherlands (first home to the ``Holland Girl Virus'' that provides victims with the phone number of a girl named Sylvia after the damage has been done.) Witty though the creators of such virus programs may be, campus computer users aren't laughing. ``This is a perverse form of intellectual sabotage,'' said Michael Vasu, director of the social sciences computer lab. ``The only purpose to write a virus is to destroy. You have someone with a high degree of technical competence who needs a basic course in ethics.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Pressure Brings Some Progress, Some Resistance on Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A concerted campaign to make it easier to sell American products in Japan appears to be yielding some results, but also is triggering debate over how far Tokyo should go to meet U.S. demands. Negotiators on both sides are racing to meet a mid-April deadline for a report on progress toward reforming business practices and laws that hinder efforts to reduce Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Washington has been demanding urgent action on key trade issues. It contends that Japan's business world is too closed, that land policies sharply boost the cost of doing business in Japan and that this country should increase public investment to help reduce dependence on exports for economic growth. In a March 2-3 summit with President Bush and in talks with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher in Tokyo last week, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu pledged to carry out some of the reforms sought in the negotiations. At Kaifu's behest, trade officials are drafting an interim report on steps to narrow the trade gap and the reforms. The report is to be released in mid-April and Japanese reports say Japanese and U.S. officials are working on it this week in Warrenton, Va. A final report on the talks is due in July. Japanese press reports on the draft report, which has not been made public, indicate Kaifu is making limited progress on the types of major changes demanded by the United States. _ Fair Trade Commission officials said Tuesday they were considering raising penalties for violations of Japan's anti-monopoly law. U.S. officials say lax enforcement of the law enables Japanese companies to form cartels and exclude foreign firms from their markets in a number of areas, including construction and electronics. _ Local media say the interim report also includes plans to ease enforcement of a Japanese law that protects small neighborhood shops from large retail competition. U.S. negotiators contend that by forcing supermarkets and department stores to wait up to 10 years to open new outlets, the law prevents foreign-owned stores like Toys 'R' Us from setting up shop in Japan. Larger Japanese stores are more likely than small shops to sell foreign-made goods, they say. _ Mosbacher, sent to Tokyo by Bush to follow up on trade demands, returned to Washington with at least one souvenir: pledges from two Japanese car makers to buy more American-made semiconductors, and promising responses from other major corporations. _ The economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun says the draft report includes plans to step up spending on roads, sewers and parks; ease restrictions on corporate takeover bids, and impose higher taxes on some farmland in an attempt make more available for commercial and residential use, thus pushing down sky-high land prices. Despite these signs of progress, Japanese negotiators are shying away from U.S. requests for measures requiring legislative approval. Japanese officials have refused to comment on the media reports. Japan's business community has strongly opposed U.S. calls to revise the anti-monopoly law, saying it only needs more rigorous enforcement. There also is strong opposition to abolishing the retail stores law, which business leaders and officials say would cause an economic slump. They express concern that the far-reaching reforms demanded by Washington would sacrifice traditional sectors of the economy, like small shops, and perhaps even the nation's robust economic growth for the sake of uncertain improvement in trade figures. And despite calls for fully opening its agricultural markets to reduce high food prices, Japan has remained adamant against lifting a ban on rice imports. It says it wants to protect its self-sufficiency in a staple food and preserve rural traditions. While many analysts say U.S. pressure is needed to bring consumer-oriented reforms in Japan, they say the onus for change should be placed on Washington. ``America believes Japan needs to make big changes. Most Japanese don't. We have made big changes already. It's necessary for the United States to change,'' former trade ministry official Makoto Kuroda told the Nihon Keizai Shimbun newspaper in a recent interview, echoing the sentiments of many past and present trade officials. The officials also question whether the United States will follow through on pledged reforms aimed at boosting export competitiveness and reducing the high consumption fueling demand for imports. ``We are under pressure to show results, but we will only promise what we can actually carry out,'' said one Japanese official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The U.S. side will promise all sorts of things, but there's no guarantee they can follow through.'' Recent trade figures indicate the two countries are slowly whittling away at their enormous trade imbalance, which accounts for 45 percent of the total $105.9 billion U.S. trade deficit. The trade imbalance, which peaked at $57.9 billion in 1987, was $49 billion last year. In January, it dropped to its lowest montly level in five years _ $2.9 billion. ``We are on the right track. The question is whether it will move fast enough to meet political demands,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Narrows Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed sharply to a better-than-expected $2.23 billion in February, the government said Thursday. The reported providing some relief to the financial markets by easing the pressure for another interest rate hike. The seasonally adjusted shortfall compared with a revised deficit of $3.23 billion in January, the Central Statistical Office said. The markets have been worried that Britain's 15 percent interest rates would be raised to boost a sagging pound and fight 7.7 percent inflation. Such a hike had seemed more likely after analysts said the government's new budget, announced Tuesday, wasn't austere enough to curb inflation. The current account deficit also narrowed to $2.23 billion from $3.23 billion the office said. The merchandise trade and current account figures were the same because the invisible trade included in the current account figures was in balance in February. Invisible trade includes services, overseas investment earnings and official transfer payments. The financial markets had been expecting a merchandise trade deficit of $2.4 billion and a current account deficit of $2.5 billion. Exports fell to $13.4 billion in February, from a revised $13.6 billion in January. Imports fell to $15.7 billion from a revised $16.8 billion. Since the beginning of the year, Britain's merchandise trade deficit has shrunk to $5.5 billion, compared with a deficit of $6.7 billion at the same time a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Punctual Passengers Can Avoid Tardy Flights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A traveler can't do much about making an airliner arrive on time, but it is possible to avoid flights that are notoriously late. More than two years after a law required airlines to report the on-time performance of each flight, few passengers seem to be taking advantage of a simple clue to flight tardiness. The clue is a single digit in the code every flight is assigned in travel agent and airliner computers. On a scale of 9 to 0, each flight is rated for punctuality. An example: If you were thinking of taking USAir Flight 896 from Philadelphia to Boston at 5:55 p.m., you could know that your chances of arriving late are excellent. ``Late'' is defined as more than 15 minutes behind schedule. In the latest monthly report, covering January, that flight was rated ``0'' and was the tardiest in the country, arriving an average of 44 minutes late 96.4 percent of the time. The clue lies in the flight's code that appears in airline and travel agent computers. The current code for the USAir flight has improved to a ``1.'' That means that lately it has been arriving on time between 10 and 20 percent of the time. A ``2'' at the end of a flight's computer code would mean the flight lands on time between 20 and 30 percent of the time, and so on up to the 90 to 100 percent range. A rating of less than 30 percent gets ``chronically late'' honors in the Transportation Department's monthly Air Travel Consumer Report. So what does a traveler do if the flight has a low score? A Philadelphia passenger who wants to improve the odds of arriving on time in Boston could take Delta Flight 648 at 4:50 p.m., which has a 60 to 70 percent on-time record, or USAir Flight 424 at 5 p.m., which has a 40 to 50 percent record. But how often do customers ask for this information? ``No one ever has,'' said Yolande Frommer, referring to customers at her Washington, D.C. travel agency. They'll ask the type of aircraft, how many seats are in a row, where the exits are and what movie is playing, she said, but they don't think to ask the chances of the plane arriving on time, even though it often is a major concern. Many people simply aren't aware that the information is available. Phil Davidoff, president-elect of the American Society of Travel Agents, said that although few travelers ask for the data, some agents notify customers when the on-time rating is below 50 percent. ``It's clearly down the line in factors that will affect a decision'' about which flight to take, Davidoff said. The data come from the airlines, which are required by law to report to the government each month. Delays due to mechanical problems are not counted in the ratings because the government thinks that including them might encourage airlines to rush repairs to keep up their on-time rating. Richard Livingston of the Airline Passengers Association of North America, a consumer and safety advocacy group, said he thinks the government should pay more attention to the relative safety and security of flights instead of collecting data that might not be used by passengers. ``They tend to focus too much on delays,'' he said. In addition to the flight data, the monthly Transportation Department report tells which of the 30 busiest airports have the most on-time arrivals at each hour of the day. It also tallies lost baggage reports and logs consumer complaints to the government.

DOC.HEAD: US Moving Toward Warning Labels on Some Toys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Toys intended for older children often get into the hands of younger siblings, so the federal consumer protection agency says some of them should have warning labels. The Consumer Product Safety Commission moved Wednesday to require labels warning that younger children can choke on small parts in toys intended for children over age 3. The commission told its staff to devise rules for the toy industry to develop mandatory warning labels for toys intended for 3 to 6 year-olds which have potentially dangerous small parts. The products affected include toys intended for children ages 3 to 6 _ games such as ``jacks'' which include small balls, marbles and balloons. The commission left unanswered whether the new rules might also apply to children's jewelry and other accessories, arts and craft equipment, puzzles and other items. In moving toward hazard warnings for specific toys, the commission sidestepped urgings by consumer groups and members of the medical community to review and develop a new small-parts standard. The agency has received reports of 146 deaths since 1980 of children under age three involving products intended for older children but staffers said they could identify only eight which might have been prevented by use of a more different test standard. ``The potential benefits to change are low,'' said commission chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Three Buses Fired On Overnight; Union Disputes Company's Service Figures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities were investigating three incidents in which Greyhound buses were fired upon by unknown assailants, the latest in a string of shootings since company drivers went on strike nearly three weeks ago. None of the shootings, which occurred Wednesday night in Texas and early today in Missouri and Illinois, caused any injuries, said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley. In another development, the drivers' union disputed Greyhound's claim that it is operating at 46 percent of its pre-strike schedule, based on mileage covered. A spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions estimated that Greyhound is operating at 15 percent of pre-strike levels. The latest round of violence brings the number of shootings to at least 17 since the strike began March 2. In San Antonio, a sheriff's officer said 30 passengers were aboard the bus when a bullet struck its service door on an entrance ramp of Interstate 35. The bullet did not penetrate the thick window and the Dallas-bound bus continued about 80 miles north to Austin before its driver reported the shooting, said Travis County sheriff's Lt. George Meek. A second shooting was reported on Interstate 55 south of St. Louis when two shots struck the windshield of a bus carrying 19 passengers from St. Louis to Memphis, Tenn. The incident was being investigated by the Missouri Highway Patrol, Gravley said. At Collinsville, Ill., not far from St. Louis, four shots struck a bus en route from Chicago to St. Louis, Gravley said. Eight passengers were aboard when the two shots struck the windshield and two struck the side of the bus. The company announced Wednesday that it had restored service to 70 locations mostly in the Boston-Washington corrider. Replacement drivers who completed training took over most of the routes, said Gravley. ``Starting today, we are running 46 percent of our pre-strike schedule miles,'' Frank J. Schmieder, president and chief operating officer of Greyhound Lines Inc., said Wednesday. But union spokesman Nick Nichols said restoration of service to 70 communities, when Greyhound had served 9,500, ``doesn't say much.'' Gravley said Greyhound had 1,514 drivers, five times more than it did the first day of the strike. About 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other employees struck the company over wages, job security and grievance procedures. Contract talks broke down Sunday in Arizona and have not been rescheduled. Union officials said the company offered a plan that failed to include guaranteed pay raises, but would have made raises contingent on increased profits and ridership. The company says in addition to the shootings, 46 bomb threats and other incidents of vandalism have been logged. Nichols said the union has documented at least 32 incidents of violence against strikers, including the death of a picketer who was crushed by a bus and assaults by Greyhound managers against pickets. ``Regrettably this stuff is happening,'' Nichols said. ``Both sides are, I believe, legitimately concerned about it. I don't know what more we can to convince people that, regardless of whether they're union members or not, that this is not the way to behave.''

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 600 Employees Out of Work; Imports Blamed
DOC.TEXT: Two big textile companies, Cone Mills Corp. and Milliken & Co., said they were laying off more than 800 employees between them because of increased competition from imports. Cone Mills said Wednesday it was shutting down its 450-employee American Spinning Plant in Greenville, S.C. Meanwhile, Milliken said it would close a mill in Robbins S.C., putting 255 people out of work, and would eliminate 129 jobs from its Drayton Mill in Spartanburg, S.C. A statement issued to Milliken employees Wednesday afternoon said that, ``While all of us have worked very hard to be successful with our customers, it has not been enough to overcome the massive, continuing growth of imported textile products into the United States. ``This huge and escalating textile import burden has directly impacted the Drayton Plant and made it impossible for that plant to continue full operations,'' a company statement said. Cone Mills Chairman Dewey Trogdon also cited imports in the closing the American Spinning plant. He also blamed rising fiber costs and the plant's multi-storied layout, which made it impractical to install more modern equipment. Employees learned of their job losses as the House Textile Caucus launched a new campaign for legislation to curb imports of textiles and apparel. Milliken spokesman Terry May and Cone Mills spokesman Jim Butner said the cutbacks had been considered for several weeks, but both said the announcements were not timed to coincide with the Textile Caucus's decision to introduce a textile bill. Layoffs at the Milliken plants will begin in about 60 days, but May said he did not know when they would be completed. The cutback at the Drayton plant will still leave about 90 employees on the job. May said the plant will continue to make yarns used in men's and women's clothing. The displaced workers would be able to transfer to other Milliken plants without loss of seniority or benefits, according to the company statement. Cone Mills layoffs will begin in late May and will be completed by the end of June, Butner said. Cone Mills is one of the nation's largest producers of denims and corduroys. It employs about 9,000 workers at 15 plants in the Carolinas and Mississippi and has annual sales around $700 million, Butner said. Milliken has estimated sales of $2.5 billion a year. The company has 14,300 employees at 55 plants in the Carolinas, Georgia, Canada and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Southland To Sell Majority Stake to Japanese Partners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf to CORRECT Farmers to Farmers Branchp
DOC.TEXT: Debt-ridden Southland Corp., which owns 7,000 7-Eleven convenience stores, said today it has agreed to sell a controlling interest to its Japanese partners for $400 million and the assumption of debt. Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd., Japan's second-largest supermarket operator, and longtime Southland affiliate 7-Eleven Japan, which Ito-Yokado controls, would acquire 75 percent of Southland's common stock under terms of the deal, Southland said in a statement. The Japanese companies would pay $400 million in cash. The deal is contingent upon the restructuring of Southland's $1.8 billion in debt and of its outstanding preferred stock. The deal, which has been approved by Southland's board, also must be approved by a syndicate of 32 banks, the company's lenders. Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Norwood said the total acquisition cost was not yet known, but the leading Japanese financial journal Nihon Keizai Shimbun today estimated the deal at about $1 billion. In addition to company-owned 7-Eleven stores, Southland's six food processing centers and five distribution centers are also included in the deal. Independent licensees and affiliates also operate more than 5,900 7-Eleven stores in the United States and 21 foreign countries. 7-Eleven Japan, the largest convenience-store operator in Japan, operates 3,940 licensed stores. Ito-Yokado, which Southland described as Japan's most profitable supermarket chain, owns 50.3 percent of 7-Eleven Japan. Southland has had a 17-year affiliation with the Japanese concerns. Suffering disappointing sales and earnings growth, Southland has been strained by debt associated with its $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987, which gave Dallas' Thompson family control of the chain. For the nine months ended Nov. 30, 1989, Southland lost $299 million on revenue of $6.3 billion. The company attributed the loss to heavy interest payments and additional charges associated with the buyout. Southland said in November it faced a liquidity crisis. To meet substantial debt payments last year, the company sold off its half-ownership of Citgo Petroleum Corp., which supplies many of its stores with gasoline. Southland's bank group has ordered the company to submit a restructuring plan by May 31. Under terms outlined in the company's news release, Southland proposes to issue new bonds in exchange for outstanding bonds and issue additional common stock. ``During the course of the last six months, we have reviewed a broad range of alternatives that would maintain the long-term viability and success of Southland,'' said John P. Thompson, Southland's chairman. ``We believe this strategic alliance ... is the best way to achieve the company's goals.'' The deal caught some Southland employees off guard. Johnny Lacy, who works at a 7-Eleven in the Dallas suburb of Farmers Branch, said he was confused by the announcement because the company's monthly newsletters have portrayed an increasingly fit firm. ``This is strange,'' he said. ``I thought the Thompsons were getting the company back on its feet. From the newsletters, it seemed like everything was going uphill.'' Ito-Yokado said it was approached by Southland in late January to participate in the both the financing and management of the company's restructuring. Because of current friction over Japanese investment in U.S. companies, Masaaki Kamata, senior managing director of Seven-Eleven Japan, stressed that the agreement was made in response to Southland's request for assistance. Kamata said great care would be taken to explain the deal to political and financial leaders in the United States with an interest in the company. Masatoshi Ito, the chairman of 7-Eleven Japan and president of Ito-Yokado, said he sees the deal as the beginning of a worldwide partnership. ``As the world largest convenience store chain, e will maintain and build upon our mutually strong market positions by combining the operating skills and strategic thinking of the American and Japanese companies,'' Ito said. Another Southland spokesman, Harris Diamond, said the Japanese firm will be represented on the Southland board of directors if the deal is completed. The Thompson family would retain about 15 percent of the company and would remain on the board, the spokesman said. ``There will be no layoffs, and no store closings,'' Diamond said. ``In fact, we believe the $400 million cash infusion is going to be a tremendous asset.'' Thompson said the money will be used for improvements as well as advertising and promotion. ``We believe this transaction is necessary to preserve the business we've built,'' he said.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 437.02 down 2.28 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Showdown Approaches on Aid to Coal Miners
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Following tops with 5 grafs to reflect comments today's developments, pickup 3rd graf pvs, Byrd has etc.; also moving general news wires. ^By H. JOSEF HEBERT
DOC.TEXT: The Senate approached a showdown today over whether to provide aid to coal miners who lose their jobs because of new pollution controls, and the outcome could determine whether a clean air bill passes this year. The coal issue has placed two of the Senate's most powerful members at odds: Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who was Mitchell's predecessor as Senate leader and still wields immense power as chairman of the Appropriations Committee. ``I expect that (the coal miner issue) will be resolved one way or another today,'' said Mitchell, meeting with reporters before the Senate resumed debate on the clean air bill. No action on the amendment is expected until late in the day, however. Byrd, arguing for his proposal on the Senate floor, declared: ``The coal miners are being asked to pay a very high price... they will lose their livlihood.'' Byrd has been pressing an assistance program for miners in his state and elsewhere if they lose their jobs because of tougher acid rain controls at coal-burning power plants in the Midwest. On Wednesday night, he offered to lower the package's expected cost from $700 million over four years to $500 million over three years. Byrd's amendment, offered nearly two weeks ago, has threatened to derail progress in enacting the first improvements in federal air pollution controls in 13 years. The White House vigorously opposes the assistance plan and Mitchell is fearful its passage might cause the compromise clean air bill, worked out in lengthy negotiations with the Bush administration, to unravel. The miner aid issue was expected to come to a head today as Mitchell tried to work out a compromise with the White House, while Byrd was likely to press for a vote on his amendment. ``I'm not going to stand here and say I've got 51 votes (needed for passage), but I can tell you, `You don't have 51 votes either.' And I can tell you I'm very close,'' Byrd told Mitchell during floor debate Wednesday night. While the Senate has been considering a string of amendments on the floor, the miner assistance program has been the hottest topic behind the scenes. There has been intense lobbying by the White House to defeat the amendment and an administration source said Wednesday that it has become less interested in seeking a compromise and was prepared to try to defeat the proposal. Mitchell and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., meanwhile, have been trying line up senators to vote against Byrd's proposal, but a vote on the amendment was put off twice because its defeat was not certain. Offering his revised assistance proposal, Byrd complained that the White House was unwilling to negotiate and that he wanted a vote. Mitchell and Dole said they expected a response shortly from the administration on a compromise assistance plan, crafted by aides to Mitchell, that would include benefits to coal miners as well as other workers that could lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. Many senators have complained that if coal miners were to be given special assistance, the same should be provided to workers in other industries. The Senate spent most of Wednesday debating and then defeating a proposal aimed at tightening smog pollution controls in the nation's cities. The amendment, which lost, 53-46, would have preserved the federal government's authority to impose air pollution reduction plans if states and localities failed to act. It also sought to eliminate waivers for some industrial polluters if the controls were too expensive and would have broadened the smog-reducing requirements to include smaller polluters. Earlier in the week the Senate killed requirements for tighter automobile emissions controls and an expanded alternative fuels program to reduce urban smog. The two proposals were singled out by environmentalists as being essential to assuring improved air quality in major cities. Earlier, another strengthening proposal which would have required a reduction in toxic chemical emissions from automobiles fell by 65-33. With the three defeats, environmentalists said they planned to focus on the House, where a clean air bill is still in committee, in their attempt to strengthen curbs on smog-causing pollutants.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Mostly Lower In Stock-Market Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders ignored news of a new U.S.-Soviet grain deal and focused instead on weakness in the stock market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 21 points at mid-morning following a steep drop in the Tokyo stock market. The government today announced an agreement with the Soviet Union that will increase the annual minimum shipments of U.S. grain to the Soviets to 10 million metric tons from nine million tons under the current agreement. Under the agreement, the Soviets are committed to buy at least four million tons each of wheat and feed grains. But Moscow can substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. The deal was viewed as bullish for grain prices but was overshadowed by the sharp drop in stock prices. ``If the stock market keeps going down, they're not going to pay any attention to the grain agreement,'' said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division of Gerald Inc. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to } cent lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.58} a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cent higher with May at $2.58 a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with May at $1.48} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with May at $6.02} a bushel. Cattle futures were higher while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .10 cent to .55 cent higher with April at 77.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .48 cent higher with March at 82.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .32 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 52.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .93 cent higher with March at 51.50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lease Sales Suggest Industry Recovering, Federal Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Oil companies bid nearly $590 million for the right to drill in U.S. waters in the Gulf of Mexico, the biggest total in five years and a sign the industry is recovering, federal officials said. ``The oil and gas business is starting to pick up a little,'' said Barry Williamson, director of the U.S. Mineral Management Service. ``Energy trends are starting to stabilize, and that's good news for the oil and gas industry, and the state of Louisiana.'' Ninety-five companies offered bids at Wednesday's government lease sale, 15 percent more than participated in the most recent comparable sale a year ago. The bids totaled $589.5 million for leases on 2.7 million acres of waterbottoms in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. Bids likely to be accepted by the government came to $427.4 million, also the biggest since 1985 when winning bids totaled about $1.1 billion. MMS spokesman Barney Congdon in New Orleans said the government received more offers on fewer tracts this year _ 840 on 538 tracts compared with 821 bids on 591 tracts last year bid by 83 companies. Congdon said the government last received a larger total bid in 1985, when the figure was about $1.2 billion. Last March, at a similar sale of central Gulf leases, oil companies bid a total of $397.5 million, he said. The highest bid of the day was $11.1 million won by a partnership of Italy's Agip Petroleum and Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. in an area called Vermilion South. The highest bid per acre was $3,559.12 from Samedan Oil on West Delta block. Williamson said the growing interest also shows that more independent producers are getting back into the offshore business. Wednesday's lease figures are preliminary. It was not known how many would eventually be accepted by the Mineral Management Service. Congdon said billion-dollar sales were common in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with totals of $2 billion in 1981 and $3.5 billion in 1983. Then came the oil bust. ``Those were the high numbers. Now they're down to the millions,'' Congdon said.

For release Sunday March 25
DOC.HEAD: Vacancy Rates Soar Amid Wall Street Recession
Graphic in AP Access under EMPTYSPACE
DOC.TEXT: The 25th floor of the south tower of the luxurious World Financial Center is empty save for a few boxes. So are the 26th, 27th and 28th floors. In the booming mid-1980s, Merrill Lynch & Co. expected to fill the space easily. The nation's largest securities firm booked two full towers in the ultra-modern complex in lower Manhattan that opened in 1986, using conservative estimates of employment growth. Then Merrill scaled back to one tower plus about half the second. After the 1987 stock market crash even that was too much, and now the firm plans to sublet nine floors, including the four undeveloped ones. On Wall Street _ and Broad Street and Greenwich Street and Battery Place _ a securities industry recession has created an office-space glut in the world's premier financial district. Vacancy rates are soaring in the maze of silver office towers and aging stone monoliths where stock trading began almost 200 years ago under a buttonwood tree. Property brokers compare the slump to the mid-1970s, when New York teetered on bankruptcy. ``We're still headed south,'' said Robert F.R. Ballard, an executive vice president with the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield, who has worked in the Wall Street building market since 1959. ``We haven't bottomed out yet.'' Manhattan real estate brokers say the vacancy rate in the downtown financial district is approaching 20 percent, vs. 8 percent to 12 percent in 1985 during the securities industry boom. Put another way, the 14 million square feet of available office space downtown equals three empty buildings, each as big as a 110-story World Trade Center tower. The glut is expected to worsen because hundreds of thousands of square feet to be abandoned by firms such as Merrill, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., Salomon Inc. and collapsed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. haven't been tallied yet. Unprecedented growth in stock trading and investment banking gave rise to hand-over-fist hiring and expansion by Wall Street firms in the 1980s. Average daily trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange shot up from 32.2 million shares in 1979 to 189 million shares in 1987, while employment in in New York's securities and commodities industries grew from 74 million to 163 million. During that period, Wall Street firms set ambitious expansion plans, tied to the seemingly limitless possibilities of another boom. Building ``world headquarters'' seemed logical to accomodate technological advances that required more space for more computers for more trading into the 21st century. ``Many of the financial firms don't indulge in what we call intelligent strategic planning regarding their space needs,'' said Joel Wechsler, a managing director of the real estate firm Edward S. Gordon & Co. ``They're getting a little more sophisticated in that area now.'' Stock market volume, securities underwriting, mergers and takeovers and other financial businesses are down sharply. Since the crash, the securities industry has lost more than 40,000 jobs. ``The vacancy rates are directly related to the shrinkage in the financial services industry,'' said Anthony M. Saytanides, Edward S. Gordon's chief operating officer. Ballard put it less gently: ``The developers built too much space. The tenants rented too much space. The market took a nosedive.'' During the decline, several projects were abandoned and other overly ambitious ones have cost firms hundreds of millions of dollars. Salomon took a $150 million accounting charge against earnings after dropping out of a major project. Two firms that named buildings for themselves _ E.F. Hutton & Co. and Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. _ are history. Shearson, the No. 2 brokerage behind Merrill, spent $450 million to build a 39-story office tower known as Shearson Lehman Hutton Plaza. The firm plans to fill the building, which opened late last year, but also is firing up to 5,000 workers this year, which could lead to more unused space. Workers in reduced Shearson departments say they can roam floors almost undisturbed. The firm's new tower is adorned with a Parthenon-like frieze, and some wags say it too could wind up a monument to a golden age. ``There may be some discussion in hindsight whether it was the most effective use of the firm's money at the time,'' a Shearson official privately conceded, adding that it is evaluating space needs as part of an overhaul. Merrill decided to move in the early '80s, when its headcount was growing by 13 percent annually. It booked the World Financial Center space anticipating only half that growth. But since the crash, Merrill has slashed its work force back to a 1980 level. More cuts are planned. The firm took a $470 million charge against earnings last quarter for its restructuring _ $220 million to cover real estate commitments, nearly all of that in New York. ``The growth has certainly gone in the other direction,'' Merrill spokesman Fred Yager said. ``Our fixed costs have been reduced considerably and one of our biggest fixed costs is real estate.'' For the real estate market, the glut's the thing. While modern office spaces such as the World Financial Center and World Trade Center complexes are almost fully occupied, older buildings are bearing the brunt as firms move out. The average asking rent downtown is falling, but not in proportion to available space. Brokers say top-line offices still command around $35 per square foot, among the highest in the country. Some prices for older buildings, though, have fallen into the single digits, just like in the 1970s. Brokers estimate the downtown vacancy rate will climb well above 20 percent once a rash of moves _ some across New York waterways to cheaper Brooklyn or New Jersey _ are completed. In the mid-'70s, the rate was about 25 percent, brokers said. Among the untallied moves: the Securities Industry Automation Corp.'s move to new quarters, abandoning 200,000 square feet; Salomon's shift to 7 World Trade Center, leaving 500,000 square feet behind; the consolidation by Merrill and Shearson; and about 1.5 million square feet by Drexel. During its junk-bond driven heyday, Drexel planned to build new headquarters downtown. The firm wisely scrapped the project after settling securities fraud charges with the government last April and trimming 4,000 employees by selling its retail brokerage operations. Unwisely, in retrospect, Drexel last fall extended the lease on its main Broad Street offices until 2004. Six weeks ago, Drexel's parent entered bankruptcy proceedings, listing more than $470 million in domestic lease commitments outstanding. Some brokers say the market has even further to fall because at least one sure sign of desperation has yet to take hold. ``During the '70s a lot of the older buildings were turned into apartments,'' Ballard said. ``That hasn't happened yet, and if that hasn't happened we haven't hit bottom.''
