DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Company Profits Up Despite Anti-Smoking Clamor
DOC.TEXT: All the huffing and puffing against smoking has failed to blow tobacco's house down. Industry analysts say profits in the tobacco business are growing at a double-digit clip due to higher prices, improved production efficiency, stable leaf costs and clever marketing. They expect similar increases in the future. But the anti-smoking drive could have an unintended side effect. Some media executives say newspapers and magazines will be hurt if new limits on tobacco advertising are adopted. Publishers planning new magazines, for instance, must consider in devising a business plan whether the magazine could survive if tobacco advertising were banned. Tobacco opponents say their chief goal has not been to make tobacco less profitable but to raise awareness of health issues and to puncture the glamorous image of smoking that some cigarette ads still promote. Results of their efforts are readily apparent _ smoking is prohibited on most domestic air flights and in many public places such as restaurants, hospitals and offices. One tobacco company withdrew plans to test a new cigarette aimed at blacks after disclosure of the plans stirred a barrage of complaints that it was preying on a minority group. The segment of the adult population that smokes tumbled to 29.1 percent in 1987, the most recent year for which such statistics are available, from 40.7 percent in 1966, the U.S. Office on Smoking and Health says. Cigarette sales volume has also dropped steadily in recent years. The Tobacco Institute, a trade organization, said cigarette shipments dropped to 562 billion in 1988, down 2.3 percent from 1987 and 12.2 percent from the peak of 640 billion in 1984. John C. Maxwell Jr., who follows the tobacco business for Wheat First Securities in Richmond, Va., estimates sales dropped by 6.1 percent to 524 billion in 1989. He said the decline would have been half as large without unusual efforts by one company to reduce inventories held by wholesalers. But the decline in sales volume and the percentage of smokers has not translated into a decline in cigarette revenue or profits. The Tobacco Institute said domestic cigarette revenue reached a record $35.8 billion in 1988, up 6.5 percent from 1987. Tobacco company domestic pretax operating profits rose more than 10 percent last year to $7.2 billion, said industry watcher Diana Temple. Philip Morris USA, the industry leader with 41.9 percent of the market and the best-selling Marlboro brand, had an operating profit of $3.6 billion alone on revenue of $9.5 billion in 1989. Ms. Temple, an analyst for the Salomon Brothers Inc. investment firm, said the industry has reported an average 14 percent annual increase in operating profits over the past five years. She said the dropoff in 1989 reflected the unusually large volume decline, not anti-smoking efforts. Maxwell said the anti-smoking effort hasn't cut into tobacco profits and he forecast a continuation of double-digit increases in operating profits for the forseeable future. He said the tobacco companies have been able to overcome the impact of volume declines by raising prices as often as twice a year. Ms. Temple said an average pack of cigarettes cost $1.44 in 1989, up 11 percent from 1988. Tobacco companies also have controlled costs by investing in machinery that produces nearly twice as many cigarettes a minute. In addition, domestic growers have been reluctant to raise raw leaf prices, fearing cigarette makers will buy from foreign suppliers, Maxwell said. Analysts also said that despite the well-publicized misstep in developing a new cigarette for blacks, the tobacco companies have proven adept marketers who have been able to identify customers and tailor messages for them. Ms. Temple said tobacco companies also have grown more profitable because few have dared challenge the six leaders _ Philip Morris, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., Brown & Williamson, Lorillard, American Brands and Liggett Group. ``It is an unglamorous business that doesn't attract a lot of new entrants,'' she said. Proposals to restrict tobacco advertising would not necessarily hurt profitability and could improve it, analysts said. Maxwell said an ad ban would save money that would ``come right down to the bottom line'' for tobacco companies. Ms. Temple said the tobacco companies would probably shift ad spending to promotions, such as distributing free samples, sponsoring concerts or sports events or setting up more store displays. Federal Trade Commission figures show the tobacco companies spent $2.58 billion on advertising and promotions in 1987, including $413.5 million on advertising in newspapers and magazines. A recent study by a group of advertisers, media companies and advertising agencies said that by 1993, a ban on tobacco advertising could drive 165 magazines, or 1.3 percent of the projected total of 12,490, and 12 newspapers, or 0.8 percent of the projected total of 1,506, out of business. It said prices would have to rise to compensate for lost ad revenue. Critics of the study said it failed to allow sufficiently for the possibility that other advertisers would fill the void left by tobacco ads, just as occurred when tobacco ads were banned on radio and TV in 1971. But the possibility that tobacco ads will be banned is already figuring into plans for new magazines. Michael Klingensmith, publisher of Time Warner Inc.'s month-old Entertainment Weekly, said the magazine gets about 10 percent of its ad revenue from cigarette companies and supports the right to advertise a legal product. But he said in drafting the magazine's business plan he had to consider the possibility of a tobacco ad ban. ``Anybody launching a magazine today would have to consider that,'' he said. Alan Wragg, publisher of TV Time, a new weekly TV listings magazine, said he is counting on a ``much smaller contribution from cigarette advertising than if we were doing this five years ago.''

DOC.HEAD: As the U.S. Market Shrinks, Tobacco Companies Target Foreign Smokers
With BC-Smoking-Troubles
DOC.TEXT: Long banned from American airwaves, the Marlboro Man still gallops across television screens in the Philippines and other developing countries where U.S. tobacco companies are selling more cigarettes than ever and lung-cancer rates are soaring. As the market shrinks at home, the U.S. government is helping American tobacco companies invade foreign markets, particularly along the booming Pacific Rim. In Thailand, where 65 percent of men over 20 smoke, the U.S. Trade Office is threatening sanctions unless import taxes and other barriers to American cigarettes are lowered. Health groups from nine Asian countries sent a letter to President Bush last year calling the threat ``a mockery of your country's efforts to curb the export of other addictive drugs into your country.'' Billboards for Marlboro and Winston are common in Bangkok, despite a year-old law prohibiting all cigarette advertising. Thai health officials fear opening the door to U.S. tobacco interests, as South Korea, Japan and Taiwan did four years ago, could mean a sharp increase in the number of teen-age and female smokers. ``My bottom line is anti-smoking,'' said Dr. Prakit Vatee-Satokit of the Thai Anti-Smoking Campaign Project. ``I don't care if it's Thai or American cigarettes. I see people die of smoking every day.'' In Hong Kong, where American cigarettes dominate 70 percent of the market, lung-cancer deaths increased 58 percent in the last decade and the number of teen-age smokers is on the rise. Taiwanese anti-smoking advocates say 85 percent of young smokers, whose ranks are being filled through American hard-sell, prefer imports. Smoking _ and lung-cancer deaths _ are declining overall in some Western European countries where health concerns mirror those in the United States. In Britain, the heaviest smokers are blue-collar workers and people in their 20s, but the number of teen-age smokers is dropping. They were the target of the government Health Education Authority's recent $16.5 million no-smoking campaign and an anti-smoking group called Parents Against Tobacco. Young adults also are Italy's most avid smokers, although smoking is declining overall. The most recent statistics say 29 percent of Italians smoked in 1986, down from 35 percent in 1980. The warning ``Smoking is dangerous to your health'' is printed on all cigarette packs sold in Argentina and Uruguay, but surveys say 68 percent of all men in Uruguay and 32 percent of women smoke. About 60 percent of the population of Japan smokes, and the admonition ``Be careful not to smoke too much for your health'' in barely visible print on cigarette packs does little to counteract the impact of television advertising. Foreign actors such as James Coburn and Roger Moore appear in ads promoting a glamorous image for smoking, and Japanese cigarette companies have taken a cue from their American counterparts by creating products for specific groups, such as a brand for teen-agers called Dean after the late actor James Dean, a hero among Japanese youth. Anti-smoking efforts have fared poorly in Japan, South Korea and China, where 250 million smokers follow their leaders puffing Panda and other domestic brands. Beijing did, however, participate in the first World Smoking Day last April, when stalls in the city sold anti-smoking ointments and mouth gargles. An official Czechoslovakian anti-smoking campaign called ``Chance For 3 Million'' _ a reference to the number of babies expected to be born in that country in the next decade _ appeared to put a damper on smoking for the first half of 1989. But smoking is on the rise again, and the Health Ministry now calls the campaign a failure.

DOC.HEAD: Blockbuster Chief Pushing Business at Fast-Forward
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: At a recent meeting with video industry analysts, Blockbuster Entertainment Corp. executives passed out free ``Cinderella'' tapes. The symbolism was subtle yet clear for those familiar with Blockbuster's chief _ who went from the unglamorous world of trash collection to the glitz of the movie industry and quickly transformed an obscure group of video stores into the nation's top chain. ``We're not twice as smart. We just work twice as hard,'' said H. Wayne Huizenga, Blockbuster chairman and chief executive officer. ``We've only been at it for three years. I'd say that's not too bad.'' Huizenga also is unabashedly upbeat about his latest venture _ professional sports. Earlier this month, the 52-year-old multimillionaire purchased a 15 percent share in the Miami Dolphins football team and a 50 percent stake in Robbie Stadium Corp., which operates the 75,000-seat home of the Dolphins. He predicts regular-season major league baseball will be played in Miami before 1995. ``There is no question we'll get a franchise someday in Miami. The question is how soon,'' said Huizenga. ``There's no reason not to be optimistic.'' Huizenga resembles former New York mayor Ed Koch, but doesn't copy Koch's famous line: ``How am I doin'?'' Huizenga prefers to let numbers tell the story. Since Huizenga purchased Blockbuster for less than $19 million from a Dallas-based video retailer, the chain has grown from 19 to nearly 1,200 outlets from Guam to England. At the present rate, an average of one new Blockbuster store opens a day, and Huizenga predicts sales could top $1 billion this year. Although Blockbuster's aggressive expansion has led to concern by some industry analysts, Huizenga believes the pace is manageable. About 160 of the nearly 400 stores opened by Blockbuster last year were company-owned. The rest were franchise operators who need little, if any, help in getting started, he said. ``So that's really about one store every other day we're directly responsible for. It's fast, but not unreasonable,'' said Huizenga. Blockbuster's Fort Lauderdale headquarters give only small hints of show business. A glass-encased ship model and leather chairs dominate the lobby of the Spanish-style building. A small framed picture of President Bush is signed: ``To my video advisor.'' Nearby is a figurine of a teen-age boy slumped in a chair. He's watching a video. For Huizenga, couch potatoes are generally sweet. ``This is nothing like the trash business,'' said Huizenga. ``If someone rents a movie and doesn't like it, they blame Hollyood, not Blockbuster. There are very few problems with customers.'' Color television was still a novelty in the 1960s when Huizenga took up a garbage collection route in Fort Lauderdale bringing in $500 a week. Huizenga drove the truck and lugged the trash until the business grew. Meanwhile, his uncles in Chicago were doing well with their trash collection and salvage company. The two merged, and in 1971 put up the first public stock offering of Waste Management Inc. Last year, the company reported revenue of $4.5 billion. Although Waste Management is based in Chicago, Huizenga would return each weekend to Fort Lauderdale, where he had moved as a high school freshman. When he left the company in 1984, he began a number of ventures ranging from a bottled water service to dry cleaning. He still operates a helicopter fleet that picks up cash from atop banks. The rapid expansion of Blockbuster began almost immediately after Huizenga's 1987 acquisition. Blockbuster's national presence was boosted by the January 1989 purchase of Las Vegas-based Major Video Corp.'s 175 stores. Now, Blockbuster is experimenting with huge video warehouses in former supermarket sites. In Atlanta, one store features a basketball hoop in the back for kids. The company prohibits X-rated videos. Huizenga _ who foresees up to 3,000 Blockbuster stores in the United States _ believes the company's most promising frontier lies overseas. Blockbuster has 15 stores in the United Kingdom, 42 in Canada and is negotiating for franchises in other European countries and Australia. ``I don't see any reason we can't compete in Asia and South America and anywhere people have VCRs,'' he said. ``Entertainment is a universal commodity.'' But some analysts wonder about Blockbuster's rapid growth. Last May, Blockbuster stock fell following the release of a report by Bear Stearns & Co. Inc. that Blockbuster artificially inflated its financial statements by writing off the costs of tapes over three years, rather than nine months. Blockbuster has reported more than 100 percent increases in earnings for two consecutive years. In 1989, Blockbuster revenue was up 133 percent to $663 million and net income rose 153 percent to $44.2 million. With the baseball pay negotiations settled, Huizenga said he and several other south Florida corporate leaders will begin their own talks on how best to lure the major leagues to Joe Robbie Stadium, which would need about $10 million in renovations to accomodate baseball. One option, said Huizenga, is to acquire an existing team. At present prices, Huizenga's stock in Blockbuster and Waste Management is worth about $308 million, giving him considerable financial muscle as a potential buyer. However, he'd settle for bidding on an expansion club. Already, cities such as St. Petersburg, Buffalo and Jacksonville are far ahead of Miami on lobbying the league for a new team. ``If we don't get it on the first round, then during the next expansion,'' said Huizenga. ``We haven't spoken with anyone offically yet about anything. The only thing we have going for us at this point is our drive and enthusiasm.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Land Prices Rise 17 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS dollar figures throughout
DOC.TEXT: The rapidly rising land prices that hit the Tokyo area several years ago have spread to Osaka in western Japan and other regions, the National Land Agency said Thursday. Average residential land prices in Japan rose 17 percent last year, with prices in Osaka jumping 58.6 percent, an agency report said. Commercial land prices rose an average of 16.7 percent nationwide, while business properties in Osaka surged 43.9 percent. Japan's most expensive commercial land was valued at $23,000 a square foot in Tokyo's Marunouchi business district and in the nearby Ginza shopping district, the report said. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu owns a condominium in Japan's most expensive residential area, Tokyo's Sanbancho in Chiyoda ward, where land was valued at $7,500 per square foot, the report said. The Land Agency said residential land prices in Tokyo slipped an average of 0.3 percent last year, but commercial land prices in the capital rose 1.7 percent. The report was based on a survey of land prices conducted Jan. 1 at 16,865 spots across the country, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Butterworth to Intervene in Bass-Poynter Court Case
DOC.TEXT: Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth said Thursday he would intervene in a lawsuit filed by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass over dividends paid to the Poynter Institute, a media center that runs the St. Petersburg Times and other publications. Bass's attempt to obtain dividends paid to the institute, Butterworth said, has the potential to disrupt its funding. He said he was getting involved because he has the constitutional athority ``to protect the integrity of charitable interests.'' Andrew Barnes, editor and president of the Times, institute chairman and chairman and chief executive officer of the Times Holding Co. and Times Publishing Co., issued a statement saying he welcomed Butterworth's move. A spokesman for the Bass group questioned the state's action. ``We are puzzled by the attorney general's announcement,'' said David Bonderman, a general partner in the Bass venture. ``Our longstanding request that Times management act fairly and in accordance with its legal obligations poses absolutely no threat to the continuing survival of the Poynter Institute. Nor would our request in any way interfere with the services provided by the institute to public high schools and universities or Florida residents,'' he added. Butterworth said he would seek to stop an effort by Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd., an investor partnership controlled by Bass, to obtain dividends now paid to the non-profit journalism institute. ``The Poynter Institute is unique to Florida and has served our public high schools and universities, as well as numerous Florida residents,'' Butterworth said. ``It is important to Florida public policy to protect charitable institutions from attack by profiteers.'' The partnership includes the nieces of the late Eleanor Poynter Jamison, sister of founder Nelson Poynter. It has made a $270 million buyout offer for Times Publishing Co., parent firm of the newspaper, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. The Bass group owns 40 percent of the voting stock of Times Publishing Co. That organization, under the complex stock arrangement set up by Nelson Poynter, is in turn controlled by the Times Holding Co., which is controlled by the Poynter Institute. Bass maintains it wants a better return on its investment, while Times Publishing defends the current stock arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of the Poynter Institute, which offers education and national conferences to journalists and students.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Higher in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell marginally against the major currencies in what dealers called nervous and volatile European trading on Thursday. Gold prices gained about $1.50 an ounce. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar fluctuated throughout the day on serious international developments. They cited tension over Lithuania's demand for independence from Moscow, Romania's unrest over its Hungarian minority and uncertainty over German unification. The dealers said the fusion of the two German economies, which could take place this summer, would likely lead to higher costs for the Bonn government, undermining the traditionally strong West German mark. After four weeks of decline, the British pound gained half a cent after slightly better than expected trade figures for February. In London, one British pound cost $1.6015 late Thursday, more expensive for buyers than Wednesday's late $1.5965. Other European late dollar rates compared with Wednesday's late levels were: 1.7054 West German marks, down from 1.7070; 1.5150 Swiss francs, down from 1.5192; 5.7505 French francs, down from 5.7575; 1.9210 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9230; 1,255.50 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; and 1.1757 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1769. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar closed at 154.83 yen, up from 154.00 yen late in London Wednesday, when the Tokyo markets were closed for a holiday. Gold bullion prices recovered modestly after falls of more than $6 an ounce on Wednesday. Dealers said the gold price moved slowly in tune with the dollar's narrow fluctuations on the foreign-exchange market. They said there was little interest in gold and no news to influence the price. Gold closed in London, the major market, at a bid of $393.05 a troy ounce, up from $391.75. The closing Zurich bid price was $393.00, up from $391.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $392.85 bid, down from $393.65. Silver bullion traded late in London at $5.08 bid a troy ounce, up from $5.06.

DOC.HEAD: President of Retail Trade Group Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: James R. Williams, president of the National Retail Merchants Association for 19 years, has resigned and formed his own consulting business, it was announced Thursday. Williams stepped down as president of the Retail Services Division of the newly formed National Retail Federation. The Federation was created earlier this year when the National Retail Merchants Association merged with the American Retail Federation. There was no immediate word on who would replace Williams. Williams said in a news release that his New York-based consulting business will concentrate on retail clients and others that need to know how retailers operate. Before joining the trade group, Williams was a retailing executive and had been president of Williams Bros. Co., a department store founded by his family. He had been responsible for expanding the trade group's international operations and had an active part in organizing the World Conference of Retailers, held every two years. He has represented the U.S. retailing industry at meetings of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, an international trade monitoring organization, and appeared before congressional committes, federal agencies and other bodies to present the retailer's point of view.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Credit Card Giant Taking Stab At US Market
Graphic in AP Access under CREDITCARDS
DOC.TEXT: First came the trinkets and toys, then the cameras, cars, computers and electronics. Now Japan is ready to take on a remaining bastion of American economic dominance, the credit card. JCB International Credit Card Co. Ltd., the largest Japanese credit card company, is expanding aggressively in the United States and plans to peddle the card to American consumers beginning this summer. The effort has jolted U.S. card companies, which are watching JCB with a mix of awe, curiosity and fear. At first, JCB officials say, the card will be offered primarily to U.S. individuals such as business people who travel extensively in the Far East, where JCB is the most widely accepted plastic. They say the card is not intended for a broader U.S. audience, but aren't ruling out that possibility. ``I frankly don't see JCB as a mass card in this country,'' said Dwayne Krumme, head of JCB's American operation, based in Los Angeles. ``I think the JCB card will be niche card, at least in the early years.'' Krumme, who formerly ran the credit card business of Los Angeles-based First Interstate Bancorp, said JCB has held preliminary discussions with at least three banks in the Midwest and East about issuing JCB cards in the same way banks issue Visa and Mastercard. He declined to identify the banks but said ``we think we can work something out with them.'' JCB already is issuing corporate cards to U.S. businesses and has negotiated deals with credit-card processing companies for repayment services. In is accepted by a growing number of American merchants, from hotels and airlines to swank retailers eager to encourage spending by wealthy Japanese tourists and business people. ``The JCB card, in an international context, is really a travel and entertainment card,'' said Krumme. ``When it's used for other purposes, it's an upscale card used at Tiffany's, Chanel and Gucci's.'' At least 300,000 American outlets are expected to accept JCB cards soon, double the present number, JCB officials say. Worldwide, JCB is accepted by 1.4 million merchants, triple the number of five years ago. JCB's effort to muscle into the U.S. market comes as credit card companies already are competing intensely. JCB's entry also reflects Japan's seemingly inexhaustible financial might, an advantage that some rivals find intimidating. ``We think JCB is going to be one of the major competitive threats of the `90s,'' said Richard Woods, a spokesman for Mastercard International, accepted by about 8 million merchants worldwide. ``They have deep pockets. They're long-term players. There's no question they have an interest in providing global payment services,'' Woods said. ``We're watching them very closely.'' Visa International, accepted by 7.5 million merchants worldwide, also is monitoring JCB's forays, said spokesman Richard Brancoli. But he suggested JCB should be watching its own backyard. ``There are 25 million Japanese who have Visa cards,'' Brancoli said. ``We expect it to increase to 40 million in Japan.'' JCB stands for Japan Credit Bureau, founded three decades ago by Sanwa Bank, one of Japan's largest commercial banks. JCB is the oldest and predominant credit card company in Japan, with about 70 million cards issued. The card's biggest threat may be to the American Express card. Both are charge cards targeted mainly to the same market of affluent consumers. Users must pay their balance in full each month. Visa, Mastercard and the Discover card, issued by retailing giant Sears Roebuck & Co., are revolving credit cards, targeted to a much wider income range of consumers. Users do not have to pay their full balance, but are charged interest on the unpaid portion. Steven Richardson, vice president of travel-related services at American Express, said he didn't consider the JCB card a significant threat and noted that in Japan, both card companies have a partnership arrangement. Nonetheless, he said, ``We obviously look at any new developments in the industry and consider them all seriously.'' Credit-card experts speculated that American Express, accepted by 3 million merchants worldwide, is looking hard at ways to learn more about the competition. ``Obviously the American market is an attractive place,'' said Bruce Brittain, head of Brittain Associates Inc., an Atlanta-based consulting firm that does market research on credit-card use. ``They're targeting people with the big bucks.'' So far JCB's only U.S. offices are in Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco and New York. They are seeking to increase the U.S. merchant-acceptance base, but also operate as travel centers to help Japanese cardholders, much like American Express does abroad for its clients. Mitsuo Funayama, New York branch manager, said any rival fears of a Japanese assault were unfounded. ``I'm sure JCB won't be so big in this country,'' he said.

Share prices on Wall Street tumbled today in the wake of another big loss in the Tokyo stock market. It was the third straight decline on the New York Stock Exchange, following a vigorous rally in recent weeks. ``It's a belated reaction to the Japanese market,'' said Charles Jensen, an analyst for MKI Securities Corp. ``We've been ignoring that market for a couple of weeks. You can only ignore reality for so long.'' After a break for a national holiday Wednesday, the Tokyo stock market fell again in chaotic trading today, three days after the third-worst drop in its history. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 963.85 points, ending the day at 29,843.34, its lowest closing since Dec. 24, 1988. Today's drop puts the Nikkei's losses so far this year at 23 percent, or 9,072.53 points. Dealers blamed the market tumble on the Japanese yen's continuing erosion against the dollar. The yen's losses come despite Tuesday's 1 percent rise in Japan's official discount rate to 5.25 percent, which was intended to bolster the weak Japanese currency. Analysts said the New York market was ripe for a pullback after its recent advance, and the Japanese debacle exacerbated Wall Street's retreat. ``The market was overextended,'' said Monte Gordon, vice president and director of research at Dreyfus Corp. ``You would expect the market to retrace.'' Last week, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained a net 57.89 points to 2,741.22, its highest level since early January. The advance continued on Monday, as the blue-chip barometer picked up another 14.41 points. But it stalled in Tuesday's trading and the retreat was extended Wednesday and today.

DOC.HEAD: National Sandwich Chain Adopts `Dolphin-Safe' Tuna Policy
DOC.TEXT: The Blimpie chain of submarine sandwich shops said Thursday it soon will serve only tuna said to be caught in ways that do not seriously threaten dolphins. Blimpie's new policy states that no store will purchase any tuna unless it is deemed ``dolphin-safe'' _ caught by means posing only minimal risk to the marine mammals. But an environmental group said it advocates a boycott of all canned tuna because it knows of no brand available in the United States containing only dolphin-safe tuna. Blimpie, which says its 350 franchised shops served 4{ million tuna sandwiches last year, will not purchase Yellowfin tuna, the type associated most closely with harm to dolphins. Anthony Conza, president and co-founder of Blimpie's, said the company began working on the tuna-dolphin issue when it was raised by various environmental and animal rights groups. ``We believe that the fast food consumer will support our decision to take an environmentally responsible stance,'' he said. Blimpie decided against an outright boycott in part because consumers enjoy tuna sandwiches. ``Tuna is a low-fat, high-protein food that is highly recommended by nutritionists and well-liked by our consumers,'' Conza said. ``It is not our responsibility to make the decision for the consumer on whether or not to boycott tuna.'' Food distributors have assured Blimpie that the policy will be followed, the company said. Most of the stores, which operate in 16 states, will become part of the program by the summer. Blimpie already serves Skip Jack tuna from the Philippines in 60 of its Southeastern stores and in 28 of its Houston locations. Yellowfin tuna, one of the most commonly used varieties, are caught with the involuntary help of dolphins. Schools of Yellowfin swim below dolphins, so tuna fleets, mainly off the coasts of Southern California and South America, search out dolphins to locate Yellowfin. The dolphins often are injured or killed as the Yellowfin are caught. Dolphins supposedly do not swim with Skip Jack tuna. ``We do applaud the efforts but right now we are focusing on a canned tuna boycott,'' said Brenda Killian, a national organizer of the Save the Dolphins Project of San Francisco-based Earth Island Institute. ``We are in support of any restaurants that are looking for dolphin-safe tuna and if indeed distributors can guarantee it, we would like to know.'' ``As far as we know, there is no canned tuna being sold in the United States that is 100 percent Skip Jack,'' she added. The Save the Dolphins Project plans a nationwide Dolphin Day on April 14 to highlight the issue. Most tuna consumed in the United States is caught by methods that kill at least 100,000 dolphins each year, Ms. Killian said, citing biologists' estimates. Blimpie is a division of the publicly held Astor Restaurant Group Inc. of New York. It says it sells about 39 million sandwiches each year and has systemwide annual sales exceeding $120 million.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern, ALPA Agree to Interim Contract
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines and its pilots union have agreed to an interim contract calling for a 25 percent wage cut and benefit concessions, the company announced Thursday. The pact did not resolve the issue of rehiring more of the pilots who engaged in a sympathy strike with the Machinists union in March 1989. Eastern also insisted it needs twice the amount of concessions given in the interim pact by the time the contract expires on July 1 to successfully emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. Time to resolve the dispute ``regrettably has just about run out, in light of the reorganization timetable,'' said Thomas J. Matthews, senior vice president of human resources for Eastern, which is owned by Texas Air Corp. Eastern insisted federal mediators would have to continue efforts to reach a permanent agreement to cut costs further. ``If expedited mediation is not successful in leading to such an arrangement, Eastern ... will have to promptly seek bankruptcy court permission to achieve full cost reductions on a long-term basis,'' the carrier said in a news release. The interim cut applies to Eastern's approximately 850 pilots still being paid at the pre-strike wage rate of about $72,000. Eastern had 3,600 union pilots who honored picket lines when the Machinists went on strike on March 4, 1989. Since then, many pilots have returned, replacements have been hired at lower wages and the airline has sold many routes. Edward Breen, spokesman for the Eastern Air Line Pilots Association, contended the company intends to use the temporary agreement, negotiated with the help of the National Mediation Board, as a device to crush the union. He said that by demanding more concessions in advance, Eastern hoped to push the talks into a final impasse. Breen said ALPA executives had agreed in principle to the contract, but it would not be signed until after a formal vote of the Master Executive Committee on Saturday in Washington. The 25 percent wage cuts exclude about 950 replacement pilots hired at an average $27,500 when the strike began. The new wage levels are among the lowest in the country for major carriers, Breen said. ``An Eastern pilot after this will make about 50 percent of what a United Airlines pilot makes _ and they still can't make a profit,'' he said. Eastern lost $282.6 million in the last quarter of 1989, bringing total losses for the year to $852.3 million. Overall, Houston-based Texas Air lost $885.6 million. The interim agreement also calls for a reduction in the airline's contribution to the pilots' pension plan, increased pilot contributions to their medical and dental insurance, and the preservation of tougher work rules in effect since the strike. Eastern's ALPA contract expired in June 1988, but its provisions had remained in effect. Federal mediators have guided negotiations since September, although Eastern said the two sides have been consulting regularly for 33 months. Under Eastern's reorganization plan, pilots will have to reduce their wages and benefits to the same degree as other employees, Matthews said.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: and today.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 32.21 points to 2,695.72. Declining issues outstripped advances by around 3 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,194 down, 358 up and 410 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 175.93 million shares, up from 130.99 million in Wednesday's session. The NYSE's composite index fell 2.12 to 184.70. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.67 at 360.48.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Accepts Conditional Pleas From Development Company, Executives
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Thursday delayed accepting a guilty plea from General Development Corp. and ordered an independent expert to review a plan to monitor the company and repay thousands of people allegedly overcharged for its homes. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt gave conditional acceptance to guilty pleas from the Miami-based home builder and two former executives pending review of pre-sentencing reports. General Development, former President Robert Ehrling and former Chairman David Brown were named last week in a 16-count indictment alleging a seven-year scheme to sell overvalued homes at its nine Florida communities. The indictment claims the company priced homes well above comparable residences in Florida and kept prospective buyers from learning about the difference. Most of the General Development customers were Northeast and Midwest residents brought to Florida on heavily subsidized trips. Reading from prepared statements in court, both Ehrling and Brown apologized and admitted their knowledge of the price-hike scheme. The company allegedly sold 10,000 overpriced homes for $850 million from 1982 to 1989. ``I am truly sorry I did not take action sooner, and I'm sorry for the customers who were misled,'' said Brown. Under the plea agreement with federal prosecutors, the two executives and the company would plead guilty to one fraud count, while the 15 additional counts would be dismissed. Charges against GDV Financial Corp., a General Development subsidiary that provided mortgages and financial aid to homeowners, would be dropped, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Norman Moscowitz. If Ms. Nesbitt accepts the guilty pleas from Brown, 49, and Ehrling, 50, each could face up to five years in prison, a $250,000 fine and restitution payments. Sentencing is scheduled for May 22. Brown and Ehrling were making $600,000 a year each before they were forced out by General Development directors March 9 after the company disclosed it was facing indictment. General Development's estimated $100 million, 25-year restitution program is detailed in a civil consent decree that prosecutors expect to file within the next week. Ms. Nesbitt said she wants an expert, perhaps a former trustee of a dissolved corporation, to review the consent decree ``for its feasibility.'' ``I don't want to accept something now and be locked in,'' she said. A hearing on the consent decree is scheduled for April 3. The company also could face a maximum $500,000 fine for its guilty plea. In court, Moscowitz said General Development priced its homes an average of 40 percent higher than market value, and lot prices were inflated by up to 10 times. Up to half of the General Development homebuyers were from the New York metropolitan area, he said. The indictment also alleges General Development kept customers from learning about other homes prices in Florida by assigning a sales representatives to stay with the people constantly and even to screen their calls in some cases. The 35-year-old company has sold or has available 350,000 lots in Florida and also operates a time-share resort near Walt Disney World, a recreational community in Tennessee and 10 time-share resorts in the West. General Development recently laid off 5,500 workers _ about 10 percent of its work force _ and shut sales offices in Hollywood, Fla., and Boston. The company is also the target of several class-action suits involving thousands of homebuyers alleging overpricing. In Delaware Chancery Court, a General Development shareholder filed suit last week seeking a court order to nominate three candidates to the board of directors in May and three others in 1991. General Development claims New York-based United Capital Corp., which owns about 12.7 percent of its outstanding shares, missed the filing deadline for this year's corporate elections and that directors can appoint people to the 1991 vacancies. The Delaware suit alleges Brown persuaded United Capital Chairman Attilio Petrocelli to sign a letter dropping the proxy slate in exchange for permission to acquire up to 20 percent of General Development stock. But Brown failed to disclose the company's financial problems and the pending indictments, the suit alleges. The suit seeks to nullify the agreement and restore United Capital's proxy slate.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Senate Approves Media Antitrust Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Italian Senate on Thursday passed a bill that would restrict ownership of television and newspapers, and ban commercials during film, opera and theater productions on television. The measure is seen as a major threat to the television empire of Italian media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi. The bill, approved by a show of hands in the Senate, must be considered next week by the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of Parliament. The TV law would prevent those who own more than 16 percent of Italy's total newspaper circulation from owning a television station. Those who control from 8 percent to 16 percent of the circulation would be restricted to just one television station and those who own up to 8 percent of the circulation could own two stations. Someone who does not own a newspaper could own up to three television stations. Italy is the only European nation without a law regulating television ownership. Under the bill, Berlusconi could be forced to give up one of his three TV stations or his newspapers. The Rome daily La Repubblica, which Berlesconi controls through his acquisition of Mondadori Editore, estimated he could lose up to $320 million a year in advertising if the amendment on commercials passes. Gianni Letta, a spokesman for Berlusconi's holding company Fininvest, said Wednesday that approval of the amendment ``would mean the end of commercial television in Italy to the advantage of a monopoly by (state-run) RAI.'' The state-run television carries advertising but mainly between shows.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Is Latest Victim of LBO Debt Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp., with its announcement Thursday that it was selling out to a Japanese firm, became the latest company forced to seek outside help after being swamped by leveraged buyout debt. The parent of 7,000 7-Eleven convenience stores said it was selling a controlling interest to Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd., Japan's second-largest supermarket operator and a partner in the $4.9 billion buyout of Southland in 1987, for $400 million and the assumption of Southland's debt. Southland joined the growing ranks of companies such as Campeau Corp., Revco D.S. Inc. and Doskocil Cos. that were unable to handle the large debt bills run up in takeover deals. Their stories have common elements: A debt-financed buyout made during the rosy days of the 1980s takeover binge. Disappointing sales and earnings that can't support massive interest payments. Assets put up for sale to bring in desperately-needed cash. Economists are predicting that as time goes on, more companies will find themselves in similar straits, especially if the already slowing economy takes a downturn. Finding an outside investor, as Southland has done, is one option a struggling company has for getting out of trouble. The infusion of cash and assumption of debt brings an immediate end to the financial crisis, but the price, in this case a loss of corporate control, can be high. For other companies _ including Revco, Campeau and Doskocil _ the answer has been bankruptcy court protection. Revco, one of the country's biggest drugstore chains, went private in a $1.5 billion junk bond-financed buyout in 1986. It was the first big leveraged buyout to fail, and Revco is selling hundreds of stores as it reorganizes. Campeau was unable to handle a $7 billion debt load after buying Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., again with high-interest junk bond financing. When news of the company's troubles broke in September, it set off a plunge in the junk bond market and helped bring the debt-financed takeover boom to an end. Campeau placed the store businesses in bankruptcy court in January. Doskocil, a food processing company, defaulted on a $133 million loan after taking over the much larger Wilson Foods Corp. Doskocil has been unable to find a buyer for assets it has tried to sell, and the higher prices it has been forced to pay for raw materials has left it short of cash. The company sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors earlier this month. All of these companies, when they went heavily into debt, indicated they could handle the payments. But the economy has slowed, profits have fallen and interest rates have moved higher, leaving some highly-leveraged operations in a bind. Retailers have been particularly vulnerable, as several of tese firms illustrate. The retail industry has been in a slump for several years, and an expected improvement never materialized. What looked like a great investment two years ago is today's bad deal. Some economists have warned the economy eventually could run into trouble because of highly-leveraged businesses. Companies that do business with financially-distressed concerns may find they aren't being paid for merchandise they have shipped, or aren't receiving as many orders. They may have to cut back, and possibly lay off workers, as a result. Furthermore, a company strapped by debt could be limited in its ability to compete and might lose market share to other concerns, including foreign businesses. A drop in market share means less demand for a companies' products _ which also can mean lost jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Shawmut Revises Earnings To Beef Up Reserves Against Bad Loans
DOC.TEXT: Shawmut National Corp. has revised its 1989 earnings after an examination by federal bank regulators, posting a $129 million loss for the year instead of a previously announced $200 million profit. The bank revised its fourth-quarter statement to reflected a $327 million loss instead of a $3.9 million profit. It also announced Wednesday that it had lowered its dividend per share to 25 cents from 36 cents. The revision was another sign of the troubles facing banks because of the slumping real estate market. Examinations of real estate lending led to a $1.1 billion loss at Bank of New England Corp. earlier this year. Investors seemed unconcerned by Shawmut's move, which could be viewed as protecting the bank against future problems. Shawmut stock gained 37{ cents Thursday to close at $15.25 in New York Stock Exchange trading. Shawmut, one of New England's largest banking companies, said bad loans for the fourth quarter jumped sharply, to $123.4 million from $46.4 million. After the review by federal regulators, Shawmut, which is based in Boston and Hartford and has more than 400 branches, said it nearly doubled the size of its reserves for loan losses at the end of 1989 to $739 million from $383 million. Bank examiners convinced Shawmut to post the loss. Shawmut had called in 180 examiners from three federal agencies in a confidence-building effort after federal officials gave both Bank of New England and Bank of Boston poor marks. Examinations of New England banks have drawn fire, with bank officials accusing the examiners of being excessively harsh after failing to nip the savings and loan crisis in the bud. Shawmut chairman and chief executive officer Joel Alvord said the examiners had not changed the regulations but were ``calling the plays a little tighter.'' ``When you see clouds on the horizon, you carry an umbrella,'' Alvord said. ``We may see showers, but others might see storm clouds or a torrential downpour.'' Shawmut also said it expected a $40 million first-quarter 1990 profit, but that the figured would include $56 million in one-time gains and tax benefits. News of the revision prompted both Standard and Poor's Corp. and Fitch Investors Service Inc. to lower their credit ratings of the bank's senior debt issues to take the greater risk into account.

DOC.HEAD: Hit New Record of $391.23 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 505 money market mutual funds rose $199.04 million to an all-time record of $391.23 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise broke the previous record of $391.03 billion set a week earlier. That record originally was reported as $390.79 billion but was revised upward by the Washington-based trade group to reflect the inclusion of four new funds. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 247 general purpose funds fell $968.9 million to $132.57 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds increased $637.0 million to $166.78 billion, and assets of 156 institutional funds rose $530.9 million to $91.88 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.67 percent from 7.65 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield rose to 7.65 percent from 7.64 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, up from 43 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.25 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from the previous week. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged at 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.88 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged. Yields were 8.01 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 7.97 percent; 8.01 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.96 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.03 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Change in Corporate Culture for New Microsoft President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday PMs report
DOC.TEXT: A change of corporate culture is in store for Michael Hallman, who is trading the presidency of Boeing Computer Services for the same job at Microsoft Corp. Boeing is nearing its 75th anniversary; Microsoft was founded in the mid-1970s. Boeing deals with everything from fax machines to fluid dynamics models; Microsoft focuses on computer software. Boeing has airplane models expected to be in development or use for 50 to 70 years; the software industry has to react to sudden market changes. ``It's going to be a fun place to work,'' Hallman said in an interview Tuesday. ``It's a place where you can work hard, be successful and have fun doing it.'' Hallman, 44, was named earlier this week by Bill Gates, Microsoft's 34-year-old billionaire chairman and chief executive, to succeed Jon A. Shirley, who retires June 30. Hallman will join Microsoft April 2. Hallman, who also will be chief operating officer, described his new job as overseeing day-to-day operations while company founder Gates provides overall product and development direction. The key, he said, will be to help Microsoft cope with ``the realities that rapid growth and large size create, but at the same time ensure there's the entrepreneurial spirit and environment that has kept the creativity flowing there.'' Microsoft has about 5,000 employees and is expected to hit $1 billion in sales in 1990. Its operating system software for IBM personal computers and compatibles is the industry standard. Microsoft also leads in applications software such as word processing programs and programming languages. At Boeing Computer Services, Hallman directed about 13,000 employees and a Boeing Co. division that does more than $1 billion in business a year. About two-thirds of the division's work is for Boeing, but selling computer time and its expertise in data management and telecommunications brought about $360 million in sales last year. BCS handles information management for all Boeing divisions, writes software and develops technologies such as artificial intelligence and computer-aided design and manufacturing. It operates about $1.3 billion worth of computer gear, including a state-of-the-art Cray supercomputer. It also has one of the world's largest private telecommunications networks, linking six major data centers nationwide. And its customers include large corporations and the federal government _ the sort Microsoft also would like. ``I think that's an area where my background would lend itself well,'' Hallman said. Besides selling to such customers, Hallman also brings the perspective of an individual computer operator _ he has three in his home _ and a large, corporate computer user. Boeing Computer was in charge of acquiring the company's 43,000 personal computers and the software for them. Hallman does not foresee Microsoft switching its emphasis on desktop computers used by individuals and small businesses, but he said the 1990s will see more personal computers linked in networks and with large mainframes. Microsoft's products will need to reflect that, he said. Hallman joined Boeing three years ago after spending 20 years at International Business Machines Corp., much of that in sales and marketing. He ran Boeing Computer's outside sales until he was named president in November 1987. Microsoft spokesman Marty Taucher said Hallman's compensation would be comparable to that of Shirley, who made $315,000 a year, according to Microsoft's 1989 proxy statement. Hallman said he was approached by Microsoft about the president's job last fall, with contact accelerating after Shirley formally announced his retirement earlier this year. In recent weeks, Hallman said he spent a lot of time with Gates and other Microsoft senior executives, discussing the job and ``making sure the chemistry was right.'' ``Bill and I get along great,'' Hallman said. ``I think the facts are we share the same enthusiasm and passion and vision for where this technology is going to go.'' Hallman added that the change in corporate history and style from Boeing to Microsoft would be an advantage. ``It would be a mistake to bring someone in who had exactly the same view because no value would be added there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Higher
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against most major currencies except the sagging Japanese yen Thursday as a weak showing on Wall Street unsettled investors. Gold prices gained in domestic and overseas dealing. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for March delivery settled at $394 a troy ounce, up $2.20 from Wednesday. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $394 for a troy ounce of gold, $2.10 higher than Wednesday's late bid. Dealers said cross trading involving sales of Japanese yen and purchases of West German marks dominated activity in the currency markets. ``People were watching the Dow Jones but I don't think that was the most important factor in the foreign exchange markets,'' said Renato Strauss, assistant vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Co. in New York. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks tumbled 32.21 points to 2,695.72, closing above its worst levels of the day. Stock traders said the selloff was a belated reaction to the profound weakness this year in the Tokyo exchange. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 963.85 points earlier Thursday, ending the day at 29,843.34. The drop put the Nikkei's loss so far this year at 23 percent, or 9,072.53 points. Sales of dollars to collect profits made during its recent strong performance also weighed down the currency. European dealers reported earlier that the dollar fluctuated in response to international developments. Tension over Lithuania's demand for independence from Moscow, Romania's unrest over its Hungarian minority and uncertainty over German unification all influenced currency trading. After four weeks of decline, the British pound regained some lost ground after the government reported slightly better than expected trade figures for February. One British pound was quoted at $1.6040 late in New York, stronger than late Wednesday's level of $1.5955. In London, one British pound cost $1.6015 late Thursday, more expensive for buyers than Wednesday's late $1.5965. One dollar bought 155.105 Japanese yen late Thursday in New York, up from 154.365 yen late Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo the dollar closed at 154.83 yen, up from 154.00 yen late Wednesday in London, when the Tokyo markets were closed for a holiday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Wednesday, included: 1.7028 West German marks, down from 1.7100; 1.5120 Swiss francs, down from 1.5225; 5.7415 French francs, down from 5.768; 1,255.50 Italian lire, down from 1,259.75; and 1.17575 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17875. Dollar rates in late European compared with Wednesday included: 1.7054 West German marks, down from 1.7070; 1.5150 Swiss francs, down from 1.5192; 5.7505 French francs, down from 5.7575; 1.9210 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9230; 1,255.50 Italian lire, down from 1,257.25; and 1.1757 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1769. Gold bullion prices recovered modestly after falls of more than $6 an ounce on Wednesday. Silver posted minor gains. In London, the major European precious metals market, gold closed at a bid of $393.05 a troy ounce, up from $391.75. The closing Zurich bid price was $393.00, up from $391.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $392.85 bid, down from $393.65. In New York, silver bullion for March delivery closed at $5.084 a troy ounce compared to Wednesday's settlement of $5.055. Silver bullion traded late in London at $5.08 bid a troy ounce, up from $5.06.

DOC.HEAD: Former MTV Developer Named To Head Time Warner Enterprises Unit
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Thursday that Robert W. Pittman, who oversaw the creation of the MTV cable television network nearly a decade ago, has been appointed to head Time Warner's business development division. Pittman, 36, was named president and chief executive of Time Warner Enterprises, and will be involved in strategic and business development as well as in entrepreneurial ventures. In a telephone interview, Pittman said his job would be to ``take advantage of assets we already have in place'' and look for new ways ``to keep our company growing and expanding'' both domestically and internationally. Pittman said he was the original head of programming for MTV: Music Television, the music cable network that debuted in 1981 under the ownership of what was then called Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Co. Warner Amex was a joint venture of Warner Communications Inc. and American Express Co. At Warner Amex, he was also instrumental in developing The Movie Channel, a pay-television service. From 1983 to 1985, Pittman served as chief operating officer of MTV. Pittman was part of a group that unsuccessfully tried to buy MTV in 1985 but lost out to a bid by Viacom Inc. Pittman stayed on for two years after the buyout as president and chief executive on MTV Networks, the successor company to Warner Amex that operates the MTV, Nickelodeon, Nick at Nite and VH-1 cable networks. In 1987, he co-founded with MCA Inc. a company called Quantum Media Inc. which created and produced TV programs and made investments in media properties. That company was acquired in September for an undisclosed price by Time Warner, which itself was formed last year when Time Inc. bought Warner Communications. Pittman then became an executive adviser at Time Warner. Steven J. Ross, a co-chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner, said in a statement, ``We've had a long and productive relationship with Bob.'' During Pittman's tenure as chief operating officer and chief executive at MTV Networks, the company was ``the most profitable basic-cable network in the country at that time. We're delighted to welcome him back,'' Ross said. Pittman joins Arthur R. Barron, a former Paramount Communications Inc. executive, at the helm of Time Warner Enterprises. Barron, 55, was named chairman of Time Warner Enterprises in February. ``I have known Bob Pittman and admired his creative talents for several years,'' Barron was quoted as saying in a news release. ``I look forward to working alongside Bob in expanding Time Warner's business.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Japan-Markets, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on Wall Street tumbled Thursday in the wake of another big loss in the Tokyo stock market. It was the third straight decline on the New York Stock Exchange, following a vigorous rally in recent weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 32.21 points to 2,695.72, breaching the key psychological level of 2,700. The blue-chip barometer was down more than 40 at one point in the afternoon. Declining issues outstripped advancing ones by around 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks, with 1,200 down, 368 up and 409 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 175.93 million shares, up from 130.99 million in Wednesday's session. ``It's a belated reaction to the Japanese market,'' said Charles Jensen, an analyst for MKI Securities Corp. ``We've been ignoring that market for a couple of weeks. You can only ignore reality for so long.'' After a break for a national holiday Wednesday, the Tokyo stock market fell again in chaotic trading Thursday, three days after the third-worst drop in its history. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 963.85 points, ending the day at 29,843.34, its lowest closing since Dec. 24, 1988. Thursday's drop puts the Nikkei's losses so far this year at 23 percent, or 9,072.53 points. Dealers blamed the market tumble on the Japanese yen's continuing erosion against the dollar. The yen's losses occurred despite Tuesday's 1 percent rise in Japan's official discount rate to 5.25 percent, which was intended to bolster the weak Japanese currency. Analysts said the New York market was ripe for a pullback after its recent advance, and the Japanese debacle exacerbated Wall Street's retreat. ``The market was overextended,'' said Monte Gordon, vice president and director of research at Dreyfus Corp. ``You would expect the market to retrace.'' Last week, the Dow Jones average gained a net 57.89 points to 2,741.22, its highest level since early January. The advance continued on Monday, as the average picked up another 14.41 points. But it stalled in Tuesday's trading and the retreat was extended Wednesday and Thursday. The declines in New York haven't been as severe as those wrenching the Tokyo market, however. While the Nikkei average lost 3.13 percent Thursday, for example, its Dow Jones counterpart finished 1.18 percent lower. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, American Express dropped 1[ to 26|, General Electric was down } at 63], AT&T lost { at 41] and Citicorp declined ] to 23|. Boeing was up [ at 71\, Ford Motor jumped { to 48{ and Beverly was unchanged at 4]. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 211.00 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $36.19 billion, or 0.44 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.12 to 184.70. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.67 to 389.56, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 4.05 at 335.69. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 4.79 to 434.51. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.67 at 360.48.
