DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Hazelwood Convicted on One Minor Charge, Acquitted on 3 Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs, UPDATING with juror comments; Trims; Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Thursday acquitted Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood of being drunk and reckless in connection with the nation's worst oil spill but convicted him of a minor charge of negligent discharge of oil. After deliberating for just 10{ hours, the jurors absolved Hazelwood of one felony and two misdemeanor counts stemming from the disaster, in which his tanker ran aground, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989. The misdemeanor charge on which he was convicted carries a maximum sentence of 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, far less than the 7\ years and $61,000 fine he could have faced if found guilty on all four charges. There were bursts of applause in the court room as Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone read the first three verdicts of ``not guilty.'' Johnstone said he would set a sentencing date later in the day. Hazelwood's New York lawyer, Michael Chalos, a former classmate of Hazelwood's at the Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler, N.Y., clapped the skipper on the shoulder and hit the counsel table with his hand at the first ``Not guilty'' verdict. The normally taciturn defendant smiled broadly for the first time in the two-month-long trial and commented briefly to reporters, saying only, ``I'm just relieved. I was nervous.'' ``We think it's a great victory for Captain Hazelwood,'' Chalos said. ``We had great faith in the jury system. The only charge he's been convicted of is a low-level misdemeanor.'' One of the jurors said he found unbelievable the prosecution's complicated effort to prove Hazelwood was intoxicated through backward calculations. The skipper's blood was not tested until long after the disaster, and juror Jeff Sage said he and the other panelists figured out that from the prosecution expert's calculations, the captain would have had to consume an enormous amount of liquor before his ship ran aground. ``If Hazelwood's an average Joe and you figured backwards the way he said, it's clear he'd have to be dead'' from the alcohol, Sage said. ``The jury felt there were just too many variables to pinpoint whether he was drunk at all,'' Sage said. But he said the panel concluded that Hazelwood was negligent to leave the bridge of his ship during an icy transit. ``To this day, we're never going to know exactly what caused the accident,'' Sage said. But he found no fault in the state's decision to try the skipper on criminal charges. ``I think that someone had to be tried,'' he said, ``and he's the captain. He was in charge.'' After a year of accusations against faceless villains _ Exxon and oil-related agencies _ the Hazelwood trial provided a human side to the Exxon Valdez calamity, focusing on frailties of captain and crew. Although 150 civil suits were filed and Exxon was indicted in federal court, Hazelwood was the only individual charged criminally. His lawyers complained he was a ``scapegoat'' in a disaster with many culprits. His trial in Anchorage Superior Court had the elements of an engrossing sea story with a dark subplot involving liquor, troubled crew members and a star-crossed captain whose battles with the bottle were well known. But the skipper, who had been painted as a liquor swigging brigand, turned out to be a quiet figure intent on nothing more than blending into the woodwork. He sat back, stroking his beard, while others addressed the trial's key questions: Was the skipper drunk on duty and was he reckless to leave the ship's bridge? Whether Hazelwood was drunk when his ship grounded remained a muddled issue because authorities failed to do a timely blood alcohol test. When they got around to it 10{ hours after the grounding, Hazelwood had a .061 alcohol reading, lower than the Alaska standard of .10 for drunken driving. A prosecution expert witness tried to calculate backward and concluded that Hazelwood had a blood alcohol reading of .14 when the ship grounded. But defense experts ridiculed the figures as ``nonsense,'' saying results could not be conclusive because there was too long a wait before the test and too many variables, including whether Hazelwood drank after the grounding. Hazelwood, who chose not to testify, never explained. In six weeks of testimony, witnesses came forward to tell what they knew of the day the Exxon Valdez and Hazelwood sailed into history. It was the Thursday before Good Friday, and the tanker had pulled into its namesake port of Valdez to pick up a load of oil. Hazelwood went ashore for lunch with two crew members and a local pilot; they remember that he sipped iced tea. Then they separated to do shopping. Later in the day _ the hour remained in dispute _ Hazelwood met with his pals at the Pipeline Club, a bar where they said he drank three vodkas in about three hours. A woman patron of the club, wife of a Coast Guard investigator in the case, placed Hazelwood there much earlier, drinking for seven hours. But her testimony never was corroborated. On the way back to the ship, the men stopped and bought pizza for the crew, and Hazelwood had another drink, either beer or vodka. When they arrived at the Valdez terminal about 8:20 p.m., they learned that the sailing time, originally set for 10 p.m., had been moved up to 9 p.m. The prosecution would maintain that Hazelwood's tardiness in boarding his ship showed recklessness. Was the skipper intoxicated? He showed no signs of it. During the trial not a single witness said he appeared drunk. ``Did he stagger?'' defense attorneys would ask. ``Did he slur his words?'' Inevitably, the answers were, ``No.'' Pilot William Murphy, who guided the tanker through the Valdez Narrows, said he noticed a trace of alcohol on Hazelwood's breath. After a half-hour on the bridge, he said the skipper went below and remained there for an hour. When Murphy left the ship at about 10:30 p.m., he conferred with Hazelwood: ``I reminded him there was ice reported ahead.'' The crucial period, recounted repeatedly in testimony, began at 11:53 p.m. when Hazelwood decided to leave the bridge in control of third mate Gregory Cousins after discussing maneuvers that would take the Exxon Valdez out of shipping lanes to avoid ice, then turn back to the lanes before leaving Prince William Sound. ``He asked if I felt comfortable with what we were going to do and I said, `Yes,' recalled Cousins. ``He said, `Do you feel comfortable enough that I can go below and get rid of some paperwork?' I said I felt very comfortable.'' The prosecution would note that Cousins did not have the special endorsement Hazelwood had for piloting in Prince William Sound, a license the defense claimed was mere formality and had been waived by the Coast Guard. At the helm was Robert Kagan, a seaman who had problems with steering in the past. Many witnesses would blame Kagan for ramming the oil-filled tanker into a charted reef. Cousins said he ordered Kagan to make a 10-degree right rudder turn, a routine order. But he failed to check until it was too late to see if the turn had been made. By then, the Exxon Valdez was steaming toward Bligh Reef. Ten minutes after Hazelwood left the bridge, Cousins glanced at the rudder indicator and, ``I could tell we hadn't turned. ... I think Mr. Kagan didn't really understand the command.'' Cousins called Hazelwood in his cabin. ``I told him that we were getting into serious trouble ...,'' the third mate recalled. ``That was then we suffered the first shock and we were hard aground.'' Deep holes were gashed in the ship's underbelly. It was impaled on a rock the size of a Volkswagen, and warm oil was bubbling into the cold, clear waters of Prince William Sound. In all, the ship belched out nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil in a hemorrhage that killed countless birds, fish and wildlife on the richly populated sound. The rocky shore turned black for hundreds of miles. One issue which consumed half the trial was whether Hazelwood, in the frantic moments after grounding, tried to drive his ship off the reef. He denied it, but prosecutors tried to show he risked capsizing the tanker and killing the crew. The issue became moot when the defense proved the ship was immovable, and the judge agreed Hazelwood could not be convicted of trying something that was impossible.

DOC.HEAD: State Joins Union, Managers to Buy Strike-Torn Gunmaker
DOC.TEXT: The state of Connecticut on Thursday joined with striking workers, managers and private investors to buy the firearms division of Colt Industries, giving the 154-year-old gunmaker new life after a bitter, four-year strike. State Treasurer Francisco L. Borges said the state would put up $25 million from pension funds for a 47 percent stake in a newly created company to be called Colt's Manufacturing Company. ``Let me emphasize that this is a carefully thought out, carefully structured, potentially very profitable business venture,'' Borges said. ``The state's participation is not a bailout, not a handout, and not a subsidy.'' Union members, white-collar workers and investors also will hold stakes in the company, which Colt Industries decided to sell in order to concentrate on its larger aerospace, automotive and industrial services businesses. The new company's first official act was to write a check for $10 million in back pay for 1,050 workers who had been on strike since Jan. 24, 1986. About 50 striking workers applauded when the company produced the check at a news conference in Borges' office. Under terms of the buyout, the company will pay a total of $13 million in back wages to settle an unfair labor practices lawsuit brought by the United Auto Workers union against Colt Industries in the wake of the strike. Strikers will be put back to work based on seniority. In addition to back pay they will receive a 13 percent wage increase and a stock plan that will allow United Auto Workers members to own 11.5 percent of the stock in the new company. In return for the back pay, the UAW dropped its lawsuit against Colt Industries for unfair labor practices. The National Labor Relations Board said the settlement was the largest in its 55-year history, topping a $12 million settlement in 1979 to chemical plant workers in Westwego, La. Salaried workers will own about 12 percent of the shares in Colt's Manufacturing, while the investor group C.F. Holding Corp. will own about 12 percent, said Antony Autorino, chairman of C.F. Holding Corp. Colt Industries put the firearms division up for sale 11 months ago. At the time, the division was ravaged by a three-year-old strike, and had just lost the contract to produce M-16 rifles for the U.S. Department of Defense. With no buyer in sight, the striking workers won a major victory in September 1989 when an NLRB administrative law judge ruled the strike was caused by Colt's unfair labor practices. The judge ordered the company to reinstate the workers and pay them lost wages estimated as high as $40 million. In November, C.F. Holding announced it had agreed to buy the firearms division. There was no mention at the time of union or state participation, although both were expected to be part of a final agreement. Borges said Thursday his office had fully investigated the firearms division and the firearms industry and concluded the business was a good investment for the state. Borges said he knew of no other instance in which labor, management and public and private investors joined to preserve a company as big as Colt's firearms division. He described the deal as a ``bold, exciting and very inventive partnership in the best tradition of Samuel Colt's entrepreneurial spirit.'' Colt was founded in 1836 in Hartford by Samuel Colt, inventor of the first successful repeating pistol. After Colt's death in 1862, the company developed the six-shooter that almost every cowboy carried _ the legendary gun that won the West. In addition to the M-16, the standard Army-issue rifle, Colt makes the Colt 45 handgun, the King Cobra magnum revolver and the AR-15 rifle.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Drop As Labor Tensions Ease
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell from five-month highs Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange in response to an easing of labor tensions in Canada and Peru and a sharp drop in stock prices. On other commodity markets, precious metals advanced, grains and soybeans were mixed; cocoa futures surged; sugar retreated; energy futures fell; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 3.5 cents lower with the contract for spot delivery at $1.291 a pound. Copper futures had surged as much as 4.6 cents Wednesday on speculation that union workers at a Noranda Inc. copper smelter in Canada's Quebec province would reject management's final contract offer, setting the stage for a strike. But workers approved the contract by a narrow margin, and reports of the results early Thursday morning gave the copper market its initial downward shove. Later in the morning, the port workers union in Peru announced it had ended a nationwide strike after two days, freeing Peruvian copper exports to move again. A miners strike against Southern Peru Copper Corp., the country's largest copper producer, continued into its 11th day but analysts said the company had copper stockpiled against the strike and had not yet broken any shipping commitments. ``What threw a monkey wrench into it was the dockworkers strike,'' said James Steel, a metals analyst with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc. ``That kind of worried everybody, the fact they couldn't get it out.'' The strike against Southern Peru Copper is threatening to spread, though, with a national miners work stoppage set for Monday. And analysts are increasingly speculating that the company will soon declare force majeure on shipping commitments. Declaring force majeure means a company cannot be held to a contract due to circumstances beyond its control. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 32 points Thursday, prompting further selling in the copper market. Because copper is used heavily in construction and industrial production, copper prices are extremely sensitive to economic signals. Gold and silver futures rose moderately on the Commodity Exchange, boosted mainly by the dollar's weakness against most other major currencies. Gold settled $2 to $2.20 higher with April at $394.70 a troy ounce; silver was 2.5 cents to 2.9 cents higher with March at $5.084. Soybean futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade on strength in the soybean meal market. Wheat futures retreated while corn advanced. The markets displayed only slight interest in news that U.S. and Soviet negotiators had reached tentative agreement on a new five-year grain pact increasing to 10 million metric tons from 9 million the amount of U.S. grain the Soviet Union is obligated to buy each year. ``I think it was pretty much expected,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a brokers advisory service in Chicago. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1{ cents lower with May at $3.58} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $2.58} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent higher with May at $1.49} a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 2} cents higher with May at $6.05 a bushel. Cocoa futures surged and sugar futures fell sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange in trading inspired largely by technical signals. Further buying in the cocoa market was linked to news that the International Cocoa Organization is likely to vote Monday on a two-year extension of a price-support agreement, keeping 250,000 metric tons of buffer-stock cocoa off the market. Cocoa settled $44 to $49 higher with March at $1,147 per ton; sugar ended .10 cent to .31 cent lower with May at 15.48 cents a pound. Firm cash markets supported livestock and meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle settled unchanged to .38 cent higher with April at 76.82 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .38 cent higher with March at 82.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .20 cent lower to .65 cent higher with April at 53.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .68 cent higher with March at 51.45 cents a pound. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 40 cents lower to 4 cents higher with May at $20 a barrel; heating oil was .30 cent to .54 cent lower with April at 55.01 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .47 cent to 1.15 cents lower with April at 57.38 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: GM Puts Incentives on New Minivans
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s new line of three minivans was dumped into the incentive pool for the first time Thursday as the automaker offered $1,000 in cash rebates on the vehicles. GM officials said the front-wheel-drive minivans _ sold as the Chevrolet Lumina APV, the Pontiac Trans Sport and the Oldsmobile Silhouette _ were selling well, but needed the incentives anyway. ``We could see that there is a need in today's market to have incentives on just about anything,'' said Pontiac spokesman Ed Lechtzin. ``Because people are coming in and like the vehicle, but look at the price and say, `How much (rebate) money am I getting?''' Lechtzin said there was some concern that production at the sole plant producing the minivans may outpace demand. But Oldsmobile spokesman Ross Ruehle said the sales demand is a little stronger than anticipated for the Silhouette. ``I have heard that they are selling relatively well,'' said senior economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. When asked why GM would offer a rebate on something selling well he said: ``Good question.'' Herb Adcox, owner of Herb Adcox Chevrolet in Chattanooga, Tenn., said he suspected months ago that GM would offer incentives on the minivans when production at the North Tarrytown, N.Y., assembly plant reached a certain level, mainly because consumers expected them. The company is increasing production at the plant, which is expected to produce about 175,000 vans this year and about 225,000 next year. The new minivans went on sale last October. Since then, GM has sold 30,891 of the them, with the Chevrolet model making up more than half. The new incentives became effective Thursday and run until May 2. Chrysler Corp., whose minivan sales command more than half of the vehicle's market segment, offered rebates on the vans for the first time between last Dec. 15 and Jan. 31. Sales of the Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town and Country soared during the incentive period. Since then, the minivan sales pace has dropped. ``What we think is we have been out there trying to sell something up against someone with an incredible rebate,'' said Chevrolet spokeswoman Mary McElyea. Ford Motor Co. is offering a $500 rebate on its Aerostar minivan. That offer expires April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Knight-Ridder Increases Stock Repurchase Amount
DOC.TEXT: Directors of Knight-Ridder Inc. on Thursday authorized the repurchase of 3 million shares of common stock. The increase brings to 4.5 million the number of shares authorized for repurchase as part of the company's standard policy to keep 4 million to 5 million shares open for repurchase, said Larry Levine, treasurer of the Miami-based media company. Levine said there is no deadline for repurchasing the stock. Knight-Ridder operates 28 daily newspapers, including The Miami Herald and the Detroit Free Press. It sold off the last of its television stations last year. Knight-Ridder stock closed down $1.75 at $52.75 Thursday in New York Stock Exchange trading. The company has about 51 million shares outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: H-P To Close Scottish Plant, Consolidate Operations
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. will close its plant in Livingston, Scotland, and move its operations to three other sites, the company said Thursday. The plant repairs computer boards and assembles workstations. Its 240 workers will be offered H-P jobs elsewhere. Board repair operations will be moved to H-P's plant about 12 miles away in South Queensferry, which employs about 1,000 people. The plant's workstation manufacturing operations will be merged with similar activities in Exeter, N.H., and Boeblingen, West Germany, Hewlett-Packard said. The computer, electronics and instruments company acquired the Livingston plant when it bought Apollo Computer Inc. in May 1989. Livingston employees who do not accept jobs elsewhere with H-P will be offered a severance package that includes an amount equal to six months of pay and half-a-month's pay for each year of service.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Increases Dividend for First Time Since Breakup
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has increased its quarterly stock dividend for the first time since the 1984 breakup of the old Bell System. The phone company's board of directors on Wednesday declared a dividend of 33 cents a share, up 10 percent from the previous 30 cents a share. The dividend is payable May 1 to shareholders of record March 30. ``The board's decision to increase the dividend confirms its belief that 1990 will be another year of revenue and profit growth,'' said AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen. AT&T is the most widely held stock in the nation, with 2.6 million registered shareholders for the 1.1 billion shares outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS M2 figures in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended March 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,269.3 billion from a revised $3,269.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,069.4 billion from a revised $4,072.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $802.2 billion from a revised $807.0 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.1 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,243.5 billion, a 6.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,055.1 billion, up 3.3 percent, while M1 rose 1.5 percent to an average of $798.4 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $292 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $74 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $304.2 billion in the two-week period ended March 21, up from $301.3 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Publisher To Buy Back $159 Million in Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Ingersoll Newspapers Inc. offered Thursday to buy back $158.6 million of high-yield junk bonds at prices sharply discounted from face value as the publishing company struggles to meet debt interest payments. Ingersoll Newspapers is a holding company controlled by publisher Ralph Ingersoll. Its properties include the weekly St. Louis Suburban Journals, the Try (N.Y.) Record and several other medium-sized papers. The offer is for as much as 80 percent of $125 million in 13 percent reset notes issued by Community Newspapers Inc., also a unit of Ingersoll Publications Inc. The buyback would account for 55 percent of the principal amount. Ingersoll Newspapers also is offering to buy as much as 51 percent of its $114.9 million of 14.75 percent discount debentures for 25 percent of the principal amount. The 13 percent notes have been trading around $390 to $420 for $1,000 notes and the 14.75 percent debentures for about $200 for $1,000 notes. The company is under the pressure of a June 30 deadline to reset its interest rate to restore the value of the notes to face amount, said junk bond analyst Ned Zachar of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Reset notes must be adjusted periodically to keep their trading value in line with face value. Zachar said Ingersoll, like other newspaper companies in the northeastern United States, is facing financial problems from the overall economic slowdown. Ingersoll spokesman Mark Harnett said earnings have fallen off. Zachar said he believes bondholders should accept some kind of offer to avoid pushing the company into bankruptcy, but he expected a higher purchase price to result from negotiations. ``I think there's a pretty good chance Ingersoll will suceed with a tender offer,'' he said. ``But whether it will be at this price or another remains to be seen. The bondholders will likely push for a little more.'' Ingersoll, chairman of Ingersoll Publications Co., owns 50 percent of Community Newspapers and Ingersoll Newspapers. The other half of both companies is owned by Warburg, Pincus Capital Partners. Community Newspapers operates newspapers mostly in monopoly, medium-sized markets, including the Lorain (Ohio) Journal outside Cleveland. The debt to be repurchased originally was issued by now-collapsed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in 1987.Ingersoll is close friends with Drexel's indicted former junk-bond chief Michael Milken. Linda Hesse, a spokeswoman for Ingersoll Publications, referred all calls on the buyback to Goldman, Sachs & Co., which is acting as dealer managers for the offer. Goldman officials declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Sag on New Government Data
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `In trading... to ADD that West Texas Intermediate; PICKS UP 5th graf, `Among refined...
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures sagged in moderate trading Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, pressured by new government statistics that showed energy supplies are bigger than expected. The report by the Department of Energy contrasted with industry statistics released Tuesday that showed oil products in the nation's storage tanks fell sharply last week. Tuesday's figures by the American Petroleum Institute helped boost oil prices Wednesday. The DOE report showed that inventories fell but by much smaller amounts. In trading Thursday on the New York Merc, contracts for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude, for delivery after May fell between 1 cent and 40 cents. The May contract edged up 4 cents to finish at $20 a 42-gallon barrel. Among refined products, April heating oil, which surged 1.19 cents on Wednesday, fell 0.53 cent to 55.01 cents a gallon. May heating oil rose 0.54 cents to 52.97 cents and June advanced 0.49 cent to to 52.09 cents. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in April, which gained 0.63 cent in the previous session, fell 0.56 cent to finish at 57.38 cents a gallon. The May contract dropped 0.47 cent to 61.98 cents and June lost 0.66 cent to 61.79 cents. Analysts said the government report on oil inventories dominated trading. ``The DOE report out today showed less support for the products,'' said Bob Baker of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``The decline in prices was a reaction to the government report after the overreaction on the API report.'' According to the DOE, crude oil stocks declined 1.5 million barrels in the week ended March 16 to 351 million barrels but rose 21.4 million barrels from the comparable period last year. Gasoline supplies fell 2.1 million barrels to 245.2 million, and distillate fuel fell 3.7 million to 107.1 million barrels. Figures from API, the oil industry trade association that represents major oil refiners, showed that total gasoline stocks fell 2.6 million barrels in the week ended March 16 to 241 million barrels. Distillate fuel supplies dropped 4.2 million barrels to 105.9 million, while crude oil inventories rose 188,000 barrels to 350.9, API reported.

DOC.HEAD: Federal, State Charges Filed Against Northwest Flight Crew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with pilots' ages, details of allegations, comment by Arnold and pilots to be arraigned. No pickup; Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three former Northwest Airlines pilots were charged by federal and state officials Thursday with operating a Boeing 727 commercial jetliner while under the influence of alcohol. Charges were filed separately by the U.S. attorney's office in Minneapolis and by North Dakota officials against Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., First Officer Robert Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and Second Officer Joseph Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn. ``We consider the driving of a common carrier, whether it be an aircraft, a train or a bus, while under the influence of alcohol to be a very serious offense,'' U.S. Attorney Jerry Arnold told a news conference here. According to an FBI agent's affidavit, Prouse purchased 14 rum and Diet Cokes at a bar over a six-hour period the evening before the March 8 flight left Fargo, N.D., for Minneapolis, and another bar patron purchased five additional drinks for him. The affidavit said the other two crew members were served seven pitchers of beer. Witnesses said Prouse, Balzer and Kirchner were ``visibly intoxicated'' at the bar, the affidavit said. Between 7 to 8 hours expired from the time the pilots left the bar and their 6:30 a.m. flight time. Tests conducted at the Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis shortly after the pilots' arrest showed Prouse had a blood-alcohol level of 0.12 percent. Balzer's blood-alcohol level was 0.07 percent and while Kirchner's was 0.06 percent, according to the test results, which were made available to The Associated Press. Federal regulations prohibit pilots from flying if they have higher than a 0.04 percent level. The legal limit for driving a vehicle is 0.10 in most states. Arnold said the federal felony charges were brought under a statute passed by Congress as part of the 1986 Anti-Drug Abuse Act prohibiting operation of a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The maximum penalty on the federal charges is 15 years in prison and-or a $250,000 fine, he said. Arnold said arrangements were being made for the three pilots to turn themselves in voluntarily next week in Minneapolis. They are scheduled to be arraigned March 29, he said. In North Dakota, the three were charged in Cass County Court with operating an aircraft while intoxicated and acting as an aircraft crew member within eight hours of drinking. The charges each are misdemeanors punishable by a $1,000 fine and one year in prison under North Dakota law. ``This kind of conduct by airline pilots should not be condoned and cannot be tolerated by today's traveling public,'' county prosecutor Robert Hoy said. ``It's incumbent upon those individuals with positions of responsibility over this type of conduct to make sure it does not happen again.'' Prouse, Balzer and Kirchner were detained in Minneapolis upon landing Flight 650 safely, following a tip to federal authorities that the crew had been drinking the night before. The airline has fired the three and the Federal Aviation Administration has revoked their pilot licenses. The three plan to appeal their license revocations, their attorneys have said. Mark McDermott, a Washington, D.C., lawyer representing Kirchner, said the defense will ``do whatever we have to do to defend his rights.'' Bruce Hanley, the Minneapolis attorney who represents Balzer, said his client will plead innocent. He said it was too early to comment on the allegations in the government's affidavit. Prouse has an unlisted telephone number. Prosecutors from the city attorney's office in Minneapolis have met with federal attorneys to discuss the case. Deputy City Attorney Mitchell Rothman said Wednesday his office would wait until federal authorities decided whether to prosecute the pilots before deciding whether to file city charges. Rothman had said the city isn't likely to prosecute if federal authorities do so. Bob Gibbons, Northwest Airlines' director of media relations, declined to comment Thursday on the charges, saying, ``We won't have any viewpoint on any of the court action involving the former pilots.''

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Adds Check Insurance to Customer Inducements
DOC.TEXT: Coast Savings, a thrift with $11.2 billion in assets, said Thursday it would provide free insurance on many items purchased with personal checks drawn on its accounts. The move is the latest by man banks and thrifts to attract customers. Since last summer, banks have extended Monday through Friday hours, opened on weekends, created branches in supermarkets and even paid bonuses to customers if service lags. ``Everybody is after market share,'' said Dan Williams, a bank analyst with Sutro & Co. in San Francisco. ``If (deposit insurance) works for Coast, it may get to the point where everyone will have to do it.'' The plan is similar to those already provided by American Express Co. and other credit card companies' ``gold cards,'' and a small but growing number of banks, including California's Napa Valley Bank and Valley National Bank of Arizona. Purchases included in the program and paid for in full with Coast checks are insured for 90 days against theft, loss, accidental breakage and fire. Manufacturers' warranties are doubled up to a year, so a 90-day warranty is good for 180 days. Claims can be filed through a toll-free, 24-hour number. Coast, with $11.2 billion in assets and 125 branches in the state, is the first major California financial institution to provide such insurance. Its president, Gerrald D. Barrone, said a quarter of Coast's customers now have checking accounts, about 200,000 in all. The thrift hopes to improve that figure by 50 percent this year, taking in about $20 million a month in new checking accounts, he said. The program begins Monday. Some items, such as vehicles, dwellings, coins, services, art objects, items used for business, and consumables such as fuel and food, are excluded from coverage. Barrone said Coast pays an insurance company 86 cents per year per checking account for the purchase insurance service. Coast has a conventional range of checking accounts; one popular one provides free checking with a minimum balance of $500. Financial services consultant Bert Ely said the United States is glutted with banks and thrifts. Coast's new program ``is taking place in the context of an extremely competitive industry,'' Ely said. Big banks were watching carefully. ``It's definitely something we're looking at and we're aware it's gaining in popularity, but we have no plans for a similar program at this time,'' said Kathleen Shilkret, a spokeswoman for San Francisco's Wells Fargo Bank.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Moves on Clean Air; Senate Bogged Down
DOC.TEXT: A House committee approved a compromise Thursday on tougher smog controls in a clean air bill, while a proposal for financial aid to coal miners still held up movement on similar legislation in the Seante. The 38-2 vote by the House Energy and Commerce Committee created one areas of likely conflict when the Senate and House versions of the two bills eventually have to be reconciled. The Senate earlier in the week rejected some of the same smog controls. Meanwhile, Senate leaders worked with the White House and Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., in an attempt to find a way to resolve the dispute over the coal miner assistance. A vote on the amendment, brought to the floor by Byrd nearly two weeks ago, has been postponed at least twice. Senate leaders are fearful that Byrd has the votes to get it passed. That could unravel the compromise legislation worked out with the White House, they fear, because of the temptation it would pose for lawmakers to claim similar aid for other industries. The coal aid amendment did not surface again Thursday or Thursday night and aides to Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said the issue would be held over to next week. Earlier in the day Mitchell had said he expected it to ``be resolved one way or another'' by the end of the day Thursday. The House committee vote came after two days of negotitions among committee leaders, including Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the chairman. Many members voted only minutes after having first seen the inch-thick document. The House provisions would continue to allow the Environmental Protection Agency to impose an air pollution control plan if local officials fail to act, would bring many small businesses under smog-control regulations in cities with the dirtiest air, and would eliminate certain waivers now possible on grounds that compliance would cost too much. These were provisions the Senate rejected earlier in the week. The Senate spent much time on marginal amendments. The Byrd proposal calls for a $500 million program to help miners who lose their jobs from tougher acid rain pollution controls. The White House calls the plan too expensive and has lobbied hard against it. But Byrd, one of the Senate's most influential and most powerful members as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, returned to the Senate floor Thursday to plead his case. ``The coal miners are being asked to pay a very high price. ... They will lose their livelihood,'' declared Byrd, calling the assistance program essential to help 5,000 miners who are likely to lose their jobs. Mitchell, eanwhile, was working with Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, to try to get the White House to produce a compromise aid package that might be agreeable to Byrd. Mitchell and Dole have said they are concerned that passage of the assistance program would cause the White House to drop support for the compromise clean air legislation that was agreed to in lengthy closed-door negotiations between Senate leaders and the Bush administration. If the deal falls apart there likely will be no clean air bill from the Senate this year, Mitchell maintained earlier in the week. On Wednesday night, Byrd offered to lower the package's expected cost from $700 million over four years to $500 million over three years. Now, he said, he would retreat no further. ``I'm not going to stand here and say I've got 51 votes (needed for passage), but I can tell you, `You don't have 51 votes either.' And I can tell you I'm very close,'' Byrd told Mitchell as debate on the issue continued late into the night Wednesday. Byrd complained that the White House had been unwilling to negotiate with him, so ``I've negotiated with myself.'' Originally Byrd had sought a much broader aid package, which could have cost $1.6 billion over six years. Byrd argued that coal miners should be singled out for help because the bill, which calls for reducing sulfur dioxide emissions from electric utilities by 10 million tons a year by the end of the decade, takes ``direct aim'' at these workers. Industry has argued forcefully among senators in recent weeks that the tougher proposed controls on toxic industrial chemical releases would cost thousands of jobs in the steel, chemical and petroleum industries.
